1.shlok:
धृतराष्ट्र उवाच
धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः।
मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय।।१.१।।
1.translit:
dhṛtarāṣṭra uvāca
dharma-kṣetre kuru-kṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ
māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāś caiva kim akurvata sañjaya
1.translate: Dhṛtarāṣṭra said — What did my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu do, O Sañjaya, when they had assembled, eager for battle, on the sacred field of Kurukṣetra?
1.sridhara:
Here, indeed, the Lord — an incarnation for the welfare of all the worlds, one whose feet are revered by all, the supremely compassionate son of Devakī — raised Arjuna, who had abandoned his own dharma and was intent on the dharma of others, due to the delusion and sorrow arising from lack of true knowledge, by means of the teaching concerning the knowledge of dharma, delivered as a boat to cross over the ocean of grief and delusion. That very teaching, imparted by the Blessed Lord, was composed by Kṛṣṇa Dvaipāyana (Vyāsa) in seven hundred verses. Among them, he mostly recorded the verses that issued directly from the mouth of Śrī Kṛṣṇa, and composed some himself to connect them. As it is said in the Gītā Māhātmya:
“Gītā, well-sung, should be studied — what use are other voluminous scriptures?
She has issued from the lotus-mouth of Padmanābha (Viṣṇu) himself.”
Thus, beginning with “dharma-kṣetre” up to “idam abravīt” (verse १.१), the narrative sets the context for the dialogue between Śrī Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna.
“Dharma-kṣetre” — O Sañjaya, on the field of dharma, Kurukṣetra, my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu, who had assembled and were eager for battle — what did they do?

1.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा।
आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत्।।१.२।।
1.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṁ vyūḍhaṁ duryodhanas tadā
ācāryam upasaṅgamya rājā vacanam abravīt
1.translate: Sañjaya said — Then, seeing the army of the Pāṇḍavas arranged in formation, King Duryodhana approached the teacher and spoke these words.
1.sridhara: “Dṛṣṭveti” — Having seen the army of the Pāṇḍavas arranged in formation (vyūha-racanayā vyavasthitam), King Duryodhana went near Droṇācārya and spoke the following words.

1.shlok:
पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम्।
व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता।।१.३।।
1.translit:
paśyaitāṁ pāṇḍu-putrāṇām ācārya mahatīṁ camūm
vyūḍhāṁ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā
1.translate: Behold, O Teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pāṇḍu, arranged in formation by the son of Drupada, your wise disciple.
1.sridhara:
This very statement is expressed in the next nine verses, beginning with “paśyaitām.”
O teacher, behold the army of the sons of Pāṇḍu that has been spread out. It has been arranged (vyūḍhām) in battle formation by the son of Drupada, Dhṛṣṭadyumna.

1.shlok:
अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि।
युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः।।१.४।।
1.translit:
atra śūrā maheṣvāsā bhīmārjuna-samā yudhi
yuyudhāno virāṭaś ca drupadaś ca mahā-rathaḥ
1.translate: Here are heroes, mighty bowmen, equal in battle to Bhīma and Arjuna — Yuyudhāna, Virāṭa, and Drupada, the great chariot-warrior.
1.sridhara: “Atra śūrā iti” — Here in this army, there are heroic warriors. “Iṣavo bāṇāḥ asyante ebhir iti iṣvāsāḥ” — the term “maheṣvāsāḥ” refers to those whose bows are great and who shoot arrows from them. Bhīma and Arjuna are already well-known as exceptional warriors. Equal to them in valor and adherence to the warrior’s dharma (kṣātra-dharma) are other heroes. He names them: Yuyudhāna, that is, Sātyaki.

1.shlok:
धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान्।
पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः।।१.५।।
1.translit:
dhṛṣṭaketuś cekitānaḥ kāśirājaś ca vīryavān
purujit kuntibhojaś ca śaibyaś ca nara-puṅgavaḥ
1.translate: Dhṛṣṭaketu, Cekitāna, and the valiant king of Kāśī; Purujit and Kuntibhoja, and Śaibya, the foremost among men.
1.sridhara: Furthermore — “dhṛṣṭaketur iti.” Cekitāna is the name of one king. Śaibya is a “nara-puṅgava,” a foremost among men.

1.shlok:
युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान्।
सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः।।१.६।।
1.translit:
yudhāmanyuś ca vikrānta uttamaujāś ca vīryavān
saubhadro draupadeyāś ca sarva eva mahā-rathāḥ
1.translate: Yudhāmanyu, who is powerful, and Uttamaujas, who is valiant, the son of Subhadrā (Abhimanyu), and the sons of Draupadī — all of them are great chariot-warriors.
1.sridhara:
“Yudhāmanyuś ceti” — Yudhāmanyu is one name; he is powerful (vikrāntaḥ). Saubhadra is Abhimanyu. The Draupadeyas are those born of Draupadī from the five (brothers beginning with Yudhiṣṭhira) — namely, the five sons like Prativindhya. The definition of a mahāratha (great chariot-warrior) is as follows:
“One who can fight alone against ten thousand bowmen and is proficient in both weapons and scriptures is known as a mahāratha.”
“One who can fight against innumerable warriors is called an atiratha (supreme charioteer). One who fights only with a single warrior and is weaker than a rathī is called an ardhārathī.”
Thus goes the traditional definition.

1.shlok:
अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम।
नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते।।१.७।।
1.translit:
asmākaṁ tu viśiṣṭā ye tān nibodha dvijottama
nāyakā mama sainyasya saṁjñārthaṁ tān bravīmi te
1.translate: But, O best of the twice-born, know also those among us who are distinguished — the leaders of my army. I shall name them to you for your understanding.
1.sridhara: “Asmākam iti” — “Nibodha” means understand. “Nāyakāḥ” means leaders. “Saṁjñārtham” means for the sake of full knowledge or understanding.

1.shlok:
भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः।
अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च।।१.८।।
1.translit:
bhavān bhīṣmaś ca karṇaś ca kṛpaś ca samitiñjayaḥ
aśvatthāmā vikarṇaś ca saumadattis tathaiva ca
1.translate: Yourself, and Bhīṣma, and Karṇa, and also Kṛpa, the conqueror in battle; Aśvatthāmā, Vikarna, and the son of Somadatta as well.
1.sridhara: “Tān evāha bhavān iti dvābhyām” — He names them beginning with “bhavān.” “Bhavān” refers to Droṇa. “Samitiṁ saṅgrāmaṁ jayati iti” — one who conquers battle is meant. “Saumadattiḥ” means Bhūriśravā, the son of Somadatta.

1.shlok:
अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः।
नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः।।१.९।।
1.translit:
anye ca bahavaḥ śūrā mad-arthe tyakta-jīvitāḥ
nānā-śastra-praharaṇāḥ sarve yuddha-viśāradāḥ
1.translate: And also many other heroes who have given up their lives for my sake, equipped with various weapons and missiles, all skilled in warfare.
1.sridhara: “Anye ceti” — “Mad-arthe” means for my benefit or purpose. “Tyakta-jīvitāḥ” means they are resolved to give up their lives — that is the intent. “Nānā” means various; “śastrāṇi” are weapons, and “praharaṇas” are means of striking — those who possess these. “Yuddhe viśāradāḥ” — they are skilled in warfare. “Nipuṇāḥ” — they are adept — that is the meaning.

1.shlok:
अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम्।
पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम्।।१.१०।।
1.translit:
aparyāptaṁ tad asmākaṁ balaṁ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam
paryāptaṁ tv idam eteṣāṁ balaṁ bhīmābhirakṣitam
1.translate: That army of ours, protected by Bhīṣma, is inadequate, whereas this army of theirs, protected by Bhīma, is adequate.
1.sridhara:
“Tatḥ kim ity ata āha — aparyāptam iti” — So what? That is now said:
Though our army is filled with such heroes and is protected by Bhīṣma, still it appears inadequate, unable to oppose them in battle. But this army of theirs, the Pāṇḍavas, protected by Bhīma, appears adequate, capable.
Why? Because Bhīṣma is impartial toward both sides, whereas Bhīma is partial to one side (the Pāṇḍavas). Hence, our army is incapable of opposing the Pāṇḍava forces, while theirs appears strong.

1.shlok:
अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः।
भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि।।१.११।।
1.translit:
ayaneṣu ca sarveṣu yathā-bhāgam avasthitāḥ
bhīṣmam evābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva eva hi
1.translate: Therefore, all of you, stationed in your respective positions at the various strategic points, should support and protect Bhīṣma alone.
1.sridhara:
“Tasmād bhavadbhiḥ evaṁ vartitavyam ity āha — ayaneṣv iti” — Therefore, you all must act accordingly — stationed at the entrances (ayaneṣu), which are the openings or approaches of the formation (vyūha-praveśa-mārgeṣu), remain in your assigned sections of the battlefield (yathā-bhāgaṁ vibhaktām svām svām raṇabhūmim aparityajya avasthitāḥ), and let all of you protect Bhīṣma alone.
Protect him in such a way that, while he is fighting with others, he is not killed from behind by someone — so guard him from all sides.
The implication is: our very lives depend on the strength of Bhīṣma.

1.shlok:
तस्य संजनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः।
सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान्।।१.१२।।
1.translit:
tasya sañjanayan harṣaṁ kuru-vṛddhaḥ pitāmahaḥ
siṁha-nādaṁ vinadyo ccaiḥ śaṅkhaṁ dadhmau pratāpavān
1.translate: To cheer him up, the glorious grandsire of the Kurus, Bhīṣma, roared like a lion and loudly blew his conch.
1.sridhara:
“Tad evaṁ bahu-māna-yuktaṁ rājño Duryodhanasya vākyaṁ śrutvā Bhīṣmaḥ kiṁ kṛtavāṁs tad āha — tasya iti” — Thus, after hearing Duryodhana’s speech, filled with reverence, what did Bhīṣma do? That is said here:
To generate joy (harṣaṁ sañjanayan) in that king (tasya rājñaḥ), the grandsire (pitāmahaḥ) Bhīṣma roared a mighty lion’s roar (uccair mahāntaṁ siṁha-nādaṁ kṛtvā) and blew his conch (śaṅkhaṁ dadhmau vāditavān).

1.shlok:
ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः।
सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत्।।१.१३।।
1.translit:
tataḥ śaṅkhāś ca bheryaś ca paṇavānaka-gomukhāḥ
sahasaiva abhyahanyanta sa śabdas tumulo ’bhavat
1.translate: Then the conches, kettledrums, tabors, drums, and cow horns blared forth suddenly, and the sound was tumultuous.
1.sridhara:
“Tad evaṁ senāpater Bhīṣmasya yuddhotsavam ālakṣya sarvataḥ yuddhotsavaḥ pravṛtta ity āha — tataḥ iti” — Thus, perceiving the war celebration initiated by commander Bhīṣma, a general festivity of battle was set in motion, as stated:
“Paṇavāḥ, ānakāḥ, gomukhāḥ ca” — paṇava, ānaka, and gomukha are different kinds of musical instruments.
“Sahasā eva” — instantly, at that very moment (tat-kṣaṇam eva), they were struck (abhyahanyanta vāditāḥ).
And that sound produced by the conches and other instruments became tumultuous (tumulaḥ mahān abhavat).

1.shlok:
ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ।
माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः।।१.१४।।
1.translit:
tataḥ śvetair hayair yukte mahati syandane sthitau
mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaś caiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ
1.translate: Then Mādhava and the son of Pāṇḍu, standing in their magnificent chariot yoked with white horses, blew their divine conches.
1.sridhara:
“Tataḥ pāṇḍava-sainye pravṛttaṁ yuddhotsavam āha — tataḥ iti pañcabhiḥ” — Then, the festive preparation for war commenced also in the Pāṇḍava army, as stated in the next five verses beginning with “tataḥ.”
“Tataḥ” — following the uproar from the Kaurava side, the two — Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna — standing (rathasthaḥ) in their chariot (syandane), which was great and yoked with white horses (śvetair hayair yukte mahati syandane), blew (pradadhmatuḥ) divine conches (divyau śaṅkhau prakarṣeṇa) — i.e., they sounded them with great intensity.

1.shlok:
पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनंजयः।
पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः।।१.१५।।
1.translit:
pāñcajanyaṁ hṛṣīkeśo devadattaṁ dhanañjayaḥ
pauṇḍraṁ dadhmau mahā-śaṅkhaṁ bhīma-karmā vṛkodaraḥ
1.translate: Hṛṣīkeśa blew the Pāñcajanya, Dhanañjaya blew the Devadatta, and Vṛkodara, the doer of terrible deeds, blew the great conch Pauṇḍra.
1.sridhara:
“Tad eva vibhāgena darśayann āha — pāñcajanyam iti” — That very act is now described in detail.
“Pāñcajanya”- and the others are the names of the conches of Śrī Kṛṣṇa and others.
“Bhīmaṁ ghoram karma yasya saḥ” — He whose actions are terrible is called Bhīma-karma.
“Vṛka-vad udaraṁ yasya saḥ” — He whose belly is like that of a wolf is Vṛkodara.
He blew (dadhmau) the great conch (mahāśaṅkhaṁ) named Pauṇḍra.

1.shlok:
अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः।
नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ।।१.१६।।
1.translit:
anantavijayaṁ rājā kuntī-putro yudhiṣṭhiraḥ
nakulaḥ sahadevaś ca sughoṣa-maṇipuṣpakau
1.translate: King Yudhiṣṭhira, the son of Kuntī, blew the conch named Anantavijaya; Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughoṣa and Maṇipuṣpaka conches.
1.sridhara: “Anantavijayam iti” — Nakula blew the conch named Sughoṣa. Sahadeva blew the one named Maṇipuṣpaka.

1.shlok:
काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः।
धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः।।१.१७।।
1.translit:
kāśyaś ca parameṣvāsaḥ śikhaṇḍī ca mahā-rathaḥ
dhṛṣṭadyumno virāṭaś ca sātyakiś cāparājitaḥ
1.translate: The king of Kāśī, an excellent archer; Śikhaṇḍī, the mighty chariot-warrior; Dhṛṣṭadyumna, Virāṭa, and the undefeated Sātyaki also blew their conches.
1.sridhara: “Kāśyaś ceti” — Kāśya means the king of Kāśī. What kind of person was he? He was a supreme (parama) bowman (iṣvāsaḥ), that is, one who possessed an excellent bow and great skill in archery.

1.shlok:
द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते।
सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान् दध्मुः पृथक् पृथक्।।१.१८।।
1.translit:
drupado draupadeyāś ca sarvaśaḥ pṛthivī-pate
saubhadraś ca mahā-bāhuḥ śaṅkhān dadhmuḥ pṛthak-pṛthak
1.translate: Drupada and the sons of Draupadī, O King, and the mighty-armed son of Subhadrā (Abhimanyu), blew their conches individually from their respective positions.
1.sridhara: “Drupada iti” — O ruler of the earth (he pṛthivīpate), O Dhṛtarāṣṭra — this is an address directed to you.

1.shlok:
स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत्।
नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलो व्यनुनादयन्।।१.१९।।
1.translit:
sa ghoṣo dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṁ hṛdayāni vyadārayat
nabhaś ca pṛthivīṁ caiva tumulo vy-anunādayan
1.translate: That tumultuous sound rent the hearts of the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, making the sky and the earth resound.
1.sridhara:
“Sa ca śaṅkhānāṁ nādas tvadīyānāṁ mahā-bhayaṁ janayāmāsa ity āha — sa ghoṣa iti” — That sound of the conches, coming from your side’s opponents, caused great fear.
It tore apart (vidāritavān) the hearts (hṛdayāni) of the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra — your own men.
Doing what? — “nabhāś ca pṛthivīṁ ca eva tumulo vy-anunādayan” — resounding tumultuously throughout the sky and the earth.

1.shlok:
अथ व्यवस्थितान् दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान् कपिध्वजः।
प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसंपाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः।।१.२०।।
1.translit:
atha vyavasthitān dṛṣṭvā dhārtarāṣṭrān kapi-dhvajaḥ
pravṛtte śastra-saṁpāte dhanur udyamya pāṇḍavaḥ
1.translate: Then, seeing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra standing arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, whose banner bore the emblem of Hanumān, took up his bow.
1.sridhara:
“Tasmin samaye Śrī-Kṛṣṇam Arjuno vijñāpayāmāsa ity āha — atha iti caturbhiḥ” — At that moment, Arjuna began to address Śrī Kṛṣṇa — this is conveyed in the next four verses starting with “atha.”
“Vyavasthitān” means standing ready for battle (yuddha-udyogena sthitān).
“Kapi-dhvajaḥ” means Arjuna, whose banner bore the figure of Hanumān.

1.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत।।१.२१।।
1.translit:
arjuna uvāca
hṛṣīkeśaṁ tadā vākyam idam āha mahīpate
senayor ubhayor madhye rathaṁ sthāpaya me ’cyuta
1.translate: Arjuna said: O Hṛṣīkeśa, O Acyuta, place my chariot between the two armies, O King.
1.sridhara:
“Hṛṣīkeśam iti” — The very speech (Arjuna's request) is now stated:
“Tad eva vākyam āha — ‘senayor’ iti” — That specific speech he spoke is this: "Place the chariot between the two armies."

1.shlok:
यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान्।
कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन्रणसमुद्यमे।।१.२२।।
1.translit:
yāvad etān nirīkṣe ’haṁ yoddhu-kāmān avasthitān
kair mayā saha yoddhavyam asmin raṇa-samudyame
1.translate: So that I may see those who stand here eager to fight, and with whom I must fight in this undertaking of war.
1.sridhara:
“Yāvad etān iti” — One might ask: "You are a warrior, not a spectator of war — why this desire to observe?"
In response, he says: “With whom must I fight?” That is why I wish to see them.

1.shlok:
योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः।
धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः।।१.२३।।
1.translit:
yotsyamānān avekṣe ’haṁ ya ete ’tra samāgatāḥ
dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddher yuddhe priya-cikīrṣavaḥ
1.translate: I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight, intending to do what is pleasing in battle to the evil-minded son of Dhṛtarāṣṭra.
1.sridhara:
“Yotsyamānān iti” — Those who have assembled here (iha samāgatāḥ), wishing to act in a way that pleases the evil-minded Duryodhana (dhārtarāṣṭrasya duryodhanasya priyaṁ kartum icchantaḥ), I wish to observe them —
Therefore, place my chariot between the two armies — this is the implied continuation (anvayaḥ).

1.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम्।।१.२४।।
1.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
evam ukto hṛṣīkeśo guḍākeśena bhārata
senayor ubhayor madhye sthāpayitvā rathottamam
1.translate: Sañjaya said: O Bhārata, thus addressed by Guḍākeśa, Hṛṣīkeśa placed the excellent chariot in the midst of the two armies.
1.sridhara:
“Tataḥ kiṁ pravṛttam ity apekṣāyāṁ Sañjaya uvāca — evam iti” — “What happened next?” — anticipating this, Sañjaya speaks:
“Guḍākā nidrā, tasyā īśena” — “Guḍākeśa” means Arjuna, conqueror of sleep.
“Evaṁ uktaḥ san he Bhārata Dhṛtarāṣṭra” — Thus spoken to, O Bhārata (Dhṛtarāṣṭra),
“Senayoḥ madhye rathānām uttamam rathaṁ Hṛṣīkeśaḥ sthāpitavān” — Hṛṣīkeśa placed the supreme chariot in between the two armies.

1.shlok:
भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम्।
उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति।।१.२५।।
1.translit:
bhīṣma-droṇa-pramukhataḥ sarveṣāṁ ca mahīkṣitām
uvāca pārtha paśyaitān samavetān kurūn iti
1.translate: In front of Bhīṣma and Droṇa and all the kings, He said: "O Pārtha, behold these Kurus assembled here."
1.sridhara:
“Bhīṣma-droṇe iti” — Placing the chariot directly in front of Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and the other kings (mahīkṣitaḥ),
He said: “O Pārtha, behold these Kurus who have assembled here for battle.”

1.shlok:
तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान्पार्थः पितॄन् अथ पितामहान्।
आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातॄन् पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा।।१.२६।।
1.translit:
tatrāpaśyat sthitān pārthaḥ pitṝn atha pitāmahān
ācāryān mātulān bhrātṝn putrān pautrān sakhīṁs tathā
1.translate: There, Arjuna, the son of Pṛthā, saw standing—fathers, and also grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends as well.
1.sridhara:
Then what happened? That is said: “Pitṝn” — that is, paternal uncles and others.
“Putrān pautrān” — the sons and grandsons of Duryodhana and others — he saw them.
“Sakhīn” — friends; and also “suhṛdaḥ,” those who had done favors to him — he saw them.

1.shlok:
श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि।
तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान्।।१.२७।।
1.translit:
śvaśurān suhṛdaś caiva senayor ubhayor api
tān samīkṣya sa kaunteyaḥ sarvān bandhūn avasthitān
1.translate: Fathers-in-law and friends also in both the armies—seeing all those relatives standing there, the son of Kuntī (Arjuna) became overwhelmed.
1.sridhara:
Then what did he do? That is said: “Tān iti.”
“Āviṣṭaḥ” — overpowered, enveloped, filled with.
“Viṣīdan” — sinking deeply in grief, experiencing dejection and disheartenment.

1.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
कृपया परयाऽऽविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत्।
दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम्।।१.२८।।
1.translit:
arjuna uvāca
kṛpayā parayāviṣṭo viṣīdann idam abravīt
dṛṣṭvemaṁ sva-janaṁ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṁ samupasthitam
1.translate: Arjuna said: Seeing this kinsfolk of mine, O Kṛṣṇa, standing here eager to fight, I am overwhelmed with deep compassion and sorrowfully spoke the following.
1.sridhara:
What did he say? That is expressed beginning from “dṛṣṭvemam” up to the end of the chapter.
“O Kṛṣṇa, seeing these relatives of mine (bandhu-jana), who are firmly arrayed before me, desiring to fight, my limbs — beginning with arms and legs — grow weak.”
Furthermore, “my mouth dries up completely.” That is, it becomes devoid of moisture.

1.shlok:
सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति।
वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते।।१.२९।।
1.translit:
sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṁ ca pariśuṣyati
vepathuś ca śarīre me roma-harṣaś ca jāyate
1.translate: My limbs fail, my mouth becomes dry, a trembling arises throughout my body, and my hair stands on end.
1.sridhara:
Further: “Vepathuḥ” — trembling or quivering.
“Roma-harṣaḥ” — horripilation (hair standing on end).
“Sraṁsate” — slips or falls away.
“Paridahyate” — burns entirely, tormented from all sides.

1.shlok:
गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते।
न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः।।१.३०।।
1.translit:
gāṇḍīvaṁ sraṁsate hastāt tvak caiva paridahyate
na ca śaknomy avasthātuṁ bhramatīva ca me manaḥ
1.translate: The Gāṇḍīva (bow) slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over; I am unable to stand, and my mind seems to reel.
1.sridhara:
And furthermore: “Na ca” — I do not see favorable omens (viparītāni nimittāni), signs foretelling misfortune.
They are inauspicious omens (aniṣṭa-sūcaka śakunāni), and I behold them.

1.shlok:
निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव।
न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे।।१.३१।।
1.translit:
nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni keśava
na ca śreyo'nupaśyāmi hatvā svajanam āhave
1.translate: And I see adverse omens, O Keśava; nor do I foresee any good in killing my own people in battle.
1.sridhara: And furthermore: “Na ca” — I do not perceive (na paśyāmi) any auspicious outcome (śreyaḥ-phalam) by killing (hatvā) my own people (svajanam) in battle (āhave).

1.shlok:
न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च।
किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा।।१.३२।।
1.translit:
na kāṅkṣe vijayaṁ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṁ sukhāni ca
kiṁ no rājyena govinda kiṁ bhogair jīvitena vā
1.translate: I do not desire victory, O Kṛṣṇa, nor kingdom, nor pleasures. What use is kingdom to us, O Govinda, or enjoyments or even life?
1.sridhara:
If you say, “Why do you not seek the fruit of victory, etc.?” — to that he says, “Na kāṅkṣe” (I do not desire).
He elaborates this further with “Kiṁ no” in the next and following verse.
Those for whose sake (yad-artham) kingdom and such are desired by us — these (ete) have renounced (tyaktvā) their very lives and wealth and taken up renunciation (tyāgam aṅgīkṛtya) and stand prepared for war.
Therefore, what use have we (kim asmākam) for kingdom and such? — that is the meaning.

1.shlok:
येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च।
त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च।।१.३३।।
1.translit:
yeṣām arthe kāṅkṣitaṁ no rājyaṁ bhogāḥ sukhāni ca
ta ime'vasthitā yuddhe prāṇāṁs tyaktvā dhanāni ca
1.translate: Those for whose sake kingdom, enjoyments, and pleasures are desired by us — they stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.
1.sridhara:
Same as above (repetition in source):
If you say, “Why do you not seek the fruit of victory, etc.?” — to that he says, “Na kāṅkṣe.”
He elaborates this further with “Kiṁ no” in the next and following verse.
Those for whose sake kingdom and such are desired by us — these (ete) have renounced (tyaktvā) their very lives and wealth and taken up renunciation (tyāgam aṅgīkṛtya) and stand prepared for war.
Therefore, what use have we for kingdom and such? — that is the meaning.

1.shlok:
आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः।
मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा।।१.३४।।
1.translit:
ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrās tathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ
mātulāḥ śvaśurāḥ pautrāḥ śyālāḥ sambandhinas tathā
1.translate: Teachers, fathers, sons, and also grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives—
1.sridhara:
You may object: “Even if out of compassion you do not kill them, they will certainly kill you out of greed for the kingdom. Therefore, slay them and enjoy the kingdom.”
To that he replies in the next verse beginning with “Etān na.”
Even if they strike us, even if they are slaying us, I do not wish to kill them — even for the sake of attaining sovereignty over the three worlds.
How much less, then, for the sake of mere earthly dominion — that is the meaning.

1.shlok:
एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन।
अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते।।१.३५।।
1.translit:
etān na hantum icchāmi ghnato'pi madhusūdana
api trailokyarājyasya hetoḥ kiṁ nu mahīkṛte
1.translate: These I do not wish to kill, even if they attack me, O Madhusūdana — not even for the sake of sovereignty over the three worlds; what then to speak of for the sake of the earth?
1.sridhara:
Same continuation:
You may object: “Even if out of compassion you do not kill them, they will certainly kill you out of greed for the kingdom. Therefore, slay them and enjoy the kingdom.”
To that he replies: “Etān na hantum icchāmi” — I do not wish to kill them, even if they are striking us (ghnantaḥ), even if they are slaying us (ghātayantaḥ), not even for the sake of sovereignty over the three worlds.
What then to speak of (kim punar) for the sake of merely obtaining the earth — that is the meaning.

1.shlok:
निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन।
पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः।।१.३६।।
1.translit:
nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrān naḥ kā prītiḥ syāj janārdana
pāpam evāśrayed asmān hatvaitān ātatāyinaḥ
1.translate: By killing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, what joy would be ours, O Janārdana? Only sin would befall us from killing these aggressors.
1.sridhara:
You might argue: “But isn’t it stated in smṛti that one who sets fire, one who administers poison, one with a weapon in hand, a robber, one who seizes land or wife — these six are to be considered ātatāyins (aggressors)?”
Yes — by such six causes, these indeed are ātatāyins. And the killing of an ātatāyin is certainly justified, as stated:
“One should slay an advancing ātatāyin without hesitation; there is no fault whatsoever in slaying an ātatāyin.”
However, that rule belongs to arthaśāstra, and is weaker than dharmaśāstra. As stated by Yājñavalkya:
“When there is a conflict between smṛti texts, reasoning (nyāya) prevails in practical matters; and dharmaśāstra is stronger than arthaśāstra.”
Therefore, even in the killing of ātatāyins, since they are noble elders (āryas), for us the result would be sin alone — because such killing is unjust and contrary to dharma.
And moreover, there would be no happiness here from this act — as he says in the next: “svajanaṁ hi...”.

1.shlok:
तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान्।
स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव।।१.३७।।
1.translit:
tasmān nārhā vayaṁ hantuṁ dhārtarāṣṭrān svabāndhavān
svajanaṁ hi kathaṁ hatvā sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava
1.translate: Therefore, we ought not to kill the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, our own relatives. For, O Mādhava, how could we be happy by killing our own people?
1.sridhara:
You may object: “But when the blame for killing relatives is equal in both cases, just as they are engaging in battle despite acknowledging the sin, so too should you fight. Why fall into this sorrow?”
To that he replies in the next two verses, beginning with “yady api.”
Even if those like Duryodhana, whose discrimination has been ruined by greed for the kingdom, do not see the fault in killing relatives,
nonetheless, we — who do see that fault — how can we not refrain from this sin?
Indeed, the resolve should be to withdraw from it — that is the meaning.

1.shlok:
यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम्।।१.३८।।
1.translit:
yady apy ete na paśyanti lobhopahata-cetasaḥ
kulakṣaya-kṛtaṁ doṣaṁ mitra-drohe ca pāpakam
1.translate: Even if these, whose intellects are overpowered by greed, do not see the fault in the destruction of the family or the sin in betraying friends—
1.sridhara: No commentary given by Śrīdhara Svāmī on this verse.

1.shlok:
कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम्।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन।।१.३९।।
1.translit:
kathaṁ na jñeyam asmābhiḥ pāpād asmān nivartitum
kulakṣaya-kṛtaṁ doṣaṁ prapaśyadbhir janārdana
1.translate: Why should we not, O Janārdana, who clearly see the fault in the destruction of families, learn to turn away from this sin?
1.sridhara: No commentary given by Śrīdhara Svāmī on this verse.

1.shlok:
कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः।
धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत।।१.४०।।
1.translit:
kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ
dharme naṣṭe kulaṁ kṛtsnam adharmo'bhivavaty uta
1.translate: When the family is destroyed, the ancient family traditions perish. With the loss of dharma, the whole family is overcome by adharma.
1.sridhara: No commentary given by Śrīdhara Svāmī on this verse.

1.shlok:
अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः।
स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः।।१.४१।।
1.translit:
adharmābhibhavāt kṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kula-striyaḥ
strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇeya jāyate varṇa-saṅkaraḥ
1.translate: By the rise of unrighteousness, O Kṛṣṇa, the women of the family become corrupt; and when women are corrupted, O Vārṣṇeya, caste-mixing arises.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

1.shlok:
सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च।
पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः।।१.४२।।
1.translit:
saṅkaraḥ narakāyaiva kula-ghnānāṁ kulasya ca
patanti pitaro hy eṣāṁ lupta-piṇḍodaka-kriyāḥ
1.translate: Caste-mixing surely leads to hell for the destroyers of the family and the family itself; their ancestors fall, being deprived of ritual offerings of rice and water.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

1.shlok:
दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः।
उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः।।१.४३।।
1.translit:
doṣair etaiḥ kula-ghnānāṁ varṇa-saṅkara-kārakaiḥ
utsādyante jāti-dharmāḥ kula-dharmāś ca śāśvatāḥ
1.translate: By these faults of the destroyers of the family, which cause caste-mixing, the eternal duties of both caste and family are destroyed.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

1.shlok:
उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन।
नरकेऽनियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम।।१.४४।।
1.translit:
utsanna-kula-dharmāṇāṁ manuṣyāṇāṁ janārdana
narake ’niyataṁ vāso bhavatīty anuśuśruma
1.translate: O Janārdana, we have heard that for those men whose family duties are destroyed, an unending stay in hell is certain.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

1.shlok:
अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम्।
यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः।।१.४५।।
1.translit:
aho bata mahat pāpaṁ kartuṁ vyavasitā vayam
yad rājya-sukha-lobhena hantuṁ svajanam udyatāḥ
1.translate: Alas! We are determined to commit a great sin, in that, out of greed for the pleasures of kingdom, we are prepared to kill our own people.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

1.shlok:
यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः।
धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत्।।१.४६।।
1.translit:
yadi mām apratīkāram aśastraṁ śastra-pāṇayaḥ
dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyus tan me kṣemataraṁ bhavet
1.translate: If the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, weapons in hand, were to slay me in battle when I am unresisting and unarmed, that would be better for me.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

1.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
एवमुक्त्वाऽर्जुनः संख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत्।
विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः।।१.४७।।
1.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
evam uktvā ’rjunaḥ saṅkhye rathopastha upāviśat
visṛjya saśaraṁ cāpaṁ śoka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ
1.translate: Sañjaya said: Having thus spoken on the battlefield, Arjuna sat down on the seat of the chariot, casting away his bow and arrows, his mind overwhelmed by sorrow.
1.sridhara: No commentary provided.

2.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
तं तथा कृपयाऽविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम्।
विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः।।२.१।।
2.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
taṁ tathā kṛipayāviṣṭam aśru-pūrṇākulekṣaṇam
viṣīdantam idaṁ vākyam uvāca madhusūdanaḥ
2.translate: Sañjaya said: To him who was thus overwhelmed with compassion, whose eyes were full of tears and agitated, and who was sorrowing—Madhusūdana spoke the following words.
2.sridhara: Now, anticipating the question “What happened next?”, Sañjaya spoke: “taṁ tathā” — to him who was in such a state. “Aśrubhiḥ pūrṇe ākule īkṣaṇe yasya tam” — the one whose eyes were filled with tears and agitated; to Arjuna, who was grieving in this manner, Madhusūdana spoke these words.

2.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम्।
अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन।।२.२।।
2.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
kutas tvā kaśmalam idaṁ viṣame samupasthitam
anārya-juṣṭam asvargyam akīrti-karam arjuna
2.translate: The Blessed Lord said: From where has this dejection come upon you at this critical moment, Arjuna? It is not befitting an honourable person, leads not to heaven, and results in disgrace.
2.sridhara: The Blessed Lord said this very statement: “Kutaḥ” — from what cause or reason, “tvām” — has this confusion or delusion come upon you, “viṣame” — in this crisis? “Idaṁ kaśmalam samupasthitam” — this defilement or delusion has arisen. It is “anārya-juṣṭam” — not practiced by noble people, “asvargyam” — not conducive to heaven, and “akīrti-karam” — bringing infamy.

2.shlok:
क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते।
क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप।।२.३।।
2.translit:
klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat tvayy upapadyate
kṣudraṁ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṁ tyaktvottiṣṭha parantapa
2.translate: Yield not to unmanliness, O Pārtha! This does not befit you. Cast off this petty weakness of the heart, and rise up, O scorcher of foes!
2.sridhara: Therefore he says: “klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ” — do not yield to weakness or cowardice, O Pārtha. Because “etad tvayi na upapadyate” — this does not befit you. “Kṣudraṁ hṛdaya-daurbalyam” — this mean faint-heartedness should be given up. “Uttiṣṭha yuddhāya” — arise for battle, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes).

2.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
कथं भीष्ममहं संख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन।
इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन।।२.४।।
2.translit:
arjuna uvāca
kathaṁ bhīṣmam ahaṁ saṅkhye droṇaṁ ca madhusūdana
iṣubhiḥ pratiyotsyāmi pūjārhāv ari-sūdana
2.translate: Arjuna said: How shall I fight in battle with arrows against Bhīṣma and Droṇa, O Madhusūdana, they who are worthy of worship, O destroyer of foes?
2.sridhara: I am not withdrawing out of fear, but due to the unrighteousness of the battle. So Arjuna said: “katham” — how, “ahaṁ yotsyāmi” — shall I fight, “prati” — against, “bhīṣma-droṇau pūjāyām arhāv” — Bhīṣma and Droṇa, who are worthy of worship? And not just fight, but “iṣubhiḥ” — with arrows! Even to speak of fighting them is improper; then how could I actually do so? O Ari-sūdana (destroyer of enemies)!

2.shlok:
गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान्
श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके।
हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव
भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान्।।२.५।।
2.translit:
gurūn ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān
śreyo bhoktuṁ bhaikṣyam apīha loke
hatvā artha-kāmāṁs tu gurūn ihaiva
bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān
2.translate: It is better to live in this world on alms than to slay these noble teachers. But having slain the teachers, I would enjoy pleasures stained with their blood.
2.sridhara:
If it is said: “Then how will you sustain yourself?”, the reply is given: “gurūn iti” — without killing the noble gurus like Droṇa, whose slaying obstructs heavenly progress, it is better even to live in this world by eating food obtained by begging. On the other hand, “hatvā gurūn” — by killing the teachers, “ihaiva” — even in this life, I would “bhuñjīya bhogān rudhira-pradigdhān” — enjoy pleasures tainted with their blood.

Alternatively, “artha-kāmān” may qualify the teachers — those driven by desire for wealth and pleasures — thus they would not desist from war. Therefore their killing becomes inevitable. As Bhīṣma once told Yudhiṣṭhira:
“arthasya puruṣo dāso dāsas tv artho na kasyacit |
iti satyaṁ mahārāja baddho ’smy arthena kauravaiḥ ||”
“The man is the servant of wealth; wealth is servant to none. This is the truth, O King. I am bound by wealth to the Kauravas.”

2.shlok:
न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो
यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः।
यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषाम
स्तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः।।२.६।।
2.translit:
na caitad vidmaḥ kataran no garīyo
yad vā jayema yadi vā no jayeyuḥ
yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāma
ste ’vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ
2.translate: And we do not know which is better for us—whether we should conquer them or they should conquer us. Those very sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, after killing whom we do not wish to live, are standing before us in battle.
2.sridhara: Moreover, even though we might adopt unrighteousness, still we do not know whether victory or defeat would be better for us—this is stated by “na ca etad vidmaḥ.” Between these two, we do not know which would be more beneficial for us. He then states the two alternatives: “yad vā”—if we should conquer them, or “yadi vā”—if they should conquer us. Furthermore, even if we were to win, it would, in effect, be a defeat. Why? Because those very people—“yān eva hatvā na jijīviṣāma”—whom we do not wish to live after killing, are now standing before us in battle.

2.shlok:
कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः
पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसंमूढचेताः।
यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्िचतं ब्रूहि तन्मे
शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्।।२.७।।
2.translit:
kārpaṇya-doṣopahata-svabhāvaḥ
pṛcchāmi tvāṁ dharma-saṁmūḍha-cetāḥ
yac chreyaḥ syān niścitaṁ brūhi tan me
śiṣyas te ’haṁ śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam
2.translate: My nature is overpowered by the defect of faint-heartedness. My mind is confused about dharma. I ask You—tell me decisively what is truly beneficial. I am Your disciple. Instruct me, who has taken refuge in You.
2.sridhara: “kārpaṇya-doṣopahata-svabhāvaḥ”—Due to faint-heartedness and the fault born from the destruction of one’s own family, my nature, characterized by valor and strength, has been overwhelmed. Therefore I ask You. Also, “dharme saṁmūḍhaṁ cetaḥ”—my mind is confused regarding dharma: whether it is right or wrong for a kṣatriya to renounce fighting and resort to begging. Hence, I ask You—“yat niścitaṁ śreyaḥ syāt”—that which is truly beneficial, please tell me that. Moreover, I am Your disciple, worthy of instruction. Therefore, instruct me, who has taken refuge in You.

2.shlok:
न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्या
द्यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम्।
अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं
राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम्।।२.८।।
2.translit:
na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād
yac chokam ucchoṣaṇam indriyāṇām
avāpya bhūmāv asapratnam ṛddhaṁ
rājyaṁ surāṇām api cādhipatyam
2.translate: I do not see what could remove my grief, which dries up my senses, even if I were to attain unrivaled and prosperous rulership on earth—or sovereignty over the gods.
2.sridhara: If You say, “You yourself should consider and act accordingly,” he responds with “na hi prapaśyāmi.” I do not see that which could remove this grief of mine, which completely scorches the senses. Even if I were to obtain prosperous and unrivaled rulership on earth, or even sovereignty over the gods—still I do not see a means to dispel this grief. That is the meaning.

2.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप।
न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह।।२.९।।
2.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
evam uktvā hṛṣīkeśaṁ guḍākeśaḥ parantapa
na yotsya iti govindam uktvā tūṣṇīṁ babhūva ha
2.translate: Sañjaya said: Having thus spoken to Hṛṣīkeśa, Guḍākeśa, the scorcher of foes, then said to Govinda, “I will not fight,” and became silent.
2.sridhara: When it is asked, “What did Arjuna do after saying this?” Sañjaya said: “evam uktvā”—having spoken thus, Arjuna then became silent. The meaning is clear.

2.shlok:
तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः।।२.१०।।
2.translit:
tam uvāca hṛṣīkeśaḥ prahasann iva bhārata
senayor ubhayor madhye viṣīdantam idaṁ vacaḥ
2.translate: To him who was desponding between both armies, Hṛṣīkeśa spoke these words as if smiling, O Bhārata.
2.sridhara: When it is asked, “What happened then?”—that is answered with “tam uvāca.” “Prahasann iva” means “with a pleased expression.”

2.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे।
गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः।।२.११।।
2.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
aśocyān anvaśocas tvaṁ prajñā-vādāṁś ca bhāṣase
gatāsūn agatāsūṁś ca nānuśocanti paṇḍitāḥ
2.translate: The Blessed Lord said: You grieve for those who should not be grieved for, yet you speak words of wisdom. The wise do not grieve for the dead nor for the living.
2.sridhara: This grief of yours arises from non-discrimination between the self and the body; to reveal that discrimination, the Blessed Lord said: “aśocyān iti.” You grieve over your relatives who are truly not worthy of grief. In saying, “O Kṛṣṇa, seeing this own kinsmen assembled, eager to fight…” and so on, you expressed grief. Even though I have already instructed you with, “Whence has this dejection come upon you in this crisis…” still you speak only the words of the wise—such as in “How shall I fight Bhīṣma and Droṇa…”—but you are not truly wise. Why? Because the wise do not grieve for those whose life-breath has departed, nor for those whose life-breath has not departed—even for those relatives who are living but bereft of companionship, thinking “how will they live?”

2.shlok:
न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः।
न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम्।।२.१२।।
2.translit:
na tv evāhaṁ jātu nāsaṁ na tvaṁ neme janādhipāḥ
na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarve vayam ataḥ param
2.translate: Never indeed was I not, nor were you, nor these kings; nor shall we all ever cease to be hereafter.
2.sridhara: Now the reason why they are not to be grieved for is stated: “na tv eveti.” Just as I, the Supreme Lord, was never non-existent—even at the time of the manifestation or dissolution of the body of my divine pastime-form—rather, I always existed, due to being beginningless. Similarly, you were never non-existent—you always existed. These rulers of men too were never non-existent, being my parts. Likewise, we shall not cease to be in the future—meaning, we shall always exist. Thus, being beyond birth and death, they are not to be grieved for.

2.shlok:
देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा।
तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति।।२.१३।।
2.translit:
dehino ’smin yathā dehe kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā
tathā dehāntara-prāptir dhīras tatra na muhyati
2.translate: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so also it passes into another body; the wise are not deluded by that.
2.sridhara: One may say: “Indeed, it is true that You, O Lord, are not subject to birth and death; but for individual souls, birth and death are well known.” In response, it is said: “dehinaḥ.” For the embodied soul identified with the body, just as within this gross body there is transition through the stages of childhood, youth, and old age—these changes are dependent on the body and not caused by the self, for even amidst these changes, the recognition “I am the same” persists—so too, at the destruction of this body, the acquisition of another body is also dependent on the subtle body. There is no destruction of the self. This is known because a newborn exhibits activities like suckling due to impressions from previous lives. Therefore, the wise are not deluded by the destruction and generation of bodies, thinking “the self is dead or born.”

2.shlok:
मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः।
आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत।।२.१४।।
2.translit:
mātrā-sparśās tu kaunteya śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkha-dāḥ
āgamāpāyino ’nityās tāṁs titikṣasva bhārata
2.translate: The contacts of the senses with their objects, O son of Kuntī, which give rise to cold and heat, pleasure and pain, are transitory and impermanent—endure them, O Bhārata.
2.sridhara: If one says, “I do not grieve for the past or future, but I grieve for myself, the experiencer of the sorrow of separation,” then this is addressed: “mātrā-sparśāḥ.” “Mātrā” means sense functions, so called because objects are measured or perceived through them. Their contact with sense objects—these give rise to cold, heat, etc. But because they come and go, they are impermanent. Therefore, endure them. Just as contact with water or heat naturally gives rise to cold or heat depending on the time, so too union with or separation from desired objects gives rise to pleasure and pain. Because these are impermanent, enduring them is proper for the wise—not being overwhelmed by joy or sorrow due to them.

2.shlok:
यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ।
समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते।।२.१५।।
2.translit:
yaṁ hi na vyathayanty ete puruṣaṁ puruṣarṣabha
sama-duḥkha-sukhaṁ dhīraṁ so ’mṛtatvāya kalpate
2.translate: That man whom these (contacts) do not disturb, O best among men, who is equal in pleasure and pain, that wise person is fit for immortality.
2.sridhara: Even the effort to eliminate them (pleasure and pain) is not appropriate, for enduring them leads to the highest result. Hence it is said: “yaṁ hi.” Those sense contacts do not agitate or overpower the person who is equal in pleasure and pain. That person, unaffected by them and possessing knowledge of dharma, becomes fit for immortality, i.e., liberation.

2.shlok:
नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः।
उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः।।२.१६।।
2.translit:
nāsato vidyate bhāvo nābhāvo vidyate sataḥ
ubhayor api dṛṣṭo ’ntas tv anayos tattva-darśibhiḥ
2.translate: The unreal has no being; the real has no non-being. The end (truth) of both has been seen by the seers of the truth.
2.sridhara: One may still ask: “Even so, how can things like heat and cold, which are extremely difficult to bear, be endured? At times, enduring them may even lead to the destruction of the body.” In anticipation of this doubt, it is stated—through analysis of the nature of reality, everything is endurable. With this intention, the verse begins: “na iti.” The unreal (asataḥ), such as heat and cold, having the nature of attributes of the non-self, is non-existent (avidyamāna); hence, there is no real existence (bhāva) of heat and cold in the Self. Likewise, the real (sataḥ)—the Self, whose nature is Existence—has no non-being (abhāva), i.e., no destruction. Thus, the conclusion (antaḥ) about both—about the real and the unreal—has been seen. By whom? By the knowers of the Truth (tattva-darśibhiḥ), who know the true nature of Reality. With such discrimination, endure (the pairs of opposites)—that is the purport.

2.shlok:
अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्।
विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित् कर्तुमर्हति।।२.१७।।
2.translit:
avināśi tu tad viddhi yena sarvam idaṁ tatam
vināśam avyayasyāsya na kaścit kartum arhati
2.translate: But know that to be indestructible by which all this is pervaded. The destruction of this imperishable (Self) no one can bring about.
2.sridhara: Here, the indestructible entity whose nature is Existence (sat-svarūpa) was previously stated in general terms. Now it is shown particularly: “avināśi iti”—know that to be indestructible. That by which all this—the body and so on, which are subject to arising and perishing—is pervaded as the witness (sākṣitvena vyāptam), that is the Self. Know that essential Self to be indestructible, i.e., free from destruction. The reason for this is stated: “vināśam”—its destruction—“na kaścit kartum arhati”—no one is able to bring about.

2.shlok:
अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः।
अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत।।२.१८।।
2.translit:
antavanta ime dehā nityasyoktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ
anāśino ’prameyasya tasmād yudhyasva bhārata
2.translate: These bodies, of the eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable embodied one, are said to have an end. Therefore, fight, O Bhārata.
2.sridhara: This verse illustrates the perishable nature of what is subject to arising and ceasing: “antavanta iti.” That which has an end (antaḥ), i.e., destruction, are called “antavantaḥ.” The bodies (dehāḥ), which are the seat of pleasure and pain, etc., belong to the embodied one (śarīriṇaḥ), who is eternal (nitya)—always of the same form, indestructible (anāśin), and immeasurable (aprameya), i.e., not limited—these bodies are said to be such by the knowers of truth. Since the Self has neither destruction nor connection with pleasure and pain, therefore, giving up grief born of delusion, fight! The purport is: do not abandon your own dharma (svadharma).

2.shlok:
य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम्।
उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते।।२.१९।।
2.translit:
ya enaṁ vetti hantāraṁ yaś cainaṁ manyate hatam
ubhau tau na vijānīto nāyaṁ hanti na hanyate
2.translate: He who thinks of this (Self) as the slayer, and he who thinks of It as slain—both of them do not understand. It slays not, nor is It slain.
2.sridhara: Thus, the grief that arises due to the death of Bhīṣma and others has been negated. And that sorrow expressed regarding the Self’s being a killer—such as, “We do not wish to slay them” (२.३५)—is also, like that (previous sorrow), causeless. This is being stated: “ya enam iti”—he who considers this Self (enam ātmānam) to be the killer, and he who thinks It to be slain—both do not know. For the Self, there is neither the role of being the object (karman) in the act of killing, nor the role of being the agent (kartṛtva). The reason is: “nāyam hanti”—this Self neither kills nor is killed.

2.shlok:
न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचि
न्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः।
अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो
न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे।।२.२०।।
2.translit:
na jāyate mriyate vā kadācit
nāyaṁ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ
ajo nityaḥ śāśvato ’yaṁ purāṇo
na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre
2.translate: It is never born, nor does It ever die. Having once come into being, It does not again cease to be. It is unborn, eternal, everlasting, and ancient. It is not slain when the body is slain.
2.sridhara: “That it is not slain”—this is now established by showing the absence of the six modifications (ṣaḍ-bhāva-vikāras): “na iti.” “Na jāyate”—It is not born: this denies birth. “Na mriyate”—It does not die: this denies destruction. The word vā is used in the sense of ca (“and”). “Na ayaṁ bhūtvā bhavitā vā”—It does not, having come into being, again exist: this denies the second transformation called ‘post-birth existence’. Why? Because It is aja—unborn. That which is born comes into existence after birth, but that which exists by itself (svataḥ) does not come into being again. “Nityaḥ”—always of the same form: this denies growth. “Śāśvataḥ”—eternal: this denies decay. “Purāṇaḥ”—ancient: this denies transformation. Though existing from ancient times, It does not become new by any change; it is not that due to change It acquires a new form. Or, taking “na bhavitā” in its secondary sense, the idea is: it will not become more than what it already is—this denies increase. Thus, “ajo nityaḥ” is the reason for both absence of regeneration and of growth, and so the repetition is avoided. Therefore, all the six modifications described by Yāska and other Vedic scholars—birth, existence, growth, transformation, decline, and destruction—are denied. The purpose for denying these modifications is to affirm the indestructibility that is under discussion. This is concluded with: “na hanyate hanyamāne śarīre”—It is not slain when the body is slain.

2.shlok:
वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम्।
कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम्।।२.२१।।
2.translit:
vedāvināśinaṁ nityaṁ ya enam ajam avyayam
kathaṁ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṁ ghātayati hanti kam
2.translate: O Pārtha, he who knows this (Self) as indestructible, eternal, unborn, and immutable—how can that person slay or cause anyone to be slain?
2.sridhara: Therefore, even the idea of the Self being a killer, as previously mentioned, is invalid. This is stated: “veda iti”—he who knows the Self as eternal (nitya), free from growth, as avyaya (imperishable), free from decline, as aja (unborn), and as avināśin (indestructible), how can that person slay anyone (kaṁ hanti)? That is, there is no means for the killing of such a one. Similarly, how can he, becoming an agent (prayojaka), cause someone else to be killed? He does not kill anyone in any way whatsoever—this is the meaning. By this, the implication is: “Do not consider me (Kṛṣṇa) to be blameworthy, as even I am not an agent (prayojaka).”

2.shlok:
वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय
नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि।
तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा-
न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही।।२.२२।।
2.translit:
vāsāṁsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya
navāni gṛhṇāti naro ’parāṇi
tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāni
anyāni saṁyāti navāni dehī
2.translate: Just as a man discards worn-out garments and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self, having discarded worn-out bodies, enters new ones.
2.sridhara: One might object: “Even though the Self is indestructible, still, reflecting upon the destruction of its body, I feel sorrow.” In response to that, the verse states: “vāsāṁsi iti”—just as one gives up worn-out clothes. Since bodies arise as a result of karma, they are bound to perish—there is no need for sorrow at the destruction of a worn-out body. That is the purport.

2.shlok:
नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः।
न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः।।२.२३।।
2.translit:
nainaṁ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṁ dahati pāvakaḥ
na cainaṁ kledayanty āpo na śoṣayati mārutaḥ
2.translate: Weapons do not cut It, fire does not burn It, waters do not moisten It, and wind does not dry It.
2.sridhara: Now, in continuation of the question “How can It be slain?” the absence of any means of slaying is shown, thereby further clarifying the Self’s indestructibility: “nainaṁ iti”—weapons do not cut It. “Āpaḥ na kledayanti”—waters do not make It moist, that is, do not make It soft or weak by soaking.

2.shlok:
अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च।
नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः।।२.२४।।
2.translit:
acchedyo ’yam adāhyo ’yam akledyo ’śoṣya eva ca
nityaḥ sarva-gataḥ sthāṇur acalo ’yaṁ sanātanaḥ
2.translate: This (Self) is uncuttable, unburnable, unwettable, and undryable. It is eternal, all-pervading, stable, immovable, and ancient.
2.sridhara: Here the reasons are stated: “acchedya iti”—this Self is acchedya (incapable of being cut) and akledya (incapable of being moistened) due to its being partless (niravayavatva). “Adāhya” (incombustible) is due to being formless (amūrtatva). “Aśoṣya” (not dryable) is due to the absence of liquidity (dravatva-abhāva). Hence, it is not subject to any of these changes. Because of this, It is “nityaḥ” (eternal), i.e., indestructible; “sarvagataḥ” (all-pervading); “sthāṇuḥ” (stable) meaning with an unchanging nature (rūpāntara-apatti-śūnya); “acalaḥ” (unmoving), i.e., not giving up its previous form; “sanātanaḥ” (eternal)—without beginning.

2.shlok:
अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते।
तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि।।२.२५।।
2.translit:
avyakto ’yam acintyo ’yam avikāryo ’yam ucyate
tasmād evaṁ viditvainaṁ nānuśocitum arhasi
2.translate: This (Self) is said to be unmanifest, unthinkable, and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing It thus, you should not grieve.
2.sridhara: Moreover, It is “avyaktaḥ”—not an object of the senses such as the eye; “acintyaḥ”—not an object of thought, beyond the mind; “avikāryaḥ”—beyond the reach of action-organs (karma-indriyas), i.e., not subject to modification. The word “ucyate” (“It is said”) indicates that such statements are supported by authoritative sources. The verse concludes: “tasmāt”—therefore.

2.shlok:
अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम्।
तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि।।२.२६।।
2.translit:
atha cainaṁ nitya-jātaṁ nityaṁ vā manyase mṛtam
tathāpi tvaṁ mahā-bāho naivaṁ śocitum arhasi
2.translate: But even if you think of this (Self) as being constantly born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed, you should not grieve.
2.sridhara: Thus it has been stated that since the Self is not subject to birth and death, there is no cause for grief. Now, it is said that even accepting that the Self is born and dies along with the body, still there is no reason to grieve. This is said in “atha ceti”: Even if you think of this Self as constantly born in each body and dying when that body perishes—due to the soul’s transmigration associated with merit and demerit resulting in birth and death—still you should not grieve.

2.shlok:
जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च।
तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि।।२.२७।।
2.translit:
jātasya hi dhruvo mṛtyur dhruvaṁ janma mṛtasya ca
tasmād aparihārye ’rthe na tvaṁ śocitum arhasi
2.translate: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain. Therefore, in a matter that cannot be avoided, you should not grieve.
2.sridhara: Why is this so? He says: “jātasya iti”—for one who is born, due to the exhaustion of the karma which initiated that birth, death is inevitable. For one who has died, birth too is inevitable, due to karma done for the sake of various bodies. Therefore, since birth and death are unavoidable realities, you, being knowledgeable, should not grieve. That is, it is not appropriate for you to do so.

2.shlok:
अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत।
अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना।।२.२८।।
2.translit:
avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyakta-madhyāni bhārata
avyakta-nidhanāni eva tatra kā paridevanā
2.translate: Beings are unmanifest in the beginning, manifest in the middle, O Bhārata, and unmanifest again at the end. So what is there to lament?
2.sridhara: Further, considering the nature of bodies and the birth and death of the Self identified with bodily adjuncts, one should not grieve. Hence it is said: “avyaktādīni.” The unmanifest (avyakta) refers to Pradhāna (primordial matter)—that itself is the prior condition (ādi), i.e., the beginning state of beings such as bodies. Since all beings arise from that unmanifest cause, they are said to be avyaktādi. “Vyakta” means manifest—the middle state, characterized by the duration between birth and death. “Avyakta-nidhanāni”—those whose end is dissolution into the unmanifest. Given this, what lamentation can there be for such beings? What is the cause for wailing? Just as a person awakened from sleep does not grieve for things seen in a dream, so too here.

2.shlok:
आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेनं
आश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः।
आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति
श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित्।।२.२९।।
2.translit:
āścaryavat paśyati kaścid enaṁ
āścaryavad vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ
āścaryavac cainam anyaḥ śṛṇoti
śrutvāpy enaṁ veda na caiva kaścit
2.translate: Someone sees This (Self) as a wonder; another speaks of It as a wonder; another hears of It as a wonder; yet even after hearing, no one truly knows It.
2.sridhara: Why then do even the learned grieve in this world? Because of ignorance of the Self—this is implied. To show that the Self is difficult to understand, the verse states: “āścaryavat.” Some person sees this Self through scripture and the instruction of a teacher as a marvel. Because the Self is all-pervading, eternal, and of the nature of knowledge and bliss, its perception is extraordinary—like seeing something impossible or magical, he sees it with wonder, due to being overwhelmed by improbability. Likewise, another speaks of it as a marvel and another hears of it as such. Yet another, overpowered by contrary conceptions, even after hearing, does not understand it. By the word “ca” in “śrutvāpy,” it is to be understood that even after hearing and speaking, he does not fully comprehend it.

2.shlok:
देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत।
तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि।।२.३०।।
2.translit:
dehī nityam avadhyo ’yaṁ dehe sarvasya bhārata
tasmāt sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṁ śocitum arhasi
2.translate: This embodied Self is eternally invulnerable in the bodies of all beings, O Bhārata. Therefore, you should not grieve for any creature.
2.sridhara: Thus, having briefly taught the difficult-to-know nature of the Self, he concludes the teaching on the absence of grief: “dehī iti”—the Self, embodied in all beings, is eternal and cannot be slain. Therefore, you should not grieve for any living beings.

2.shlok:
स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि।
धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाछ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते।।२.३१।।
2.translit:
svadharmam api cāvekṣya na vikampitum arhasi
dharmyād dhi yuddhāc chreyo ’nyat kṣatriyasya na vidyate
2.translate: Also, considering your own duty, you should not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kṣatriya than a righteous war.
2.sridhara: That trembling of the body and horripilation which Arjuna spoke of—“my limbs tremble and my hair stands on end” (१.२९)—is also not proper. Hence it is said: “svadharmam iti”—you should not waver even in slaying these (people), simply because the Self is indestructible. Moreover, even by considering your own prescribed duty (svadharma), you should not waver—this is the connection. And in response to his earlier statement “I do not see any good in killing my own people in battle,” etc., it is now said: “dharmyād iti”—for a Kṣatriya, there is no greater good than a battle that is in accordance with dharma.

2.shlok:
यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम्।
सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम्।।२.३२।।
2.translit:
yadṛcchayā copapannaṁ svarga-dvāram apāvṛtam
sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham īdṛśam
2.translate: Happy are the Kṣatriyas, O Pārtha, who obtain such a war that comes of its own accord, an open door to heaven.
2.sridhara: Moreover, when such great good has arrived unasked, how can there be hesitation? Therefore it is said: “yadṛcchayeti”—this kind of war, which has come of its own accord without being sought for, is obtained only by the fortunate, the truly blessed. For this is a doorway to heaven, wide open and unobstructed. Alternatively, “those who obtain such a war—they alone are happy,” is the meaning. Thus, Arjuna’s earlier statement—“How can we be happy by killing our own people?” (१.३६)—is refuted.

2.shlok:
अथ चैत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि।
ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि।।२.३३।।
2.translit:
atha cait tvam imaṁ dharmyaṁ saṅgrāmaṁ na kariṣyasi
tataḥ svadharmaṁ kīrtiṁ ca hitvā pāpam avāpsyasi
2.translate: But if you do not undertake this righteous war, then, abandoning your own duty and honor, you will incur sin.
2.sridhara: Now the fault on the other side (i.e., if you do not fight) is stated: “atha cait tvam iti.”

2.shlok:
अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम्।
संभावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते।।२.३४।।
2.translit:
akīrtiṁ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti te ’vyayām
saṁbhāvitasya cākīrtir maraṇād atiricyate
2.translate: People will also speak of your undying infamy; and for a person who has been honored, dishonor is worse than death.
2.sridhara: Moreover, “akīrtim iti”—people will speak of your infamy, and it will be lasting. For one who has been respected, dishonor is greater than death.

2.shlok:
भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः।
येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम्।।२.३५।।
2.translit:
bhayād raṇād uparataṁ maṁsyante tvāṁ mahā-rathāḥ
yeṣāṁ ca tvaṁ bahu-mato bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam
2.translate: The great warriors will think that you have withdrawn from the battle out of fear; and having been highly esteemed by them, you will fall into disgrace.
2.sridhara: Moreover, “bhayād iti”—those by whom you were previously honored for your many qualities will think you withdrew from the battle due to fear. As a result, having once been highly respected, you will fall into dishonor.

2.shlok:
अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून् वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः।
निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम्।।२.३६।।
2.translit:
avācya-vādāṁś ca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ
nindantas tava sāmarthyaṁ tato duḥkhataraṁ nu kim
2.translate: Your enemies will also speak many unseemly words, vilifying your strength. What could be more painful than that?
2.sridhara: Moreover, “avācyeti”—your enemies, those who bear ill-will towards you, will speak many unspeakable words—words that are unfit to be uttered.

2.shlok:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम्।
तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः।।२.३७।।
2.translit:
hato vā prāpsyasi svargaṁ jitvā vā bhokṣyase mahīm
tasmād uttiṣṭha kaunteya yuddhāya kṛta-niścayaḥ
2.translate: Slain, you will attain heaven; or victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, arise, O Kaunteya, resolved to fight.
2.sridhara: In regard to what was earlier stated—“We do not know which is better, whether we should conquer them or they should conquer us” (२.६)—this is now addressed: “hato vā iti”—in both alternatives, you only stand to gain.

2.shlok:
सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ।
ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि।।२.३८।।
2.translit:
sukha-duḥkhe same kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau
tato yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṁ pāpam avāpsyasi
2.translate: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat the same, then engage in battle. Thus, you will not incur sin.
2.sridhara: With regard to what was said—“we shall incur sin” (१.३६)—this is now stated: “sukha-duḥkhe iti.” Making pleasure and pain equal, and likewise gain and loss which are their causes, and victory and defeat which are the causes of those, you should engage—“yujyasva”—prepare yourself for battle. The basis for this equanimity is freedom from elation and dejection. By giving up desire for pleasure and so on, and acting with the understanding of your duty (svadharma), you will not incur sin—this is the meaning.

2.shlok:
एषा तेऽभिहिता सांख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु।
बुद्ध्यायुक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि।।२.३९।।
2.translit:
eṣā te ’bhihitā sāṅkhye buddhir yoge tv imāṁ śṛṇu
buddhyā yukto yayā pārtha karma-bandhaṁ prahāsyasi
2.translate: This wisdom has been declared to you from the standpoint of Sāṅkhya; now hear it from the standpoint of Yoga. Endowed with this understanding, O Pārtha, you shall cast off the bondage of action.
2.sridhara: Having summarized the teaching of jñāna-yoga, He now begins the instruction on karma-yoga, which is its means: “eṣā te.” That which rightly reveals (khyāyate) the reality of things is called sāṅkhya, true knowledge; and the Self that shines forth in it is Sāṅkhya, i.e., knowledge of the Self. The discernment (buddhi) to be cultivated in it has been declared to you. Even if this buddhi of Sāṅkhya has been declared to you, and still direct realization of the Self does not arise, then—through the purification of the inner instrument (antaḥkaraṇa)—to attain direct realization of the Self, now hear this buddhi in Yoga. Endowed with this understanding—that is, by the performance of karma-yoga dedicated to the Supreme Lord, with a purified mind, and through direct realization attained by the grace of the Lord—you will cast off the bondage of action completely.

2.shlok:
नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते।
स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात्।।२.४०।।
2.translit:
nehābhikrama-nāśo ’sti pratyavāyo na vidyate
svalpam apy asya dharmasya trāyate mahato bhayāt
2.translate: In this (path), there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm (adverse result). Even a little of this dharma protects one from great fear.
2.sridhara: One might ask: “Isn’t it possible, as in farming and other actions, that due to many hindrances, or due to defect in parts like mantras, the result may be lost, or even harm result?” In reply, it is said: “neha.” In this niṣkāma-karma-yoga, there is no loss of effort, no futility. Nor is there any adverse result. Since it is undertaken for the sake of the Lord alone, obstacles and imperfections do not apply. Moreover, even a little practice of this dharma—beginning it even to a small extent—protects from great fear, that is, from the cycle of transmigratory existence (saṁsāra). It is not like desire-motivated rituals (kāmya-karma), where the slightest defect in a component leads to failure—such is not the case here.

2.shlok:
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन।
बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम्।।२.४१।।
2.translit:
vyavasāyātmikā buddhir ekeha kuru-nandana
bahu-śākhā hy anantāś ca buddhayo ’vyavasāyinām
2.translate: In this path, O joy of the Kurus, there is a single-pointed, resolute understanding. But the intellects of the irresolute are many-branched and endless.
2.sridhara: Why is there a difference between the two paths? In anticipation of this, the distinction is stated: “vyavasāyeti.” In this karma-yoga, which is characterized by devotion to God, there is only one resolute intellect—“I shall surely cross over by devotion to the Supreme Lord.” It is determined solely for the sake of devotion to the Supreme, with single-pointed focus. But for those without resoluteness—who are desirous of various results and whose minds are scattered—their intellects become manifold and endless due to their countless desires. Even within that, due to the distinctions in actions, qualities, and results, their intellects become full of branches. However, for actions done for the worship of God, like the nitya (daily) and naimittika (occasional) duties, even with some imperfection in their parts, they are not destroyed. It is instructed: "Let one do it as best as one can." Imperfection does not apply here, since it is done solely with intent toward God. But in the case of kāmya karma (desire-driven ritual), like the agnihotra sacrifice performed by one desiring heaven, or other rituals aimed at sensual pleasures—those are entirely different. Hence, the difference between the two is great—this is the idea.

2.shlok:
यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः।
वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः।।२.४२।।
2.translit:
yām imāṁ puṣpitāṁ vācaṁ pravadanty avipaścitaḥ
veda-vāda-ratāḥ pārtha nānyad astīti vādi naḥ
2.translate: Those unwise ones who are attached to the flowery words of the Vedas, O Pārtha, and who declare, “There is nothing else,” speak this attractive language.
2.sridhara: Why do even those with desires not cultivate this resolute understanding? That is now stated: “yām iti.” The flowery speech refers to scriptural statements promising desirable results—like heaven and so on—which, like a poisonous vine, seem beautiful at first glance. Those who are attached to such words, their minds are carried away by them, and so they do not develop the resolute understanding. Why do they speak in this way? Because they are avipaścitaḥ—undiscerning, deluded. The reason is given: the veda-vāda-s—the eulogistic statements in the Vedas, such as “One who performs the cāturmāsya sacrifice gains inexhaustible merit,” or “We have become immortal by drinking soma”—they are delighted in only those statements. Therefore, they say: “There is nothing higher than this,” meaning, they do not accept the supreme reality of God as the goal.

2.shlok:
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम्।
क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति।।२.४३।।
2.translit:
kāmātmānaḥ svarga-parā janma-karma-phala-pradām
kriyā-viśeṣa-bahulāṁ bhogaiśvarya-gatiṁ prati
2.translate: They are full of desires, with heaven as their goal, and they speak of actions that yield results like rebirth and fruits of works, prescribing numerous specific rituals aimed at the attainment of enjoyment and power.
2.sridhara: Therefore: “kāmātmānaḥ”—those whose minds are agitated by desire. For them, svarga (heaven) alone is the supreme goal. They teach about actions and results that lead to birth and works and their fruits. The many elaborate actions taught in those speeches are oriented toward the attainment of enjoyment and lordship—this is implied.

2.shlok:
भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम्।
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते।।२.४४।।
2.translit:
bhogaiśvarya-prasaktānāṁ tayāpahṛta-cetasām
vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate
2.translate: For those who are attached to pleasure and power, and whose minds are carried away by that (flowery speech), the resolute understanding directed toward concentration is not established.
2.sridhara: Hence: “bhogaiśvarya-prasaktānām”—those who are engrossed in pleasure and power. Whose minds are carried away, drawn in, by that flowery speech. For such persons, the resolute understanding directed toward samādhi—single-pointed focus, oriented toward the Supreme—is not established. The verb “vidhīyate” is in the causative passive sense, meaning: it does not arise.

2.shlok:
त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन।
निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान्।।२.४५।।
2.translit:
traiguṇya-viṣayā vedā nistraiguṇyo bhavārjuna
nirdvandvo nitya-sattva-stho niryoga-kṣema ātmavān
2.translate: The Vedas deal with the three modes of nature. Be you free from the three modes, O Arjuna—free from the pairs of opposites, ever established in purity (sattva), without concern for acquisition and preservation, and possessed of the Self.
2.sridhara: One may question: if heaven and such are not the highest goal, then why do the Vedas prescribe actions aimed at attaining them? That is addressed: “traiguṇya-viṣayā iti.” The Vedas, which deal with karma and its results, pertain to persons who are endowed with desire and composed of the three guṇas (qualities). But you, be nistraiguṇya—free of the guṇas—without desire. The method is explained: nirdvandvaḥ—free from the dualities such as pleasure and pain, heat and cold. Endure them—that is the meaning. How? Be nitya-sattva-sthaḥ—steadfast in inner calm and clarity (sattva). Also, be niryoga-kṣemaḥ—free from concern for acquiring what is not attained (yoga) and preserving what is already attained (kṣema). Ātmavān—be possessed of the Self, i.e., remain vigilant. For one agitated by dualities and absorbed in acquisition and preservation cannot transcend the three guṇas.

2.shlok:
यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके।
तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः।।२.४६।।
2.translit:
yāvān arthaḥ udapāne sarvataḥ samplutodake
tāvān sarveṣu vedeṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ
2.translate: To the knower, a brāhmaṇa, who understands (the Self), all the Vedas are of as much use as is a small reservoir of water in a place flooded on all sides.
2.sridhara: It might be suspected: “Is not the resolute understanding directed toward the worship of the Supreme Lord, arising from the renunciation of the various fruits mentioned in the Vedas, in fact a defective or perverse understanding?” To remove this doubt, the verse says, “yāvān iti.” A well or pond or reservoir (udapāna) is meant for obtaining drinking water, etc. But in a vast lake where water overflows on all sides, all such uses—bathing, drinking, and so on—are fulfilled together, without the need to go separately to a small well, due to the insufficiency of water in one place. Likewise, whatever benefit is attained from the various results described in all the Vedas—that total benefit is obtained all at once by the brāhmaṇa who is endowed with right knowledge and resolute understanding. Because all finite pleasures are included within the bliss of Brahman. As the śruti says: “It is only on a mere fraction of this bliss that all beings exist” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad ४.३.३२). Therefore, this alone is the true and intelligent understanding.

2.shlok:
कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन।
मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि।।२.४७।।
2.translit:
karmaṇy eva adhikāras te mā phaleṣu kadācana
mā karma-phala-hetur bhūr mā te saṅgo ’stv akarmaṇi
2.translate: You have a right only to action, never to its fruits. Let not the fruits of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.
2.sridhara: If it is said, “Then, since all fruits arise merely from the worship of the Supreme Lord, let one act with that motive alone,” this verse forbids that notion: “karmaṇy eva.” You, who are seeking knowledge of truth, have authority over action alone. You should not have any desire for the fruits, which are the cause of bondage. But someone might object: “Surely, when action is performed, its result must follow—just like the satisfaction that comes from eating.” Anticipating this, it says: “mā karma-phala-hetur bhūḥ”—do not be one for whom the fruit of action is the cause of activity. Since heaven and such results are considered fruits only when desired, what is not desired does not become fruit. Therefore, due to fear that fruit leads to bondage, do not let there be attachment to inaction either—that is, do not let your steadiness lie in refraining from action.

2.shlok:
योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय।
सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते।।२.४८।।
2.translit:
yoga-sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya
siddhy-asiddhyoḥ samo bhūtvā samatvaṁ yoga ucyate
2.translate: Perform action, O Dhanañjaya, being steadfast in yoga, abandoning attachment, and remaining the same in success and failure. Such evenness of mind is called yoga.
2.sridhara: Then what should be done? “yoga-sthaḥ” — remain established in yoga. Yoga means one-pointed focus on the Supreme Lord. Established in that, perform action. Also, abandoning attachment—meaning, giving up the insistence on doership—act solely depending on the Lord. Remaining equal in success and failure, even in the attainment of knowledge resulting from the action, act only as an offering to the Lord. Such evenness, being of the nature of mental absorption, is what is called yoga by the wise.

2.shlok:
दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय।
बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः।।२.४९।।
2.translit:
dūreṇa hy avaraṁ karma buddhi-yogād dhanañjaya
buddhau śaraṇam anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phala-hetavaḥ
2.translate: Action performed with desire is far inferior to action performed with wisdom, O Dhanañjaya. Seek refuge in that wisdom; those motivated by fruits are miserable.
2.sridhara: Action performed with desire (kāmya karma) is extremely inferior—“dūreṇa avaram.” The yoga performed with resolute intelligence (buddhi-yoga) is higher. Or, “buddhi” may refer to that which is the means to realization. Therefore, action motivated by desire is far lower than that. Because this is so, take refuge in wisdom (buddhau śaraṇam anviccha)—i.e., perform karma-yoga. Or, “seek refuge in buddhi” may mean, “take refuge in the Lord who is the protector.” Those who act with fruit as the motive are kṛpaṇāḥ—miserable. As the śruti says: “He who departs from this world without knowing the imperishable is indeed a miserable one” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad ३.८.१०).

2.shlok:
बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते।
तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम्।।२.५०।।
2.translit:
buddhi-yukto jahātīha ubhe sukṛta-duṣkṛte
tasmād yogāya yujyasva yogaḥ karma-su kauśalam
2.translate: One endowed with wisdom casts off here both good and evil deeds. Therefore, be engaged in yoga. Yoga is skill in action.
2.sridhara: But one who is joined with buddhi-yoga is superior—“buddhi-yuktaḥ.” Sukṛta means that which leads to heaven, duṣkṛta means that which leads to hell—he abandons both here itself, by the grace of the Supreme Lord. Therefore, strive for yoga for that purpose—engage in karma-yoga. Why? Because skill in actions—i.e., the cleverness of transforming actions, even those which would otherwise be binding, into means for liberation through devotion to the Supreme—is called yoga.

2.shlok:
कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः।
जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम्।।२.५१।।
2.translit:
karmajaṁ buddhi-yuktā hi phalaṁ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ
janma-bandha-vinirmuktāḥ padaṁ gacchanti anāmayam
2.translate: The wise, endowed with right understanding, having abandoned the fruit born of actions, being freed from the bondage of birth, attain the state that is free from all suffering.
2.sridhara: Now the manner in which action becomes a means to liberation is stated—“karmajam iti.” The wise ones, having renounced the fruit born of action, performing actions solely for the purpose of worshiping the Supreme Lord, become free from the bondage in the form of birth. Being such, they attain the state called mokṣa, the abode of Viṣṇu, which is free from all afflictions.

2.shlok:
यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति।
तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च।।२.५२।।
2.translit:
yadā te moha-kalilaṁ buddhir vyatitariṣyati
tadā gantāsi nirvedaṁ śrotavyasya śrutasya ca
2.translate: When your intellect crosses beyond the mire of delusion, then you will attain dispassion for what is to be heard and what has been heard.
2.sridhara: In response to the implied question, “When will I attain that supreme state?” it is said—“yadā te.” Delusion (moha) is the mistaken identification of the Self with the body and such. This is the kalila, the dense entanglement. According to the Abhidhāna-kośa, “kalila” means deep or dense.
