Therefore, when, by worship of the Supreme Lord, your intellect, by His grace, crosses over that thick, difficult-to-overcome delusion characterized by identification with the body, then you will attain dispassion (nirveda) toward both what is to be heard and what has been heard—that is, you will no longer pursue or desire them, recognizing them as not worth adopting or seeking.

2.shlok:
श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला।
समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि।।२.५३।।
2.translit:
śruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā
samādhau acalā buddhiḥ tadā yogam avāpsyasi
2.translate: When your intellect, which is perplexed by conflicting scriptural statements, becomes firmly and immovably established in samādhi, then you will attain yoga.
2.sridhara: Therefore, it is said—“śruti-vipratipannā.” Your intellect, previously distracted by hearing various Vedic passages with differing worldly and otherworldly meanings, when it becomes steady in samādhi—that is, fixed upon that in which the mind is fully absorbed—namely the Supreme Lord (because samādhi means that in which the mind is brought to absorption)—then, when your intellect becomes immovable and unshaken, not drawn toward external objects due to their distraction or instability, and established there firmly through proficiency in practice (abhyāsa), then you will attain yoga, the fruit of yoga—i.e., the knowledge of reality (tattva-jñāna).

2.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव।
स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम्।।२.५४।।
2.translit:
arjuna uvāca
sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi-sthasya keśava
sthita-dhīḥ kiṁ prabhāṣeta kim āsīta vrajeta kim
2.translate: Arjuna said: What is the description of one of steady wisdom who is established in samādhi, O Keśava? How does one of steady mind speak, how does he sit, how does he walk?
2.sridhara: Desiring to know the characteristics of the knower of the Self (ātma-tattva-jña) described in the previous verses, Arjuna said—“sthita-prajñasya iti.” One who is established in natural samādhi, and whose knowledge (prajñā) is thus steady (sthita), what is his description (bhāṣā)? Since that by which something is described is called bhāṣā (etymologically, bhāṣyate anayeti bhāṣā), the meaning is: by what characteristic is he called sthita-prajña? Also, how does a person of steady mind speak, how does he sit, how does he move about—this is the purport.

2.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
प्रजहाति यदा कामान् सर्वान् पार्थ मनोगतान्।
आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते।।२.५५।।
2.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
prajahāti yadā kāmān sarvān pārtha mano-gatān
ātmani eva ātmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita-prajñaḥ tadā ucyate
2.translate: The Blessed Lord said: When a man gives up all desires that have entered the mind, O Pārtha, and is content in the Self by the Self, then he is said to be one of steady wisdom.
2.sridhara: Here, those very internal means to knowledge for the seeker become the natural characteristics of one who is perfected. Therefore, in describing the characteristics of the perfected one, the inner disciplines (sādhana) for knowledge are simultaneously stated until the end of the chapter. Now, the answer to the first question is given in two verses, starting with “prajahāti.” The Blessed Lord said: When one completely renounces the desires residing in the mind—“mano-gatān kāmān”—that is, when one is no longer affected by them, then the cause of such renunciation is this: “ātmani eva”—in one's own Self, which is of the nature of supreme bliss—“ātmanā”—by oneself—“tuṣṭaḥ,” being satisfied. That is, when one becomes ātmārāma, one who delights in the Self, then alone does he abandon petty worldly cravings. One possessing this trait is called a sthita-prajña, a man of steady wisdom.

2.shlok:
दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः।
वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते।।२.५६।।
2.translit:
duḥkheṣv anudvigna-manāḥ sukheṣu vigata-spṛhaḥ
vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ sthita-dhīr munir ucyate
2.translate: He whose mind is unshaken amidst sorrows, who has no longing for pleasures, who is free from attachment, fear, and anger—such a sage is called one of steady wisdom.
2.sridhara: Further—“duḥkheṣu iti.” One whose mind is undisturbed even when sorrows arise is anudvigna-manaḥ. One who has no longing for pleasures is vigata-spṛhaḥ. The reason for that is—one who is free from attachment, fear, and anger—vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhaḥ. Here, rāga is affection or delight (prītiḥ). Such a person is called a muni, a sage, and a sthita-dhīḥ, one of steady wisdom.

2.shlok:
यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्।
नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।२.५७।।
2.translit:
yaḥ sarvatra anabhisnehaḥ tat-tat prāpya śubha-aśubham
na abhinandati na dveṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
2.translate: He who is unattached everywhere, and neither rejoices nor hates on obtaining good or evil—that person's wisdom is firmly established.
2.sridhara: The answer to “how does he speak?” is now given—“yaḥ iti.” One who is without attachment (anabhisnehaḥ) even toward sons and the like. Hence, upon obtaining favorable (śubha) conditions, he does not rejoice or praise them. Upon obtaining unfavorable (aśubha) conditions, he does not hate or condemn them. But rather, he speaks only with indifference (udāsīna). Such a one’s wisdom is said to be established.

2.shlok:
यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।२.५८।।
2.translit:
yadā saṁharate ca ayaṁ kūrmaḥ aṅgāni iva sarvaśaḥ
indriyāṇi indriya-arthebhyaḥ tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
2.translate: When, like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs from all sides, one withdraws the senses from sense objects, then his wisdom is firmly established.
2.sridhara: Further—“yadā iti.” When this yogī withdraws his senses from the objects of the senses—indriyārthebhyaḥ—then, for the effortless nature of that withdrawal, an analogy is given: just as the tortoise (kūrmaḥ) draws in its limbs—hands, feet, and so on—by its very nature, so too (should the yogī do).

2.shlok:
विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः।
रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते।।२.५९।।
2.translit:
viṣayā vinivartante nirāhārasya dehinaḥ
rasa-varjaṁ rasaḥ api asya paraṁ dṛṣṭvā nivartate
2.translate: The sense objects withdraw from one who abstains, but the taste for them remains; even that taste ceases upon seeing the Supreme.
2.sridhara:
It may be said that non-indulgence of the senses in their objects should not be considered a sign of steady wisdom, because even the dull, the sick, or those engaged in fasting may not engage in sense pleasures. Hence it is said—“viṣayāḥ iti.” The act of the senses receiving objects is āhāra. For one who abstains (nirāhāra), that is, one who does not let the senses engage with objects, the sense objects are indeed given up—vinivartante. That is, the experience of them ceases.

However, the rasa—the subtle taste, or longing—remains. That is, the desire does not go away. But when such a person sees the Supreme Self—paraṁ dṛṣṭvā—even that taste (rāga, longing) departs of its own accord—rasaḥ api asya...nivartate—meaning, it is destroyed.

Alternatively, for one who abstains due to fasting (nirāhāraḥ), sense objects generally withdraw due to lack of appetite, not from dispassion. But the rasa, the longing, does not go. The rest is the same as previously explained.

2.shlok:
यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः।
इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः।।२.६०।।
2.translit:
yatataḥ hi api kaunteya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ
indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṁ manaḥ
2.translate: For, O Kaunteya, even the mind of a wise man who strives (for control) is forcibly carried away by the turbulent senses.
2.sridhara: Without control over the senses, steadiness of wisdom (sthita-prajñatā) is not possible. Therefore, during the stage of spiritual practice (sādhaka-avasthā), great effort must be made. Thus, it is said—“yatataḥ hi api.” Even in one who is striving for liberation (mokṣa), and even if he is vipaścit, a man of discrimination, the senses forcibly (prasabham) carry off the mind. Why? Because the senses are pramāthīni—turbulent, agitating, and prone to disturbance.

2.shlok:
तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः।
वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।२.६१।।
2.translit:
tāni sarvāṇi saṁyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ
vaśe hi yasya indriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
2.translate: Having restrained all those (senses), one should sit disciplined, devoted to Me; for, whose senses are under control—his wisdom is firmly established.
2.sridhara: Since this is so, therefore—“tāni iti.” The disciplined one (yuktaḥ), the yogī, having restrained (saṁyamya) those senses (tāni indriyāṇi), should sit with his mind set on Me (mat-paraḥ san āsīta). Whose senses are under control (vaśe), that is, obedient (vaśavartīni), his wisdom is said to be established. By this, the answer to the question “how does he sit?” is given—it is, that he sits with the senses subdued.

2.shlok:
ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते।
सङ्गात् संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते।।२.६२।।
2.translit:
dhyāyataḥ viṣayān puṁsaḥ saṅgaḥ teṣu upajāyate
saṅgāt sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt krodhaḥ abhijāyate
2.translate: When a man thinks about sense-objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment springs desire; from desire arises anger.
2.sridhara: Having described the defect of lack of external sense-restraint, the defect of lack of mental restraint is now stated—“dhyāyataḥ iti” (in these two verses). For a man who contemplates objects with a sense of value (guṇa-buddhyā viṣayān dhyāyataḥ puruṣasya), attachment (saṅgaḥ) arises. From attachment arises intensified desire (kāmaḥ). And from obstructed desire arises anger (krodhaḥ).

2.shlok:
क्रोधाद्भवति संमोहः संमोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः।
स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति।।२.६३।।
2.translit:
krodhāt bhavati saṁmohaḥ saṁmohāt smṛti-vibhramaḥ
smṛti-bhraṁśāt buddhi-nāśaḥ buddhi-nāśāt praṇaśyati
2.translate: From anger comes delusion; from delusion, confusion of memory; from confusion of memory, destruction of intellect; from destruction of intellect, he perishes.
2.sridhara: Further—“krodhāt iti.” From anger comes saṁmohaḥ, delusion—the loss of discernment between right and wrong (kārya-akārya-viveka-abhāvaḥ). From that, the deviation (vibhramaḥ) or distortion of the memory of what was taught by scriptures and teachers (śāstra-ācārya-upadiṣṭa-artha-smṛteḥ). From that, the destruction of the intellect (buddheḥ cetanayāḥ vināśaḥ)—just as in the case of a tree, it becomes overpowered (vṛkṣa-ādiṣv iva abhibhavaḥ). Then, he is destroyed (praṇaśyati)—he becomes like one who is dead.

2.shlok:
रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्।
आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति।।२.६४।।
2.translit:
rāga-dveṣa-viyuktaiḥ tu viṣayān indriyaiḥ caran
ātma-vaśyaiḥ vidheya-ātmā prasādam adhigacchati
2.translate: But one who moves among the sense-objects with senses free from attachment and aversion, and under self-control, attains serenity.
2.sridhara:
It may be doubted that since the senses, by nature, are inclined toward sense-objects, their restraint may be impossible, and hence such a defect is insurmountable; so how can sthita-prajñatā (steadfast wisdom) be attained? Anticipating this objection, it is said—“rāga-dveṣa-viyuktaiḥ” (in these two verses). Though moving among the objects (viṣayān caran, i.e., enjoying them), one who is devoid of rāga and dveṣa—i.e., without pride (vigata-darpa)—attains prasāda, serenity or tranquility.

Rāga-dveṣa-rahitatva is further explained: one whose senses are under the control of the mind—ātmanaḥ manasaḥ vaśyaiḥ—and whose mind is obedient (vidheya-ātmā), he attains it. By this, the answer to the fourth question—“how does he walk, eat, and act?” is also given: he experiences sense-objects through self-controlled senses.

2.shlok:
प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते।
प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते।।२.६५।।
2.translit:
prasāde sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hāniḥ asya upajāyate
prasanna-cetasaḥ hi āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate
2.translate: In that tranquility, all his sorrows are destroyed; for, in the tranquil-minded person, the intellect quickly becomes steady.
2.sridhara: What happens when prasāda (serenity) arises is stated—“prasāde iti.” When there is prasāda, all sorrows (sarva-duḥkha) are destroyed. And thus, in the one whose mind is serene (prasanna-cetasaḥ), the intellect (buddhiḥ) becomes steady—pratiṣṭhitā bhavati, that is the meaning.

2.shlok:
नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना।
न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम्।।२.६६।।
2.translit:
nāsti buddhiḥ ayuktasya na ca ayuktasya bhāvanā
na ca abhāvayataḥ śāntiḥ aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham
2.translate: There is no wisdom for the unsteady; nor is there meditation for the unsteady. And for one who does not meditate, there is no peace; and for the peaceless, how can there be happiness?
2.sridhara: The fitness of sense-restraint as a means for steadfast wisdom (sthita-prajñatā) is demonstrated by way of negation: “nāsti iti.” For one who is ayukta—whose senses are not subdued—there is no wisdom (buddhiḥ), meaning knowledge of the Self derived from the scriptures and the teachings of the ācārya. Such knowledge does not arise; so how can there be firm establishment or even any talk of it? Hence, it is said: nor is there meditation (bhāvanā) for the unsteady. For, through meditation alone does wisdom become firmly established in the Self. And that is absent in one who is ayukta. Nor is there peace (śāntiḥ)—that is, mental quietude in the Self—for one who does not meditate on the Self. And for the one without peace, how can there be happiness—meaning liberation-bliss (mokṣānandaḥ)?

2.shlok:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते।
तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि।।२.६७।।
2.translit:
indriyāṇām hi caratāṁ yan manaḥ anuvidhīyate
tat asya harati prajñām vāyuḥ nāvam iva ambhasi
2.translate: For, the mind which follows in the wake of the wandering senses—that (sense) carries away his wisdom, just as the wind carries off a boat on the waters.
2.sridhara: The reason for the statement "there is no wisdom for the unsteady" is given: “indriyāṇām iti.” Among the wandering senses, which are uncontrolled and freely moving among objects, whichever one sense the mind follows (anuvidhīyate), being overpowered, it goes along with that sense. That one sense itself carries off the wisdom of the person (asya manaḥ prajñām harati) by distracting it towards objects. Then what to say of the effect when many senses act together—it will definitely carry away wisdom. Just as the wind throws about a boat on the ocean when the helmsman is inattentive, so too.

2.shlok:
तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता।।२.६८।।
2.translit:
tasmāt yasya mahā-bāho nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ
indriyāṇi indriya-arthebhyaḥ tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā
2.translate: Therefore, O mighty-armed, he whose senses are fully restrained from the sense-objects—his wisdom is steady.
2.sridhara: The earlier statement that sense-control is the means and mark of sthita-prajñatā is here summarized: “tasmāt iti.” “His wisdom is steady”—that is the meaning (pratiṣṭhitā bhavati ity arthaḥ). In concluding the characterization of the sign, it is to be understood that “his wisdom is established.” The address “O mighty-armed” indicates that, just as you (Arjuna) are capable of conquering enemies in battle, so too you are capable of restraining the senses.

2.shlok:
या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी।
यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः।।२.६९।।
2.translit:
yā niśā sarva-bhūtānāṁ tasyāṁ jāgarti saṁyamī
yasyāṁ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyataḥ muneḥ
2.translate: That which is night for all beings, in that the self-restrained one is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.
2.sridhara:
One may object: “No such person is seen in the world—one who, like a sleeper, is entirely without activity of perception and so on, due to total control of the senses. Hence, such a description is implausible.” To remove this doubt, it is said: “yā niśā iti.” That which is night (niśā) to all beings (sarva-bhūtānām)—meaning the state of absorption in the Self, which is night to those whose intellects are covered by the darkness of self-ignorance—in that the self-restrained one (saṁyamī), whose senses are subdued, is awake (jāgarti), awakened.

But that in which beings, prompted by identification with objects (viṣaya-buddhyā), are awake—engaged in sense-activities—that is night (niśā) to the sage who sees (paśyataḥ muneḥ), meaning that for him, no perceptual activity exists in that domain. The sense is this: just as owls and other nocturnal creatures, though blind by day, see at night, so too the knower of Brahman, even with open eyes, sees only Brahman—not sense-objects. Therefore, this description is not implausible.

2.shlok:
आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं
समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्।
तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे
स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी।।२.७०।।
2.translit:
āpūryamāṇam acala-pratiṣṭham
samudram āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat
tadvat kāmāḥ yam praviśanti sarve
sa śāntim āpnoti na kāma-kāmī
2.translate: As waters enter the ocean, ever full and unmoved in its place, so all desires enter into him; he attains peace, not the one who desires desires.
2.sridhara: One may wonder: “If he has no vision of the sense-objects, how then does he experience them?” In response, it is said: “āpūryamāṇam iti.” Just as the ocean, though filled by many rivers (nānā-nadībhiḥ), remains unmoved in its bounds (acala-pratiṣṭham), and waters enter it again and again—so too, into the sage, whose inner gaze is not shaken by enjoyments (antardṛṣṭiṁ bhogaiḥ avikriyamāṇam eva), all desires, in the form of sense-objects, enter due to prārabdha-karma (karma already begun). He (saḥ) alone attains peace (śāntiṁ, liberation or kaivalya), not the one who is desirous of pleasures (kāma-kāmī, one who constantly longs for enjoyments).

2.shlok:
विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः।
निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शांतिमधिगच्छति।।२.७१।।
2.translit:
vihāya kāmān yaḥ sarvān pumān carati niḥspṛhaḥ
nirmamaḥ nirahaṅkāraḥ sa śāntim adhigacchati
2.translate: That man attains peace who, having abandoned all desires, moves about without longing, without possessiveness, and without egoism.
2.sridhara: Since this is so, therefore it is said: “vihāya iti.” The person who, having given up (vihāya) the desires already obtained, becomes indifferent to them, and who is without longing (niḥspṛhaḥ) for those yet to be obtained—because he is free from egoism (nirahaṅkāraḥ), and therefore free from possessiveness (nirmamaḥ) regarding the means to enjoy them—he, being one whose vision is turned within, moves about (carati) under the influence of prārabdha karma (karma already begun), enjoying experiences or going wherever it may be. Such a one attains peace (śāntim āpnoti).

2.shlok:
एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति।
स्थित्वाऽस्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति।।२.७२।।
2.translit:
eṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha na enām prāpya vimuhyati
sthitvā asyām anta-kāle api brahma-nirvāṇam ṛcchati
2.translate: This is the Brahmic state, O Pārtha. Attaining this, one is not deluded. Established in it even at the time of death, one attains liberation in Brahman.
2.sridhara: Praising the knowledge-based discipline (jñāna-niṣṭhā) already explained, the verse concludes: “eṣā iti.” This is the brāhmī sthitiḥ—the state of being firmly established in the knowledge of Brahman, such as described above. A person who has purified his inner being (śuddhāntaḥkaraṇaḥ) through the worship of the Supreme Lord attains this state, and does not become deluded (na vimuhyati)—he does not again fall into the delusion of worldly existence (saṁsāra-mohaḥ). Why? Because even at the time of death (anta-kāle), remaining for even a single moment in this state (asyām kṣaṇa-mātram api sthitvā), he attains dissolution (nirvāṇam) in Brahman. What then to speak of one who remains established in it from childhood—he certainly attains it.

3.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन।
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव।।३.१।।
3.translit:
arjuna uvāca
jyāyasī cet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana
tat kiṁ karmaṇi ghore māṁ niyojayasi keśava
3.translate: Arjuna said: O Janārdana, if You consider knowledge to be superior to action, then why do You engage me in this dreadful action, O Keśava?
3.sridhara: In this way, beginning with “You grieve for those who should not be grieved for” (२.११), the intellect that discerns between the self and the body was first spoken of as a means to liberation. Thereafter, beginning with “This has been declared to you from the standpoint of Sāṅkhya; now hear it from the standpoint of Yoga” (२.३९), action was also taught. But the superiority of either was not clearly explained. Because of the mention of qualities such as desirelessness, control over the senses, and absence of ego in one endowed with knowledge, and the concluding statement “This is the state of Brahman, O Pārtha,” accompanied by praise, Arjuna thought that the Lord favored knowledge over action. Therefore, he said, “If, according to You, knowledge is superior to action, then why do You repeatedly instruct me to rise and fight, and engage me in this dreadful, violent action?”

3.shlok:
व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे।
तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम्।।३.२।।
3.translit:
vyāmiśreṇeva vākyena buddhiṁ mohayasīva me
tad ekaṁ vada niścitya yena śreyo ’ham āpnuyām
3.translate: With this seemingly perplexing speech, You are, as it were, confusing my understanding; therefore, tell me one definite path by which I may attain the highest good.
3.sridhara: One may object: “Was not the superiority of action already stated through verses such as ‘For a kṣatriya, there is no greater good than a righteous war’ (२.३१)?” Arjuna, suspecting this, says, “With speech that appears mixed”—because sometimes You praise action, and at other times knowledge—“You seem to confuse my intellect, causing it to waver between the two paths.” Though You are supremely compassionate and do not truly cause delusion, still, due to my own confusion, it appears to me as if You are deluding me—hence the word iva (“as if”). Therefore, among the two, whichever is truly beneficial, that one definite path declare to me. Or, the meaning may be: having determined this alone to be the means to the highest good, declare to me that one by which I may attain liberation.

3.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ।
ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम्।।३.३।।
3.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
loke ’smin dvividhā niṣṭhā purā proktā mayānagha
jñāna-yogena sāṅkhyānāṁ karma-yogena yoginām
3.translate: The Blessed Lord said: In this world, O sinless one, a twofold path was formerly declared by Me—the path of knowledge for the Sāṅkhyas, and the path of action for the Yogins.
3.sridhara: Here is the Lord’s reply: “In this world,” i.e., in the realm of eligibility divided into pure and impure minds, “a twofold pursuit was declared by Me long ago”—that is, earlier in the second chapter. If I had taught knowledge and action as completely independent means to liberation, then your question “Tell me one thing that is the best among the two” would be valid. But I did not teach so. Rather, through both paths, the same dedication to Brahman was taught. Since the two—knowledge and action—are governed respectively by sattva and rajas, their mutual independence is not possible. Rather, only a difference in approach based on the fitness of the aspirant was taught. Therefore, I, the omniscient one, have already clearly declared in the earlier chapter this twofold pursuit aimed at liberation. I refer only to this difference in approach: for those with pure minds who have ascended to the platform of knowledge, steadfastness in Brahman was prescribed through the yoga of knowledge, such as in the verse “Restraining all the senses, one should remain absorbed in Me,” etc. For those who aspire to climb that platform by purifying their minds, the yoga of action was prescribed—such as “For a kṣatriya, there is no greater good than a righteous war.” Thus, these two are simply stages of inner purification and not ultimately distinct.

3.shlok:
न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते।
न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति।।३.४।।
3.translit:
na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣkarmyaṁ puruṣo ’śnute
na ca saṁnyasanād eva siddhiṁ samadhigacchati
3.translate: Not by refraining from action does a man attain actionlessness, nor does he reach perfection by mere renunciation.
3.sridhara: Therefore, until the rise of knowledge, actions appropriate to one’s caste and stage of life must be performed for the sake of proper purification of the mind. Otherwise, due to the absence of mental purity, knowledge will not arise. Thus it is said: “Not by non-performance of actions does one attain naiṣkarmya,” i.e., knowledge. One might object: “But the Vedic text ‘Those desiring the other world take to renunciation’ declares renunciation as a means to liberation—so why not attain liberation through renunciation alone, without performing action?” To dispel this doubt, it is said: “Nor does one attain perfection merely by renunciation.” Without the purity of mind, and being devoid of knowledge, one cannot attain liberation simply by taking up renunciation.

3.shlok:
न हि कश्िचत्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्।
कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः।।३.५।।
3.translit:
na hi kaścit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhaty akarma-kṛt
kāryate hy avaśaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ
3.translate: For no one ever remains, even for a moment, without performing action; for everyone is helplessly made to act by the guṇas born of nature.
3.sridhara: And because renunciation of actions is only non-attachment to them, not renunciation in their very nature—since actual renunciation is not possible—it is said: “Indeed, no one, even for a moment, remains without performing action.” That is, at any time or in any condition, no one—whether a knower or an ignorant person—can remain as one who does not perform action. The reason for this is given: by the guṇas born of nature—by innate tendencies such as attachment and aversion—all beings are impelled to act, being helpless and not independent.

3.shlok:
कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्।
इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते।।३.६।।
3.translit:
karmendriyāṇi saṁyamya ya āste manasā smaran
indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā mithyācāraḥ sa ucyate
3.translate: He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of sense-objects in the mind—he of deluded understanding is called a hypocrite.
3.sridhara: Therefore, the ignorant renouncer of action is censured: “karmendriyāṇi saṁyamya.” Even though one restrains the organs of action—speech, hands, etc.—if he sits, under the pretense of meditation on the Lord, mentally remembering sense-objects due to the impurity of the mind and lack of stability in the self, then he is called a mithyācāraḥ—a hypocrite, a deceitful person, a pretender.

3.shlok:
यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन।
कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते।।३.७।।
3.translit:
yas tv indriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate ’rjuna
karmendriyaiḥ karma-yogam asaktaḥ sa viśiṣyate
3.translate: But he who, controlling the senses with the mind, O Arjuna, engages in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment—he excels.
3.sridhara: In contrast, one who performs karma is superior. Thus it is said: “yas tu.” That person who, having controlled the senses of knowledge with the mind—making them inclined toward God—engages with the organs of action in the discipline of action (karma yoga), being unattached and free from desire for results, sa viśiṣyate—he excels. That is to say, he becomes possessed of knowledge through purification of the mind.

3.shlok:
नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः।
शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः।।३.८।।
3.translit:
niyataṁ kuru karma tvaṁ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ
śarīra-yātrāpi ca te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ
3.translate: Perform your prescribed duty, for action is superior to inaction; and even the maintenance of your body would not be possible through inaction.
3.sridhara: Since this is so, therefore it is said: “niyatam.” Perform the prescribed daily duties such as sandhyopāsanā (meditation during twilight, etc.). Indeed, action is superior to inaction—“karma jyāyaḥ akarmaṇaḥ.” Otherwise, even the basic maintenance of your body would not be possible.

3.shlok:
यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः।
तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसंगः समाचर।।३.९।।
3.translit:
yajñārthāt karmaṇo ’nyatra loko ’yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ
tad-arthaṁ karma kaunteya mukta-saṅgaḥ samācara
3.translate: This world is bound by action, except when performed for the sake of sacrifice. Therefore, O Kaunteya, perform action for that purpose—free from attachment.
3.sridhara: Some Sāṅkhyas say, “No action whatsoever should be done, for all action causes bondage.” Refuting that, it is said: “yajñārthāt.” Here, yajña means Viṣṇu, as the Śruti declares, “Yajña indeed is Viṣṇu.” Except action performed for the sake of worshiping Him, all other action binds this world in karma. But action done for the sake of propitiating Viṣṇu does not bind. Therefore, for that purpose—tad-artham, i.e., for pleasing Viṣṇu—perform action properly, O Kaunteya, being mukta-saṅgaḥ, i.e., free from desire.

3.shlok:
सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः।
अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक्।।३.१०।।
3.translit:
saha-yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣṭvā purovāca prajāpatiḥ
anena prasaviṣyadhvam eṣa vo ’stv iṣṭa-kāma-dhuk
3.translate: Having created beings together with sacrifice in the beginning, the Creator said: “By this shall you prosper. Let this be the wish-fulfilling cow for your desires.”
3.sridhara: That even by the word of Prajāpati, the performer of action is superior is now stated in four verses beginning with “saha-yajñāḥ.” Saha-yajñāḥ means: those created along with sacrifice. The beings—especially brāhmaṇas and others entitled to sacrifice—were created in the beginning of creation by Brahmā, who then said: “By this yajña (sacrifice), you shall prosper—i.e., you shall multiply and grow.” Prasava means growth. The implication is that you shall attain ever-increasing prosperity. The reason is: “This yajña shall be your iṣṭa-kāma-dhuk”—the cow that yields all desired objects. The use of the word yajña here is meant to include obligatory actions. Though the praise of desire-motivated ritual may seem out of place in this context, it is generally acceptable here to illustrate that action is superior to inaction.

3.shlok:
देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः।
परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ।।३.११।।
3.translit:
devān bhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ
parasparaṁ bhāvayantaḥ śreyaḥ param avāpsyatha
3.translate: With this, nourish the gods, and may those gods nourish you; thus mutually nourishing one another, you shall attain the highest good.
3.sridhara: How can yajña be the milch cow of desired ends? To answer this, it is said: “devān bhāvayata.” With this yajña, nourish the gods—i.e., support them with shares of oblations. And those gods in turn nourish you, by means such as rainfall, which produces food. Thus, mutually supporting each other—the gods and you—you shall attain the supreme good.

3.shlok:
इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः।
तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः।।३.१२।।
3.translit:
iṣṭān bhogān hi vo devā dāsyante yajña-bhāvitāḥ
tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ
3.translate: The gods, nourished by sacrifice, will give you the desired enjoyments. He who enjoys what they give without offering to them, is verily a thief.
3.sridhara: Elaborating this further and indicating the fault of not performing action, it is said: “iṣṭān bhogān.” The gods, having been propitiated by yajñas, will indeed give enjoyments to you, such as food, through the medium of rain. Therefore, one who consumes food, etc., given by the gods, without first offering to them through the five daily yajñas and so on, is to be known as a thief.

3.shlok:
यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः।
भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात्।।३.१३।।
3.translit:
yajña-śiṣṭāśinaḥ santo mucyante sarva-kilbiṣaiḥ
bhuñjate te tv aghaṁ pāpā ye pacanty ātma-kāraṇāt
3.translate: The righteous who eat the remnants of sacrifice are freed from all sins. But those sinful ones who cook food for their own sake eat only sin.
3.sridhara: Therefore, only those who worship are superior, not others. Thus it is said: “yajña-śiṣṭāśinaḥ.” Those who partake of the remnants of sacrifice, such as from the Vaiśvadeva yajña, are freed from all sins associated with the five household slaughters (pañca-sūnās). These are described in the smṛti as: the mortar, the grinder, the hearth, the water pot, and the broom. “For the householder, the five slaughters are present. One who neglects them does not attain heaven.” But those who cook food solely for the sake of feeding themselves, and not for offerings like Vaiśvadeva, they are sinful and eat only sin.

3.shlok:
अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः।
यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः।।३.१४।।
3.translit:
annād bhavanti bhūtāni parjanyād anna-sambhavaḥ
yajñād bhavati parjanyo yajñaḥ karma-samudbhavaḥ
3.translate: From food beings are born; from rain food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain, and sacrifice is born of action.
3.sridhara: Also, since action is the cause of the functioning of the world-cycle, action must be performed. Thus it is said in three verses beginning here: “annāt.” From food—transformed into semen—beings are born. And food arises from rain. That rain is produced from yajña. And yajña arises from action—i.e., it is properly accomplished through the acts of the sacrificer and others. As the smṛti says: “The oblation offered into the fire reaches the sun. From the sun comes rain. From rain, food. And from food, creatures are born.”

3.shlok:
कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्।
तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम्।।३.१५।।
3.translit:
karma brahmodbhavaṁ viddhi brahmākṣara-samudbhavam
tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣṭhitam
3.translate: Know that action arises from the Veda (Brahma), and the Veda arises from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervading Brahma is always established in sacrifice.
3.sridhara: Similarly, “karma brahma-udbhavam”—know that action, in the form of activities of the sacrificer and others, arises from brahma, i.e., the Veda. And that brahma (the Veda) arises from the akṣara (Imperishable Supreme). As the Śruti declares: “From this great being's breath emerged the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, and Sāmaveda.” Since the entire sacrificial process originates from the Imperishable, yajña is certainly well-intended by Him. Therefore, the all-pervading Imperishable Brahman is eternally established in yajña—because the Supreme is attainable through yajña, it is said to be “established” in it. Just like saying: “Wealth always resides where there is enterprise.” Or else, since karma is the root of the world-cycle, therefore brahma—the Veda, which pervades all through mantras, explanatory statements, and historical examples—though all-pervading, is always established in yajña in the sense of having its purport centered in yajña. Therefore, acts such as yajña must indeed be performed.

3.shlok:
एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः।
अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति।।३.१६।।
3.translit:
evaṁ pravartitaṁ cakraṁ nānuvartayatiha yaḥ
aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṁ pārtha sa jīvati
3.translate: He who does not follow here the cycle thus set in motion, who is of sinful life and delights in the senses, O Pārtha, he lives in vain.
3.sridhara: Since this cycle of karma and yajña has been set in motion by the Supreme Lord Himself for the attainment of human ends, therefore, if one does not act accordingly, life is lived in vain. Hence it is said: “evaṁ.” From brahma, i.e., the Veda—which is the word of the Supreme Lord—there arises human inclination toward action. From that action comes performance of karma, from that rain, from that food, from that living beings, and from those beings again the same cycle of action—this is the revolving wheel. He who does not conform to this cycle—who does not follow it—is aghāyuḥ, one whose life is sinful. Because he delights only in the sense-objects with his senses, and not in action for the worship of the Lord. Therefore, such a one lives in vain.

3.shlok:
यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः।
आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते।।३.१७।।
3.translit:
yas tv ātma-ratir eva syād ātma-tṛptaś ca mānavaḥ
ātmany eva ca santuṣṭas tasya kāryaṁ na vidyate
3.translate: But the man who delights only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and content in the Self alone—for him, there is nothing that needs to be done.
3.sridhara: Thus, having taught karma-yoga as a means to inner purification for the ignorant, it is now stated that action is of no use for the knower. The verse begins: “yas tu.” One whose delight is in the Self alone, and who, being fulfilled through the experience of self-bliss, is satisfied in the Self alone—he, being free of desire for sense enjoyments, has no obligatory duty.

3.shlok:
नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन।
न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्िचदर्थव्यपाश्रयः।।३.१८।।
3.translit:
naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nākṛtenaiha kaścana
na cāsya sarva-bhūteṣu kaścid artha-vyapāśrayaḥ
3.translate: For him there is no concern at all with what is done or not done; nor does he depend on any being for any purpose.
3.sridhara: The reason for the previous verse is stated: “naiva tasya.” For such a person, there is no gain (artha)—such as merit—from action. Nor is there any loss (pratyavāya) from non-performance. Being devoid of egoism, and transcending injunction and prohibition, still—“that which the people know as this”—being liberation, “is not dear to the gods,” says the Śruti. To avoid obstacles caused by gods, one might think they should still be worshipped. To negate this, it is said: “na cāsya.” For him, there is no reliance upon any being, from Brahmā down to immobile creatures, for any purpose such as mokṣa. Since the absence of obstacles is declared by the Śruti itself—“The gods do not rule over him…”—therefore even the gods cannot hinder the one who knows the Self. The gods, indeed, are incapable of obstructing him whose knowledge of Brahman is complete. As the Śruti says, “That which the gods do not favor—the knowledge of Brahman attained by men—by this alone is their authority threatened.” Thus, obstacles exist only prior to knowledge, not afterward.

3.shlok:
तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर।
असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः।।३.१९।।
3.translit:
tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samācara
asakto hy ācaran karma param āpnoti pūruṣaḥ
3.translate: Therefore, without attachment, always perform the action that ought to be done. For, performing action without attachment, a person attains the Supreme.
3.sridhara: Since only for the knower is action unnecessary, and not for others, therefore you should perform action. Hence it is said: “tasmāt.” Being without attachment—i.e., free from clinging to the results—perform well the obligatory and occasional duties, considering them as necessary. For, performing action without attachment, a person attains the Supreme—i.e., purity of mind, which leads to liberation through knowledge.

3.shlok:
कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः।
लोकसंग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि।।३.२०।।
3.translit:
karmaṇaiva hi saṁsiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ
loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśyan kartum arhasi
3.translate: Indeed, it is through action alone that Janaka and others attained perfection. Even with a view to the welfare of the world, you should perform action.
3.sridhara: Here, the precedent of righteous conduct is cited: “karmaṇaiva.” It is also stated: “loka-saṅgraham iti”—the protection or guidance of the world. The meaning is: If I, performing action, influence the people, then all will follow; otherwise, an ignorant person might renounce action on seeing the example of a jñānī. Therefore, even the preservation of the world is a purpose to be seen, and for that reason, you ought to act, not renounce.

3.shlok:
यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः।
स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते।।३.२१।।
3.translit:
yad yad ācarati śreṣṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ
sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate
3.translate: Whatever a great person does, that very thing other people do; whatever standard he sets, the world follows that.
3.sridhara: How performing karma brings about the welfare of the world is shown here: “yad iti.” The common man imitates exactly whatever the great person does. That superior person—whatever he regards as authority, whether it be a code of action or renunciation—that the world also follows.

3.shlok:
न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन।
नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि।।३.२२।।
3.translit:
na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣu lokeṣu kiñcana
nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva ca karmaṇi
3.translate: O Pārtha, there is nothing at all that ought to be done by Me in the three worlds; nor is there anything unattained that ought to be attained—yet I continue in action.
3.sridhara: Here, the example is Myself, says the Lord, in three lines: “na me pārtha iti.” O Pārtha, there is nothing that needs to be done by Me. Because in all three worlds there is nothing unattained by Me that should yet be attained. Even so, I engage in karma. The meaning is: I do act.

3.shlok:
यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः।।३.२३।।
3.translit:
yadi hy ahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ
mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
3.translate: For if I were ever not to engage diligently in action, O Pārtha, people would entirely follow My path.
3.sridhara: Now the destruction of the people due to inaction is shown: “yadi iti.” If ever I, being not indolent but alert, did not act—i.e., did not engage in action—then people would follow exactly My path. The meaning is: they would imitate Me.

3.shlok:
उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्।
सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः।।३.२४।।
3.translit:
utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ced aham
saṅkarasya ca kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ
3.translate: These worlds would perish if I did not perform action; I would be the cause of confusion of castes, and I would destroy these beings.
3.sridhara: What would happen then? That is stated: “utsīdeyuḥ.” These worlds would perish—i.e., would be ruined—through the abandonment of karma. Then, there would be varṇa-saṅkara (confusion of castes), and I would be its cause. In that way, I Myself would destroy these beings—I would corrupt them.

3.shlok:
सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत।
कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश् चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम्।।३.२५।।
3.translit:
saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvāṁso yathā kurvanti bhārata
kuryād vidvāṁs tathāsaktaś cikīrṣur loka-saṅgraham
3.translate: As the ignorant act with attachment to action, O Bhārata, so too should the wise act—without attachment—wishing to guide the world.
3.sridhara: Therefore, even the knower must perform action out of compassion for the guidance of the world—thus the verse concludes: “saktāḥ iti.” Just as the ignorant, being attached to karma, act—so too, the wise person, remaining unattached, should act, desiring the welfare of the world.

3.shlok:
न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्।
जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तः समाचरन्।।३.२६।।
3.translit:
na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām
joṣayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācaran
3.translate: Let not the wise disturb the understanding of the ignorant who are attached to action; rather, acting with discipline, he should engage them in all actions.
3.sridhara: One might think it is appropriate to instruct the ignorant in the knowledge of the Self out of compassion. To reject that idea, it is said: “na iti.” One should not generate division in understanding—that is, misapprehension—among the ignorant who are attached to action by imparting to them the teaching that the Self is non-agent. That is, one should not cause their intellect to deviate from karma. Rather, he should make them remain engaged—“joṣayet”—in their own actions. Joṣayet means “he should make them devoted through favor or service.” How? Being integrated (yuktaḥ), himself performing those actions, he should inspire the ignorant to act. For if he were to disturb their understanding, their faith in karma would decline, and knowledge would not arise either—thus they would be lost on both sides.

3.shlok:
प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः।
अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताऽहमिति मन्यते।।३.२७।।
3.translit:
prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśaḥ
ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate
3.translate: All actions are performed entirely by the guṇas of prakṛti. One whose self is deluded by ego thinks, “I am the doer.”
3.sridhara: If even the wise must perform karma, then what is the distinction between the wise and the ignorant? Anticipating this question, the distinction between the two is stated in two verses: “prakṛteḥ” etc. All actions are performed entirely by the guṇas (qualities) of prakṛti—namely, by the senses, which are products of prakṛti. Yet, the person thinks, “I alone am the doer.” The reason for that is: his self (ātmā) is deluded by egoism—that is, due to superimposing the Self onto the senses and so on, through ego, such a person becomes bewildered.

3.shlok:
तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः।
गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते।।३.२८।।
3.translit:
tattvavit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ
guṇā guṇeṣu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate
3.translate: But he who knows the truth, O mighty-armed, concerning the distinction between guṇas and actions, knowing that the guṇas act upon the guṇas, is not attached.
3.sridhara: The knower, however, does not think in that way—this is said: “tattvavit iti.” “I am not made of guṇas”—thus he knows the distinction between the guṇas and the Self. “My Self is not the agent of actions”—thus he knows the distinction between karma and the Self. The one who knows the truth (tattvavit) of the distinction between guṇas and karma does not become attached—he does not hold onto doership. Why? Because he thinks: “The guṇas—the senses—are operating in relation to the guṇas—the objects.” Not “I.”

3.shlok:
प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु।
तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत्।।३.२९।।
3.translit:
prakṛter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu
tān akṛtsna-vido mandān kṛtsnavin na vicālayet
3.translate: Those deluded by the guṇas of prakṛti are attached to guṇa-related actions. The knower of the whole should not unsettle the dull, who do not know fully.
3.sridhara: The previously given instruction “na buddhi-bhedam janayet” (३.२६) is now concluded here: “prakṛteḥ iti.” Those who are deluded by the guṇas—sattva, rajas, and tamas—of prakṛti become attached to the guṇas (senses) and their actions, thinking “We act.” The knower of the whole (kṛtsnavit), who knows all, should not cause these dull-minded ones—who do not know completely (akṛtsnavidaḥ)—to deviate.

3.shlok:
मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा।
निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः।।३.३०।।
3.translit:
mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi saṁnyasyādhyātma-cetasā
nirāśīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ
3.translate: Renounce all actions in Me, with a mind absorbed in the Self, free from hope and possessiveness, and fight, being free from mental fever.
3.sridhara: Thus, even for a knower of truth, karma is to be performed. But you are not yet a knower of truth; therefore, you must certainly act—this is stated: “mayi iti.” Renouncing all actions in Me, i.e., offering them to Me, with a mind absorbed in the Self—thinking “I act under the supervision of the indwelling Lord.” Being free of desire (niḥkāma), and thus without possessiveness, thinking “This act is for the sake of attaining Me, and I am not the enjoyer of its fruit.” Being devoid of such attachment, and giving up sorrow—free from fever—fight.

3.shlok:
ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः।
श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः।।३.३१।।
3.translit:
ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣṭhanti mānavāḥ
śraddhāvanto’nasūyanto mucyante te’pi karmabhiḥ
3.translate: Those humans who constantly follow this teaching of Mine, with faith and without envy—they too are liberated from actions.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now the virtue in the performance of action is stated: “ye me matam iti.” Those who are full of faith in My words and free from fault-finding—i.e., who do not find fault by thinking “action is full of suffering”—those who constantly follow this doctrine of Mine, they too, by gradually performing action, are freed from actions, just like those endowed with right knowledge.

3.shlok:
ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्।
सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः।।३.३२।।
3.translit:
ye tv etad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣṭhanti me matam
sarvajñāna-vimūḍhāṁs tān viddhi naṣṭān acetasaḥ
3.translate: But those who, finding fault with this teaching of Mine, do not follow it—know them to be deluded of all knowledge, ruined, and devoid of understanding.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now the fault on the opposite side is stated: “ye tu iti.” Those who, being envious, do not follow My instruction—namely, “action must be done for the sake of the Lord”—know them to be devoid of understanding (acetasaḥ), and therefore deluded in all knowledge, both regarding action and regarding Brahman. Know them to be ruined.

3.shlok:
सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि।
प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति।।३.३३।।
3.translit:
sadṛśaṁ ceṣṭate svasyāḥ prakṛter jñānavān api
prakṛtiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣyati
3.translate: Even a person of knowledge acts according to their own nature; all beings follow their nature—what can restraint accomplish?
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
One may object: “If the results are so great, why do not all people restrain their senses and perform their own duties without desire?” In response, this is said: “sadṛśam iti.” Prakṛti is the inborn nature dependent on impressions (saṁskāras) from past actions. According to one’s own prakṛti, even a person endowed with knowledge acts—what then to say of the ignorant, who certainly act so? Thus, all beings follow their nature. In that case, what can restraint accomplish, since nature is stronger—that is the meaning.

3.shlok:
इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ।
तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ।।३.३४।।
3.translit:
indriyasyaindriasyārthe rāga-dveṣau vyavasthitau
tayor na vaśam āgacchet tau hy asya paripanthinau
3.translate: Attachment and aversion toward the objects of each sense are fixed; one should not come under their control—for they are one’s enemies.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now, one might ask: If people act entirely under the influence of nature, then what is the purpose of scriptural injunction and prohibition? To resolve this doubt, it is said: “indriyasya indriyasya iti.” By repetition, it is implied: “of each and every sense.” In its own object—i.e., what is agreeable—attachment arises, and in what is disagreeable, aversion arises. Thus, attachment and aversion are fixed for each sense. Hence, action corresponding to them is the nature (prakṛti) of beings. Still, one should not come under their control—this is enjoined by scripture. Why? Because they (attachment and aversion) are the enemies of this person seeking liberation. The idea is this: due to the arising of attachment and aversion from recollection of sense-objects, an inattentive person is forcefully driven into error by nature, like being swept into a deep current. But scripture instructs even before this to act in devotion to the Supreme Lord, which serves to block attachment and aversion toward the objects. Like one boarding a boat before being caught in a deep current, such a person does not come to harm.

3.shlok:
श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्।
स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः।।३.३५।।
3.translit:
śreyān svadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmāt svanuṣṭhitāt
svadharme nidhanaṁ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ
3.translate: Better is one’s own duty, though deficient in merit, than the well-performed duty of another. Better is death in one’s own duty; the duty of another brings fear.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now, someone might say: “If one’s nature is like that of an animal, still, one ought to give it up and engage in one’s own duty.” But then, since one’s own duty (svadharma), like the duty of a warrior involving battle, may be painful and difficult to perform properly—and because another’s duty, such as non-violence, may be easier, and since both are dharma—why not pursue the other? In response, this is said: “śreyān iti.” One’s own duty, though lacking some qualities (i.e., defective), is better—more praiseworthy—than the well-performed duty of another. Why? Because for one performing their own duty, such as fighting in war, even death is better, being a cause of attainment of heaven. But another’s duty is fearful for oneself, being forbidden and a cause of going to hell.

3.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः।
अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः।।३.३६।।
3.translit:
arjuna uvāca
atha kena prayukto’yaṁ pāpaṁ carati pūruṣaḥ
anicchann api vārṣṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ
3.translate: Arjuna said: Then, by what is a man impelled to commit sin, O Vārṣṇeya, even unwillingly, as though forced by some power?
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
When it was said “Let him not come under their control” (३.३४), thinking that this is impossible, Arjuna said: “atha kena iti.” O Vārṣṇeya (descendant of the Vṛṣṇi lineage), though unwilling to do evil, by what is this man impelled to commit sin? Although desire and anger are restrained by the power of discernment, yet since people are seen to engage again in sinful actions, Arjuna suspects that there may be some other instigator, more fundamental than these two, and he asks this question with that possibility in mind.

3.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः।
महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम्।।३.३७।।
3.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ
mahāśano mahā-pāpmā viddhy enam iha vairiṇam
3.translate: The Blessed Lord said: It is desire—it is anger—born of the guṇa of rajas; know this as the great devourer, the great sinner—this is the enemy here.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
The Lord replies: “kāma eṣa iti.” The cause you asked about is this very desire. You may object: But didn’t You also speak of anger earlier in “towards each sense-object, attachment and aversion are fixed” (३.३४)? That is true. But that anger is not separate from this. In fact, anger is merely this same desire transformed into the form of anger when it is obstructed. Thus, although anger was previously mentioned as distinct, here it is unified with desire itself—because it is born of the guṇa of rajas. This also implies that if sattva increases and rajas is diminished, then desire also is diminished. Know this desire, in the path of liberation, to be the enemy. And this enemy is to be slain in the manner described later, because it cannot be pacified by generosity, as is said: it is mahāśana—one whose appetite is great, meaning insatiable; hence, mahāpāpmā—extremely sinful. It cannot be appeased through gentleness.

3.shlok:
धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथाऽऽदर्शो मलेन च।
यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम्।।३.३८।।
3.translit:
dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathā’darśo malenaca
yatholbenaāvṛto garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛtam
3.translate: As fire is covered by smoke, as a mirror by dust, and as an embryo by the amnion, so is this (wisdom) enveloped by that (desire).
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
The enmity of desire is shown here: “dhūmena iti.” Just as fire is covered by its natural accompaniment, smoke; just as a mirror is covered by incidental dust; and just as the embryo is fully covered on all sides by the caul (the fetal membrane)—in the same way, in these three modes, this (knowledge) is enveloped by that (desire).

3.shlok:
आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा।
कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च।।३.३९।।
3.translit:
āvṛtaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā
kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣpūreṇānalena ca
3.translate: This knowledge is covered by that constant enemy of the wise, O Kaunteya, in the form of desire—insatiable and like fire.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now, showing the “this” indicated earlier, the Lord makes the enmity explicit: “āvṛtam iti.” This discriminative knowledge is covered by that (desire). For the ignorant, desire at the time of enjoyment seems to be the very cause of pleasure, but later, it assumes the nature of an enemy. For the wise, even at the moment of its arising, due to awareness of the harm that will follow, it is understood as a cause of pain—hence it is called an eternal enemy. Moreover, though filled with objects of enjoyment, it is never satisfied; it is insatiable and causes grief and affliction—therefore it is like fire. With this, its eternal enmity toward all beings is declared.

3.shlok:
इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते।
एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम्।।३.४०।।
3.translit:
indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣṭhānam ucyate
etair vimohayaty eṣa jñānam āvṛtya dehinam
3.translate: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these it deludes the embodied by veiling knowledge.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now, indicating its location, the Lord describes the means for its destruction: “indriyāṇīti” (in this verse and the next). Because desire arises through seeing, hearing, etc., of objects, through thought and decision, therefore the senses, the mind, and the intellect are called its seats. Through these—functioning in seeing, etc., and serving as its basis—desire arises, and having covered discriminative knowledge, it deludes the embodied being.

3.shlok:
तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ।
पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम्।।३.४१।।
3.translit:
tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣabha
pāpmānaṁ prajahi hy enaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśanam
3.translate: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, restraining the senses at the outset, slay this sinful one—destroyer of knowledge and realization.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Because it is so, therefore, “tasmāt tvam iti”—at the very beginning, before delusion arises, having restrained the senses, the mind, and the intellect, O scion of the Bharata lineage, destroy (prajahi) this sinful one, namely desire. Or alternatively, “prajahi” may be taken as “abandon.” Knowledge (jñāna) refers to knowledge related to the Self (ātma-viṣaya), and realization (vijñāna) refers to scriptural knowledge. Or else, jñāna is that which is received through scripture and the instruction of a teacher, while vijñāna is that which arises from deep meditation (nididhyāsana). The Br̥hadāraṇyaka Śruti (४.४.२१) says, “Having known that very Self, the wise one should cultivate discernment (prajnā).”

3.shlok:
इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः।
मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः।।३.४२।।
3.translit:
indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ
manasas tu parā buddhiḥ yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ
3.translate: They say the senses are superior to the body; superior to the senses is the mind; superior to the mind is the intellect; but one who is even beyond the intellect is He (the Self).
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
Now, since through serenity (prasannatā) and concentration of the mind (citta-praṇidhāna), the senses can be restrained, the Lord proceeds to show the nature of the Self, distinguished from the body and so on: “indriyāṇīti.” The senses are said to be superior (parāṇi) to the graspable elements such as the body (dehādayaḥ), due to their subtlety and illuminative power. Thus, by implication, they are distinct from them. Superior to the senses is the mind (manas), which is of the nature of thought (saṅkalpa), because it initiates their activity. Superior to the mind is the intellect (buddhiḥ), which is of the nature of determination, since it precedes and guides thought. That which is beyond the intellect—being established as the witness (sākṣitvena) and the inner controller of all—is the Self (ātman). It is that very Self, indicated by the word “dehin” (embodied), that deludes, and which is being referred to here as “He.”

3.shlok:
एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना।
जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम्।।३.४३।।
3.translit:
evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā saṁstabhyātmānam ātmanā
jahi śatruṁ mahābāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam
3.translate: Thus knowing Him who is beyond the intellect, and restraining the self by the Self, slay, O mighty-armed, the enemy in the form of desire—difficult to conquer.
3.sridhara:
(English translation)
He concludes the topic: “evaṁ iti.” The modifications such as desire, which are born from the senses, mind, and so on, arise only within the intellect (buddhi); but the Self (ātmā) is without modifications—it is their witness. Thus, knowing the Self to be beyond the intellect, by that very Self—being of the nature of decisive intellect (niścayātmikayā buddhyā)—stabilize (saṁstabhy) the mind (ātmānaṁ, here meaning manas), and slay (jahi) the enemy in the form of desire. It is durāsadam—difficult to approach or attain—meaning its movement or nature is difficult to discern.

4.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्।
विवस्वान् मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत्।।४.१।।
4.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
imaṁ vivasvate yogaṁ proktavān aham avyayam
vivasvān manave prāha manur ikṣvākave ’bravīt
4.translate: The Blessed Lord said: I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvān; Vivasvān told it to Manu, and Manu declared it to Ikṣvāku.
4.sridhara: To explain the manifestation and withdrawal of Himself, Lord Hari praises karma yoga for the sake of distinguishing between the meanings of “Thou” and “That.” In the two preceding chapters, karma yoga as a means and jñāna yoga as a means were spoken of as means to liberation. Wishing to now elaborate on that very yoga by showing its attributes such as “offering to Brahman” and the discernment of the meaning of “Thou,” He, first praising it as handed down through succession, says: “This imperishable yoga” (४.१), in three verses. Because it has an imperishable result, it is called avyaya (imperishable). I formerly taught this yoga to Vivasvān, the sun-god. He in turn told it to his son Manu, the progenitor of mankind. And Manu spoke it to his son Ikṣvāku.

4.shlok:
एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः।
स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप।।४.२।।
4.translit:
evaṁ paramparāprāptam imaṁ rājarṣayo viduḥ
sa kālena iha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa
4.translate: Thus, handed down in succession, the royal sages knew this yoga. But through the great passage of time, O Parantapa, this yoga has been lost here.
4.sridhara: Thus (evaṁ), the royal sages—those who were both kings and seers—such as Nimi and others, and others too, came to know this yoga, which was handed down by Ikṣvāku and others to their sons and descendants. Now, the cause for the ignorance of this yoga among people today is stated: O Parantapa (scorcher of enemies), that yoga has been lost here in this world due to the influence of time, having been interrupted.

4.shlok:
स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः।
भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम्।।४.३।।
4.translit:
sa evāyaṁ mayā te ’dya yogaḥ proktaḥ purātanaḥ
bhakto ’si me sakhā ceti rahasyaṁ hy etad uttamam
4.translate: That same ancient yoga has today been told to you by Me, because you are My devotee and friend. For this is the supreme secret.
4.sridhara: That very same yoga, though the succession has now been broken, has today been told again by Me to you. Why? Because you are My devotee and friend. It is not told by Me to another. For this is the supreme secret.

4.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः।
कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति।।४.४।।
4.translit:
arjuna uvāca
aparaṁ bhavato janma paraṁ janma vivasvataḥ
katham etad vijānīyāṁ tvam ādau proktavān iti
4.translate: Arjuna said: Later is Your birth, and earlier was the birth of Vivasvān; how am I to understand that You taught it to him in the beginning?
4.sridhara: Seeing the impossibility of the Blessed Lord having taught yoga to Vivasvān, Arjuna said: “Later is Your birth; earlier was the birth of Vivasvān. Therefore, because You are born after him, how am I to understand that You, who are younger, taught yoga in the beginning to Vivasvān, who is ancient? How can I know this?”

4.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन।
तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप।।४.५।।
4.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
bahūni me vyatītāni janmāni tava cārjuna
tāny ahaṁ veda sarvāṇi na tvaṁ vettha parantapa
4.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Many births of Mine have passed, and yours too, O Arjuna. I know them all, but you do not know them, O Parantapa.
4.sridhara: To Arjuna, who asked thus, He gave the reply, implying that He had taught it in a different form. The Blessed Lord said: “Many births of Mine have passed, and of yours too. I know all of them, because My knowledge and power are never lost. But you do not know them, because you are covered by ignorance.”

4.shlok:
अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्।
प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया।।४.६।।
4.translit:
ajo ’pi sann avyayātmā bhūtānām īśvaro ’pi san
prakṛtiṁ svām adhiṣṭhāya sambhavāmy ātma-māyayā
4.translate: Though I am unborn, of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing My own Nature, I am born by My own Māyā.
4.sridhara: Now, since it was said, “Many births of Mine have passed” (४.५), the question arises: How can You, who are beginningless and imperishable, be said to be born repeatedly? And how can You, the Lord, who are devoid of virtue and vice, be born like a jīva (individual self)? In reply to that, He says: “Though I am unborn,” etc. Indeed, it is true—though I am unborn, though I am imperishable in nature, though I am the Lord, free from dependence upon karma—still, I am born. I am truly born through My own Māyā—by My undiminished power of knowledge, strength, and valor. But then, one may object: How can You, who are devoid of a body formed of sixteen parts (the sixteen limbs of the subtle body), be born? To this, He replies: “Resorting to My own Nature”—taking hold of My own Nature, which consists of pure sattva; assuming a form composed of intense, purified sattva; I descend of My own will. That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत।
अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदाऽऽत्मानं सृजाम्यहम्।।४.७।।
4.translit:
yadā yadā hi dharmasya glānir bhavati bhārata
abhyutthānam adharmasya tadā ’tmānaṁ sṛjāmy aham
4.translate: Whenever there is decline of righteousness, O Bhārata, and rise of unrighteousness, then I manifest Myself.
4.sridhara: In anticipation of the question, “When do You take birth?”, He says: “Whenever there is decline of dharma.” Glāniḥ means decline of dharma. Abhyutthānam means the increase of adharma.

4.shlok:
परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्।
धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय संभवामि युगे युगे।।४.८।।
4.translit:
paritrāṇāya sādhūnāṁ vināśāya ca duṣkṛtām
dharma-saṁsthāpanārthāya sambhavāmi yuge yuge
4.translate: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.
4.sridhara:
In anticipation of the question, “For what purpose?”, He says: “For the protection of the good.” For the protection of the sādhus—those who follow their own dharma. For the destruction of the duṣkṛtas—those who perform wicked actions. Thus, for the establishment of dharma—to stabilize dharma by protecting the good and destroying the wicked—I am born in every age, meaning at every proper juncture. Nor should cruelty be suspected in My destroying the wicked. As it is said:
“Just as there is no lack of compassion in a mother who punishes her child with a slap, likewise, there is no cruelty in the Great Lord, the governor of merit and demerit.”

4.shlok:
जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः।
त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन।।४.९।।
4.translit:
janma karma ca me divyam evaṁ yo vetti tattvataḥ
tyaktvā dehaṁ punar janma naiti mām eti so ’rjuna
4.translate: He who thus knows, in truth, My divine birth and action—having abandoned the body—does not take birth again, O Arjuna; he comes to Me.
4.sridhara: Now, He states the result of the knowledge of such divine births and actions of the Lord: “My birth, which is by My own will, and My action, which consists in protecting dharma—these are divine, not worldly. He who knows them in reality, as being solely for the sake of the welfare of others—he, having abandoned identification with the body, does not take birth again, but attains Me alone.”

4.shlok:
वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः।
बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः।।४.१०।।
4.translit:
vīta-rāga-bhaya-krodhā man-mayā mām upāśritāḥ
bahavo jñāna-tapasā pūtā mad-bhāvam āgatāḥ
4.translate: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger; absorbed in Me; taking refuge in Me—many, purified by the austerity of knowledge, have attained My state.
4.sridhara:
Now, in response to the question, “How can the knowledge of Your birth and action lead to Your attainment?”, He says: “Freed from attachment, fear, and anger”—from which distractions arise. Having known that I perform the protection of dharma through My descent in forms composed of pure sattva, and that I am of supreme compassion—they became free from attachment, fear, and anger. Having become absorbed in Me, with mind fixed solely on Me, having taken exclusive refuge in Me—those persons attained the knowledge of the Self, which is attainable only through My grace, and the austerity that ripens into it, namely, performance of one’s own duties. The two—knowledge and austerity—are to be taken as a compound unit, like heat and light. Through that knowledge and austerity, they became purified, freed from the impurities that are effects of ignorance. They—many such people—have attained mad-bhāva, union with Me. And the meaning is that this path of devotion to Me is not newly started just now.

Thus, from “I know them all” (४.५) onwards, by showing both the Lord and the jīva through the indicators of knowledge and ignorance respectively, the distinction between “Thou” and “That” has been illustrated. And because the Lord is eternally pure due to the absence of ignorance, and because the jīva becomes pure upon the removal of ignorance by knowledge gained through the Lord’s grace, it is to be understood that unity is declared through the non-difference in the aspect of consciousness (cit-aṁśa).

4.shlok:
ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः।।४.११।।
4.translit:
ye yathā māṁ prapadyante tāṁs tathaiva bhajāmy aham
mama vartmānuvartante manuṣyāḥ pārtha sarvaśaḥ
4.translate: In whatever way people approach Me, in that same manner do I favor them. O Pārtha, people follow My path in every way.
4.sridhara: Now, the objection may be raised: “Then, is there partiality in You, since You grant union with Your own nature only to those who take exclusive refuge in You, and not to others who have desires?” In response to this, He says: “In whatever manner.” Those who worship Me in whatever way—whether with desires or free from desires—I favor them in that very same way, by bestowing the fruit they seek. It should not be thought that I neglect those who, being desirous, worship other deities such as Indra, having abandoned Me. Why? Because, in all ways, even those who worship Indra and others also follow My path, the path of devotion. Even in the form of Indra and so on, it is I alone who am to be served.

4.shlok:
काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः।
क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा।।४.१२।।
4.translit:
kāṅkṣantaḥ karmaṇāṁ siddhiṁ yajante iha devatāḥ
kṣipraṁ hi mānuṣe loke siddhir bhavati karma-jā
4.translate: Those who desire success in action sacrifice to the deities here; for in the human world, success born of action is quickly attained.
4.sridhara: Then, why is it that not everyone worships You for the sake of liberation alone? In response to this expectation, He says: “Desiring success.” Those who desire the fruit of actions mostly worship deities such as Indra here in the world of humans, and not Me directly. For, indeed, the success that comes from action—the result born of karma—quickly comes about, unlike the fruit of knowledge, namely liberation, which is difficult to attain because knowledge is difficult to obtain.

4.shlok:
चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः।
तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम्।।४.१३।।
4.translit:
cātur-varṇyaṁ mayā sṛṣṭaṁ guṇa-karma-vibhāgaśaḥ
tasya kartāram api māṁ viddhi akartāram avyayam
4.translate: The fourfold caste system was created by Me according to the divisions of guṇa and karma; though I am its creator, know Me as the non-agent and immutable.
4.sridhara: Now, one might raise a doubt: “There is variety in actions—some act with desires, others without—and among those who perform them, like the brāhmaṇas and so on, there is variety as superior, middling, etc. If You are the agent of this, then how can there be no partiality in You?” In reply to this, He says: “The fourfold division.” The four varṇas (castes) are the cāturvarṇyam. (The suffix -ya in cāturvarṇyaṁ is in the sense of the thing itself.) The meaning is: brāhmaṇas are predominated by sattva; their actions are tranquility, self-restraint, and so on. Kṣatriyas are predominated by sattva and rajas; their actions are heroism, battle, and the like. Vaiśyas are predominated by rajas and tamas; their actions are agriculture, trade, and so on. Śūdras are predominated by tamas; their actions are service to the three varṇas, etc. In this way, the fourfold varṇa system has been created by Me alone, according to the divisions of guṇas and karmas. This is true. Even so, know Me, who am its creator, to be in reality the non-agent, because I am without attachment to results. The reason for that: I am immutable (avyaya)—free from attachment, free from effort, free from destruction, and so on.

4.shlok:
न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा।
इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते।।४.१४।।
4.translit:
na māṁ karmāṇi limpanti na me karma-phale spṛhā
iti māṁ yo ’bhijānāti karma-bhiḥ na sa badhyate
4.translate: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.
4.sridhara: Showing just that, He says: “Actions do not taint Me.” Even actions such as creation of the universe do not taint Me—they do not affect Me with attachment. Because I am devoid of egoism. Since I have no desire for the fruit of actions due to My state of self-sufficiency, it is needless to say that actions do not bind Me. Therefore, he who knows Me thus—as devoid of desire for the fruit of action—is also not bound by actions. The cause of My freedom from bondage is My lack of egoism and desire; one who knows this finds that his own egoism and desire are weakened.

4.shlok:
एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः।
कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम्।।४.१५।।
4.translit:
evaṁ jñātvā kṛtaṁ karma pūrvair api mumukṣubhiḥ
kuru karma eva tasmāt tvaṁ pūrvaiḥ pūrvataraṁ kṛtam
4.translate: Knowing thus, even the ancient seekers of liberation performed action; therefore, you too should perform action, just as the ancients did in former times.
4.sridhara: Through the four verses beginning with “In whatever way they approach Me,” the incidental concern about whether the Lord has partiality was resolved. Now He recalls and expands on what was previously taught about karma-yoga. Thus, He says: “Knowing thus”—that action performed without egoism, etc., does not bind—“even the ancients, like Janaka and others, who were seekers of liberation, performed action for the sake of purity of mind.” And even earlier than them, in past ages, such actions were performed. Therefore, you too first perform action.

4.shlok:
किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः।
तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।।४.१६।।
4.translit:
kiṁ karma kim akarme ti kavayo ’py atra mohitāḥ
tat te karma pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvā mokṣyase ’śubhāt
4.translate: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. Therefore, I shall teach you about action, knowing which you shall be freed from evil.
4.sridhara: That (action) should be reflected upon along with those who know the truth—not based merely on popular tradition. Therefore, He says: “What is action?” What is action? What kind of action is the doing of karma? What is inaction? What kind of inaction is the non-doing of karma? Even regarding this, the discriminating are deluded. Therefore, knowing that, and then performing it, you shall be freed from evil, i.e., from saṁsāra. That action and inaction I shall now explain to you—listen.

4.shlok:
कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः।
अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः।।४.१७।।
4.translit:
karmaṇo hy api boddhavyaṁ boddhavyaṁ ca vikarmaṇaḥ
akarmaṇaś ca boddhavyaṁ gahanā karmaṇo gatiḥ
4.translate: One must understand the truth about action, also about prohibited action, and likewise about inaction. For the path of action is deep and difficult to understand.
4.sridhara: Now, one may say: “Isn’t action popularly understood as bodily activity, and inaction as non-activity of the body? So how can it be said that even the wise are deluded in this matter?” In response, He says: “Even of action.” The truth of enjoined action must be known; it is not merely what is commonly accepted. Likewise, the truth of inaction—non-enjoined activity—must also be known. And the truth of prohibited action must also be known. Why? Because the course of action is subtle. The word “karmaṇaḥ” (of action) stands for all: the truths of action, inaction, and prohibited action must be understood. That is the meaning: it is difficult to discern.

4.shlok:
कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः।
स बुद्धिमान् मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत्।।४.१८।।
4.translit:
karmaṇy akarma yaḥ paśyed akarmaṇi ca karma yaḥ
sa buddhimān manuṣyeṣu sa yuktaḥ kṛtsna-karma-kṛt
4.translate: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction—he is wise among men; he is disciplined and the performer of all actions.
4.sridhara:
Showing that action and the like are difficult to discern, He says: “He who sees inaction in action.” In action that is of the nature of worship of the Supreme Lord, the one who sees that this is not truly action—because it does not cause bondage, being a cause of knowledge—sees rightly. And one who sees action in inaction—i.e., the omission of what is enjoined—as producing demerit and thus a cause of bondage, he is praised: among men who perform action, he is wise, because he possesses resolute intellect; he is a yogī, and by that action attains knowledge-yoga. He is also said to be the doer of all actions, because in that act, comparable to a body of water overflowing from all sides, all other karmic results are included. By this, the previously mentioned karma-yoga (like “action is said to be the means for one seeking to ascend yoga”) is now clearly restated. And since this section is in the form of an elaboration, there is no fault of repetition.

By this same reasoning, in the higher stage of yoga (mentioned earlier as “for one who has already attained yoga, inaction is the means”), the statement that there is no use of karma also is to be interpreted as elaborated. When even for one ascending yoga action does not cause bondage, then for one already established in yoga, how could it?
