Alternatively, one who, though dwelling in activity involving the body and senses, perceives inaction (natural inaction, innate non-doership) due to realization of the Self as distinct from body and senses; and one who, in renouncing actions out of sorrow due to lack of knowledge, sees that very renunciation as karma, due to its being an obstacle (a false discipline), such a person is intelligent among all humans.

The reason: although performing all actions that arise of their own accord (like eating, etc.), he remains united (yukta), established in knowledge of the Self as a non-doer, immersed in samādhi—this is the meaning.

Thus, it should be understood that even in the case of the knower, actions that happen naturally, like eating meat or other minor irregularities, do not lead to fault. For one ignorant, however, doing so due to attachment is indeed faulty. Therefore, the truth regarding prohibited action (vikarma) is also to be understood here.

4.shlok:
यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः।
ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः।।४.१९।।
4.translit:
yasya sarve samārambhāḥ kāma-saṅkalpa-varjitāḥ
jñānāgni-dagdha-karmaāṇaṁ tam āhuḥ paṇḍitaṁ budhāḥ
4.translate: He whose undertakings are all devoid of desire and self-will, whose actions have been burnt by the fire of knowledge—him the wise call a sage.
4.sridhara:
The two meanings—expressed through scriptural citation and inference—from the statement “he who sees inaction in action” are now clarified through the five following verses, beginning with “yasya.” Actions that are well-commenced are called samārambhāḥ. Those actions which are devoid of desire (which arises from longing) and of mental projections (resolve or volition) are said to belong to the one whom the wise call a sage.

The reason: the actions of such a one, who is pure of mind, have been burnt by the fire of knowledge, and thus turned into inaction. In the advanced stage (ārūḍha-avasthā), desire refers to craving for the fruit; saṅkalpa refers to the mental resolve: “This action should be done for that fruit.” The sage is one who is free from both. The rest is clear.

4.shlok:
त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः।
कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः।।४.२०।।
4.translit:
tyaktvā karma-phala-āsaṅgaṁ nitya-tṛpto nirāśrayaḥ
karmaṇy abhipravṛtto ’pi naiva kiñcit karoti saḥ
4.translate: Having renounced attachment to the fruit of action, ever content, without dependence, he does nothing at all—though engaged in action.
4.sridhara: Further, “Having renounced.” Having renounced attachment to action and its fruit, and being ever satisfied in his own bliss, and therefore without anything to rely on for securing or preserving anything—one who is thus, though fully engaged in natural and enjoined actions, does not do anything at all. His actions attain the state of inaction—this is the meaning.

4.shlok:
निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः।
शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्।।४.२१।।
4.translit:
nirāśīr yata-cittātmā tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ
śārīraṁ kevalaṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam
4.translate: Without expectation, with mind and self controlled, having abandoned all possessions, performing only bodily action, he does not incur sin.
4.sridhara: Furthermore, “nirāśīḥ,” i.e., one from whom expectations—desires—have departed. “Yata-citta-ātmā” means one whose mind (citta) and body (ātmā) are controlled. “Tyakta-sarva-parigrahaḥ” is one who has abandoned all possessions. Such a person, performing only bodily action (śārīram karma)—that which merely maintains the body, and which is devoid of egoistic notion of agency—does not incur sin, i.e., does not become bound. In the context of the established yogī, even while performing natural actions such as alms-seeking (bhikṣāṭana), which serve merely for bodily maintenance, he does not incur sin arising from omission of scriptural duty.

4.shlok:
यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः।
समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते।।४.२२।।
4.translit:
yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭo dvandvātīto vimatsaraḥ
samaḥ siddhāvasiddhau ca kṛtvā ’pi na nibadhyate
4.translate: Content with what comes by chance, beyond the pairs of opposites, free from envy, equal in success and failure—though acting, he is not bound.
4.sridhara: Furthermore, “yadṛcchā-lābha-santuṣṭaḥ”—he is satisfied with gain that comes of its own accord, without being sought. “Dvandva-atītaḥ”—one who has overcome the dualities such as heat and cold, i.e., he is tolerant of them. “Vimatsaraḥ”—one who is free from envy or hostility. Even in regard to such gain that arises spontaneously (yadṛcchā-lābha), in success and failure, he remains equal—free from elation and sorrow. One who is thus, though performing scripturally enjoined or natural action according to the earlier and later stages of life, does not incur bondage.

4.shlok:
गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः।
यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते।।४.२३।।
4.translit:
gata-saṅgasya muktasya jñānāvasthita-cetasaḥ
yajñāyācarataḥ karma samagraṁ pravilīyate
4.translate: For one who is free of attachment, liberated, and whose mind is established in knowledge—who acts for the sake of sacrifice—his entire action is dissolved.
4.sridhara: Further, “gata-saṅgasya” means one who is devoid of attachment, “muktasya” means one who is free from passions such as desire and aversion. “Jñāna-avasthita-cetasaḥ”—one whose mind is established in knowledge. For such a person who acts for the sake of sacrifice (yajñāya), i.e., for the Supreme Lord (parameśvarārtham), the entire action along with its latent impressions (samagraṁ savāsanaṁ karma) dissolves and attains the nature of inaction. In the case of the yogī who has attained realization (ārūḍha-yoga-pakṣa), yajñāya means “for the protection of sacrifice,” i.e., performing action merely for the maintenance of the world (for loka-saṅgraha).

4.shlok:
ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्महविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्।
ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना।।४.२४।।
4.translit:
brahmārpaṇaṁ brahma-havir brahmāgnau brahmaṇā hutam
brahmaiva tena gantavyaṁ brahma-karma-samādhinā
4.translate: The offering is Brahman, the oblation is Brahman, it is offered by Brahman into the fire of Brahman; Brahman alone is to be reached by one who sees Brahman in every action.
4.sridhara:
Thus, action performed as worship of the Supreme Lord is inaction—because it causes knowledge and is therefore non-binding. In the advanced stage (ārūḍhāvasthā), even natural action becomes inaction due to the knowledge of the self as non-agent. The dissolution of action mentioned earlier in “he who sees inaction in action” is now being elaborated. The dissolution of action is explained for one who perceives Brahman in action and in its accessories.

“Brahmārpaṇam”—the arpaṇa (implement used for offering), such as the ladle (sruva), by which something is offered, is Brahman alone. The havis (oblation), such as ghee, that is being offered, is also Brahman. The fire into which it is offered (brahmāgniḥ) is Brahman. The one who offers (hutam) is also Brahman. Thus, the offering, the fire, the agent, and the act—all are Brahman. One whose mind is thus concentrated and absorbed (samādhi) in Brahman, in the form of action—that person attains only Brahman, not any other fruit.

4.shlok:
दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते।
ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति।।४.२५।।
4.translit:
daivam evāpare yajñaṁ yoginaḥ paryupāsate
brahmāgnāv apare yajñaṁ yajñenaivopajuhvati
4.translate: Some yogis perform sacrifice to the gods alone; others offer the sacrifice into the fire of Brahman, offering the self by the self.
4.sridhara:
This very knowledge, characterized by the vision of Brahman everywhere and accomplished in the form of sacrifice, is superior to all sacrifices because it is attainable through all means of sacrifice. In order to praise it thus, the Lord now speaks of many kinds of sacrifices—those which are means to knowledge—according to the qualifications of the practitioners, across eight verses beginning with “daivam.”

“Daivam yajñam”—a sacrifice in which gods like Indra and Varuṇa are worshipped. The word “eva” indicates the absence of Brahman-knowledge in Indra and others, i.e., they are not seen as Brahman. That sacrifice to the gods (daivam yajñam) is devoutly performed (paryupāsate) by some karma-yogīs. Others, namely the jñāna-yogīs, offer the sacrifice into the fire that is of the nature of Brahman (brahmāgnau) using “sacrifice itself” as the instrument—i.e., by the method previously mentioned in “brahmārpaṇam.” That is, they dissolve all actions, including sacrifice and other rituals, into Brahman. This is the knowledge-sacrifice (jñāna-yajñaḥ).

4.shlok:
श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति।
शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति।।४.२६।।
4.translit:
śrotrādīnīndriyāṇy anye saṁyamāgniṣu juhvati
śabdādīn viṣayān anye indriyāgniṣu juhvati
4.translate: Some offer the ear and other senses into the fires of restraint; others offer sound and other sense objects into the fires of the senses.
4.sridhara: “śrotrādīnīti” — Others, namely steadfast celibates (naiṣṭhika brahmacārins), offer the various sense-organs like the ear, etc., into fires in the form of restraint of those organs, meaning they dissolve them. That is, having subdued the senses, they remain focused primarily on discipline. The senses themselves are considered as fires, and into them others—namely householders—offer the sense objects such as sound, etc. Even during enjoyment, being unattached, they consider the senses to be fires and the objects like sound, etc., to be offerings, and they mentally cast them into the sense-fires. That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे।
आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते।।४.२७।।
4.translit:
sarvāṇīndriyakarmāṇi prāṇakarmāṇi cāpare
ātma-saṁyama-yogāgnau juhvati jñānadīpite
4.translate: Others offer all the functions of the senses and the functions of the life-breaths into the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint, kindled by knowledge.
4.sridhara: “sarvāṇīti” — Others, devoted to meditation, offer the functions of the knowledge-senses such as the ear (e.g., hearing, seeing, etc.), the functions of the action-senses such as speech and hands (e.g., speaking, grasping, etc.), and the ten functions of the vital airs: the outward movement of prāṇa, the downward movement of apāna, the expansion and contraction, etc., of vyāna, the proper upward movement of digested food and drink by samāna, and the upward motion by udāna. Among these, nāga is said to be the function of belching, kūrma of opening the eyelids, kṛkara is known as causing hunger, devadatta is for yawning, and dhanañjaya is said to pervade the entire body and does not depart even after death. All these are offered—where?—into the fire called the Yoga of self-restraint, which is one-pointedness in meditation. That very Yoga is the fire. Into that, illuminated by knowledge related to the object of meditation, having properly known the object of meditation, and having controlled the mind in that, they cause the cessation of all these functions. That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे।
स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः।।४.२८।।
4.translit:
dravyayajñās tapoyajñā yogayajñās tathāpare
svādhyāya-jñānayajñāś ca yatayaḥ saṁśitavratāḥ
4.translate: Others offer wealth, austerity, and Yoga as sacrifice; and others, steadfast in vows, offer the study of scriptures and knowledge as sacrifice.
4.sridhara: Now, “dravya” — Those whose sacrifice is the giving of wealth are called dravyayajñās. Those whose sacrifice consists of austerities such as kṛcchra, cāndrāyaṇa, etc., are tapoyajñās. Yoga is defined as the restraint of the mental modifications—samādhi itself is their sacrifice, and such practitioners are yogayajñās. Through the study of the Veda—by means of listening, reflection, etc.—the knowledge that arises regarding its meaning is their sacrifice; they are svādhyāya-jñānayajñās. Alternatively, there are two kinds of ascetics (yatayaḥ) engaged in effort: those who perform the sacrifice of Vedic recitation and those who perform the sacrifice of the knowledge of its meaning. Those whose vows are well-restrained, sharpened, and made resolute are called saṁśita-vratāḥ.

4.shlok:
अपाने जुह्वति प्राणं प्राणेऽपानं तथाऽपरे।
प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः।।४.२९।।
4.translit:
apāne juhvati prāṇaṁ prāṇe’pānaṁ tathāpare
prāṇāpānagatī ruddhvā prāṇāyāma-parāyaṇāḥ
4.translate: Others offer the outgoing breath into the incoming breath, and the incoming into the outgoing; restraining the movements of both, they are absorbed in breath-control.
4.sridhara: Now, “apāne” — Some offer the upward-moving prāṇa into the downward-moving apāna using the technique of inhalation (pūraka), i.e., during pūraka they merge prāṇa with apāna. Likewise, having restrained the upward and downward movements of prāṇa and apāna through kumbhaka (retention), during exhalation (recaka), they offer apāna into prāṇa. In this manner, through inhalation, retention, and exhalation, others are absorbed in prāṇāyāma (breath-control). That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति।
सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः।।४.३०।।
4.translit:
apare niyatāhārāḥ prāṇān prāṇeṣu juhvati
sarve’py ete yajñavido yajña-kṣapita-kalmaṣāḥ
4.translate: Others, with regulated diet, offer the life-breaths into life-breaths. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose impurities have been destroyed by sacrifice.
4.sridhara: Now, “apare” — Others practice food restriction and mentally contemplate the dissolution of the various functions of the senses into the decaying senses themselves—this is regarded as the offering. Alternatively, regarding “apāne juhvati prāṇam prāṇe’pānam tathāpare” from the previous verse, the inhalation and exhalation are mutually recurring, and in them the “Haṁsaḥ, So’ham” (I am that, That I am) is expressed in the normal and reverse orders by means of the ajapa-mantra (unuttered mantra), whereby they contemplate the unity of the words “tat” and “tvam.” As said in the Yoga-śāstra: “With the syllable ‘sa’ it (breath) goes out, with ‘ha’ it enters again—let one contemplate: ‘That is I, I am Haṁsaḥ.’” Now, with “prāṇāpānagatī ruddhvā,” the prāṇāyāma-sacrifices performed by others are described. The intended meaning is this: “Let two parts of the stomach be filled with food, one part with water, and the remaining fourth be reserved for the movement of air.” Those who follow such injunctions have regulated diet (niyata-āhārāḥ). Having restrained the movements of prāṇa and apāna through kumbhaka, being absorbed in prāṇāyāma, they offer the vital forces and senses into the prāṇas. Since all the vital energies become unified in kumbhaka, it is understood that the offering is performed into the senses which dissolve into that state. As it is said in the Yoga-śāstra: “To the extent that the mind becomes steady through constant practice, to that extent do the breath, speech, body, and gaze also become steady.” In this way, the result of the twelve types of sacrifice mentioned above is now stated: “sarve’py ete”—all these are knowers of sacrifice. That is, they attain the fruit of the sacrifice. Or, “yajñajñāḥ”—they are knowers of sacrifice. Their impurities have been destroyed by means of sacrifice.

4.shlok:
यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्।
नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतोऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम।।४.३१।।
4.translit:
yajña-śiṣṭāmṛta-bhujo yānti brahma sanātanam
nāyaṁ loko’sty ayajñasya kuto’nyaḥ kuru-sattama
4.translate: Those who partake of the nectar-like remnants of sacrifice attain the eternal Brahman. For one who does not perform sacrifice, even this world is not; how then the other, O best of the Kurus?
4.sridhara: “yajña-śiṣṭe” — Having performed sacrifices, they eat the food that remains afterwards, which is not prohibited and is of the nature of nectar—this is the meaning. In this way, they attain the eternal Brahman through the path of knowledge. The fault in not performing sacrifice is stated: “nāyaṁ lokaḥ” — Even this human world, though of meagre happiness, does not belong to the one who is devoid of sacrifice, i.e., who does not undertake sacrifice. How, then, the other world? Therefore, sacrifices must certainly be performed. That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे।
कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे।।४.३२।।
4.translit:
evaṁ bahu-vidhā yajñā vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe
karma-jān viddhi tān sarvān evaṁ jñātvā vimokṣyase
4.translate: Thus, manifold are the sacrifices spread out at the mouth of Brahman. Know them all to be born of action. Thus knowing, you shall be liberated.
4.sridhara: To extol the knowledge-sacrifice, the other sacrifices are concluded with “evaṁ.” These sacrifices are “vitatā brahmaṇo mukhe” — prescribed directly in the Vedas, which are the mouth of Brahman. Even so, know all these to be born of action — originating from actions of speech, mind, and body — and devoid of contact with the true nature of the Self. Since the Self is beyond the scope of action, thus knowing, becoming devoted to knowledge, you shall be liberated from saṁsāra. That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप।
सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते।।४.३३।।
4.translit:
śreyān dravya-mayād yajñāj jñāna-yajñaḥ paraṁtapa
sarvaṁ karmākhilaṁ pārtha jñāne parisamāpyate
4.translate: Superior is the sacrifice of knowledge to the sacrifice involving material offerings, O scorcher of foes. All actions in their entirety, O Arjuna, culminate in knowledge.
4.sridhara: Here, the knowledge-sacrifice is declared superior to the action-sacrifice: “śreyān” — The knowledge-sacrifice is superior to the material-sacrifice (dravya-maya), i.e., to the sacrifices involving external activities like offerings to deities. Although the knowledge-sacrifice too is dependent on mental activity, the knowledge of the Self is merely revealed as a manifestation of the transformation of the mind; it is not produced by the mind. In this lies its distinction from material-sacrifices. The reason for its superiority is stated: “sarvaṁ karma” — all action, together with its fruit, culminates in knowledge. That is, all actions become included within it. As the śruti says: “sarvaṁ tad abhisameti yat kiñcit prajāḥ sādhu kurvanti” — “All that the people do as good conduct is encompassed by knowledge.”

4.shlok:
तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया।
उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः।।४.३४।।
4.translit:
tad viddhi praṇipātena paripraśnena sevayā
upadekṣyanti te jñānaṁ jñāninas tattva-darśinaḥ
4.translate: Know that (knowledge) by submission, inquiry, and service. The wise, who have realized the truth, will instruct you in that knowledge.
4.sridhara: The means to attain such Self-knowledge is stated: “tad viddhi” — Know that knowledge, attain it. How? Through prostration (praṇipāta), i.e., bowing down like a staff; then by questioning: “Whence has this saṁsāra arisen for me, and how can it cease?” — and by service (sevayā), i.e., by devoted attendance. The knowers of the śāstra (scriptures), those who are endowed with direct experience of the truth (tattva-darśinaḥ), will impart that knowledge to you through instruction.

4.shlok:
यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव।
येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि।।४.३५।।
4.translit:
yaj jñātvā na punar moham evaṁ yāsyasi pāṇḍava
yena bhūtānyaśeṣeṇa drakṣyasy ātmany atho mayi
4.translate: Having known that, you shall not again fall into such delusion, O Arjuna. By that knowledge, you shall see all beings without exception in the Self, and also in Me.
4.sridhara: The fruit of knowledge is stated in the three-and-a-half verses beginning with “yaj jñātvā.” Having known that knowledge — having attained it — you shall not again fall into delusion, which arises due to motives like the killing of relatives, etc. The reason for that is stated: by that knowledge, you shall see all beings — like fathers, sons, etc., created by ignorance — as non-different from your own Self. Furthermore, you shall see your Self as non-different from Me, the Supreme Self — that is the meaning.

4.shlok:
अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः।
सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि।।४.३६।।
4.translit:
api ced asi pāpebhyaḥ sarvebhyaḥ pāpa-kṛt-tamaḥ
sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṁ santariṣyasi
4.translate: Even if you are the most sinful among all sinners, you shall cross over all sin by the raft of knowledge alone.
4.sridhara: Further: “api ced asi.” Even if you are excessively sinful—more so than all those who commit sinful acts—still, you shall indeed cross over the entire ocean of sin by means of the raft of knowledge, and that too completely and effortlessly.

4.shlok:
यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन।
ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा।।४.३७।।
4.translit:
yathaidhāṁsi samidddho’gnir bhasmasāt kurute’rjuna
jñānāgniḥ sarva-karmāṇi bhasmasāt kurute tathā
4.translate: As a blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ashes.
4.sridhara: To prevent the misunderstanding that sin is merely crossed over but not destroyed, the Lord gives an example: “yathā edhāṁsi.” Just as blazing fire turns firewood into ashes, so too does the fire of knowledge, which is of the nature of Self-knowledge, burn to ashes all actions except for those that have already begun to bear fruit (prārabdha-karma). That is the meaning.

4.shlok:
न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते।
तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति।।४.३८।।
4.translit:
na hi jñānena sadṛśaṁ pavitram iha vidyate
tat svayaṁ yoga-saṁsiddhaḥ kālena ātmani vindati
4.translate: Indeed, there is nothing in this world as purifying as knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds that knowledge within himself in due time.
4.sridhara: The reason is given: “na hi.” Among austerity, yoga, and other means, nothing here is as purifying as knowledge. Then why do all not pursue Self-knowledge alone? That is answered in the half-verse “tat svayam.” That knowledge—whose object is the Self—is, in due time, attained effortlessly by one who is perfected through karma-yoga. It is not attained without karma-yoga; that is the meaning.

4.shlok:
श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः।
ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति।।४.३९।।
4.translit:
śraddhāvān labhate jñānaṁ tat-paraḥ saṁyatendriyaḥ
jñānaṁ labdhvā parāṁ śāntim acireṇa adhigacchati
4.translate: The man of faith, who is devoted to it, and who has subdued the senses, obtains knowledge. Having obtained knowledge, he quickly attains supreme peace.
4.sridhara: Moreover: “śraddhāvān.” The faithful person—one who has firm belief in the teachings imparted by the guru—is “tat-paraḥ,” one-pointedly devoted to that knowledge, and is also “saṁyatendriyaḥ,” one who has controlled the senses. Such a person alone obtains knowledge, not others. Therefore, before attaining knowledge through such faith, karma-yoga must be practiced for purification. But once knowledge is attained, there remains nothing more to be done. “Having attained knowledge, he swiftly gains supreme peace,” i.e., liberation.

4.shlok:
अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति।
नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः।।४.४०।।
4.translit:
ajñaś cāśraddadhānaś ca saṁśayātmā vinaśyati
nāyaṁ loko’sti na paro na sukhaṁ saṁśayātmanaḥ
4.translate: The ignorant, the faithless, and the doubting self is ruined; for the doubting one, there is neither this world, nor the next, nor happiness.
4.sridhara: Having described the qualifications of one entitled to knowledge, the disqualification is now stated: “ajñaś ca.” One who is ignorant—unfamiliar with the teachings imparted by the guru—and who, even after gaining some knowledge, lacks faith; one whose mind is plagued by doubt, thinking “Will this succeed for me or not?”—such a person is destroyed, meaning they fall away from their own welfare. Of these three, the doubting one is completely ruined, because for such a person, this world is lost (due to failure in acquiring wealth, marriage, etc.); the other world is also lost (due to the failure of dharma); and even happiness is not possible, since even enjoyment becomes impossible for the one consumed by doubt.

4.shlok:
योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसंछिन्नसंशयम्।
आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय।।४.४१।।
4.translit:
yoga-saṁnyasta-karmāṇaṁ jñāna-saṁchinna-saṁśayam
ātmavantaṁ na karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya
4.translate: One whose actions have been renounced through Yoga, whose doubts are cut asunder by knowledge, and who is self-possessed—actions do not bind him, O Dhanañjaya.
4.sridhara: The twofold steadfastness in Brahman—consisting of karma (action) and jñāna (knowledge), and taught over the past two chapters with their respective stages—is now concluded: “yoga-saṁnyasta-karmāṇam.” That person, by whom actions have been renounced through Yoga, which is of the nature of worship of the Supreme Lord, meaning that actions have been offered unto Him, such a person is not bound by actions with their results. Moreover, “jñāna-saṁchinna-saṁśayam”—one whose doubts, which are in the form of false identification with the body and such, have been cut off by the knowledge of the Self as non-agent. And “ātmavantam”—one who is ever self-aware, free of negligence. Such a person is not bound even by actions performed naturally or for the sake of maintaining social order.

4.shlok:
तस्मादज्ञानसंभूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनाऽऽत्मनः।
छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत।।४.४२।।
4.translit:
tasmād ajñāna-sambhūtaṁ hṛt-sthaṁ jñānāsinā’tmanaḥ
chittva enaṁ saṁśayaṁ yogam ātiṣṭha uttiṣṭha bhārata
4.translate: Therefore, with the sword of Self-knowledge, cut off this doubt in your heart born of ignorance. Take refuge in Yoga and arise, O Bhārata!
4.sridhara: “tasmād”—because this is so, therefore that doubt which is born of one’s ignorance, which resides in the heart and causes grief and the like, cut it off with the sword of discrimination between the body and the Self. “ātma-jñāna-khaṅgena”—with the sword of Self-knowledge. Then, “yogam ātiṣṭha”—take refuge in karma-yoga, which is the means to knowledge of the Supreme Self. And “uttiṣṭha”—first arise for the battle at hand, which was the original context. “O Bhārata”—this is said to indicate that war is your own svadharma as a kṣatriya.

5.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि।
यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्चितम्।।५.१।।
5.translit:
arjuna uvāca
saṁnyāsaṁ karmaṇāṁ kṛṣṇa punar yogaṁ ca śaṁsasi
yac chreya etayor ekaṁ tan me brūhi suniścitam
5.translate: Arjuna said: Renunciation of actions, O Krishna, You praise, and again action with discipline. Of these two, tell me decisively which is superior.
5.sridhara: Having dispelled the doubt of Arjuna concerning karma-yoga and karma-saṁnyāsa (renunciation of action), and having described liberation for one who has controlled the senses in the fifth chapter, beginning with “He whose intellect is unattached,” the Lord said: “Sever the doubt born of ignorance with the sword of knowledge and take up karma-yoga” (४.४२). Considering there to be a contradiction between what was said earlier and what followed, Arjuna said (५.१): “You first praised complete renunciation of all actions for the wise, as in ‘He who delights in the Self alone’ (३.१७), and ‘All action, O Pārtha, entirely ends in knowledge’ (४.३३). And again, You praised yoga, saying, ‘Sever the doubt and engage in karma-yoga.’ Now, since karma-saṁnyāsa and karma-yoga are mutually exclusive and cannot be undertaken simultaneously by one person—because their natures are contradictory—therefore, among these two, if only one is to be undertaken, then tell me that one which is certainly superior.”

5.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ।
तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते।।५.२।।
5.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
saṁnyāsaḥ karma-yogaś ca niḥśreyasa-karāv ubhau
tayos tu karma-saṁnyāsāt karma-yogo viśiṣyate
5.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Renunciation and the yoga of action both lead to the highest good; but of the two, action with discipline is superior to the renunciation of action.
5.sridhara: To this, the Lord replied: “Renunciation…” (५.२). The point is: I am not prescribing karma-yoga to one who knows the truth of the Self taught in Vedānta—for that would contradict the renunciation spoken of previously. Rather, I am speaking to you, who are identified with the body, and whose grief and delusion have arisen from the killing of relatives and so on. I say, “Sever this doubt produced by mistaken identification with the body by means of knowledge that discerns the non-identity of the body and the Self, and then take up karma-yoga, which is a means to realization of the Supreme Self.” And when one becomes pure in mind through karma-yoga and realizes the truth of the Self, then for the sake of perfecting that knowledge, renunciation as an accessory to steadfastness in knowledge was previously described. Thus, since both these—karma-saṁnyāsa and karma-yoga—can be combined sequentially depending on one’s stage, and since they both lead to the highest good, therefore they are both valid paths. Nevertheless, between the two, karma-yoga is superior to the renunciation of action.

5.shlok:
ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति।
निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते।।५.३।।
5.translit:
jñeyaḥ sa nitya-saṁnyāsī yo na dveṣṭi na kāṅkṣati
nirdvandvo hi mahā-bāho sukhaṁ bandhāt pramucyate
5.translate: He should be known as a perpetual renunciant who neither hates nor desires; for, O mighty-armed, one who is free from dualities is easily released from bondage.
5.sridhara: In response to the question, “Why is karma-yoga superior to renunciation?”, the Lord praises karma-yoga under the name of renunciation and shows its superiority: “He should be known…” (५.३). One who performs actions for the sake of the Supreme Lord, being free from attachment and aversion, is to be known as a perpetual renunciant, even during the time of engaging in action. The reason is this: the one who is free from dualities such as attachment and aversion, and who has a pure mind, is easily liberated from saṁsāra through knowledge.

5.shlok:
सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः।
एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम्।।५.४।।
5.translit:
sāṅkhya-yogau pṛthag bālāḥ pravadanti na paṇḍitāḥ
ekam apy āsthitaḥ samyag ubhayor vindate phalam
5.translate: Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and action-yoga as different; he who is properly established in one attains the result of both.
5.sridhara: Because both karma-yoga and renunciation are, as means and accessories, to be combined in sequence depending on one's stage, the question of “which is better among the two?” is suitable only for the ignorant, not for the discerning. Therefore it is said: “Sāṅkhya and yoga…” (५.४). The word ‘sāṅkhya’ refers to steadfastness in knowledge and implies renunciation as its accessory. The ignorant—‘children’—speak of karma-yoga and renunciation as yielding separate and independent results. But not so the wise. Why? Because one who is truly established in either attains the result of both. That is, one who properly practices karma-yoga, becoming pure in mind, attains liberation through knowledge. And one who is firmly established in renunciation also attains liberation through the knowledge that arises from the prior performance of karma-yoga. Thus, they do not yield different results.

5.shlok:
यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते।
एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति।।५.५।।
5.translit:
yat sāṅkhyaiḥ prāpyate sthānaṁ tad yogair api gamyate
ekaṁ sāṅkhyaṁ ca yogaṁ ca yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati
5.translate: That state which is attained by the sāṅkhyas is also reached by the yogis. He truly sees who sees sāṅkhya and yoga as one.
5.sridhara: This is clarified further in: “That which is attained…” (५.५). That state called mokṣa, which is directly attained by the sāṅkhyas—those established in knowledge and renunciation—is also reached by the yogis, i.e., those who follow karma-yoga. Here the word api (‘also’) should be understood in the sense of matvarthīya (qualifying the suffix). Thus, that very same state is attained by karma-yogins too, through knowledge. Therefore, he who sees sāṅkhya and yoga as one—because they lead to the same result—is the one who truly sees.

5.shlok:
संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः।
योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति।।५.६।।
5.translit:
saṁnyāsas tu mahā-bāho duḥkham āptum ayogataḥ
yoga-yukto munir brahma nacireṇādhigacchati
5.translate: But renunciation, O mighty-armed, is difficult to attain without yoga; the sage who is united with yoga attains Brahman without delay.
5.sridhara: If even karma-yogins ultimately attain steadfastness in knowledge through renunciation, then perhaps it is proper to renounce from the beginning itself. To one thinking thus, He replies: “Renunciation…” (५.६). Without yoga—i.e., without karma-yoga—renunciation is a cause of difficulty; it is impossible, that is the meaning. For, due to the absence of purity of mind, steadfastness in knowledge is not possible. But the sage who is united with yoga, being pure in mind, becomes a renunciant and attains Brahman—realizes It directly—without delay. Therefore, prior to purity of mind, karma-yoga is superior to renunciation. This was previously established. Thus it is said by the authors of the Vārttika: “One even sees sannyāsins—those who are careless, outward-turned, malicious, eager for quarrel—whose minds, being corrupted by destiny, are thus seen to be devoid of purity.”

5.shlok:
योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः।
सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते।।५.७।।
5.translit:
yoga-yukto viśuddhātmā vijitātmā jitendriyaḥ
sarva-bhūtātma-bhūtātmā kurvann api na lipyate
5.translate: One who is devoted to yoga, whose mind is pure, who has conquered the self, whose senses are subdued, and who sees the Self as the self of all beings—though acting, he is not tainted.
5.sridhara: Even if Brahman is attained by means of karma-yoga, still one may doubt: would there not be bondage due to actions performed thereafter? To dispel that doubt, He says: “He who is united with yoga…” (५.७). Being united with yoga, therefore he is one whose mind (ātmā) is pure; thus, one who has conquered the body (ātmā); therefore, one who has subdued the senses. Consequently, he is one whose self has become the Self of all beings. Though performing actions either for the sake of maintaining the world (lokasaṅgraha) or by nature, he is not tainted by them—he is not bound.

5.shlok:
नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्।
पश्यञ् शृण्वन् स्पृशञ् जिघ्रन्नश्नन् गच्छन् स्वपञ् श्वसन्।।५.८।।
5.translit:
naiva kiṁcit karomīti yukto manyeta tattvavit
paśyañ śṛṇvan spṛśañ jighrann aśnan gacchan svapan śvasan
5.translate: “I do nothing at all”—thus would one harmonized (in yoga), a knower of truth, think, while seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, moving, sleeping, breathing.
5.sridhara: Continued in next verse.

5.shlok:
प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन्।।५.९।।
5.translit:
pralapan visṛjan gṛhṇann unmiṣan nimiṣann api
indriyāṇīndriyārtheṣu vartanta iti dhārayan
5.translate: Speaking, letting go, grasping, opening and closing the eyes—convinced that the senses act upon their objects—he thinks thus.
5.sridhara:
(on ५.८–५.९)
If it is said that though one acts, one is not tainted—might that not be contradictory? To dispel such doubt, it is said: due to absence of egoistic identification as the doer, it is not contradictory. That is stated in these two verses: “He who is united…” (५.८–५.९). One who is harmonized in karma-yoga and gradually becomes a knower of truth—though engaging in seeing, hearing and so on—considers, through firmly established understanding, that “I do nothing at all,” because “the senses move among the sense objects.” That is, vision, hearing, touch, smell, eating are the activities of the knowledge senses (jñānendriyas) such as eyes, ears, skin, etc. Walking is the activity of the feet; sleep belongs to the intellect; breathing belongs to prāṇa; speech to the organ of speech; elimination to the organs of excretion and generation; grasping to the hands; opening and closing the eyes belong to the tortoise-named prāṇa. These are the distinctions. Performing all such actions, yet due to absence of identification as the agent, the knower of Brahman is not tainted. Thus, the Vedānta Sūtra states: “Because of its attainment (of Brahman), there is no contact or destruction of previous or future karma, because of the scriptural declaration” (Brahma Sūtra ४.१.१३).

5.shlok:
ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः।
लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा।।५.१०।।
5.translit:
brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ
lipyate na sa pāpena padma-patram ivāmbhasā
5.translate: He who performs actions, offering them to Brahman, abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not wetted by water.
5.sridhara: Then, one might think: for him who possesses the egoistic notion “I act,” the impurity from karma is inevitable; and due to impurity of mind, even renunciation becomes impossible—thus he is plunged into a grave difficulty. To dispel such concern, the Lord says: “He who offers…” (५.१०). Offering all actions to Brahman, i.e., surrendering them to the Supreme Lord, and renouncing attachment to their results—he who acts in this way is not tainted by sin, that is, not bound by karma that yields sinful or meritorious results. Just as a lotus leaf, even though resting on water, is not wetted by it, so too is he untouched.

5.shlok:
कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि।
योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वाऽऽत्मशुद्धये।।५.११।।
5.translit:
kāyena manasā buddhyā kevalair indriyaiḥ api
yoginaḥ karma kurvanti saṅgaṁ tyaktvātma-śuddhaye
5.translate: Yogins perform actions with the body, mind, intellect, and even with the senses alone—having abandoned attachment—for the purification of the self.
5.sridhara: Having previously stated the absence of bondage (for the karma-yogin), He now shows how action becomes a cause of liberation when accompanied by righteous conduct: “With the body…” (५.११). With the body, they perform such actions as bathing; with the intellect, they engage in the ascertainment of truth. With the senses alone—that is, with senses not obsessed with action—they perform actions such as listening, chanting, and so on. Abandoning attachment to the fruits, the yogins act for the purification of the self (i.e., the mind).

5.shlok:
युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्।
अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते।।५.१२।।
5.translit:
yuktaḥ karma-phalaṁ tyaktvā śāntim āpnoti naiṣṭhikīm
ayuktaḥ kāma-kāreṇa phale sakto nibadhyate
5.translate: The one who is united (with yoga), having abandoned the fruit of action, attains lasting peace; the ununited, driven by desire and attached to the result, is bound.
5.sridhara: A doubt may arise: how is it that by the same action, some are liberated and others bound? To this He replies: “The united…” (५.१२). One who is united—i.e., devoted exclusively to the Supreme Lord—abandoning the fruit of actions, attains final peace (i.e., liberation) while performing actions. But the ununited, outward-turned, moved by desire (kāmakāreṇa), and attached to the fruit, certainly attains bondage.

5.shlok:
सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी।
नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन्।।५.१३।।
5.translit:
sarva-karmāṇi manasā saṁnyasyāste sukhaṁ vaśī
nava-dvāre pure dehī naiva kurvan na kārayan
5.translate: Mentally renouncing all actions, the self-controlled one dwells happily in the city of nine gates, the body, neither acting nor causing action.
5.sridhara: So far, it was demonstrated that for one without purity of mind, karma-yoga is superior to renunciation. Now it is stated that for one with a pure mind, renunciation is superior: “Mentally renouncing all actions…” (५.१३). Vaśī means one who has controlled the mind. Renouncing with the mind all actions that distract (from knowledge), the knower of truth remains happily. Where does he remain? He remains in the city with nine gates: two eyes, two nostrils, two ears, the mouth—these seven located in the head—and two downward (below) openings, the anus and genitals—these constitute the nine gates in the body, likened to a city. The embodied one resides in this body devoid of ego-identification. Because of the absence of ego (ahaṅkāra), he does not act; and due to the absence of possessiveness (mamakāra), he does not cause action. Hence it is said that one with a purified mind abides thus. One with an impure mind, even though he renounces, later acts and causes others to act. But not this one. Therefore, he dwells happily.

5.shlok:
न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः।
न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते।।५.१४।।
5.translit:
na kartṛtvaṁ na karmāṇi lokasya sṛjati prabhuḥ
na karma-phala-saṁyogaṁ svabhāvas tu pravartate
5.translate: The Lord does not create agency or actions for the world, nor the connection with the fruits of actions. But it is nature that acts.
5.sridhara: One may ask: “Is it not the Supreme Lord Himself who causes the righteous to perform virtuous deeds—wishing to elevate them—and the wicked to perform evil deeds—wishing to cast them down? If that is so, then the individual is not independent. How then can he renounce actions? For even in the path of knowledge, he would be caused by the Lord to abandon or perform actions as per His will. Then, the Lord too would be bound by the defects of partiality and cruelty.” To prevent such a misunderstanding, the Lord states in these two verses: “The Lord does not create…” (५.१४–५.१५). The Lord, being the Master, does not produce agency, actions, or the connection with the fruit of actions for beings. Rather, it is the very nature (svabhāva) of the being—ignorance itself—that acts in the form of agency, etc. Due to the nature of beginningless ignorance and desire, the Lord causes beings who are thus inclined to act according to their past actions; He does not Himself create agency, etc. This is the meaning.

5.shlok:
नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः।
अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः।।५.१५।।
5.translit:
nādatte kasyacit pāpaṁ na caiva sukṛtaṁ vibhuḥ
ajñānenāvṛtaṁ jñānaṁ tena muhyanti jantavaḥ
5.translate: The Lord accepts neither the sin nor the virtue of anyone. Knowledge is covered by ignorance; through that, beings are deluded.
5.sridhara:
Because this is so, therefore: “He accepts not…” (५.१५). Even though He is the ordainer, the Lord does not accept anyone’s sin or merit. Why? Because He is vibhu, the all-pervading, complete One—meaning, He is desireless, being ever-complete. If He were to compel action out of self-interest, then it would be otherwise. But that is not the case. The Lord, being ever-satisfied, causes beings to act in accordance with their prior karma, through His inconceivable power of māyā.
Objection: “If the Lord shows grace to His devotees and punishes the non-devotees, then is He not partial? How then can He be said to be ever-satisfied?” To this, He replies: “Knowledge is covered by ignorance…” The punishment itself is grace. Thus, the knowledge that “the Supreme Lord is equal in all respects” is covered by ignorance. Because of that, beings (jīvas) become deluded. That is, they impute partiality to the Lord.

5.shlok:
ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः।
तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम्।।५.१६।।
5.translit:
jñānena tu tad ajñānaṁ yeṣāṁ nāśitam ātmanaḥ
teṣām ādityavat jñānaṁ prakāśayati tat param
5.translate: But for those whose ignorance of the self has been destroyed by knowledge, that knowledge reveals the Supreme, like the sun.
5.sridhara: That the wise are not deluded is now stated: “By knowledge…” (५.१६). For those whose ignorance—consisting of the misconception of inequality in the Lord—has been destroyed by the knowledge of the Self, which is the Lord Himself, that knowledge, having destroyed ignorance, reveals the Supreme—i.e., the complete nature of the Lord. Just as the sun, dispelling darkness, illumines all things, so too does knowledge.

5.shlok:
तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः।
गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः।।५.१७।।
5.translit:
tad-buddhayaḥ tad-ātmānaḥ tan-niṣṭhās tat-parāyaṇāḥ
gacchanti apunar-āvṛttiṁ jñāna-nirdhūta-kalmaṣāḥ
5.translate: Those whose intellects are fixed in That, whose selves are in That, established in That, and who have That as their supreme goal—those whose impurities have been dispelled by knowledge—they go to the state from which there is no return.
5.sridhara: The fruit of devotion to such a Lord is stated: “Those whose intellects are fixed…” (५.१७). Those whose intellect (buddhi), which determines truth, is fixed in Him alone; whose self—the mind—is in Him alone; whose steadiness and goal (niṣṭhā) is in Him alone; whose supreme refuge (parāyaṇa) is that very Lord. By the knowledge of the self obtained through His grace, their impurities (kalmaṣa) having been washed away, they attain non-return—i.e., liberation.

5.shlok:
विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि।
शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः।।५.१८।।
5.translit:
vidyā-vinaya-saṁpanne brāhmaṇe gavi hastini
śuni caiva śvapāke ca paṇḍitāḥ sama-darśinaḥ
5.translate: Sages look equally upon a learned and humble Brahmin, a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even a dog-eater.
5.sridhara: In response to the question: “What are those wise ones like who attain non-return?”—He says: “In a Brahmin endowed with learning and humility…” (५.१८). Those whose nature it is to perceive the one Brahman equally in all things, even in those that appear unequal—such are the wise (paṇḍitāḥ). Here, difference in action is shown: the Brahmin endowed with learning and humility, and the dog-eater, who cooks a dog. In the mention of the cow, elephant, and dog, difference of species is indicated. Yet the wise perceive sameness.

5.shlok:
इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः।
निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः।।५.१९।।
5.translit:
ihaiva tair jitaḥ sargo yeṣāṁ sāmye sthitaṁ manaḥ
nirdoṣaṁ hi samaṁ brahma tasmād brahmaṇi te sthitāḥ
5.translate: Even here (in this life), birth is overcome by those whose minds are established in equality. For Brahman is equal and flawless; therefore, they are established in Brahman.
5.sridhara: Objection: “How can those who see equality among unequal things be considered wise? As Gautama says: ‘When equals and unequals are treated equally or unequally in worship, demerit arises.’” The meaning of that statement is: when a worshipper performs the same type of worship for an unequal as for an equal, or vice versa, he falls from both this world and the next. To this, the verse replies: “Even here…” (५.१९). Even while living, they overcome sarga (rebirth, samsāra). Who? Those whose mind is established in equanimity (sāmya). The reason is given: since Brahman is equal and faultless, those who have equal vision are indeed established in Brahman—they have attained the state of Brahman. The fault cited by Gautama applies only before attaining the state of Brahman, since the fault is referred to in the context of one who is still a worshipper.

5.shlok:
न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्।
स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः।।५.२०।।
5.translit:
na prahṛṣyet priyaṁ prāpya nodvijet prāpya cāpriyam
sthira-buddhir asammūḍhaḥ brahma-vid brahmaṇi sthitaḥ
5.translate: One who knows Brahman, whose intellect is steady and undeluded, does not rejoice when attaining what is pleasant, nor grieve when obtaining what is unpleasant—being established in Brahman.
5.sridhara: The characteristics of one who has attained Brahman are now stated: “He does not rejoice…” (५.२०). He who, having become a knower of Brahman, is established in Brahman—he does not rejoice when attaining the pleasant; he is not elated or full of delight. Nor is he agitated when attaining the unpleasant—that is, he does not grieve. Why? Because his intellect is firm (sthira-buddhi)—steady and unshaken. What causes this firmness? Because he is undeluded (asaṁmūḍha)—free from delusion.

5.shlok:
बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्।
स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते।।५.२१।।
5.translit:
bāhyasparśeṣv asaktātmā vindaty ātmani yat sukham
sa brahma-yoga-yuktātmā sukham akṣayam aśnute
5.translate: He whose mind is unattached to external contacts finds the happiness that is in the self; being joined in union with Brahman, he attains unending happiness.
5.sridhara: The reason for freedom from delusion and steadiness of intellect is now stated: “To the external contacts…” (५.२१). The objects (viṣayās) that are contacted by the senses are called sparśās—they are external sense-objects. One whose mind is unattached to these external sense-objects, who is detached in his mind, finds—that is, attains—that happiness which is peaceful in nature (upaśamātmaka), sattvic in character, and located within, in the internal organ (antaḥkaraṇa). And having obtained that happiness which is of the nature of peace, he whose self is joined in union with Brahman—by samādhi or meditative absorption—and who has attained oneness with that, such a person experiences (aśnute) imperishable (akṣaya) happiness.

5.shlok:
ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते।
आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः।।५.२२।।
5.translit:
ye hi saṁsparśajā bhogā duḥkha-yonaya eva te
ādya-antavantaḥ kaunteya na teṣu ramate budhaḥ
5.translate: For the pleasures that are born of contact are indeed sources of suffering; they have a beginning and an end, O Kaunteya. The wise do not delight in them.
5.sridhara: An objection may be raised: “If the enjoyment of agreeable sense-objects is given up, how can liberation (mokṣa) be considered a goal for humans?” In response, the verse says: “Indeed, those pleasures…” (५.२२). The sparśās—sense-objects—are called so because they are contacted (saṁspṛśyante) by the senses. The enjoyments (bhogās) that arise from them are called pleasures (sukhāni), but even in the present moment, due to being afflicted by competition, envy, and so on, they are indeed sources of sorrow—they are causes of pain. And they are also marked by a beginning and an end. Therefore, the wise do not delight in them.

5.shlok:
शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात्।
कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः।।५.२३।।
5.translit:
śaknotīhaiva yaḥ soḍhuṁ prāk śarīra-vimokṣaṇāt
kāma-krodhodbhavaṁ vegaṁ sa yuktaḥ sa sukhī naraḥ
5.translate: He who can endure here itself, before the body is cast off, the urge born of desire and anger—he is a yogin, he is a happy man.
5.sridhara:
Therefore, liberation (mokṣa) alone is the highest goal of human life. And the impulse (vega) of desire and anger is its strong opposite. Hence, only one who is capable of enduring that becomes qualified for liberation. This is stated: “He who can endure…” (५.२३). The impulse born of desire and anger—marked by disturbance in the mind, eyes, and other faculties—arises. He who, right here, at the very time of their arising, can endure—i.e., restrain—that impulse, not just for a moment, but before the casting off of the body, until the fall of the body—that person alone becomes liberated (muktaḥ), composed (samāhitaḥ), and happy.

Alternatively, even when, after death, a man is being embraced by weeping young women, by sons and others, or even being burned—yet like one devoid of life, he endures the impulse of desire and anger. So too, he who, even before death, while still living, can endure like that, he alone is a yogin (yuktaḥ) and truly happy (sukhī). As the sage Vasiṣṭha said: “Just as the body, when life has gone, feels neither pleasure nor pain, so too if one, even while possessing life, remains like that, he dwells in the abode of liberation.”

5.shlok:
योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः।
स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति।।५.२४।।
5.translit:
yo ’ntaḥ-sukho ’ntar-ārāmas tathā ’ntar-jyotir eva yaḥ
sa yogī brahma-nirvāṇaṁ brahma-bhūto ’dhigacchati
5.translate: He who delights within, who rejoices within, and who is illumined within—such a yogin attains Brahman-nirvāṇa, having become Brahman.
5.sridhara: Not by merely restraining the impulses of desire and anger does one attain liberation. Rather—“He who delights within…” (५.२४). One whose happiness (sukha) is within, in the self—not in sense-objects; whose pleasure (ārāma) is internal—not in external things; whose light or vision (jyotis) is internal—not in music, dance, and so on—such a person, having become Brahman (brahma-bhūtaḥ), attains dissolution in Brahman (brahma-nirvāṇa), i.e., liberation (mokṣa).

5.shlok:
लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः।
छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः।।५.२५।।
5.translit:
labhante brahma-nirvāṇam ṛṣayaḥ kṣīṇa-kalmaṣāḥ
chinna-dvaidhā yatātmānaḥ sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
5.translate: The seers (ṛṣis) whose impurities have been destroyed, whose doubts are cut off, who are self-controlled and who delight in the welfare of all beings—these obtain Brahman-nirvāṇa.
5.sridhara: Moreover—“They attain…” (५.२५). The seers (ṛṣayaḥ), those with true insight, whose impurities (kalmaṣa) are exhausted, whose doubts (dvaidha—i.e., delusions or dualities) are cut off, whose minds (ātmā) are controlled (yata), and who are devoted to the welfare of all beings—being compassionate—such persons attain liberation (brahma-nirvāṇa).

5.shlok:
कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम्।
अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम्।।५.२६।।
5.translit:
kāma-krodha-viyuktānāṁ yatīnām yata-cetasām
abhito brahma-nirvāṇaṁ vartate viditātmanām
5.translate: To those ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their minds, and who have known the Self—Brahman-nirvāṇa exists on all sides.
5.sridhara: Furthermore: “Of those who are free from desire and anger…” (५.२६). For the ascetics (yatīnām)—renunciants—who are devoid of desire and anger (kāma-krodha), who are self-controlled in mind (saṁyata-cittānām), and who have realized the truth of the Self (jñātātma-tattvānām), Brahman-nirvāṇa—absorption in Brahman—is present all around (abhitaḥ), both in the case of those who are dead and of those who are living. That is to say, their absorption into Brahman does not occur only in another body after death—it exists even while they are living.

5.shlok:
स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः।
प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ।।५.२७।।
5.translit:
sparśān kṛtvā bahir bāhyāṁś cakṣuś caivāntare bhruvoḥ
prāṇāpānau samau kṛtvā nāsābhyantara-cāriṇau
5.translate: Having turned outward sense-contacts outward, and the gaze fixed in between the eyebrows, having made the incoming and outgoing breaths moving within the nostrils equal—
5.sridhara: It was said earlier, “that yogin attains Brahman-nirvāṇa” and so on. Now, that very yoga by which liberation (mokṣa) is attained is briefly described in these two verses (५.२७–२८): “Having made the contacts…” (५.२७). The sparśās—objects like form and taste—are external sense-objects. Even when they are imagined, they enter inwardly. By abandoning such thoughts, keeping them outside (bahir eva kṛtvā), and placing the gaze at the space between the brows (bhruvor antare)—fixing it precisely at the midpoint between the eyebrows. If the eyes are completely closed, the mind merges into sleep; if fully open, it wanders outward. To avoid both these faults, the gaze is directed to the space between the brows with half-closed eyes (ardha-nimīlana). The prāṇa and apāna, moving within the nose (nāsa-antare), are the upward and downward flowing vital airs. Making them equal by restraining their upward and downward movement (nirodha), meaning holding the breath (kumbhaka). Alternatively, the prāṇa not moving outward, and the apāna not moving inward—but both remaining at the middle of the nose—are thus made equal through slow inhalation and exhalation.

5.shlok:
यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः।
विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः।।५.२८।।
5.translit:
yatendriya-mano-buddhir munir mokṣa-parāyaṇaḥ
vigata-icchā-bhaya-krodho yaḥ sadā mukta eva saḥ
5.translate: He whose senses, mind, and intellect are controlled, the sage who is devoted to liberation, who is free from desire, fear, and anger—he is always liberated.
5.sridhara: “With the senses controlled…” (५.२८). Through the aforementioned means, he whose senses, mind, and intellect are restrained; for whom liberation (mokṣa) is the supreme goal (param ayanam), to be attained; and hence who is devoid of desire, fear, and anger—such a sage (muniḥ) is always liberated, even while living (jīvan api mukta eva). That is the meaning.

5.shlok:
भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्।
सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति।।५.२९।।
5.translit:
bhoktāraṁ yajña-tapasāṁ sarva-loka-maheśvaram
suhṛdaṁ sarva-bhūtānāṁ jñātvā māṁ śāntim ṛcchati
5.translate: Knowing Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds, and the friend of all beings, one attains peace.
5.sridhara: An objection: “How can liberation arise by mere restraint of the senses and mind?” Not by that alone, but through knowledge—thus the verse says: “The enjoyer of sacrifices…” (५.२९). Of the sacrifices and austerities offered by My devotees, I am the enjoyer—or the protector. I am the supreme Lord (mahā-īśvaraḥ) of all worlds, the friend (suhṛt) of all beings—one who benefits them without expectation, the inner dweller (antar-yāmin). Knowing Me in this way, one attains peace (śāntiḥ), i.e., liberation (mokṣaḥ), through My grace.

6.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः।
स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः।।६.१।।
6.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
anāśritaḥ karma-phalaṁ kāryaṁ karma karoti yaḥ
sa saṁnyāsī ca yogī ca na niragnir na cākriyaḥ
6.translate: The Blessed Lord said: He who performs the action that ought to be done, without depending on the fruits of action—he is a renunciate and a yogī, not one who is without the sacred fire and without action.
6.sridhara: Even if the mind is pure, liberation does not arise from mere renunciation alone without meditation. Therefore, in this sixth chapter, the yoga of meditation is elaborated. The beginning of this chapter is intended to expand upon the yoga that was concisely taught at the end of the previous chapter. There, starting from “All actions are to be mentally renounced,” because the commitment to knowledge preceded by renunciation was expressed as the intended meaning, and because action was said to be of the nature of suffering, there arises the excessive tendency toward immediate renunciation of action. To prevent that, karma-yoga is praised here as superior even to renunciation. The Blessed Lord said: “He who performs...” etc., in the next two verses. One who performs obligatory action as something that must certainly be done, without expectation of its fruit—he alone is a renunciate and a yogī; not one who has given up iṣṭa-karmas (Vedic rituals performed with fire), that is, one who is “without fire”; nor one who has given up pūrta-karmas (actions like almsgiving, etc., that are not fire-based), that is, one who is “without action.”

6.shlok:
यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव।
न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन।।६.२।।
6.translit:
yaṁ saṁnyāsam iti prāhur yogaṁ taṁ viddhi pāṇḍava
na hy asaṁnyasta-saṅkalpo yogī bhavati kaścana
6.translate: That which they call renunciation, O Pāṇḍava, know that to be yoga; for no one becomes a yogī without renouncing desires (saṅkalpa-s).
6.sridhara: Wherefore?—With that question in mind, the Lord affirms that karma-yoga itself is renunciation. “That which they call renunciation,” i.e., that which is praised as renunciation, or declared to be supreme—as in the scriptural statement “Renunciation alone excels” and similar—know that to be yoga itself, because it is defined as the giving up of fruits alone. What is the reason? The word “iti” implies the reason, which is further explained—“for” (hi). One who has not given up the desire for fruits—whether he is committed to action or to knowledge—does not become a yogī at all. Therefore, due to the sameness between the renunciate and the yogī in the abandonment of desire for fruit, he is a renunciate because of that, and also a yogī—because the absence of mental distraction arises from the very abandonment of desire for fruit.

6.shlok:
आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते।
योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते।।६.३।।
6.translit:
ārurukṣor muner yogaṁ karma kāraṇam ucyate
yogārūḍhasya tasyaiva śamaḥ kāraṇam ucyate
6.translate: For the sage who seeks to ascend to yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained yoga, tranquility (cessation of action) is said to be the means.
6.sridhara: Then is karma-yoga to be practiced for one’s whole life? Anticipating that doubt, the limit or end-point of karma-yoga is stated: “ārurukṣoḥ,” i.e., for a person who desires to ascend to the path of knowledge-yoga, action is said to be the means, because it purifies the mind. But for one who has already ascended to knowledge-yoga, that is, who is firmly established in knowledge, the means is śama—quietude, i.e., the cessation of activities which cause distraction of the mind—which leads to the full maturity of knowledge.

6.shlok:
यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते।
सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते।।६.४।।
6.translit:
yadā hi nendriyārtheṣu na karmasv anuṣajjate
sarva-saṅkalpa-saṁnyāsī yogārūḍhas tadocyate
6.translate: When one is not attached either to sense-objects or to actions, and has renounced all desires, then that person is said to be established in yoga.
6.sridhara: What sort of person is that yogārūḍha (one who has attained yoga) for whom śama (quietude) is said to be the means? That is now described: “When indeed…”—when one is not attached to sense-objects, i.e., objects of the senses such as sound and so on, and not attached to actions which are the means to acquire them. The reason for this is: he whose habit is to renounce all saṅkalpa-s—mental constructions—pertaining to sense enjoyments and actions, which are rooted in attachment. Then, such a one is said to be established in yoga.

6.shlok:
उद्धरेदात्मनाऽऽत्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्।
आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः।।६.५।।
6.translit:
uddhared ātmanātmānaṁ nātmānam avasādayet
ātmaiva hy ātmano bandhur ātmaiva ripur ātmanaḥ
6.translate: Let one uplift oneself by the Self; let not one degrade oneself. For the Self alone is one’s friend, and the Self alone is one’s enemy.
6.sridhara: Therefore, having considered that non-attachment to sense-objects leads to liberation, and that attachment leads to bondage, one should abandon the nature of passion and so on. That is stated here: “Let one uplift oneself…” By the self endowed with discrimination, let one lift up the self from saṁsāra. Let one not degrade the self—that is, not lead oneself downward. For, the self—when the mind is withdrawn from worldly contact—is indeed one’s friend, i.e., benefactor. And when the mind is engrossed in worldly association, it is indeed the enemy, i.e., harmful to oneself.

6.shlok:
बन्धुरात्माऽऽत्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः।
अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत्।।६.६।।
6.translit:
bandhur ātmātmanas tasya yenātmaivātmanā jitaḥ
anātmanas tu śatrutve vartetātmaiva śatruvat
6.translate: The self is the friend of the self of him by whom the self has been conquered by the self; but for one who has not conquered the self, the self behaves inimically, like an enemy.
6.sridhara: In response to the question: “For what kind of person is the self a friend? And for what kind is the self an enemy?”—this is explained: “The self is the friend…” For the one by whom the self—consisting of the aggregate of body and senses—has been conquered, that is, brought under control, by his very own self, for such a person, the self is indeed a friend. But for one who is “anātmā,” i.e., one who has not subdued the self, the self becomes like an enemy—it operates with the nature of an enemy, causing harm.

6.shlok:
जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः।
शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः।।६.७।।
6.translit:
jitātmanaḥ praśāntasya paramātmā samāhitaḥ
śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu tathā mānāpamānayoḥ
6.translate: For one who has conquered the self and is tranquil, the Supreme Self is established (in awareness), in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as well as in honor and dishonor.
6.sridhara: The fact that the self is a friend to one who has conquered it is now clearly stated: “For one who has conquered the self…”—that is, for one by whom the self has been conquered, and who is tranquil, i.e., free from passions such as attachment. For such a person alone, the Supreme Self is fixed, i.e., established in the heart—even when cold, heat, and so on are present. Alternatively, it may be interpreted that the Supreme Self is situated (samāhitaḥ) in his heart.

6.shlok:
ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः।
युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः।।६.८।।
6.translit:
jñāna-vijñāna-tṛptātmā kūṭastho vijitendriyaḥ
yukta ity ucyate yogī sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ
6.translate: The yogī who is satisfied in the Self by knowledge and wisdom, who is unchanging, who has conquered the senses, and to whom a clod of earth, stone, and gold are the same—that yogī is said to be united (in yoga).
6.sridhara: Now, having previously stated the marks and excellence of one established in yoga, that is now concluded and substantiated here: “One whose mind is satisfied with knowledge and wisdom…”—jñāna refers to knowledge received through instruction; vijñāna is direct realization. He whose self—i.e., mind—is satisfied and no longer craves, due to these, is said to be tṛpta. Therefore, he is “kūṭastha,” unchanging; and hence, one by whom the senses have been conquered. Therefore, he regards clod, stone, and gold alike—he sees no distinction of rejection or acquisition among them. Such a one is called “yukta,” established in yoga.

6.shlok:
सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु।
साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते।।६.९।।
6.translit:
suhṛn-mitrāryudāsīna-madhyastha-dveṣya-bandhuṣu
sādhuṣv api ca pāpeṣu sama-buddhir viśiṣyate
6.translate: He who has an equal mind toward the well-wisher, friend, enemy, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relative, the righteous, and even the unrighteous—such a one excels.
6.sridhara: The one who has equal-mindedness toward the well-wisher, friend, etc., is said to be superior even among yogīs. How so? “Toward the well-wisher…”—the well-wisher is one who naturally wishes for another’s welfare; the friend is one who helps out of affection; the enemy is a harm-doer; the indifferent is one who is neutral even to disputing parties; the mediator is one who wishes well even to those in conflict; the hateful is one who harbors hostility; the relative is one’s kinsman; the righteous are those of good conduct; the sinners are those of wicked conduct. The one whose intellect is equal, free from passion and hatred, toward all these—is said to be exceptional.

6.shlok:
योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः।
एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः।।६.१०।।
6.translit:
yogī yuñjīta satatam ātmānaṁ rahasi sthitaḥ
ekākī yata-cittātmā nirāśīr aparigrahaḥ
6.translate: Let the yogī constantly engage the self in meditation, staying in seclusion, alone, with mind and body restrained, free from desires and possessions.
6.sridhara: Thus, having stated the characteristics of one established in yoga, now the Lord sets forth the formal method of yoga, beginning with “Let the yogī…”—This instruction is concluded with the statement: “The yogī is superior to all,” later in the chapter. The yogī—i.e., one established in yoga—should constantly engage the mind in meditation on the Self. Residing in solitude, in a secluded place; alone, free from worldly association; with restrained mind and controlled body; without desire—i.e., free from craving—or, alternatively, without dependence on food; and devoid of possession—i.e., free from attachment to acquisitions.

6.shlok:
शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः।
नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम्।।६.११।।
6.translit:
śucau deśe pratiṣṭhāpya sthiram āsanam ātmanaḥ
nātyucchritaṁ nātinīcaṁ cailājinakuśottaram

Simple
6.translate: In a clean place, having established a firm seat for himself, not too high and not too low, made with cloth, a deerskin, and kuśa-grass, one above the other.
6.sridhara: Describing the regulation regarding the seat, he says: “In a clean place…” in two verses. In a pure place, having established a seat for oneself—what kind of seat? Firm, immovable, neither too high nor too low. One in which there is cloth, deerskin (from tiger etc.), and kuśa-grass, arranged one over the other—i.e., with kuśa-grass at the bottom, deerskin above that, and cloth at the top.

6.shlok:
तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः।
उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये।।६.१२।।
6.translit:
tatraikāgraṁ manaḥ kṛtvā yata-cittendriya-kriyaḥ
upaviśyāsane yuñjyād yogaṁ ātma-viśuddhaye

Simple
6.translate: There, having made the mind one-pointed and the activities of the mind and senses controlled, seated on the seat, let him practice yoga for the purification of the self.
6.sridhara: “Tatra”—there, on that seat, seated, making the mind one-pointed (i.e., free from distraction), he should practice yoga. Whose activities of the mind and senses are restrained—i.e., for the purification (viśuddhi) and quietening of the mind.

6.shlok:
समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः।
संप्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन्।।६.१३।।
6.translit:
samaṁ kāya-śiro-grīvaṁ dhārayann acalaṁ sthiraḥ
saṁprekṣya nāsikāgraṁ svaṁ diśaś cānavalokayan

Simple
6.translate: Holding the body, head, and neck erect and still, firm, gazing at the tip of his own nose, without looking in any direction—
6.sridhara: Now showing the regulation of posture conducive to one-pointedness of mind, he says: “With body, head, and neck held straight…”—“kāya” means the middle part of the body. “Kāya-śiraḥ-grīva,” from the base (mūlādhāra) to the crown of the head, should be straight, without bend, and immobile, firmly held. “Sthiraḥ” means with firm effort. Gazing at the tip of his own nose—this implies half-closed eyes. Not glancing here and there in any direction—this continues with the next verse.

6.shlok:
प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः।
मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः।।६.१४।।
6.translit:
praśāntātmā vigata-bhīr brahmacāri-vrate sthitaḥ
manaḥ saṁyamya mac-citto yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ

Simple
6.translate: Serene in mind, fearless, firm in the vow of brahmacarya, having controlled the mind, with Me as the focus of thought, let the yogī sit, intent on Me as the supreme goal.
6.sridhara: “Praśānta-ātmā”—whose mind is tranquil; “vigata-bhīḥ”—free from fear; remaining firm in the vow of brahmacarya (celibacy), having restrained the mind through withdrawal (pratyāhāra); whose mind is fixed in Me alone; for whom I alone am the supreme goal—such a one, being thus integrated (yuktaḥ), let him sit.

6.shlok:
युञ्जन्नेवं सदाऽऽत्मानं योगी नियतमानसः।
शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति।।६.१५।।
6.translit:
yuñjann evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī niyata-mānasaḥ
śāntiṁ nirvāṇa-paramāṁ mat-saṁsthām adhigacchati

Simple
6.translate: Thus always keeping the mind engaged, the yogī with the restrained mind attains peace—supreme liberation—which rests in Me.
6.sridhara: Now he states the result of the practice of yoga: “Thus, constantly (sadaiva) engaging the self”—that is, the mind—in the way described above, making it absorbed; whose mind is restrained, controlled—such a one attains peace, meaning cessation from saṁsāra (worldly bondage). What kind of peace? That which has “nirvāṇa” (liberation) as its culmination, and which is rooted in Me—“mat-saṁsthā,” i.e., existing as My very nature.

6.shlok:
नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः।
न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन।।६.१६।।
6.translit:
nāty-aśnatas tu yogo ’sti na caikāntam anaśnataḥ
na cāti-svapna-śīlasya jāgrato naiva cārjuna

Simple
6.translate: Truly, Yoga is not for one who eats too much, nor for one who does not eat at all; not for one who sleeps excessively, nor for one who is always awake, O Arjuna.
6.sridhara: Here, describing the regulation of food and related habits for one engaged in the practice of yoga, he says, “na iti” in the next two verses. Yoga—meaning meditation—is not possible for one who eats excessively, nor for one who does not eat at all. Similarly, yoga is not possible for one who is excessively addicted to sleep or who is excessively wakeful.

6.shlok:
युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु।
युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा।।६.१७।।
6.translit:
yuktāhāra-vihārasya yukta-ceṣṭasya karmasu
yukta-svapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkha-hā

Simple
6.translate: For one whose food and recreation are regulated, whose efforts in actions are moderate, and whose sleep and wakefulness are balanced—yoga becomes a destroyer of sorrow.
6.sridhara: Then, what kind of person does yoga become successful for? To address this, he says: “yukta iti.” For one whose food (āhāra) and recreation (vihāra)—such as movement—are regulated; whose actions in duties are moderate; whose sleep and waking are also regulated and balanced—for such a person, yoga becomes a destroyer of sorrow and succeeds.

6.shlok:
यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते।
निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा।।६.१८।।
6.translit:
yadā viniyataṁ cittam ātmanyevāvatiṣṭhate
niḥspṛhaḥ sarva-kāmebhyo yukta ity ucyate tadā

Simple
6.translate: When the well-controlled mind rests solely in the Self, free from all desires, then one is said to be “united” (in yoga).
6.sridhara: When does a person become one who has attained yoga? To address this expectation, he says: “yadā.” When the mind, being especially restrained (viniyatam), becomes steady in the Self alone. Moreover, when one becomes free from all desires—for all enjoyments, both worldly and otherworldly—then one is said to be united in yoga.

6.shlok:
यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता।
योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः।।६.१९।।
6.translit:
yathā dīpo nivāta-stho neṅgate sopamā smṛtā
yogino yata-cittasya yuñjato yogam ātmanaḥ

Simple
6.translate: As a lamp placed in a windless place does not flicker, so is said to be the comparison for the yogī whose mind is controlled, practicing yoga in the Self.
6.sridhara: Now he presents a simile for the mind that is absorbed in the Self alone: “yathā.” Just as a lamp situated in a windless place does not flicker—that is the comparison (upamā). Of whom? Of the yogī who practices yoga with regard to the Self, whose mind is disciplined and controlled. His mind remains steady, like the flame—unshaken and luminous, not flickering.

6.shlok:
यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया।
यत्र चैवात्मनाऽऽत्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति।।६.२०।।
6.translit:
yatroparamate cittaṁ niruddhaṁ yoga-sevayā
yatra caivātmanātmānaṁ paśyann ātmani tuṣyati

Simple
6.translate: When the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, becomes still, and when, seeing the self by the self, one is satisfied in the self alone.
6.sridhara:
In the verse “yaṁ sannyāsam iti prāhur yogaṁ taṁ viddhi pāṇḍava” (६.२), the word “yoga” referred to action. But from “nātyaśnataḥ tu yogaḥ asti” (६.१६) onward, “yoga” refers to samādhi. Now, when the question arises, “What is the principal yoga among these?”, he describes and defines samādhi by its nature and result, and states that this alone is the principal yoga. He says: “yatra” through the next three and a half verses.

“Yatra”—in whatever specific state—the mind becomes restrained and ceases through the practice of yoga, that is the definition of yoga by its essential nature. Thus, the Pātañjala sūtra also says: “yogaḥ citta-vṛtti-nirodhaḥ” (Yoga is the cessation of mental modifications). He then defines that same yoga by its result, as marked by the attainment of the desired.

“In which state, with the purified mind (ātmana), one sees the Self (ātmā), and not the body and such”—that is, “sees the Self by the Self”—and becomes satisfied only in the Self, not in external objects. The words “yatra” in this verse and the following ones are connected with the fourth verse, as: “let that state be known as yoga.”

6.shlok:
सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम्।
वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः।।६.२१।।
6.translit:
sukham ātyantikaṁ yat tad buddhi-grāhyam atīndriyam
vetti yatra na caiva ayaṁ sthitaś calati tattvataḥ

Simple
6.translate: Wherein one knows that infinite bliss which is grasped by the intellect and transcends the senses; and wherein, being established, one does not move from the Reality.
6.sridhara:
Now he gives the reason for satisfaction in the Self alone: “sukham iti.” In which specific state, one experiences that which is the highest, unsurpassed (ātyantika), and eternal happiness.

But how can there be happiness at that time when there is no connection between the senses and objects? This he clarifies: “atīndriyam”—it is beyond the contact of sense-objects and senses. It is grasped solely by the intellect (buddhi) when it takes on the form of the Self.

Therefore, being established in that state, one never moves away from the Reality—from the true nature of the Self.

6.shlok:
यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः।
यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते।।६.२२।।
6.translit:
yaṁ labdhvā cāparaṁ lābhaṁ manyate nādhikaṁ tataḥ
yasmin sthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vicālyate

Simple
6.translate: Which, having attained, one does not regard any other gain as superior to it; and being established in it, is not shaken even by great sorrow.
6.sridhara:
Now he substantiates the immovability (steadiness) described earlier: “yam iti.” That gain which is of the nature of bliss in the Self (ātma-sukha-rūpa-lābhaṁ), having attained which, one does not consider any other gain to be superior—because it is of unsurpassed bliss.

And being established in that (state), one is not shaken or overcome even by great sorrows like extreme cold and heat. By this result of the cessation of what is undesirable, too, the characteristics of yoga are to be understood.

6.shlok:
तं विद्याद् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम्।
स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा।।६.२३।।
6.translit:
taṁ vidyād duḥkha-saṁyoga-viyogaṁ yoga-saṁjñitam
sa niścayena yoktavyo yogo ’nirviṇṇa-cetasā

Simple
6.translate: Let that be known as Yoga, the disconnection from the contact with sorrow. This Yoga should be practiced with firm resolve and with an undepressed mind.
6.sridhara:
Now he names that specific state of being described above: “tam” in the first half. The word “duḥkha” includes even the pleasure that is mixed with suffering from sense-objects. The state in which there is separation (viyoga) from the contact (saṁyoga), even the mere touch, of suffering—let that particular state be known as “yoga.”

Yoga is the union of the individual self (kṣetrajña) with the Supreme Self (paramātmā). Alternatively, “yoga” is called the severance from contact with pain, by contrary definition, like calling a brave man a “non-coward” (śūre kātara-śabda-vat).

In the context of action (karma), the word “yoga” is used only in a figurative sense—because such action becomes a means to attain this yoga.

Since this yoga yields such a great result, it alone must be diligently practiced—thus he says, “sa iti” in the second half. That yoga must be practiced with “niścaya”—certainty born of the teachings of scripture and the instructions of the teacher (śāstra-ācārya-upadeśa-janita).

Even if it does not succeed quickly, it must be practiced with a mind that is free from despair (nirviṇṇa-cetasa). Despondency (nirveda) arises when effort becomes slack due to perceiving the practice as suffering.
