6.shlok:
सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः।
मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः।।६.२४।।
6.translit:
saṅkalpa-prabhavān kāmāṁs tyaktvā sarvān aśeṣataḥ
manasaiva indriya-grāmaṁ viniyamya samantataḥ

Simple
6.translate: Abandoning completely all desires born of imagination (saṅkalpa), and restraining entirely the group of senses from all sides by the mind alone.
6.sridhara: Furthermore, he says: “saṅkalpa-prabhavān iti.” Those desires that arise from saṅkalpa (fanciful thought) and which are contrary to yoga—having abandoned all of them completely, along with their latent impressions (vāsanās), and restraining thoroughly the entire group of senses that spread out in all directions, by the mind alone—by such means, yoga is to be practiced. This connects with the previous verse.

6.shlok:
शनैः शनैरुपरमेद् बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया।
आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किञ्चिदपि चिन्तयेत्।।६.२५।।
6.translit:
śanaiḥ śanair uparamed buddhyā dhṛti-gṛhītayā
ātma-saṁsthaṁ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiñcid api cintayet

Simple
6.translate: Little by little, let one withdraw (the mind) by the intellect held with firmness; having made the mind established in the Self, let one not think of anything at all.
6.sridhara:
If, due to latent impressions from past karma, the mind becomes unsettled, then one should steady it through firmness—thus he says: “śanaiḥ śanaiḥ iti.” Firmness (dhṛti) means concentration (dhāraṇā); with such firmness, by intellect that is held steady, having placed the mind firmly in the Self (ātma-saṁstham)—i.e., well-established, unmoving in the Self—let one withdraw (uparamed).

And this should be done gradually, step by step through repeated practice (abhyāsa-krama), not abruptly. He now defines what that state of withdrawal is: “na kiñcid api cintayet”—let him not think of anything whatsoever. When the mind becomes still, one becomes spontaneously manifest as the very form of Supreme Bliss (paramānanda-svarūpa), self-luminous, and does not even turn away from that through meditation on the Self. That is the intended meaning.

6.shlok:
यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम्।
ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत्।।६.२६।।
6.translit:
yato yato niścarati manaś cañcalam asthiram
tatas tato niyamya etad ātmani eva vaśaṁ nayet

Simple
6.translate: From wherever the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, from there let it be restrained and brought under control in the Self alone.
6.sridhara: Even so, if the mind moves due to the force of rajas (the quality of activity), then again, it should be subdued by withdrawal—thus he says: “yato yato.” The mind, by nature, is fickle and unstable—even when being held, it is unsteady. Wherever it goes out toward any object, from there itself, drawing it back, let one make it steady in the Self alone.

6.shlok:
प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम्।
उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम्।।६.२७।।
6.translit:
praśānta-manasaṁ hy enaṁ yoginaṁ sukham uttamam
upaiti śānta-rajasaṁ brahma-bhūtam akalmaṣam

Simple
6.translate: Supreme bliss indeed comes to this Yogi whose mind is peaceful, whose rajas is calmed, who has become Brahman, and is without sin.
6.sridhara: Thus, through repeated control of the mind by withdrawal, when rajas has subsided, one attains the happiness of yoga—so he says: “praśānta-manasam.” By the method described above, one whose rajas is calmed—therefore, whose mind is peaceful—such a one, being sinless and having attained the state of Brahman, this yogin attains the highest bliss, the bliss of samādhi, of its own accord.

6.shlok:
युञ्जन्नेवं सदाऽऽत्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः।
सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते।।६.२८।।
6.translit:
yuñjan evaṁ sadātmānaṁ yogī vigata-kalmaṣaḥ
sukhena brahma-saṁsparśam atyantaṁ sukham aśnute

Simple
6.translate: The Yogi, always uniting the self in this manner, free from impurities, effortlessly attains infinite bliss from contact with Brahman.
6.sridhara: From this, he becomes one who has fulfilled the purpose of life—thus he says: “yuñjan iti.” In this manner, always uniting the self, that is, subduing the mind, and being one whose accumulated impurities have departed, that Yogi effortlessly enjoys the contact with Brahman—that is, the direct realization that removes ignorance. That itself is the supreme bliss, which he attains. The meaning is: he becomes liberated while living (jīvanmuktaḥ).

6.shlok:
सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि।
ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः।।६.२९।।
6.translit:
sarva-bhūta-stham ātmānaṁ sarva-bhūtāni cātmani
īkṣate yoga-yuktātmā sarvatra sama-darśanaḥ

Simple
6.translate: With the mind disciplined by Yoga, one sees the Self dwelling in all beings and all beings dwelling in the Self—such a one sees the same everywhere.
6.sridhara: He now describes the realization of Brahman: “sarva-bhūta-stham iti.” With the mind integrated through Yoga practiced repeatedly, one becomes endowed with sameness of vision (samadarśanaḥ), seeing Brahman alone equally everywhere. He sees his own Self, which is free from the limiting adjuncts of body and so on—produced by ignorance—as abiding in all beings, from Brahmā down to immovable things; and he sees them also as abiding in his own Self, through non-difference.

6.shlok:
यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति।
तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति।।६.३०।।
6.translit:
yo māṁ paśyati sarvatra sarvaṁ ca mayi paśyati
tasyāhaṁ na praṇaśyāmi sa ca me na praṇaśyati

Simple
6.translate: He who sees Me in all things and sees all things in Me—he never becomes lost to Me, nor do I become lost to him.
6.sridhara: That devotion to Me, which arises from such knowledge of the Self as existing in all beings—this is the chief cause (of liberation)—thus he says: “yaḥ mām iti.” He who sees Me, the Supreme Lord, in all—i.e., in every living being—and who sees all beings in Me, I do not become unseen to him; nor does he become unseen to Me. The meaning is: becoming directly manifest, I look upon him with eyes of grace and favor him.

6.shlok:
सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः।
सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते।।६.३१।।
6.translit:
sarvabhūtasthitaṁ yo māṁ bhajaty ekatvam āsthitaḥ
sarvathā vartamāno ’pi sa yogī mayi vartate

Simple
6.translate: He who, being established in oneness, worships Me who dwells in all beings—such a Yogi, though engaged in all ways of life, abides in Me.
6.sridhara: And such a person is not one who becomes bound by rituals—so he says: “sarvabhūtasthitam.” He who, having taken refuge in non-difference, worships Me who dwell in all beings—that Yogi, being a knower, abides in Me alone even while living in every possible manner, including the renunciation of action. He is not fallen—this is the meaning.

6.shlok:
आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन।
सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं स योगी परमो मतः।।६.३२।।
6.translit:
ātmaupamyena sarvatra samaṁ paśyati yo ’rjuna
sukhaṁ vā yadi vā duḥkhaṁ sa yogī paramo mataḥ

Simple
6.translate: He who sees all things equally everywhere, O Arjuna, through the likeness of the Self—whether it be pleasure or pain—that Yogi is considered the highest.
6.sridhara: Thus, among the Yogis who worship Me, the one who is compassionate toward all beings is the best—so he says: “ātmaupamyena.” By the likeness of the self—through similarity to oneself—just as happiness is dear to me and suffering is unpleasant, so too for others: seeing this sameness everywhere, desiring happiness for all and not suffering for anyone—that Yogi is the best, most beloved to Me. This is the meaning.

6.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन।
एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात् स्थितिं स्थिराम्।।६.३३।।
6.translit:
arjuna uvāca
yo ’yaṁ yogas tvayā proktaḥ sāmyena madhusūdana
etasyāhaṁ na paśyāmi cañcalatvāt sthitiṁ sthirām

Simple
6.translate: Arjuna said: O Madhusūdana, this Yoga of equality as taught by You—I do not see a firm stability in it, due to the restlessness of the mind.
6.sridhara: Considering that the Yoga as previously described is not possible, Arjuna said: “yo ’yam iti.” That Yoga taught by You, where the mind remains in a state of equality—free from absorption and distraction, remaining in the form of pure self-awareness alone—that Yoga, I do not see a firm, stable duration for it, due to the restlessness of the mind.

6.shlok:
चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम्।
तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम्।।६.३४।।
6.translit:
cañcalaṁ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavad dṛḍham
tasyāhaṁ nigrahaṁ manye vāyor iva suduṣkaram

Simple
6.translate: Indeed, O Kṛṣṇa, the mind is restless, turbulent, strong, and unyielding; I think its restraint is as difficult as that of the wind.
6.sridhara: He elaborates on this: “cañcalam iti.” The mind is fickle by its very nature. Further, it is pramāthi—of a disruptive nature, meaning it agitates the body and senses. Further, it is balavat—difficult to overcome even by inquiry. Further, it is dṛḍham—firmly attached due to tendencies toward sense-objects, and difficult to penetrate. Therefore, just as it is impossible to restrain the wind moving freely in space within a pot or similar vessel, in the same way I consider the restraint of the mind to be extremely difficult—to be completely impossible to do.

6.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलं।
अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते।।६.३५।।
6.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
asaṁśayaṁ mahābāho mano durnigrahaṁ calam
abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate

Simple
6.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed, the mind is difficult to restrain and restless; but, O son of Kuntī, it is controlled by practice and by dispassion.
6.sridhara: Accepting what you have said about the mind being restless and so on, and stating the means for restraining the mind, the Blessed Lord said: “asaṁśayam iti.” What you said—that due to its restlessness and so on, the mind is impossible to restrain—this is undoubtedly true. Yet, by practice—which is preceded by non-thinking about sense-objects, and involves a mental mode having the form of the Supreme Self—and by dispassion, the mind is restrained. Through practice, absorption is maintained; through dispassion, distraction is blocked. Then the mind becomes steady and transformed into the form of the Supreme Self. The Yoga Scripture also says: “The state of the mind devoid of all mental functions, abiding as Brahman alone—that is known as saṁprajñāta-samādhi.”

6.shlok:
असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः।
वश्यात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः।।६.३६।।
6.translit:
asaṁyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti me matiḥ
vaśyātmanā tu yatatā śakyo ’vāptum upāyataḥ

Simple
6.translate: Yoga, in my view, is hard to attain by one of uncontrolled mind; but it can be attained by one who has self-mastery and strives through proper means.
6.sridhara: Now, this much is the established conclusion—so he says: “asaṁyatātmaneti.” Yoga is hard to attain—i.e., it is not possible to attain—for one whose mind is unrestrained, whose mind is not governed through the previously described means of practice and dispassion. But for one whose mind is restrained—i.e., governed through practice and dispassion—and who also puts in effort by this very means, for him, Yoga is attainable.

6.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः।
अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति।।६.३७।।
6.translit:
arjuna uvāca
ayatiḥ śraddhayopeto yogāc calita-mānasaḥ
aprāpya yoga-saṁsiddhiṁ kāṁ gatiṁ kṛṣṇa gacchati

Simple
6.translate: Arjuna said: One who, though endowed with faith, is lacking in effort, and whose mind has strayed from Yoga—without attaining perfection in Yoga, what path does he go to, O Kṛṣṇa?
6.sridhara: What is the fruit attained by one who, due to lack of practice and dispassion, has not gained perfect knowledge? Arjuna asks: “ayatiḥ iti.” At first, he has faith and has undertaken Yoga—not hypocritically. Then, due to being ayatiḥ—not putting in adequate effort, i.e., his practice has become slack. And his mind has strayed from Yoga, i.e., his mind is inclined toward objects—meaning his dispassion is weak. Thus, due to slackness in practice and dispassion, he has not attained perfection in Yoga—i.e., knowledge. What path does he attain?

6.shlok:
कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति।
अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि।।६.३८।।
6.translit:
kaccin nobhaya-vibhraṣṭaś chinnābhram iva naśyati
apratiṣṭho mahābāho vimūḍho brahmaṇaḥ pathi

Simple
6.translate: O mighty-armed, fallen from both, does he not perish like a torn cloud—unsupported, deluded on the path to Brahman?
6.sridhara: He explains the intent of the question: “kaccid iti.” Because his actions were offered to God, and because he did not complete them, he does not attain the fruit of karma, such as heaven. And because he did not perfect Yoga, he does not attain liberation either. Thus, having fallen from both, he becomes unsupported—without foundation. Because of this, he becomes deluded on the path leading to Brahman. Does he not perish? Or does he perish? This is the question. For the idea of perishing, a simile is given: just as a cloud separated from the larger mass and not having reached another becomes dissolved midair—so it is here as well.

6.shlok:
एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः।
त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते।।६.३९।।
6.translit:
etan me saṁśayaṁ kṛṣṇa chettum arhasy aśeṣataḥ
tvad anyaḥ saṁśayasya asya chettā na hy upapadyate

Simple
6.translate: This doubt of mine, O Kṛṣṇa, do You completely dispel; for none but You is fit to dispel this doubt.
6.sridhara: This doubt of mine must be dispelled by You, who are omniscient. No one other than You can remove this doubt—so he says: “etan me iti.” Etan means enam—this [doubt

6.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते।
नहि कल्याणकृत्कश्िचद्दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति।।६.४०।।
6.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
pārtha naiveha nāmutra vināśas tasya vidyate
na hi kalyāṇa-kṛt kaścid durgatiṁ tāta gacchati

Simple
6.translate: The Blessed Lord said: O Pārtha, there is no destruction for him either here or hereafter; for no doer of good, My dear one, ever comes to misfortune.
6.sridhara: Now, in response, the Blessed Lord said: “pārtha” and so on, in four halves. In this world, there is no vināśa—falling due to having abandoned both [paths

6.shlok:
प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोकानुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः।
शुचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते।।६.४१।।
6.translit:
prāpya puṇya-kṛtāṁ lokān uṣitvā śāśvatīḥ samāḥ
śucīnāṁ śrīmatāṁ gehe yoga-bhraṣṭo ’bhijāyate

Simple
6.translate: Having attained the worlds of the righteous and dwelt there for many ages, one who fell from Yoga is born in a pure and prosperous household.
6.sridhara: Then, what does he attain? In anticipation of this, he says: “prāpya iti.” Having attained the worlds of the virtuous performers of meritorious acts, such as those who have performed aśvamedha sacrifices, and having lived there for many years (śāśvatīḥ samāḥ), experiencing the pleasures of heavenly residence, the one who fell from Yoga is born in the house of pure ones—those of good conduct—and of the wealthy.

6.shlok:
अथवा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम्।
एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम्।।६.४२।।
6.translit:
athavā yoginām eva kule bhavati dhīmatām
etad dhi durlabhataraṁ loke janma yad īdṛśam

Simple
6.translate: Or else, he is born in the family of wise Yogis only; verily, such a birth as this is very hard to obtain in this world.
6.sridhara: In the case of one who fell after a short time of practice, the previous verse described the result. Now, in the case of one who fell after long-continued practice, another alternative is stated: “athavā iti.” He is born in the family of Yogins alone—of wise ones, knowers of the Self—not in the families previously described, which are not firmly established in Yoga. He praises this birth: a birth such as this is exceedingly rare in this world, because it is a cause of liberation.

6.shlok:
तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम्।
यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन।।६.४३।।
6.translit:
tatra taṁ buddhi-saṁyogaṁ labhate paurva-dehikam
yatate ca tato bhūyaḥ saṁsiddhau kuru-nandana

Simple
6.translate: There, he attains the connection with the intellect from the previous body, and from there again he strives for perfection, O son of the Kurus.
6.sridhara: Then what? He says: “tatra iti” in this half verse. There, in either of the two types of birth, he attains the same union with the intellect regarding Brahman which existed in the previous body. And from that point onward, he again makes effort for perfection in liberation (saṁsiddhau mokṣe).

6.shlok:
पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः।
जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते।।६.४४।।
6.translit:
pūrvābhyāsena tenaiva hriyate hy avaśo ’pi saḥ
jijñāsur api yogasya śabda-brahmātivartate

Simple
6.translate: By that very former practice, he is carried forward even involuntarily; even the mere seeker of Yoga transcends the sacred word of the Vedas.
6.sridhara: The reason for that is given: “pūrva iti.” By that very practice done in the previous body, even though he is avaśaḥ—not intentionally desiring it due to some obstacle—he is impelled. He is turned away from the objects and made steadfast in Brahman. Thus, due to the force of previous practice, even while continuing to exert effort, he is gradually liberated. To make this meaning clearer by the method of implication (kaimutya nyāya), he states: “jijñāsuḥ iti” with the next half. Even one who is merely a seeker of the true nature of Yoga—not yet having attained Yoga—even if he falls due to sin, he transcends the śabda-brahman—i.e., he goes beyond the fruits of actions prescribed in the Vedas. He attains a result greater than those, and is liberated—this is the meaning.

6.shlok:
प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः।
अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम्।।६.४५।।
6.translit:
prayatnād yatamānas tu yogī saṁśuddha-kilbiṣaḥ
aneka-janma-saṁsiddhas tato yāti parāṁ gatim

Simple
6.translate: But the Yogi who strives with effort, having been purified of sins and perfected over many births, then attains the highest goal.
6.sridhara: If even a Yogi of weak effort attains the highest goal, then what need is there to speak of a Yogi who, striving earnestly with increasing vigor in Yoga, becomes purified of sins by Yoga alone? Such a person, having been perfected through Yoga accumulated over many births, becomes a knower of the Self, and then attains the supreme goal—what more needs to be said?

6.shlok:
तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः।
कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन।।६.४६।।
6.translit:
tapasvibhyo ’dhiko yogī jñānibhyo ’pi mato ’dhikaḥ
karmibhyaś cādhiko yogī tasmād yogī bhavārjuna

Simple
6.translate: The Yogi is superior to ascetics, he is considered greater than even the men of knowledge; and he is also superior to those engaged in action. Therefore, become a Yogi, O Arjuna.
6.sridhara: Since this is so, therefore: “tapasvibhyaḥ iti.” The Yogi is superior even to those devoted to austerities such as kṛcchra and cāndrāyaṇa; he is superior to those who are knowers—possessors of scriptural knowledge; and also to those who are performers of action, engaged in works such as iṣṭā-pūrta (rituals and charitable acts). Therefore, you become a Yogi.

6.shlok:
योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना।
श्रद्धावान्भजते यो मां स मे युक्ततमो मतः।।६.४७।।
6.translit:
yoginām api sarveṣāṁ mad-gatenāntar-ātmanā
śraddhāvān bhajate yo māṁ sa me yukta-tamo mataḥ

Simple
6.translate: And among all the Yogis, the one who worships Me with inner self absorbed in Me and with faith—he is considered by Me to be the most united (Yogi).
6.sridhara: Among all Yogis—those engaged in yama, niyama, and so on—My devotee is the highest. He says: “yoginām iti.” The one whose inner self (mind) is absorbed in Me (mad-gatena antar-ātmanā), who is endowed with faith, and who worships Me—Vāsudeva, the Supreme Lord—that Yogi is the best among those established in Yoga, and is regarded by Me as such. Therefore, one should become My devotee—this is the purport.

7.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
मय्यासक्तमनाः पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रयः।
असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु।।७.१।।
7.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
mayy āsakta-manāḥ pārtha yogaṁ yuñjan mad-āśrayaḥ
asaṁśayaṁ samagraṁ māṁ yathā jñāsyasi tac chṛṇu
7.translate: The Blessed Lord said: O Pārtha, with your mind attached to Me, practicing Yoga, taking refuge in Me—hear how you will know Me fully and without doubt.
7.sridhara:
The nature of the Self, which is to be known, along with Yoga, has been explained. Now, the form of the Lord, which is to be worshipped, is being stated.
At the end of the previous chapter, it was said: “He who worships Me with the inner self merged in Me, he is considered the most accomplished yogi.”
There, to clarify “what kind of person should offer that devotion?” and intending to explain His own essential nature, the Blessed Lord speaks: mayy āsakta-manāḥ—he whose mind is attached to Me, the Supreme Lord, in the sense of being fully absorbed; mad-āśrayaḥ—one for whom I alone am the refuge, having no other shelter; yogaṁ yuñjan—practicing Yoga;
in this manner, asaṁśayaṁ samagram—without any doubt and in full, endowed with glories, power, lordship, and so on—māṁ yathā jñāsyasi—how you will know Me, that which is now going to be spoken by Me, tac chṛṇu—hear it.

7.shlok:
ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः।
यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते।।७.२।।
7.translit:
jñānaṁ te ’haṁ sa-vijñānam idaṁ vakṣyāmy aśeṣataḥ
yaj jñātvā neha bhūyo ’nyaj jñātavyam avaśiṣyate
7.translate: I shall declare to you in full this knowledge along with realization, after knowing which nothing else remains to be known in this world.
7.sridhara:
He praises the knowledge that is going to be spoken by saying: jñānam iti—“knowledge.”
Jñāna is scriptural knowledge, and vijñāna is realization, direct experience—together with that.
Idam—this (knowledge) concerning Me, I will explain aśeṣataḥ—completely, in its entirety.
By knowing which, for one who abides on the path of liberation, na bhūyaḥ anyat jñātavyam avaśiṣyate—there does not remain any other thing to be known.
Therefore, one becomes fulfilled (kṛtārtha) by that alone—this is the meaning.

7.shlok:
मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्चिद्यतति सिद्धये।
यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्चिन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वतः।।७.३।।
7.translit:
manuṣyāṇāṁ sahasreṣu kaścid yatati siddhaye
yatatām api siddhānāṁ kaścin māṁ vetti tattvataḥ
7.translate: Among thousands of men, one strives for perfection; even among those striving and perfected, one knows Me in truth.
7.sridhara:
He says that knowledge of Me is difficult to attain without devotion to Me: manuṣyāṇām iti.
Among the countless living beings, except for humans, there is no engagement in the pursuit of liberation at all.
But among humans, sahasreṣu—out of thousands, only kaścit—one, due to highly auspicious merits, strives for perfection—meaning, for knowledge of the Self.
Even among those who strive, only kaścit—one, again due to exceptional merit, comes to know the Self.
And among thousands of such perfected knowers of the Self, only kaścit eva—one, by My grace, knows Me, the Supreme Self, tattvataḥ—in truth.
Therefore, though such knowledge of Me is extremely rare, still I will now speak it to you—this is the meaning.

7.shlok:
भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च।
अहङ्कार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा।।७.४।।
7.translit:
bhūmir āpo ’nalo vāyuḥ khaṁ mano buddhir eva ca
ahaṅkāra iti iyaṁ me bhinnā prakṛtir aṣṭadhā
7.translate: Earth, water, fire, air, space, mind, intellect, and ego—this is My nature divided eightfold.
7.sridhara:
Now, turning directly toward the listener, intending to describe the nature of the Supreme Lord as the cause of creation and so on, through prakṛti (nature), which He has proposed, He speaks of the twofold division of prakṛti, into higher and lower: bhūmir iti, in two verses.
The words bhūmi-ādi refer to the five subtle elements (tanmātras) such as smell, etc.
Manas refers to its cause, ahaṅkāra (ego), and buddhi refers to its cause, mahat-tattva (cosmic intellect).
Ahaṅkāra itself refers to its cause, avidyā (ignorance).
In this way, there is a division into eight.
Or, bhūmi-ādi may refer to the five great elements (mahābhūtas), taken together with their subtle counterparts.
Ahaṅkāra refers directly to ego, and thereby also includes its products—indriyas (sense organs).
Buddhi is mahat-tattva, and manas refers to the unmanifest pradhāna, which is inferred by the mind and is formless.
In this way, Me prakṛtiḥ, My nature, which is called māyā, is said to be divided into eightfold forms.
Although it is usually said to be twenty-fourfold, the sixteen other categories are considered included within these eight, and so it is said to be aṣṭadhā bhinnā—divided eightfold.
Indeed, in the upcoming chapter on the kṣetra (the field), the very same prakṛti will be elaborated as consisting of twenty-four categories:
“mahābhūtāny ahaṅkāro buddhir avyaktam eva ca, indriyāṇi daśaikam ca pañca cendriya-go-carāḥ” (Gītā १३.६–७).

7.shlok:
अपरेयमितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम्।
जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत्।।७.५।।
7.translit:
apareyam itas tv anyāṁ prakṛtiṁ viddhi me parām
jīva-bhūtāṁ mahā-bāho yayedaṁ dhāryate jagat
7.translate: This is My lower nature. But know that, distinct from it, O mighty-armed, is My higher nature—life-forming and conscious—by which this world is sustained.
7.sridhara:
Having concluded the lower prakṛti, He now speaks of the higher prakṛti: apareyam iti.
This prakṛti, which was mentioned as eightfold, is aparā—lower, due to being inert and existing for the sake of another.
Itaḥ sakāśāt—distinct from this, parām—superior, anyām—another, jīva-svarūpām—having the nature of the individual soul, me prakṛtiṁ viddhi—know it as My nature.
The reason it is superior: yayā—by which consciousness, which is the knower of the field (kṣetrajña), idaṁ jagat dhāryate—this world is upheld through its own action.

7.shlok:
एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणीत्युपधारय।
अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगतः प्रभवः प्रलयस्तथा।।७.६।।
7.translit:
etad-yonīni bhūtāni sarvāṇīty upadhāraya
ahaṁ kṛtsnasya jagataḥ prabhavaḥ pralayas tathā
7.translate: Understand that all beings have these (two natures) as their source. I am the origin and also the dissolution of the whole universe.
7.sridhara:
Having shown that these two (prakṛtis) are His own nature, He now states His role as the cause of creation, etc., through them: etad iti.
These two—prakṛtis in the form of the field and the knower of the field—are the source (yonī) of all beings.
All beings—both mobile and immobile—are born of them, hence they are to be understood as etad-yonīni.
Among them, the inert prakṛti transforms into the form of the body. The conscious prakṛti, being a part of Me, enters into bodies as the enjoyer and, through its own karma, upholds them.
And both of these prakṛtis arise from Me.
Therefore, I alone am the prabhavaḥ—the origination—of the entire universe endowed with both forms of prakṛti. That is, I am the supreme cause.
And likewise, I am the pralayaḥ—the dissolution—since all things dissolve into Me. That is the meaning.

7.shlok:
मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय।
मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव।।७.७।।
7.translit:
mattaḥ parataraṁ nānyat kiñcid asti dhanañjaya
mayi sarvam idaṁ protaṁ sūtre maṇi-gaṇā iva
7.translate: There is nothing whatsoever higher than Me, O Dhanañjaya. All this is strung on Me like clusters of pearls on a thread.
7.sridhara:
Because this is so, therefore: mattaḥ.
From Me, there is nothing higher or greater, no independent cause of creation and dissolution of the universe.
I alone am the cause even for its continuance—this is said by: mayi.
Mayi sarvam idaṁ jagat protaṁ—all this world is strung, joined, and supported in Me.
The example is clear: just as pearls are strung on a thread.

7.shlok:
रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययोः।
प्रणवः सर्ववेदेषु शब्दः खे पौरुषं नृषु।।७.८।।
7.translit:
raso ’ham apsu kaunteya prabhāsmi śaśi-sūryayoḥ
praṇavaḥ sarva-vedeṣu śabdaḥ khe pauruṣaṁ nṛṣu
7.translate: I am the taste in water, O Kaunteya; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, the sound in space, and manliness in men.
7.sridhara:
He now elaborates His being the cause of the universe’s continuance:
raso ’ham iti—I am the taste in water. Through the glory (vibhūti) in the form of the subtle element of taste, I exist in water as its basis—that is the meaning.
Likewise, prabhā (radiance) in the moon and the sun—I am that. Through the radiance which is their support, I exist in the moon and sun.
Similarly, for what follows.
In all the Vedas, as uttered speech, I am praṇava (Om), the primordial syllable which is their basis.
In kha (space), I am śabda-tanmātra (the subtle element of sound).
In men, I am pauruṣam—effort or initiative. Indeed, by effort men are sustained.

7.shlok:
पुण्यो गन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ।
जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु।।७.९।।
7.translit:
puṇyo gandhaḥ pṛthivyāṁ ca tejaś cāsmi vibhāvasau
jīvanaṁ sarva-bhūteṣu tapaś cāsmi tapasviṣu
7.translate: I am the pure fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in fire. I am life in all beings, and I am austerity in the austere.
7.sridhara:
Furthermore: puṇyaḥ—the pure, unmodified fragrance; gandha-tanmātra, which is the support in earth—I am that.
Alternatively, since the intended meaning is My presence as the substratum through My glories (vibhūtis), and since only the fragrant scent is considered excellent as a vibhūti, therefore He says puṇyo gandhaḥ.
Similarly, in vibhāvasu (fire), the tejas—the natural brilliance—I am that.
In all beings, jīvanam—the vital force, the sustaining life or lifespan—I am that.
In ascetics, such as forest-dwelling hermits, I am tapas—the austerity in the form of endurance of dualities.

7.shlok:
बीजं मां सर्वभूतानां विद्धि पार्थ सनातनम्।
बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम्।।७.१०।।
7.translit:
bījaṁ māṁ sarva-bhūtānāṁ viddhi pārtha sanātanam
buddhir buddhimatām asmi tejas tejasvinām aham
7.translate: Know Me, O Pārtha, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent and the power of the powerful.
7.sridhara:
Moreover: bījam iti—Of all beings, both mobile and immobile, the bīja (seed), which is the capacity to produce similar effects in its own kind, which is eternal and pervades all succeeding manifestations—know that as My vibhūti.
It is not perishable with each individual.
Also, buddhir buddhimatām—I am the intelligence of the intelligent; tejas tejasvinām—I am the brilliance or boldness of the bold.

7.shlok:
बलं बलवतां चाहं कामरागविवर्जितम्।
धर्माविरुद्धो भूतेषु कामोऽस्मि भरतर्षभ।।७.११।।
7.translit:
balaṁ balavatāṁ cāhaṁ kāma-rāga-vivarjitam
dharmāviruddho bhūteṣu kāmo ’smi bharatarṣabha
7.translate: Of the strong, I am the strength that is free from desire and attachment. In beings, I am the desire that is not opposed to Dharma, O best of the Bhāratas.
7.sridhara:
Further: balaṁ iti.
Kāma is the desire for something not yet obtained—this is rājasika; rāga, attachment to an already obtained object and desire for more, which delights the mind, is synonymous with craving and is tāmasika.
I am the bala—the strength—of the strong, devoid of these two.
This strength is sāttvika, the capability for the performance of one’s own duty (svadharma)—that is the meaning.
I am the desire for union with one’s own wife that is not opposed to Dharma and is only for the sake of begetting progeny.

7.shlok:
ये चैव सात्त्विका भावाः राजसास्तामसाश्च ये।
मत्त एवेति तान्विद्धि न त्वहं तेषु ते मयि।।७.१२।।
7.translit:
ye caiva sāttvikā bhāvā rājasās tāmasāś ca ye
matta eveti tān viddhi na tv ahaṁ teṣu te mayi
7.translate: Whatever states arise from sattva, rajas, or tamas—know them all as being from Me alone. But I am not in them—they are in Me.
7.sridhara:
Further: ye ca iti.
Whatever other sāttvika bhāvas, such as calmness and self-restraint; rājasika, such as anger and pride; and tāmasika, such as grief and delusion—arise in beings as a result of their own karma—know all of them to have arisen from Me alone.
Because they are effects of the three guṇas of My own prakṛti.
Even so, I am not in them—meaning, I do not depend on them like the jīva.
Rather, they depend on Me and exist in Me—that is the meaning.

7.shlok:
त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत्।
मोहितं नाभिजानाति मामेभ्यः परमव्ययम्।।७.१३।।
7.translit:
tribhir guṇa-mayair bhāvair ebhiḥ sarvam idaṁ jagat
mohitaṁ nābhijānāti mām ebhyaḥ param avyayam
7.translate: Deluded by these states composed of the three guṇas, this whole world does not know Me, who am beyond them and immutable.
7.sridhara:
Why does the world not know You as the Supreme Lord? That is now said: tribhir iti.
By these threefold states composed of the guṇas—such as desire and greed, which are modifications of the guṇas—this world is deluded.
Therefore, it does not know Me.
How am I? I am beyond these states.
I am unsullied by them. I am their controller, and thus I am immutable, that is, changeless.

7.shlok:
दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया।
मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते।।७.१४।।
7.translit:
daivī hy eṣā guṇa-mayī mama māyā duratyayā
mām eva ye prapadyante māyām etāṁ taranti te
7.translate: Indeed, this divine illusion of Mine, made of the guṇas, is difficult to cross. But those who take refuge in Me alone— they cross over this illusion.
7.sridhara:
Who, then, truly knows You? That is now said: daivī hi.
This daivī (divine), meaning extraordinary, guṇa-mayī, consisting of the transformations of sattva and the other guṇas, is My māyā—the power of the Supreme Lord.
It is duratyayā—hard to cross. Indeed, this is well known.
Even so, those who take refuge in Me alone—with the word eva indicating unwavering devotion—prapadyante, surrender to Me.
They alone cross over this difficult-to-cross illusion.
Therefore, they come to know Me—this is the intended meaning.

7.shlok:
न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः।
माययापहृतज्ञाना āsuraṁ bhāvam āśritāḥ।।७.१५।।
7.translit:
na māṁ duṣkṛtino mūḍhāḥ prapadyante narādhamāḥ
māyayāpahṛta-jñānā āsuraṁ bhāvam āśritāḥ
7.translate: The evildoers, the deluded, the lowest among men—those whose knowledge is taken away by māyā and who are of demoniacal nature—they do not surrender to Me.
7.sridhara:
Why, then, do not all worship You alone? That is said: na mām.
Those who are the lowest among men do not surrender to Me, do not worship Me.
The cause of their lowliness is that they are mūḍhāḥ—undiscerning, lacking in discrimination.
Why? Because they are duṣkṛtinaḥ—given to sinful actions.
Therefore, their knowledge—though it may have arisen from scripture or a teacher—is taken away, destroyed by māyā.
And thus, they have taken shelter in the āsura bhāva—a nature characterized by hypocrisy, arrogance, pride, anger, harshness, etc., as will be described.
Such people do not worship Me.

7.shlok:
चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन।
आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानी च भरतर्षभ।।७.१६।।
7.translit:
caturvidhā bhajante māṁ janāḥ sukṛtino ’rjuna
ārto jijñāsur arthārthī jñānī ca bharatarṣabha
7.translate: Four kinds of people of virtuous deeds worship Me, O Arjuna: the distressed, the seeker of knowledge, the seeker of wealth, and the wise—O best of the Bhāratas.
7.sridhara:
The virtuous alone worship Me. And even among them, according to the gradation in merit, they are of four kinds—that is being stated: caturvidhā iti.
Those people who have performed meritorious deeds in previous births worship Me. They are of four kinds:

Ārtaḥ — the one afflicted by disease or other miseries. If he has merit from past lives, then he worships Me. Otherwise, he resorts to the worship of lesser deities. The same should be understood for the others as well.

Jijñāsuḥ — the one who desires knowledge of the Self.

Arthārthī — one who desires wealth or the means of enjoyment, either here or in the next world.

Jñānī — the knower of the Self.

7.shlok:
तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्तिर्विशिष्यते।
प्रियो हि ज्ञानिनोऽत्यर्थमहं स च मम प्रियः।।७.१७।।
7.translit:
teṣāṁ jñānī nitya-yukta eka-bhaktir viśiṣyate
priyo hi jñānino ’tyarthaṁ ahaṁ sa ca mama priyaḥ
7.translate: Among them, the wise one who is ever steadfast and devoted to the One excels; for I am very dear to the wise, and he is dear to Me.
7.sridhara:
Among these, the wise is the highest—that is being stated: teṣām iti.
Among them, the jñānī is distinguished. The reasons are:
He is nitya-yuktaḥ—always devoted to Me; and eka-bhaktiḥ—one whose devotion is fixed on Me alone.
Because he is devoid of identification with body and so on, the wise one is free from mental distractions and thus can be always united with Me and devoted exclusively to Me—this is possible only for the wise and not for others.
Therefore, I am exceedingly dear to him, and he is dear to Me.
Thus, due to these four causes—eternal devotion, exclusive devotion, freedom from distraction, and dearness to Me—he is supreme among them.

7.shlok:
उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम्।
आस्थितः स हि युक्तात्मा मामेवानुत्तमां गतिम्।।७.१८।।
7.translit:
udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tv ātmaiva me matam
āsthitaḥ sa hi yuktātmā mām evānuttamāṁ gatim
7.translate: All these indeed are noble, but the wise one is considered by Me as My very Self; for he, with a disciplined mind, has taken refuge in Me alone as the highest goal.
7.sridhara:
Then, do the other three not attain liberation? No—it is not so. Hence, He says: udārāḥ iti.
All of them are indeed udārāḥ—noble, magnanimous. The meaning is: they are all eligible for liberation.
But the jñānī—the knower—is considered to be My very self—this is My opinion.
Why? Because he is yukta-ātmā—his mind is united with Me alone.
He has taken refuge in Me alone, the anuttamā gati—the unsurpassable, highest goal.
That is, he does not consider any result apart from Me.

7.shlok:
बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते।
वासुदेवः सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभः।।७.१९।।
7.translit:
bahūnāṁ janmanām ante jñānavān māṁ prapadyate
vāsudevaḥ sarvam iti sa mahātmā su-durlabhaḥ
7.translate: At the end of many births, the one endowed with knowledge surrenders to Me, knowing “Vāsudeva is all”; such a great soul is very rare.
7.sridhara:
Such a devotee of Mine is extremely rare—this is being said: bahūnām iti.
After many births, and the gradual accumulation of merit, in the final birth, the one who possesses knowledge, seeing everything—both moving and unmoving—as Vāsudeva alone through the vision of the Self in all, surrenders to Me.
Therefore, such a great soul, whose vision is unbounded, is very rare.

7.shlok:
कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः।
तं तं नियममास्थाय प्रकृत्या नियताः स्वया।।७.२०।।
7.translit:
kāmais tais tair hṛta-jñānāḥ prapadyante anya-devatāḥ
taṁ taṁ niyamam āsthāya prakṛtyā niyatāḥ svayā
7.translate: Those whose knowledge has been carried away by various desires surrender to other deities, following particular disciplines, being constrained by their own nature.
7.sridhara:
So far, it was stated that even those with desires worship Me, and upon attaining those desires, they gradually get liberated.
Now it is said: those who are excessively dominated by desire and immersed in rajas and tamas, worship lesser deities and remain in saṁsāra—this is stated in four verses, beginning with kāmaiḥ iti.
Those whose discrimination is overpowered by various desires—such as desire for sons, fame, victory over enemies—they worship lesser deities such as bhūtas, pretas, yakṣas.
How? Following the specific observances (niyama) such as fasting and other rituals associated with each deity.
And even in that, due to their own nature, driven by impressions from previous practice (vāsanā) and habit, they are led to worship particular deities.

7.shlok:
यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति।
तस्य तस्याचलां श्रद्धां तामेव विदधाम्यहम्।।७.२१।।
7.translit:
yo yo yāṁ yāṁ tanuṁ bhaktaḥ śraddhayārcitum icchati
tasya tasya acalāṁ śraddhāṁ tām eva vidadhāmy aham
7.translate: Whatever form a devotee desires to worship with faith, to that very form I make his faith firm and steady.
7.sridhara: Among them, whoever the devotee is who desires to worship whichever form—that is, a deity-form, which is truly none other than a form of Mine—with faith, that particular faith related to that particular form, I Myself, as the indwelling Self (antar-yāmin), make firm and unwavering.

7.shlok:
स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते।
लभते च ततः कामान्मयैव विहितान् हि तान्।।७.२२।।
7.translit:
sa tayā śraddhayā yuktaḥ tasyārādhanam īhate
labhate ca tataḥ kāmān mayā eva vihitān hi tān
7.translate: Endowed with that faith, he seeks to worship that form, and from it he obtains his desires—those very desires being indeed granted by Me.
7.sridhara: Then, that devotee, endowed with that firm faith, performs the worship of that particular deity. And from that deity he obtains the desired objects he had resolved upon. However, even those objects are granted by Me alone, who am the indwelling Self of those deities. This is evident, because even those deities are under My control, and since I am their very essence (mūrtitva), therefore they are subordinate to Me.

7.shlok:
अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम्।
देवान्देवयजो यान्ति मद्भक्ता यान्ति मामपि।।७.२३।।
7.translit:
antavat tu phalaṁ teṣāṁ tad bhavaty alpa-medhasām
devān deva-yajo yānti mad-bhaktā yānti mām api
7.translate: But the fruit of those people of limited understanding is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to the gods, but My devotees come to Me.
7.sridhara: Although all the deities are indeed My own forms, and therefore their worship is, in essence, My worship, and I alone am the giver of those respective results—still, there is a difference in the fruit for My direct devotees and those others. This is being said: “antavat tu.” The result given even by Me to those of limited understanding, who have a restricted vision, is perishable. Hence it is said: “the worshippers of the gods go to the gods”—that is, to the perishable. But My devotees attain Me, who am beginningless and endless, the supreme bliss.

7.shlok:
अव्यक्तं व्यक्तिमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः।
परं भावमजानन्तो ममाव्ययमनुत्तमम्।।७.२४।।
7.translit:
avyaktaṁ vyaktim āpannaṁ manyante mām abuddhayaḥ
paraṁ bhāvam ajānanto mama avyayam anuttamam
7.translate: The undiscerning think of Me—the Unmanifest—as having assumed manifestation, not knowing My higher, immutable, unsurpassed nature.
7.sridhara: Now, one might ask: “When the effort is the same, and the difference in result is great, why then do not all people abandon other deities and worship only You?” To address this, He says: avyaktam—Me, who am beyond all phenomena—they think has become vyakti (manifest), i.e., as a human, or as a fish, tortoise, etc. These people of little understanding (abuddhayaḥ) think in this way. The reason is given: they do not know My paraṁ bhāvam—My essential nature. What kind of nature? avyayam—eternal; anuttamam—than which there is none greater. Therefore, seeing Me, the Supreme Lord—whose forms, taken up for the protection of the world, are freely manifested with pure, powerful sattva—they regard Me as having a physical, karma-produced body, and as being equal to other deities. These people of dull intellect do not highly esteem Me. Rather, they worship other deities for immediate results, and thereby, as previously described, attain perishable fruit.

7.shlok:
नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः।
मूढोऽयं नाभिजानाति लोको मामजमव्ययम्।।७.२५।।
7.translit:
nāhaṁ prakāśaḥ sarvasya yoga-māyā-samāvṛtaḥ
mūḍho ’yaṁ nābhijānāti loko mām ajam avyayam
7.translate: I am not manifest to all, being veiled by Yoga-Māyā; this deluded world does not know Me, the unborn and imperishable.
7.sridhara: Now the cause for their ignorance is stated: nāhaṁ prakāśaḥ—I do not become manifest to everyone in the world, but only to My devotees. Why? Because I am covered by Yoga-Māyā. Yoga means extraordinary power or inconceivable display of intelligence, and that itself is Māyā—the skill of doing the impossible. Hidden by this, the deluded world does not know Me. And thus, being ignorant of My true nature, this deluded world does not know Me—who am unborn and imperishable.

7.shlok:
वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन।
भविष्याणि च भूतानि मां तु वेद न कश्चन।।७.२६।।
7.translit:
vedāhaṁ samatītāni vartamānāni cārjuna
bhaviṣyāṇi ca bhūtāni māṁ tu veda na kaścana
7.translate: I know, O Arjuna, all beings of the past, present, and future; but no one knows Me.
7.sridhara: It was said that My supreme nature is unknown to all. That very supremacy of Mine, as being endowed with unobstructed knowledge and power, is now shown while simultaneously indicating the ignorance of others: vedāham—I know; samatītāni—the past; vartamānāni—the present; bhaviṣyāṇi—the future; bhūtāni—all beings, both mobile and immobile. I know them all, because I am established in Māyā, and Māyā has no capacity to delude Me, its source. But māṁ tu—Me, no one knows, because they are deluded by My Māyā. It is well-known that Māyā depends on Me for its support and functions only as a deluding power for others, not for Me.

7.shlok:
इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत।
सर्वभूतानि संमोहं सर्गे यान्ति परन्तप।।७.२७।।
7.translit:
icchādveṣa-samutthena dvandva-mohena bhārata
sarva-bhūtāni saṁmohaṁ sarge yānti parantapa
7.translate: O Bhārata, by the delusion of dualities arising from desire and aversion, all beings fall into delusion at birth, O scorcher of foes.
7.sridhara: Thus, it was stated that beings, due to association with Māyā, are ignorant of the Supreme Lord. The cause for the firmness of this ignorance is now stated: ichchhā-dveṣa-samutthena—arising from desire and aversion, which begin upon the appearance of a gross body. One develops desire for what is favorable and aversion for what is unfavorable. From these arises delusion (moha), a loss of discrimination, caused by dualities like heat and cold, pleasure and pain, etc. By that delusion, sarva-bhūtāni—all beings fall into saṁmohaṁ—deep confusion, identifying with notions such as “I am happy” or “I am unhappy.” As a result, due to absence of knowledge of Me, they do not come to know Me.

7.shlok:
येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम्।
ते द्वन्द्वमोहनिर्मुक्ता भजन्ते मां दृढव्रताः।।७.२८।।
7.translit:
yeṣāṁ tv anta-gataṁ pāpaṁ janānāṁ puṇya-karmaṇām
te dvandva-moha-nirmuktā bhajante māṁ dṛḍha-vratāḥ
7.translate: But those people of virtuous actions whose sins have come to an end, they, freed from the delusion of dualities, worship Me with firm resolve.
7.sridhara: How, then, is it that some people are seen to worship You? That is answered: yeṣāṁ—those among people who are given to meritorious acts (puṇya-karmaṇām), whose pāpa—sins are completely destroyed (anta-gataṁ), they become freed from the delusion born of duality (dvandva-moha-nirmuktāḥ), and having single-pointed resolve (dṛḍha-vratāḥ), they worship Me exclusively.

7.shlok:
जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये।
ते ब्रह्म तद्विदुः कृत्स्नमध्यात्मं कर्म चाखिलम्।।७.२९।।
7.translit:
jarā-maraṇa-mokṣāya mām āśritya yatanti ye
te brahma tad-viduḥ kṛtsnam adhyātmaṁ karma cākhilam
7.translate: Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, they know that Brahman fully, as well as the Self and all action.
7.sridhara: Thus, those who worship Me come to know all that is to be known and attain fulfillment—this is said here: those who strive (yatanti) for liberation from old age and death (jarā-maraṇa-mokṣāya), taking refuge in Me (mām āśritya), they know Brahman (tat brahma viduḥ), and kṛtsnam adhyātmam—the entire truth of the Self, which is to be known and attained, the pure Self distinct from body, etc.; and they also know all action (karma ca akhilam), which is the means to that knowledge, along with its secrets.

7.shlok:
साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः।
प्रयाणकालेऽपि च मां ते विदुर्युक्तचेतसः।।७.३०।।
7.translit:
sādhibhūtādhidaivaṁ māṁ sādhiyajñaṁ ca ye viduḥ
prayāṇa-kāle ’pi ca māṁ te vidur yukta-cetasaḥ
7.translate: Those who know Me with the Adhibhūta, Adhidaiva, and also as the Adhiyajña—such steadfast-minded people know Me even at the time of death.
7.sridhara: There is no fear of the yogic path being interrupted for such persons—this is stated: sādhibhūtādhidaivaṁ māṁ sādhiyajñaṁ—those who know Me along with adhibhūta, adhidaiva, and adhiyajña (whose meanings the Lord will explain in the next chapter); te yukta-cetasaḥ—with their minds absorbed in Me; even at the time of death (prayāṇa-kāle ’pi), they know Me, and do not forget Me even then. Therefore, there is no fear of yogic fall for My devotees.

8.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
किं तद्ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम।
अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते।।८.१।।
8.translit:
arjuna uvāca
kiṁ tad brahma kim adhyātmaṁ kiṁ karma puruṣottama
adhibhūtaṁ ca kiṁ proktam adhidaivaṁ kim ucyate
8.translate: Arjuna said: What is that Brahman? What is Adhyātma? What is karma, O Supreme Person? What is called Adhibhūta? And what is said to be Adhidaiva?
8.sridhara:
“Those whose minds are devoted solely to Kṛṣṇa know Brahman, karma, Adhibhūta, etc.” — having said this, Brahman, karma, etc. are now clearly explained in this eighth chapter.
At the end of the previous chapter, the Lord briefly mentioned seven terms: Brahman, Adhyātma, etc. Desiring to understand their true meaning, Arjuna asked: “What is that Brahman?” — thus he spoke the first two verses. The meaning is clear.

8.shlok:
अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन।
प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः।।८.२।।
8.translit:
adhiyajñaḥ kathaṁ ko ’tra dehe ’smin madhusūdana
prayāṇa-kāle ca kathaṁ jñeyo ’si niyatātmabhiḥ
8.translate: Who is Adhiyajña in this body, O Madhusūdana? And how are You to be known at the time of death by the self-controlled?
8.sridhara:
Furthermore — “Adhiyajñaḥ” — in this body, what is the yajña that is taking place? Who is its Adhiyajña — the presiding deity, the instigator, and the giver of results? After asking about the essential nature, Arjuna asks about the manner of that presiding: “How — by what means — is that One situated in this body and presiding over the yajña?”
The word “yajña” here stands for all actions. And at the time of death, by what means is He to be known by those who are self-disciplined in mind?

8.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते।
भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः।।८.३।।
8.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
akṣaraṁ brahma paramaṁ svabhāvo ’dhyātmam ucyate
bhūta-bhāvodbhava-karo visargaḥ karma-saṁjñitaḥ
8.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Brahman is the supreme, imperishable. One’s own nature is called Adhyātma. The offering which causes the origin and development of beings is called karma.
8.sridhara:
The Lord replies in the order of the questions — “akṣaram” — in three parts. “That which does not perish or move is called akṣara.”
Now, one might ask: “Is the jīva also not imperishable?” To this it is said: “The supreme akṣara, which is the root cause of the world, that is Brahman.” “This indeed is that Akṣara,” say the Brāhmaṇas in the Śruti (Bṛhadāraṇyaka).
The Brahman’s own state of partial manifestation as the jīva is called svabhāva. That same entity, functioning as the experiencer in relation to the body, is denoted by the term “Adhyātma.”
The production (bhāva) and development (udbhava) of beings such as those born from wombs (jarāyuja) — that is, the emergence and growth of entities — are brought about by “visargaḥ,” the act of offering, in the form of sacrifice offered with substances and intent toward deities.
This stands for all action in general. Hence, it is referred to by the term “karma.”

8.shlok:
अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम्।
अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर।।८.४।।
8.translit:
adhibhūtaṁ kṣaro bhāvaḥ puruṣaś cādhidaivatam
adhiyajño ’ham evātra dehe deha-bhṛtāṁ vara
8.translate: Adhibhūta is the perishable being; Puruṣa is the Adhidaiva. I alone am the Adhiyajña in this body, O best among embodied beings.
8.sridhara:
Furthermore — “adhibhūtam” — the perishable (kṣara), destructible forms such as body, etc., which pertain to living beings, is called adhibhūta.
The cosmic Puruṣa, residing in the solar orb, the overlord of all the deities who are his portions — he is the adhidevata. “The ruling deity over all deities is that embodied one, and he is the first embodied being — that is the Puruṣa,” as stated in Śruti: “He was the originator; he existed before creation.”
Here in this body, I Myself, residing as the Inner Controller (antaryāmin), am the Adhiyajña — the deity presiding over yajña, the instigator of yajña and other actions, and the giver of their fruits.
The answer to “how” (from verse २) is to be seen in this very explanation.
The indwelling Lord (antaryāmin), due to His qualities like non-attachment, differs from the jīva, although He resides within the body — this is well known.
As the Śruti says: “Two birds, bound in friendship, dwell upon the same tree. One eats the fruits, the other watches without eating.”
Addressing Arjuna as “best among the embodied,” the Lord suggests: “You too should understand Me, the antaryāmin, through dependence and discernment of your own actions and their connection with Me.”

8.shlok:
अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम्।
यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः।।८.५।।
8.translit:
anta-kāle ca mām eva smaran muktvā kalevaram
yaḥ prayāti sa mad-bhāvaṁ yāti nāsty atra saṁśayaḥ
8.translate: And whoever, at the time of death, departs remembering Me alone, after leaving the body — he attains My state; of this there is no doubt.
8.sridhara:
The question, “How are You to be known at the time of death?” is now answered, along with the fruit of such knowledge.
“One who, at the time of death (anta-kāle), remembers Me alone (mām eva) — as described above, in the form of the antaryāmin, the Supreme Lord — and departs, he goes by the supreme path (like the arcir-mārga) and attains My state (mad-bhāvam), My own form.
Of this there is no doubt.”
Thus, remembrance is the means of knowledge, and the attainment of My state is the result.

8.shlok:
यं यं वापि स्मरन् भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम्।
तं तमेवैति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः।।८.६।।
8.translit:
yaṁ yaṁ vāpi smaran bhāvaṁ tyajaty ante kalevaram
taṁ tam evaiti kaunteya sadā tad-bhāva-bhāvitaḥ
8.translate: Whatever being one remembers at the time of death when leaving the body—O Kaunteya, that alone he attains, having been always absorbed in that state.
8.sridhara:
It is not only that one who remembers Me attains My state—this is not a fixed rule. What then? — “yaṁ yam iti.”
Whatever state, whether another deity or anything else, one remembers at the time of death while giving up the body—that very state, the remembered object, he attains.
The cause of remembering a particular form at the end is this: “sadā” — always, he has been absorbed in that state, repeatedly contemplating that form, and thus his mind is conditioned by it.

8.shlok:
तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च।
मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयम्।।८.७।।
8.translit:
tasmāt sarveṣu kāleṣu mām anusmara yudhya ca
mayy arpita-mano-buddhir mām evaiṣyasy asaṁśayam
8.translate: Therefore, at all times, remember Me and fight. With your mind and intellect dedicated to Me, you shall surely come to Me—there is no doubt.
8.sridhara:
“tasmāt” — therefore, since earlier impressions alone are the cause of remembrance at death, and because, at that time, one cannot consciously make an effort to remember, being helpless — hence, always remember Me — reflect upon Me continually.
Such constant remembrance does not arise without purity of mind. Therefore, “yudhya ca” — fight. The meaning is: perform battle and other duties in accordance with one’s own dharma, for the sake of purification of the mind.
In this way, when your mind (the seat of intention) and intellect (the seat of discrimination) are both offered to Me, you shall attain Me alone. There is no doubt in this—there is no uncertainty here.

8.shlok:
अभ्यासयोगयुक्तेन चेतसा नान्यगामिना।
परमं पुरुषं दिव्यं याति पार्थानुचिन्तयन्।।८.८।।
8.translit:
abhyāsa-yoga-yuktena cetasā nānya-gāminā
paramaṁ puruṣaṁ divyaṁ yāti pārthānucintayan
8.translate: With a mind made steadfast by the discipline of repeated practice, not moving toward anything else, one who constantly reflects on the Supreme, divine Puruṣa—he, O Pārtha, attains Him.
8.sridhara:
Showing that repeated practice (abhyāsa) is the inner means to achieve constant remembrance, He says: “abhyāsa iti.”
Abhyāsa is the continuous flow of similar thoughts. That itself is the discipline of yoga. One who is engaged in that, whose mind is focused, and therefore whose mind does not move toward any other object—such a person, constantly meditating upon the Supreme, divine Puruṣa, O Pārtha, attains Him alone.

8.shlok:
कविं पुराणमनुशासितारं
अणोरणीयांसमनुस्मरेद्यः।
सर्वस्य धातारमचिन्त्यरूपं
आदित्यवर्णं तमसः परस्तात्।।८.९।।
8.translit:
kaviṁ purāṇam anuśāsitāram
aṇor aṇīyāṁsam anusmared yaḥ
sarvasya dhātāram acintya-rūpaṁ
āditya-varṇaṁ tamasaḥ parastāt
8.translate: Whoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler, subtler than the atom, the sustainer of all, of inconceivable form, radiant like the sun, beyond the darkness (of matter) —
8.sridhara:
Again He defines the Puruṣa to be constantly contemplated — “kavim iti,” in two lines.
“Kaviṁ” — the all-knowing, the originator of all knowledge; “purāṇam” — the one who is beginningless and self-established; “anuśāsitāram” — the ruler, controller; “aṇoḥ aṇīyāṁsam” — subtler than even the atom, subtler than space, time, and direction.
“sarvasya dhātāram” — the sustainer of all; “acintya-rūpam” — of inconceivable form, because His greatness cannot be grasped by impure mind and intellect;
“āditya-varṇam” — of the form of self-luminous light like the sun, whose nature is to shine upon self and others; “tamasaḥ parastāt” — who exists beyond darkness, meaning beyond prakṛti.
The Śruti also says: “I have known that great Puruṣa, self-luminous like the sun, who exists beyond darkness.”

8.shlok:
प्रयाणकाले मनसाऽचलेन
भक्त्या युक्तो योगबलेन चैव।
भ्रुवोर्मध्ये प्राणमावेश्य सम्यक्
स तं परं पुरुषमुपैति दिव्यम्।।८.१०।।
8.translit:
prayāṇa-kāle manasā ’calena
bhaktyā yukto yoga-balena caiva
bhruvor madhye prāṇam āveśya samyak
sa taṁ paraṁ puruṣam upaiti divyam
8.translate: At the time of departure, with an unwavering mind, endowed with devotion, and also through the power of yoga, establishing the life-breath properly between the eyebrows—he attains that Supreme, divine Puruṣa.
8.sridhara:
One who, at the time of death, meditates upon that Puruṣa who stands beyond manifest prakṛti — endowed with devotion (bhakti), with an unwavering mind (acala-manas), free from distraction — he attains Him.
The reason for the mind’s steadiness is “yoga-balena” — by the strength of yoga.
“samyak” — by the proper method, placing the prāṇa between the eyebrows through the path of the suṣumṇā —
He attains that Supreme Puruṣa — the form of the supreme Self (paramātma-svarūpa), resplendent and divine.

8.shlok:
यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति
विशन्ति यद्यतयो वीतरागाः।
यदिच्छन्तो ब्रह्मचर्यं चरन्ति
तत्ते पदं संग्रहेण प्रवक्ष्ये।।८.११।।
8.translit:
yad akṣaraṁ vedavido vadanti
viśanti yad yatayo vīta-rāgāḥ
yad icchanto brahmacaryaṁ caranti
tat te padaṁ saṁgraheṇa pravakṣye
8.translate: That imperishable goal which the knowers of the Veda declare, which the self-controlled, desireless ascetics enter, and desiring which celibacy is practiced—that goal I shall declare to you in brief.
8.sridhara:
Wishing to prescribe an internal method of practice centered on praṇava (Om), superior even to the sole practice of yoga through repetition, He declares — “yad akṣaram iti.”
That imperishable (akṣara) which the knowers of Vedānta describe — “under the command of this imperishable, O Gārgī, the sun and moon are held in their orbits” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad) —
Those from whom attachment has departed are the “vīta-rāgā yatayaḥ” — the striving ascetics who enter into that imperishable.
And, desiring to know that, others practice brahmacarya (celibate discipline) in the home of a teacher.
That very goal — “padam,” that which is reached, the destination — I shall tell you in brief (“saṅgraheṇa”) — that is, I will explain the means to attain it.

8.shlok:
सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च।
मूर्ध्न्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम्।।८.१२।।
8.translit:
sarva-dvārāṇi saṁyamya mano hṛdi nirudhya ca
mūrdhny ādhāyātmanaḥ prāṇam āsthito yoga-dhāraṇām
8.translate: Restraining all the sense gates, confining the mind in the heart, and fixing the life-breath in the head, one should remain established in the firmness of yoga.
8.sridhara:
He now states the method and its associated means, as previously promised — “sarva-dvārāṇi iti,” in these two verses.
Withdrawing all the gates of the senses — i.e., by controlling them.
Not perceiving external objects with the senses like the eye and others — this is the meaning.
And the mind is to be confined in the heart — i.e., not allowing memory of external objects to arise.
Then, fixing the prāṇa (vital breath) in the head — between the eyebrows —
One who abides in this state has taken refuge in “yoga-dhāraṇā,” the stability or firmness of yoga.

8.shlok:
ओमित्येकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्याहरन्मामनुस्मरन्।
यः प्रयाति त्यजन्देहं स याति परमां गतिम्।।८.१३।।
8.translit:
om ity ekākṣaraṁ brahma vyāharan mām anusmaran
yaḥ prayāti tyajan dehaṁ sa yāti paramāṁ gatim
8.translate: Uttering the single-syllabled Om, which is Brahman, and remembering Me, one who departs, leaving the body, attains the supreme goal.
8.sridhara:
“Om iti” — that single syllable which is “Om” — that alone is “Brahman,” either because it directly denotes Brahman, or because it serves as a symbol for Brahman, like an image or other representation.
Reciting that (i.e., uttering “Om”), and remembering Me,
He who departs, casting off the body — he goes, in an exalted way, by the path of the deities (arcirādi-mārga), and attains the supreme goal — My own destination.

8.shlok:
अनन्यचेताः सततं यो मां स्मरति नित्यशः।
तस्याहं सुलभः पार्थ नित्ययुक्तस्य योगिनः।।८.१४।।
8.translit:
ananya-cetāḥ satataṁ yo māṁ smarati nityaśaḥ
tasyāhaṁ sulabhaḥ pārtha nitya-yuktasya yoginaḥ
8.translate: One who thinks of Me constantly, daily, with an undistracted mind—to that yogī who is always united with Me, O Pārtha, I am easily attainable.
8.sridhara:
Thus, it is only through constant daily practice that one attains Me through dhāraṇā (concentration) at the time of death—not otherwise.
He now reiterates what was previously said — “ananya-cetāḥ.”
One whose mind is not directed to anything else — such a person, who remembers Me constantly (satataṁ), continuously, and “nityaśaḥ” — every day,
For him who is always engaged (nitya-yukta), collected in mind — I am easily attainable. Not so for others.

8.shlok:
मामुपेत्य पुनर्जन्म दुःखालयमशाश्वतम्।
नाप्नुवन्ति महात्मानः संसिद्धिं परमां गताः।।८.१५।।
8.translit:
mām upetya punar janma duḥkhālayam aśāśvatam
nāpnuvanti mahātmānaḥ saṁsiddhiṁ paramāṁ gatāḥ
8.translate: Having attained Me, the great souls do not take birth again, which is the abode of sorrow and impermanence; they have reached the highest perfection.
8.sridhara:
Although I am easily attainable — then what? He explains — “mām iti.”
The great souls, characterized as My devotees, having attained Me, do not obtain rebirth, which is the source of sorrow and is impermanent.
Why? Because they have attained the highest, complete perfection — that is, liberation itself.
Or, alternatively: having attained Me, they no longer obtain birth — which is the abode of sorrow — thus reaching the supreme goal.

8.shlok:
आब्रह्मभुवनाल्लोकाः पुनरावर्तिनोऽर्जुन।
मामुपेत्य तु कौन्तेय पुनर्जन्म न विद्यते।।८.१६।।
8.translit:
ābrahma-bhuvanāl lokāḥ punar-āvartino ’rjuna
mām upetya tu kaunteya punar janma na vidyate
8.translate: From the world of Brahmā downwards, all worlds are subject to return, O Arjuna. But having reached Me, O son of Kuntī, there is no rebirth.
8.sridhara:
He establishes that all worlds are subject to return — “ābrahma iti.”
All worlds, including Brahmā’s abode — “brahmaṇaḥ bhuvanaṁ,” the dwelling-place of Brahmā, i.e., Brahma-loka — are subject to rebirth, because Brahma-loka too is impermanent.
Those who reach Brahma-loka through the path of gradual liberation (krama-mukti) but have not attained knowledge will necessarily be reborn.
Only those who attain knowledge there will be liberated along with Brahmā.
Thus it is said: “When Brahmā and all others reach dissolution, those who have realized the Self enter the Supreme Abode.”
At the end of Brahmā’s lifespan, those who have attained realization — whose minds have become identified with Brahman — and who have reached Brahma-loka through karma (rituals and upāsanā), are not liberated unless they have realized the Self.
This is conclusive.
But those who have attained Me do not undergo rebirth at all — that is the meaning.

8.shlok:
सहस्रयुगपर्यन्तमहर्यद्ब्रह्मणो विदुः।
रात्रिं युगसहस्रान्तां तेऽहोरात्रविदो जनाः।।८.१७।।
8.translit:
sahasra-yuga-paryantam ahar yad brahmaṇo viduḥ
rātriṁ yuga-sahasrāntāṁ te ’ho-rātra-vido janāḥ
8.translate: Those who know that Brahmā’s day lasts for a thousand yugas, and his night ends with a thousand yugas as well — they are the knowers of day and night.
8.sridhara:
It is said in the Purāṇas, “The ascetics, the charitable, the dispassionate, the tolerant — they attain a sorrowless realm beyond the three worlds.”
From such statements it is understood that higher realms like Maharloka are superior to the three worlds (Bhuḥ, Bhuvaḥ, Svaḥ).
But if all are subject to destruction, how is there any distinction?
Anticipating this doubt, He explains that the distinction lies in their lasting longer — for many cosmic cycles — and thus He shows the duration of Brahmā’s day and night according to His own scale — “sahasra-yuga-paryantam.”
A day of Brahmā is the duration of a thousand yugas, and his night also ends with a thousand yugas.
Those who know this, through yogic strength — they alone are the true knowers of day and night.
But those who only know the day and night through the movement of the sun and moon are not truly knowledgeable — their vision is limited.
Here, the term yuga refers to the set of four yugas — Satya, Tretā, Dvāpara, and Kali.
According to the Viṣṇu Purāṇa: “A thousand such sets of four yugas make up one day of Brahmā.”
The word “Brahmaṇaḥ” also includes the residents of Maharloka, etc.
Now, the calculation is as follows:
One human year equals one day and night for the gods.
With such divine days and nights, following the lunar months and solar years, १२,००० divine years make one four-yuga cycle.
A thousand such cycles make one day of Brahmā, and an equal amount makes his night.
Thus, with such days and nights, counted by months and years, his total lifespan is १०० such years.

8.shlok:
अव्यक्ताद्व्यक्तयः सर्वाः प्रभवन्त्यहरागमे।
रात्र्यागमे प्रलीयन्ते तत्रैवाव्यक्तसंज्ञके।।८.१८।।
8.translit:
avyaktād vyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavanti ahar-āgame
rātry-āgame pralīyante tatraiva avyakta-saṁjñake
8.translate: At the beginning of the day, all manifested beings arise from the Unmanifest; at the coming of the night, they dissolve into that very same, which is called the Unmanifest.
8.sridhara:
What then happens? He says — “avyaktād iti.”
From that avyakta — the unmanifest, which is the causal state and the subtle form of effects — all manifested beings, both moving and unmoving, are produced (i.e., emerge).
When? At the commencement of the day of Brahmā.
Likewise, at the beginning of the night of Brahmā — when Brahmā goes to sleep — they dissolve into that same cause, called the avyakta.
Alternatively, it can be taken as follows:
“The knowers of day and night” — the previously mentioned beings — are said to know that,
“At the start of Brahmā’s day, beings emerge from the unmanifest;
and at the beginning of his night, they dissolve into it.”
Thus, this is the connection of both parts.

8.shlok:
भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते।
रात्र्यागमेऽवशः पार्थ प्रभवत्यहरागमे।।८.१९।।
8.translit:
bhūta-grāmaḥ sa eva ayaṁ bhūtvā bhūtvā pralīyate
rātry-āgame avaśaḥ pārtha prabhavati ahar-āgame
8.translate: This same multitude of beings, coming into being again and again, dissolves helplessly at the coming of the night, O Pārtha; and arises again at the coming of the day.
8.sridhara:
To dispel the doubt that beings are destroyed forever and may not return, He now shows the uninterrupted flow of creation and dissolution, so as to promote dispassion — “bhūta iti.”
The multitude (grāmaḥ) of beings — of moving and unmoving creatures —
Which existed before, that same group arises again at the beginning of the day,
And at the beginning of the night, it dissolves.
They dissolve, and again at the beginning of the day they come into being, helplessly —
Dependent on karma, they arise without any alternative.
There is no other way.

8.shlok:
परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः।
यः स सर्वेषु भूतेषु नश्यत्सु न विनश्यति।।८.२०।।
8.translit:
paras tasmāt tu bhāvaḥ anyo ’vyakto ’vyaktāt sanātanaḥ
yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati
8.translate: But beyond that Unmanifest, there is another unmanifest, eternal, which is not destroyed when all beings are destroyed.
8.sridhara:
After showing the impermanence of the worlds, He now demonstrates the eternal nature of the Supreme Lord — “paraḥ iti,” in these two verses.
Beyond that unmanifest, which is the cause of all moving and unmoving beings —
There is another, distinct from it, unmanifest — i.e., not perceivable by the senses like the eyes, etc.
That reality is sanātanaḥ — without beginning.
That is not destroyed even when all beings, consisting of effects and causes, are destroyed.

8.shlok:
अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम्।
यं प्राप्य न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम।।८.२१।।
8.translit:
avyakto’kṣara ity uktaḥ tam āhuḥ paramāṁ gatim
yaṁ prāpya na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama
8.translate: What is called the Unmanifest and the Imperishable, that they declare to be the highest goal. Having attained it, none return. That is My supreme abode.
8.sridhara: Showing the proof for its imperishability, He says: “avyakta iti.” That entity, which is unmanifest (avyakta), beyond the senses, and imperishable (akṣara)—free from emergence and destruction—is called akṣara in such scriptural statements as “From that akṣara arises this world,” etc. That (entity), they say, is the highest goal (paramāṁ gatim), the supreme end of human pursuit. Scriptural texts such as “There is nothing beyond the Puruṣa; that is the ultimate limit, the highest goal,” confirm this. The very quality of being the supreme goal is established with the statement “having attained which, they do not return.” And that is indeed My own dhāma (abode), My essential nature. The genitive “of Me” is used in the sense of identification, as in “Rāhu’s head,” meaning Rāhu is nothing but head. Therefore, the meaning is: I Myself am the supreme goal.

8.shlok:
पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया।
यस्यान्तःस्थानि भूतानि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्।।८.२२।।
8.translit:
puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyas tv ananyayā
yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvam idaṁ tatam
8.translate: That Supreme Puruṣa, O Pārtha, is attainable by exclusive devotion. All beings dwell within Him, and He pervades all this.
8.sridhara: That bhakti is the inner means to attain Him—this is reiterated: “puruṣaḥ iti.” That Supreme Puruṣa—who is I Myself—is attainable only by unwavering (ananyayā) bhakti, i.e., by one whose devotion is not directed to any other as a refuge. He is not attainable otherwise. His supremacy is again declared: all beings reside within Him, who is their cause, and by whom this entire universe is pervaded, as He is the cause.

8.shlok:
यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः।
प्रयाता यान्ति तं कालं वक्ष्यामि भरतर्षभ।।८.२३।।
8.translit:
yatra kāle tv anāvṛttim āvṛttiṁ caiva yoginaḥ
prayātā yānti taṁ kālaṁ vakṣyāmi bharatarṣabha
8.translate: O best of the Bhāratas, now I will tell you the time at which departing, yogis do not return, and also that time at which they do return.
8.sridhara: Thus it was said that those devoted to the Supreme Lord, upon attaining that state, do not return, whereas others do. In anticipation of the question, “By what path do some not return, and by which do others return?” this is explained: “yatra.” The time at which (kāle) departing yogis attain non-return (anāvṛtti), and the time at which departing ones attain return (āvṛtti)—that time I shall declare. Here, since the discussion involves following specific rays (raśmi) and the indirect indication (nyāya) of the southern course being ruled out, the word kāla (time) is intended to imply the devatās presiding over those time periods. Thus, the sense is: I will describe the path characterized by the devatās who preside over particular times—through whom, yogis and performers of action attain, respectively, non-return and return. Although “Agni,” “Jyoti,” etc., are not in themselves presiding deities of time, the devatās mentioned such as “day,” “night,” “year,” “celestial realms” etc., in scriptures, imply time-personified deities. Therefore, just as in “mango grove,” etc., it is valid to interpret the term kāla as inclusive of the devatās presiding over those times.

8.shlok:
अग्निर्ज्योतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम्।
तत्र प्रयाता गच्छन्ति ब्रह्म ब्रह्मविदो जनाः।।८.२४।।
8.translit:
agnir jyotir ahaḥ śuklaḥ ṣaṇ-māsā uttarāyaṇam
tatra prayātā gacchanti brahma brahmavido janāḥ
8.translate: Fire, light, daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the sun’s northern course—departing then, those who know Brahman go to Brahman.
8.sridhara: Here, the path of non-return is described: “agniḥ iti.” By the words “Agni” and “Jyoti,” the deity identified with flame (arciṣ) mentioned in the scriptures is indicated. “Ahaḥ” refers to the deity of daytime. “Śukla” indicates the deity presiding over the bright fortnight. “The six months of the northern course” means the deity of Uttarāyaṇa. These are also representative of other deities mentioned in scripture, such as those presiding over the year, deva-loka, etc. Following this path—marked by such deities—the devotees of Bhagavān depart and attain Brahman, because they are knower of Brahman. The scriptures also say: “They reach flame, from flame to day, from day to bright fortnight, from there to the six months of northern solstice, from there to the deva-loka.” For those who attain immediate liberation (sadyo-mukti) by true knowledge, there is no question of any such path, because of the statement: “From him, the prāṇa does not depart.”

8.shlok:
धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम्।
तत्र चान्द्रमसं ज्योतिर्योगी प्राप्य निवर्तते।।८.२५।।
8.translit:
dhūmo rātris tathā kṛṣṇaḥ ṣaṇ-māsā dakṣiṇāyanam
tatra cāndramasaṁ jyotir yogī prāpya nivartate
8.translate: Smoke, night, the dark fortnight, and the six months of the southern course—departing then, the yogī attains lunar light and returns.
8.sridhara: The path of return is described: “dhūmaḥ iti.” The deity presiding over smoke is intended. As before, the words “night,” “dark fortnight,” and “the six months of the southern course” imply the deities ruling over them. The path characterized by such deities—when followed by karmayogins—leads to the lunar light (cāndramasaṁ jyotir), meaning the realm of the moon (svarga-loka), which is signified by that light. Having enjoyed the fruits of iṣṭāpūrta karmas there, they return again. The scriptures say: “They reach smoke, then night, then the dark fortnight, from there the six months of the southern course, then the world of the ancestors, and from there the moon. They, having reached the moon, become food,” etc. Thus, through upāsanā accompanied by nitya-karma (regular rites), there is gradual liberation. Through kāmya-karma (desire-based rites), there is enjoyment in heaven followed by return. Through forbidden actions, return after suffering in hell. For beings of lesser karma, there is repeated rebirth here itself.

8.shlok:
शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगतः शाश्वते मते।
एकया यात्यनावृत्तिमन्ययाऽऽवर्तते पुनः।।८.२६।।
8.translit:
śukla-kṛṣṇe gatī hy ete jagataḥ śāśvate mate
ekayā yāty anāvṛttim anyayā’vartate punaḥ
8.translate: These two paths—bright and dark—are considered to be eternal paths of the world. By the one, one goes without returning; by the other, one returns again.
8.sridhara: He concludes the description of the two paths: “śukla iti.” The bright path (śuklā gatiḥ) beginning with the deity of flame (arciṣ), is so called because it is full of light; the dark path (kṛṣṇā), beginning with the deity of smoke (dhūma), is so called because it is pervaded by darkness. These two paths—of those qualified for knowledge and action, respectively—are considered eternal (śāśvatau) in relation to the world (jagataḥ), being accepted as without beginning, due to the beginninglessness of saṁsāra. Of these two, by the bright one, one attains non-return (mokṣa); but by the other, the dark one, one returns again (punarāvṛtti).

8.shlok:
नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन।
तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु योगयुक्तो भवार्जुन।।८.२७।।
8.translit:
naite sṛtī pārtha jānan yogī muhyati kaścana
tasmāt sarveṣu kāleṣu yoga-yukto bhavārjuna
8.translate: O Pārtha, knowing these two paths, no yogī is ever deluded. Therefore, at all times, be steadfast in yoga, O Arjuna.
8.sridhara: Showing the fruit of knowing these paths, He concludes the teaching on bhakti-yoga: “naite iti.” O Pārtha, the yogī who knows these two paths—leading respectively to liberation and saṁsāra—is not deluded. That is, he does not desire svarga and other fruits under the impression of their being pleasurable, but remains firmly devoted to the Supreme Lord alone. The rest is clear.

8.shlok:
वेदेषु यज्ञेषु तपःसु चैव
दानेषु यत्पुण्यफलं प्रदिष्टम्।
अत्येति तत्सर्वमिदं विदित्वा
योगी परं स्थानमुपैति चाद्यम्।।८.२८।।
8.translit:
vedeṣu yajñeṣu tapaḥsu caiva
dāneṣu yat puṇya-phalaṁ pradiṣṭam
atyeti tat sarvam idaṁ viditvā
yogī paraṁ sthānam upaiti cādyam
8.translate: Whatever fruit of merit is declared in the Vedas, in sacrifices, in austerities, and in gifts—that, the yogī transcends entirely, having known this; and he attains the supreme, primeval abode.
8.sridhara: He concludes the entire chapter—the resolution of the eight questions—with its fruit: “vedeṣu iti.” Whatever merit is declared in the scriptures to arise from study of the Vedas (vedeṣu), from performance of sacrifices (yajñeṣu), from bodily austerities (tapaḥsu), and from gifts made to worthy recipients (dāneṣu)—the yogī transcends all of that; i.e., he attains the excellence of yoga (yoga-aiśvarya), which is superior even to those merits. How? By knowing this truth (idam viditvā), meaning by understanding the reality expounded through the answers to the eight questions. And thus, becoming a yogī and a jñānī, he attains the supreme and foremost (paraṁ and ādyam) abode, which is the original source of the universe—Viṣṇu’s supreme position (viṣṇoḥ paramaṁ padam).

9.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे।
ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात्।।९.१।।
9.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
idaṁ tu te guhya-tamaṁ pravakṣyāmy anasūyave
jñānaṁ vijñāna-sahitaṁ yaj jñātvā mokṣyase 'śubhāt
9.translate:
The Blessed Lord said:
I shall now declare to you, who are free from envy, this most secret knowledge—together with realization—knowing which, you shall be liberated from what is inauspicious.
9.sridhara:
It was concluded in the eighth chapter that the Supreme Lord is attained through pure devotion. In this ninth chapter, His divine and most wondrous majesty is now elaborated upon.
