Thus, having stated in the seventh and eighth chapters that one’s own supreme nature, that is, the Supreme Lord, is attainable only through devotion and not otherwise, the Blessed Lord, intending now to expound His inconceivable divine majesty and the extraordinary influence of devotion, said: “idaṁ tu.”
“This knowledge”—knowledge concerning the Supreme Lord, together with “vijñāna” (realization), meaning meditation (upāsanā), by which it is specially understood—this I shall declare to you, who are “anasūyave” (free from fault-finding), since you, being supremely compassionate and devoid of any defect-seeing towards Me who repeatedly proclaim My own greatness.
The particle tu signifies distinction.
Now, He states: “guhyatamam”—Is it the knowledge of dharma that is secret? Beyond that, the knowledge of the Self as distinct from the body is more secret. Beyond even that, the knowledge of the Supreme Self is the most secret, because of its extreme subtlety.
By knowing this, you shall be liberated from “aśubha,” that is, from saṁsāra, the cycle of birth and death. Indeed, you shall immediately become free.

9.shlok:
राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम्।
प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम्।।९.२।।
9.translit:
rāja-vidyā rāja-guhyaṁ pavitram idam uttamam
pratyakṣāvagamaṁ dharmyaṁ su-sukhaṁ kartum avyayam
9.translate: This is the king of sciences, the king of secrets, the most sacred, superior, directly realizable, righteous, easy to practice, and imperishable.
9.sridhara:
Moreover—“rāja-vidyā”—this knowledge is the king of sciences, the foremost among all sciences. And “rāja-guhyaṁ”—the king among all secrets—because it is the most excellent among all teachings and hidden doctrines. This indicates supreme superiority. Due to the rule of compounds like “rāja-danta” etc., the subordinate member attains prominence here. That is, the knowledge of kings or the secret of kings.
It is “uttamam,” the highest. It is “pavitram,” supremely purifying.
It is “pratyakṣāvagamam”—that whose realization is direct and clear to the knower. That is, its result is directly experienced.
It is “dharmyam”—not opposed to dharma, since it yields the fruit of all dharmas.
It is “sukhaṁ kartum”—easily practiced. That is, it can be performed without difficulty.
And “avyayam”—its fruit is imperishable.

9.shlok:
अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप।
अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युसंसारवर्त्मनि।।९.३।।
9.translit:
aśraddadhānāḥ puruṣā dharmasyāsya parantapa
aprāpya māṁ nivartante mṛtyu-saṁsāra-vartmani
9.translate: Those men who have no faith in this dharma, O Parantapa, do not attain Me and return to the path of death and rebirth.
9.sridhara:
Now, a doubt may arise: If this path is so very easy to practice, who then are those who remain bound in saṁsāra? To that He replies—“aśraddadhānāḥ” (those who lack faith).
“Of this dharma” means of this path that consists of knowledge characterized by devotion. The genitives are karmani ṣaṣṭhī (expressing relation to the action).
Those who do not accept this dharma with faith (āstikya), even if they have made efforts by other means to attain Me, without attaining Me, they return to the path of saṁsāra that is joined with death.
That is, they revolve along the path of worldly existence, which is pervaded by death.

9.shlok:
मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना।
मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः।।९.४।।
9.translit:
mayā tatam idaṁ sarvaṁ jagad avyakta-mūrtinā
mat-sthāni sarva-bhūtāni na cāhaṁ teṣv avasthitaḥ
9.translate: This entire world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest form. All beings exist in Me, yet I do not dwell in them.
9.sridhara:
Thus, by praising this knowledge to awaken eagerness in the listener, the Lord now explains that very knowledge in the next two verses—beginning with “mayā tatam.”
“This entire world is pervaded by Me,” who have an “avyakta-mūrti” (unmanifest form), meaning a nature that is beyond the senses. As stated in the Śruti: “Having created that, He entered into it.”
Therefore, “mat-sthāni sarva-bhūtāni”—all beings, both moving and unmoving, exist in Me, who am the cause.
Even so, just as pots and other effects exist in clay, yet clay is not said to be located in them—in the same way, though beings exist in Me, I am not present in them, due to My unattachment, like space.

9.shlok:
न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्।
भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः।।९.५।।
9.translit:
na ca mat-sthāni bhūtāni paśya me yogam aiśvaram
bhūta-bhṛn na ca bhūta-stho mamātmā bhūta-bhāvanaḥ
9.translate: And yet, beings do not exist in Me. Behold My divine Yoga! Though sustaining all beings and being their source, My Self does not dwell in them.
9.sridhara:
Moreover—“na ca”—the beings are not in Me, because I am without attachment.
Now, one may suspect: Does this not contradict the previously stated pervasiveness and support? To that He replies: “paśya me aiśvaram yogam”—behold My divine and unique Yoga, the mysterious power of My Māyā, a marvelous skill that makes the impossible possible.
Because the grandeur of My Yogic Māyā is beyond reasoning, there is no contradiction whatsoever.
Now He speaks of another wonder—“bhūta-bhṛt”—one who upholds the beings, sustains them; “bhūta-bhāvanaḥ”—one who generates, protects the beings.
Even though such is My nature, “mama ātmā”—My own Self, My supreme nature—“na bhūta-sthaḥ” (does not dwell in beings).
The meaning is: Just as the jīva, supporting and sustaining the body, stands identified with it due to ego, in the same way, although I sustain and protect the beings, I do not dwell in them, because I am free from ego.

9.shlok:
यथाऽऽकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान्।
तथा सर्वाणि भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय।।९.६।।
9.translit:
yathā’kāśa-sthito nityaṁ vāyuḥ sarvatra-go mahān
tathā sarvāṇi bhūtāni mat-sthānīti upadhāraya
9.translate: As the great wind, which moves everywhere, is always situated in space, even so, know that all beings reside in Me.
9.sridhara:
Now, to illustrate the relation of support and supported even in the case of entities that are unconnected, He says: “yathā” etc.
The wind, though moving everywhere, is always situated in space—because, without space, it cannot exist anywhere. Yet, even being great, it is not in contact with space, due to the latter being without parts, making contact impossible.
In the same manner, know that all beings reside in Me.

9.shlok:
सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम्।
कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम्।।९.७।।
9.translit:
sarva-bhūtāni kaunteya prakṛtiṁ yānti māmikām
kalpa-kṣaye punas tāni kalpādau visṛjāmy aham
9.translate: All beings, O Kaunteya, go into My Prakṛti at the end of a kalpa; again, at the beginning of a kalpa, I send them forth.
9.sridhara:
Thus, having stated that though unattached, He is the cause of the world’s persistence through Yoga-Māyā, He now states that through the same, He is also the cause of creation and dissolution—“sarvāṇi” etc.
At the end of a kalpa, at the time of dissolution, all beings enter into My Prakṛti—My Māyā made up of the three guṇas—and are absorbed there. Again, at the beginning of the kalpa, at the time of creation, I send them forth—“visṛjāmi,” meaning I manifest them specifically.

9.shlok:
प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः।
भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात्।।९.८।।
9.translit:
prakṛtiṁ svām avaṣṭabhya visṛjāmi punaḥ punaḥ
bhūta-grāmam imaṁ kṛtsnam avaśaṁ prakṛter vaśāt
9.translate: Controlling My own Prakṛti, I again and again send forth this entire multitude of beings, helpless, under the control of Prakṛti.
9.sridhara:
Now, if one wonders: “Being unattached and changeless, how do You create?”, He answers with “prakṛtim” etc.
Grasping (i.e., presiding over) My own Prakṛti—over which I have control—I create again and again this entire fourfold multitude of beings that had become dissolved at the time of dissolution.
They are helpless, being dependent on karma and other such causes. I create them repeatedly or in varied forms.
How? “prakṛter vaśāt”—due to the force of their prior karma and the inherent tendencies produced thereby.

9.shlok:
न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय।
उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु।।९.९।।
9.translit:
na ca māṁ tāni karmāṇi nibadhnanti dhanañjaya
udāsīna-vad āsīnam asaktaṁ teṣu karmasu
9.translate: Nor do those actions bind Me, O Dhanañjaya, for I remain seated like one indifferent, unattached to those actions.
9.sridhara:
Now, one may wonder: Though You perform diverse actions like creation, why are You not bound like a jīva? Anticipating this, He says: “na ca.”
Those actions such as creation do not bind Me. For, attachment to action is the cause of bondage—and that does not exist in Me, since all My desires are fulfilled.
Therefore, they do not produce bondage in Me, who remain like one indifferent.
Since there is no agency in true indifference, the term “udāsīna-vat sthitam” (situated like one indifferent) is used.

9.shlok:
मयाऽध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम्।
हेतुनाऽनेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तते।।९.१०।।
9.translit:
mayādhyakṣeṇa prakṛtiḥ sūyate sa-carācaram
hetunānena kaunteya jagad viparivartate
9.translate: Under My supervision, Prakṛti brings forth the moving and the unmoving. Because of this, O Kaunteya, the world revolves.
9.sridhara:
He now establishes the same: “mayādhyakṣeṇa.”
Under My supervision, being the presiding and causal factor, Prakṛti gives birth to this world consisting of moving and unmoving beings.
Because of this supervision of Mine, this world revolves—again and again it is born.
Since My supervision is only by mere presence, therefore there is no contradiction between My agency and indifference. This is the intent.

9.shlok:
अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम्।
परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम्।।९.११।।
9.translit:
avajānanti māṁ mūḍhā mānuṣīṁ tanum āśritam
paraṁ bhāvam ajānanto mama bhūta-maheśvaram
9.translate: Fools disregard Me, having taken on a human form, not knowing My higher nature as the great Lord of beings.
9.sridhara:
Now, one may ask: Why do some not show reverence toward You, who are the Supreme Lord? To this, He says: “avajānanti” in these two verses.
Fools—those who are ignorant—disregard Me, not knowing My supreme nature (param bhāvam), which is My true essence as the great Lord of all beings.
And what is the reason for their disregard? It is because I have taken on a human form, despite having a body constituted of pure sattva, solely out of the desire of My devotees. Not recognizing this, they show Me disrespect.

9.shlok:
मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः।
राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः।।९.१२।।
9.translit:
moghāśā mogha-karmāṇo mogha-jñānā vicetasaḥ
rākṣasīm āsurīṁ caiva prakṛtiṁ mohinīṁ śritāḥ
9.translate: With vain hopes, vain actions, and vain knowledge, those of confused minds, having taken refuge in the deluding nature—rākṣasī and āsurī—are indeed deluded.
9.sridhara:
Moreover: “moghāśā” etc.
Those whose hopes are futile—because they believe that other deities, apart from Me, will quickly grant results—are of vain hopes (moghāśāḥ).
Because of their aversion to Me, their actions are also futile (moghakarmāṇaḥ), and their knowledge, based on various erroneous arguments and devoid of scripture, is also vain (moghajñānāḥ).
As a result, they are “vicetasaḥ,” distracted in mind. This applies in all respects.
They have taken refuge in rākṣasī prakṛti, which is tāmasic and full of cruelty, and āsurī prakṛti, which is rājasic and full of desire and pride—both of which are deluding and cause the ruin of discernment.
Being established in such dispositions, they disregard Me—this should be connected with the previous verse.

9.shlok:
महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः।
भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम्।।९.१३।।
9.translit:
mahātmānas tu māṁ pārtha daivīṁ prakṛtim āśritāḥ
bhajanty ananya-manaso jñātvā bhūtādim avyayam
9.translate: But the great-souled ones, O Pārtha, resorting to divine nature, worship Me with minds that do not stray elsewhere, knowing Me as the imperishable origin of beings.
9.sridhara:
Then who indeed worships You? He says: “mahātmānas tu.”
The great-souled ones, whose minds are not overpowered by desire and the like—because they have taken refuge in divine nature (daivī prakṛti), which will be described later as characterized by fearlessness and purity of sattva, etc.—
Therefore, their minds are not directed toward anything other than Me.
Knowing Me, the imperishable cause of the world and all beings, they worship Me.

9.shlok:
सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः।
नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते।।९.१४।।
9.translit:
satataṁ kīrtayanto māṁ yatantaś ca dṛḍha-vratāḥ
namasyantaś ca māṁ bhaktyā nitya-yuktā upāsate
9.translate: Always glorifying Me, striving with firm vows, bowing to Me with devotion—they worship Me, ever steadfast.
9.sridhara:
He now speaks of the various ways in which they worship: “satatam” etc.
Some worship Me by always (satatam) glorifying Me through hymns and mantras.
Some, who are of firm vows (dṛḍha-vratāḥ), strive in acts such as worship of the Lord and in restraining the senses, etc.
Some bow with devotion—namasyantaḥ, offering prostration.
All of them are “nitya-yuktāḥ,” ever intent (on Me).
That is, even their acts of glorifying Me, etc., are done with constant concentration. “With devotion” applies also to those engaged in glorification and other acts.

9.shlok:
ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते।
एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम्।।९.१५।।
9.translit:
jñāna-yajñena cāpy anye yajanto mām upāsate
ekatvena pṛthaktvena bahudhā viśvato-mukham
9.translate: Others too, offering the sacrifice of knowledge, worship Me—some as one, others as distinct, and yet others in manifold ways as the all-faced.
9.sridhara:
Moreover: “jñāna-yajñena.”
Knowledge in the form of realization that “Vāsudeva is all”—the vision of Him as the Self of all—is itself the sacrifice (yajña).
By this knowledge-sacrifice (jñāna-yajña), some worship Me.
Among them, some meditate on Me as one—the supreme Brahman, in the form of the ultimate non-dual truth.
Others meditate on Me as distinct—thinking “I am His servant” (dāsō’ham) and so on.
Yet others worship Me, who am all-faced (viśvato-mukham), possessing the form of all—such as in the forms of Brahmā, Rudra, and others—in many ways.

9.shlok:
अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाऽहमहमौषधम्।
मंत्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम्।।९.१६।।
9.translit:
ahaṁ kratur ahaṁ yajñaḥ svadhāham aham auṣadham
maṁtro ’ham aham evājyam aham agnir ahaṁ hutam
9.translate: I am the Kratu; I am the Yajña; I am the offering to the ancestors (svadhā); I am the medicinal herb; I am the mantra; I am indeed the clarified butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.
9.sridhara:
He elaborates His all-pervasiveness: “ahaṁ” in the next four verses.
Kratu means the Vedic ritual (śrauta), such as Agniṣṭoma. Yajña refers to the smārta (household) rituals, like the five great sacrifices (pañca-yajñas). Svadhā is the offering in the rites for ancestors (śrāddha, etc.).
Auṣadha refers to food derived from plants, or medicine. Mantra refers to the invocatory and other mantras such as yājyā and puro’nuvākyā. Ājya is the ghee used in oblations. Agni is the ritual fire (āhavanīya and others). Huta means the act of offering (homa).
All of these—I alone am.

9.shlok:
पिताऽहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः।
वेद्यं पवित्रमोंकार ऋक् साम यजुरेव च।।९.१७।।
9.translit:
pitāham asya jagato mātā dhātā pitāmahaḥ
vedyaṁ pavitram oṁkāra ṛk sāma yajur eva ca
9.translate: I am the father of this world, the mother, the sustainer, the grandfather; the object to be known, the purifier, the syllable Om, and also the Ṛg, Sāma, and Yajur Vedas.
9.sridhara:
Furthermore: “pitā” etc.
Dhātā means the giver of the fruits of actions. Vedyaṁ is that which is to be known. Pavitram means that which purifies, or that which removes sin, such as expiatory acts.
Oṅkāra is the sacred syllable praṇava. The Vedas—Ṛg, Sāma, and Yajur—are also Myself. The rest is clear.

9.shlok:
गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत्।
प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम्।।९.१८।।
9.translit:
gatir bhartā prabhuḥ sākṣī nivāsaḥ śaraṇaṁ suhṛt
prabhavaḥ pralayaḥ sthānaṁ nidhānaṁ bījam avyayam
9.translate: I am the goal, the sustainer, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the refuge, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the support, the repository, and the imperishable seed.
9.sridhara:
Further: “gatiḥ” etc.
Gatiḥ—That which is reached, i.e., the goal or fruit. Bhartā—The nourisher. Prabhuḥ—The controller. Sākṣī—The observer of virtue and vice.
Nivāsa—The place of enjoyment (dwelling). Śaraṇam—The protector. Suhṛt—One who acts for the benefit (of others).
Prabhavaḥ—That from which something arises prominently, i.e., the creator. Pralayaḥ—That into which everything dissolves, i.e., the destroyer. Sthānam—That in which all beings remain, i.e., the foundation.
Nidhānam—That in which things are placed, i.e., the place of dissolution. Bījam—The cause.
Even so, it is imperishable (avyayam)—not perishable like rice seeds and the like. That is the meaning.

9.shlok:
तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च।
अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन।।९.१९।।
9.translit:
tapāmy aham ahaṁ varṣaṁ nigṛhṇāmy utsṛjāmi ca
amṛtaṁ caiva mṛtyuś ca sad asac cāham arjuna
9.translate: I give heat; I withhold and release the rain; I am immortality and also death; I am existence and non-existence, O Arjuna.
9.sridhara:
Furthermore: “tapāmi” etc.
Because I abide as the Sun, I heat (tapāmi) the world during the hot season. I release (utsṛjāmi) rain during the rainy season, and sometimes I withhold it (nigṛhṇāmi).
I am immortality (amṛtam)—life; and also death (mṛtyuḥ)—destruction.
Sat refers to the gross, visible; asat to the subtle, invisible.
All of this—I alone am.
Therefore, considering Me to be all of these, they worship Me in various ways—this connects with the previous section.

9.shlok:
त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा
यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते।
ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोक
मश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान्।।९.२०।।
9.translit:
traividyā māṁ somapāḥ pūtapāpā
yajñair iṣṭvā svargatiṁ prārthayante
te puṇyam āsādya surendra-lokaṁ
aśnanti divyān divi deva-bhogān
9.translate: The knowers of the three Vedas, the Soma-drinkers, purified of sins, worship Me with sacrifices and pray for the path to heaven. Having attained the world of Indra, they enjoy the divine pleasures of the gods in heaven.
9.sridhara:
Thus, in the two verses beginning “avajānanti māṁ mūḍhā” (९.११–९.१२), non-devotees who, desiring quick results, worship other deities and disrespect Me, were shown.
Then in “mahātmānas tu māṁ pārtha” (९.१३), the devotees were described. Among them, some worship Me in non-dual vision (ekatvena), others in duality (pṛthaktvena).
Those who do not worship the Supreme Lord Vāsudeva in either way—such people remain bound in the stream of birth and death. That is expressed now: “traividyā” etc.

Traividyāḥ: Those who possess the three Vedas—Ṛg, Yajus, and Sāma—are called ‘traividyāḥ.’ Or, those who study and know the three Vedas. The meaning is: those devoted to rituals prescribed in the three Vedas.
Even though they do not know that the other deities they worship are My forms, in reality, by worshiping those deities, they worship Me Myself—because those deities are My forms such as Indra, etc.
They are “somapāḥ”—drinkers of the Soma, the remnant of sacrifice. Thus, they are “pūtapāpāḥ”—purified of sins.
Desiring heaven (svargatiṁ prārthayante), they attain the merit-born world of Indra (sura-indra-loka), and there in heaven (divi), they enjoy (aśnanti) the supreme, divine pleasures of the gods.

9.shlok:
ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं
क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति।
एव त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना
गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते।।९.२१।।
9.translit:
te taṁ bhuktvā svargalokaṁ viśālaṁ
kṣīṇe puṇye martyalokaṁ viśanti
eva trayīdharmam anuprapannā
gatāgataṁ kāmakāmā labhante
9.translate: They, having enjoyed that vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted. Thus, those who follow the path of the three Vedas and are desirous of desires attain the state of coming and going.
9.sridhara:
Then: “te taṁ bhuktvā” — Those desiring heaven, having enjoyed that vast heaven which they had sought, when the merit that led to enjoyment is exhausted, they enter the mortal world.
Again and again, following the dharma prescribed in the three Vedas, being desirous of enjoyments (kāma-kāmāḥ), they attain the state of coming and going (gatāgati), i.e., the cycle of repeated birth and death.

9.shlok:
अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते।
तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम्।।९.२२।।
9.translit:
ananyāś cintayanto māṁ ye janāḥ paryupāsate
teṣāṁ nityābhiyuktānāṁ yogakṣemaṁ vahāmy aham
9.translate: But those people who, thinking of Me alone, worship Me with exclusive devotion—to them, who are ever steadfast, I carry what they lack and preserve what they have.
9.sridhara:
But My devotees, through My grace, attain fulfillment.
“Ananyāḥ”—those for whom there is no other desirable worshipable deity apart from Me.
Those people who worship Me, thinking of Me with such exclusive devotion, who are ever joined to Me with single-mindedness—“nityābhiyuktānām”—I Myself carry (vahāmi) their yoga (attainment of what they do not have, i.e., wealth, etc.) and kṣema (protection of what they have, or liberation), even though they do not ask for it.

9.shlok:
येऽप्यन्यदेवता भक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयाऽन्विताः।
तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम्।।९.२३।।
9.translit:
ye ’py anyadevatābhaktā yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ
te ’pi mām eva kaunteya yajanty avidhipūrvakam
9.translate: Even those who, devoted to other deities, worship them with faith—they too, O Kaunteya, worship Me alone, though not according to proper method.
9.sridhara:
Now, since in truth there is no deity other than You, how can those who worship Indra and others be Your devotees? To this he replies:
Even those people who are endowed with faith and are devoted (bhaktāḥ) to other deities, and who perform sacrifices to them—indeed, they worship Me alone, that is true.
However, they worship without the proper method (avidhipūrvakam)—that is, without the method that leads to liberation. Therefore, they return again.

9.shlok:
अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च।
न तु मामभिजानन्ति तत्त्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते।।९.२४।।
9.translit:
ahaṁ hi sarvayajñānāṁ bhoktā ca prabhur eva ca
na tu mām abhijānanti tattvenātaś cyavanti te
9.translate: For I alone am the enjoyer and also the Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in reality, therefore they fall (return to birth and death).
9.sridhara:
He explains the same:
“I alone am the enjoyer and the master of all sacrifices” performed to various deities—I Myself am the recipient, in the form of those deities. I am the Lord, the bestower of the fruits as well.
They do not truly know Me thus—in My real nature (tattvena). Therefore, they fall—cyavanti—i.e., they return again.
But those who, seeing Me as the inner controller of all deities, worship Me alone—they do not return.

9.shlok:
यान्ति देवव्रता देवान् पितृ़न्यान्ति पितृव्रताः।
भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम्।।९.२५।।
9.translit:
yānti devavratā devān pitṛn yānti pitṛvratāḥ
bhūtāni yānti bhūtejyā yānti madyājino ’pi mām
9.translate: Worshippers of the gods go to the gods; worshippers of the ancestors go to the ancestors; worshippers of the spirits go to the spirits; but those who worship Me come to Me.
9.sridhara:
This is explained further:
“Devavratā”—those whose vow is to the gods, such as Indra, attain the perishable gods—therefore, they return again.
“Pitṛvratāḥ”—those whose vow is to the ancestors, engaged in rites like śrāddha, attain the ancestors.
“Bhūtejyā”—those who worship beings like Vināyaka and Mātrikā attain such beings.
But those who habitually worship Me (“madyājinaḥ”) attain Me—Nārāyaṇa—who is imperishable and the very form of supreme bliss.

9.shlok:
पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति।
तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः।।९.२६।।
9.translit:
patraṁ puṣpaṁ phalaṁ toyaṁ yo me bhaktyā prayacchati
tad ahaṁ bhakty-upahṛtam aśnāmi prayatātmanaḥ
9.translate: Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit, or water, I accept that offering made with devotion by one of pure mind.
9.sridhara:
Thus, it was stated that the fruits for My devotees are inexhaustible. Now, the ease of devotion for My devotees is shown: “patram iti.” Even a mere leaf, flower, etc.—whoever offers it to Me with devotion, that is, with love, I accept. That is to say, I gladly receive what is offered by one who is of pure heart, a self-controlled person (prayatātmā), and a desireless devotee, when it is offered with devotion.
Indeed, for Me—the Lord of great glories, the Supreme Lord—satisfaction does not arise through sacrifices accomplished with immense wealth, as it does for minor deities. Rather, I am satisfied by mere devotion alone. Therefore, whatever is offered by the devotee—even a small item like a leaf—is accepted solely for the sake of grace. This is the meaning.

9.shlok:
यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत्।
यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम्।।९.२७।।
9.translit:
yat karoṣi yad aśnāsi yaj juhoṣi dadāsi yat
yat tapasyasi kaunteya tat kuruṣva mad-arpaṇam
9.translate: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, and whatever austerity you perform, O Kaunteya, do that as an offering to Me.
9.sridhara:
Even offerings such as leaves and flowers must not be procured with great effort like sacrificial materials such as soma and animals. Then what should be done? He replies: “yat karoṣi.”
Whatever action you do—whether naturally or scripturally ordained—whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, and whatever austerity you perform, all that should be done in such a way that it is offered to Me. Do thus.

9.shlok:
शुभाशुभफलैरेवं मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः।
संन्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि।।९.२८।।
9.translit:
śubhāśubha-phalair evaṁ mokṣyase karma-bandhanaiḥ
saṁnyāsa-yoga-yuktātmā vimukto mām upaiṣyasi
9.translate: Thus shall you be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil results. Equipped with the yoga of renunciation, and liberated, you shall come to Me.
9.sridhara:
Now hear the result that you will attain by doing so: “śubha-aśubha-phalair evaṁ mokṣyase.”
By doing thus, you will be freed from the bondage of actions which result in pleasant and unpleasant fruits. Because your actions are offered to Me, the connection between you and their results no longer applies.
Thus freed from them, endowed with the yoga of renunciation—renunciation being the offering of all actions to Me, and that itself is yoga—and with a mind thus absorbed, you shall come to Me.

9.shlok:
समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः।
ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम्।।९.२९।।
9.translit:
samo 'haṁ sarva-bhūteṣu na me dveṣyo 'sti na priyaḥ
ye bhajanti tu māṁ bhaktyā mayi te teṣu cāpy aham
9.translate: I am equal to all beings. There is no one hateful or dear to Me. But those who worship Me with devotion—they are in Me, and I am also in them.
9.sridhara:
If You give liberation only to devotees and not to non-devotees, then is there partiality on Your part arising from attachment or aversion? To deny this, He says: “samaḥ aham.”
I am equal toward all beings. Therefore, no one is dear or hateful to Me.
Even so, those who worship Me—those devotees abide in Me. I too dwell in them, out of grace. The meaning is: just as fire removes cold and darkness only for those who approach it, not due to bias, and just as a wish-fulfilling tree bestows according to one’s desire, so too, even though I favor My devotees, it is not due to partiality. Rather, such is the greatness of My devotees.

9.shlok:
अपि चेत्सुदुराचारो भजते मामनन्यभाक्।
साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः।।९.३०।।
9.translit:
api cet su-durācāro bhajate mām ananya-bhāk
sādhur eva sa mantavyaḥ samyag vyavasito hi saḥ
9.translate: Even if one of very evil conduct worships Me with single-pointed devotion, he must be regarded as righteous, for he has rightly resolved.
9.sridhara:
The power of My devotion is beyond logic. This is shown now: “api cet.”
Even if someone is extremely wicked—if he does not worship other gods separately, but worships Me, Śrī Nārāyaṇa, with the understanding that Vāsudeva alone is Supreme—then he is indeed to be considered a sādhū, an exalted person.
Why? Because he has rightly resolved, thinking: “By devotion to the Supreme Lord alone, I shall attain fulfillment.” He has made a pure resolve.

9.shlok:
क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति।
कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि न मे भक्तः प्रणश्यति।।९.३१।।
9.translit:
kṣipraṁ bhavati dharmātmā śaśvac-chāntiṁ nigacchati
kaunteya pratijānīhi na me bhaktaḥ praṇaśyati
9.translate: Quickly he becomes righteous and attains eternal peace. O Kaunteya, declare for certain that My devotee never perishes.
9.sridhara:
Now, one might wonder how merely having a proper resolve makes such a person a sādhū (righteous). To clarify this, the Lord says: “kṣipram iti.”
Even though he was of extremely bad conduct, if he worships Me, he quickly becomes devoted to righteousness. Thereafter, he attains lasting peace—both eternal and of the nature of inner stillness (free of mental agitation), firmly established in the Supreme Lord.
To encourage Arjuna, whose heart may be unsettled by doubts such as, “Discerning people who are harsh in logic may not believe this,” the Lord says:
“O Kaunteya, go forth into assemblies resounding with conches and drums, raise your hand, and boldly proclaim—without hesitation—that even one who was of very sinful conduct, if he is My devotee, does not perish. Rather, he certainly becomes fulfilled.”
By your bold declaration, the skeptics will be silenced, and with their doubts destroyed, they will undoubtedly take refuge in you as their teacher.

9.shlok:
मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः।
स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम्।।९.३२।।
9.translit:
māṁ hi pārtha vyapāśritya ye 'pi syuḥ pāpa-yonayaḥ
striyo vaiśyās tathā śūdrās te 'pi yānti parāṁ gatim
9.translate: For, O Pārtha, even those of sinful birth—women, vaiśyas, and śūdras—taking refuge in Me, attain the supreme goal.
9.sridhara:
If devotion to Me purifies even one fallen from righteous conduct, what wonder is there in that? Since devotion to Me delivers even the unqualified and low-born from saṁsāra, that is now stated: “māṁ hi.”
Even those who may be of sinful birth—those born in degraded castes such as outcastes, or those like vaiśyas engaged only in agriculture and trade, or women and śūdras who are without entitlement to study the Vedas—if they take refuge in Me, that is, serve Me, they too attain the supreme goal. “Hi” means certainly.

9.shlok:
किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा।
अनित्यमसुखं लोकमिमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम्।।९.३३।।
9.translit:
kiṁ punar brāhmaṇāḥ puṇyā bhaktā rājarṣayas tathā
anityam asukhaṁ lokam imaṁ prāpya bhajasva mām
9.translate: How much more then the pure Brāhmaṇas and the devoted royal sages! Having attained this impermanent and joyless world, worship Me.
9.sridhara:
Since even the low-born attain the supreme goal, what need is there to speak of those of noble birth and righteous conduct who are My devotees? This is the intent of: “kiṁ punar.”
The virtuous (puṇyāḥ) Brāhmaṇas, those born into noble families; likewise, the royal sages—kṣatriyas who are both kings and seers—all such people certainly attain the supreme goal.
Therefore, having obtained this human birth in the form of a royal sage, worship Me.
Moreover, having attained this world—impermanent (anitya), without lasting joy (asukham), and mortal—do not delay due to its transience, nor strive for its fleeting pleasures. Instead, worship Me alone—this is the meaning.

9.shlok:
मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु।
मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं मत्परायणः।।९.३४।।
9.translit:
man-manā bhava mad-bhakto mad-yājī māṁ namaskuru
mām evaiṣyasi yuktvaivam ātmānaṁ mat-parāyaṇaḥ
9.translate: Fix your mind on Me, be devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow down to Me. In this way, having united yourself with Me, with Me as your supreme goal, you shall come to Me.
9.sridhara:
The Lord concludes by teaching the method of devotion: “man-manā iti.”
Let your mind be fixed on Me alone—that is, become one whose mind is entirely absorbed in Me. Likewise, become devoted to Me, My servant. Become one who offers sacrifice to Me, and bow to Me alone.
Thus, by these means, having fixed your mind on Me, absorbed in Me, and taking Me as your supreme aim (mat-parāyaṇaḥ), you shall attain Me, the embodiment of supreme bliss.

10.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
भूय एव महाबाहो श्रृणु मे परमं वचः।
यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया।।१०.१।।
10.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
bhūya eva mahābāho śṛṇu me paramaṁ vacaḥ
yat te 'haṁ prīyamāṇāya vakṣyāmi hita-kāmyayā
10.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Once again, O mighty-armed, listen to My supreme word, which I shall declare to you who are beloved, with the desire for your welfare.
10.sridhara:
The divine manifestations (vibhūtis) were briefly stated before at the beginning of Chapter ७—now, in Chapter १०, they are presented more fully for the purpose of perceiving the Lord everywhere.
Thus, in Chapters ७–९, the Supreme Lord who is to be worshipped has been described. His divine manifestations were shown briefly in Chapter ७ through verses such as “I am the taste in water, O Kaunteya,” etc. In Chapter ८, by statements like “I alone am the adhiyajña here.” In Chapter ९, through verses like “I am the season, I am the sacrifice,” etc.
Now, wishing to elaborate upon those very manifestations and to describe the necessity of devotion for His devotees, the Blessed Lord said: “Bhūya eva.”
“O mighty-armed,” whose strong arms are skilled in great deeds like performing one’s own duty in war or offering great service—“again, listen to My word.”
What kind of word? “Paramam”—supreme, meaning centered on the Supreme Self.
To you who are “prīyamāṇa”—beloved, who attain joy just from the nectar of My words—I shall declare this for your benefit, out of the desire to do what is good for you.

10.shlok:
न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः।
अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः।।१०.२।।
10.translit:
na me viduḥ sura-gaṇāḥ prabhavaṁ na maharṣayaḥ
aham ādir hi devānāṁ maharṣīṇāṁ ca sarvaśaḥ
10.translate: Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for I am, in every way, the source of the gods and the great sages.
10.sridhara:
Now, in reiterating what has already been stated, the reason for its difficulty of comprehension is given—“na me.”
Even the hosts of gods, and the great sages such as Bhṛgu and others, do not know My exalted origin—namely, My manifestation through various divine glories, despite Me being birthless.
Why is that? Because I am indeed the beginning—the cause—of the gods and great sages, in every way: as their source, as the one who initiates their intellects, and so on.
Therefore, without My grace, no one can know Me—this is the meaning.

10.shlok:
यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम्।
असम्मूढः स मर्त्येषु सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते।।१०.३।।
10.translit:
yo mām ajam anādiṁ ca vetti loka-maheśvaram
asammūḍhaḥ sa martyeṣu sarva-pāpaiḥ pramucyate
10.translate: He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds—he, undeluded among mortals, is released from all sins.
10.sridhara:
Now the result of knowing the Supreme Self in this way is stated: “yo mām.”
Since I am the cause of all, I have no beginning—that is, no cause—hence I am “anādi.” Thus, I am “aja”—unborn.
He who knows Me as the great Lord (maheśvara) of all the worlds, such a person among mortals is “asaṁmūḍha”—free from delusion—and is released from all sins.

10.shlok:
बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसंमोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः।
सुखं दुःखं भवोऽभावो भयं चाभयमेव च।।१०.४।।
10.translit:
buddhir jñānam asaṁmohaḥ kṣamā satyaṁ damaḥ śamaḥ
sukhaṁ duḥkhaṁ bhavo ’bhāvo bhayaṁ cābhayam eva ca
10.translate: Intellect, knowledge, freedom from delusion, forgiveness, truth, restraint, calmness, pleasure, pain, birth, death, fear, and also fearlessness—
10.sridhara: Continued in next verse.

10.shlok:
अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः।
भवन्ति भावाः भूतानां मत्त एव पृथग्विधाः।।१०.५।।
10.translit:
ahiṁsā samatā tuṣṭis tapo dānaṁ yaśo ’yaśaḥ
bhavanti bhāvā bhūtānāṁ matta eva pṛthag-vidhāḥ
10.translate: Non-injury, equanimity, contentment, austerity, charity, fame and infamy—these various dispositions of beings arise from Me alone.
10.sridhara:
Now, the Lord clearly affirms His status as the Great Lord of the worlds:
“Buddhiḥ” is the ability to discern between what is essential and non-essential.
“Jñānam” is knowledge related to the Self.
“Asaṁmohaḥ” is the absence of agitation.
“Kṣamā” is forbearance.
“Satyaṁ” is truthful speech.
“Damaḥ” is restraint of the external senses.
“Śamaḥ” is control of the inner faculties.
“Sukham” is that which is perceived as agreeable.
“Duḥkham” is the opposite of that.
“Bhavaḥ” is arising (birth); “abhāvaḥ” is the opposite (death).
“Bhayaṁ” is fear; “abhayaṁ” is the opposite of fear.
These qualities arise from Me—this is to be connected with the next verse.

Further:
“Ahiṁsā” is refraining from injuring others.
“Samatā” is absence of attachment and aversion—equanimity towards friend and foe.
“Tuṣṭiḥ” is contentment with what is obtained by fate.
“Tapaḥ” refers to austerity relating to body, etc., which will be described later.
“Dānam” is the offering of wealth righteously earned to a worthy recipient.
“Yaśaḥ” is good reputation; “ayaśaḥ” is ill-repute.

All these—beginning from intellect and knowledge, as well as their opposites like ignorance—are various dispositions of living beings that arise solely from Me.

10.shlok:
महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा।
मद्भावा मानसा जाता येषां लोक इमाः प्रजाः।।१०.६।।
10.translit:
maharṣayaḥ sapta pūrve catvāro manavas tathā
mad-bhāvā mānasā jātā yeṣāṁ loka imāḥ prajāḥ
10.translate: The seven great sages, the ancient four (Kumaras), and also the Manus—being of My nature and born from My mind—are those from whom all these beings in the world have descended.
10.sridhara: Further: “mahārṣayaḥ iti.” The seven great sages—Bṛgu and others—are known from the Purāṇas, as in the statement “these seven Brāhmaṇas have attained certainty,” and so on—thus well-established in the Purāṇic tradition. Prior even to them were four other great sages—Sanaka and others. Likewise, the Manus such as Svāyambhuva. These—being of My own nature (“mad-bhāvāḥ”), endowed with My power—were born from My very mind, from mere intention, as forms of Hiraṇyagarbha. This very power is described by the clause: “yeṣāṁ loka imāḥ prajāḥ”—from these sages and Manus such as Bṛgu and Sanaka, beings such as Brāhmaṇas in this world are born, flourishing in the forms of sons and grandsons, and also as disciples and grand-disciples, and so on.

10.shlok:
एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः।
सोऽविकम्पेन योगेन युज्यते नात्र संशयः।।१०.७।।
10.translit:
etāṁ vibhūtiṁ yogaṁ ca mama yo vetti tattvataḥ
so ’vikampena yogena yujyate nātra saṁśayaḥ
10.translate: He who knows in truth this majesty and Yoga of Mine is united with unwavering Yoga; there is no doubt about it.
10.sridhara: The fruit of true knowledge of the majesty and power just described is now stated—“etām iti.” He who knows in essence this majesty of Mine, characterized by beings like Bṛgu, and this Yoga, which is My divine power—he becomes united with unwavering Yoga, that is, with right knowledge free from doubt. There is no doubt about this.

10.shlok:
अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते।
इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भावसमन्विताः।।१०.८।।
10.translit:
ahaṁ sarvasya prabhavo mattaḥ sarvaṁ pravartate
iti matvā bhajante māṁ budhā bhāva-samanvitāḥ
10.translate: I am the origin of all; from Me everything proceeds. Understanding this, the wise worship Me with devotion.
10.sridhara: How, through knowledge of majesty and Yoga, one attains full understanding—this is shown in the next four verses beginning with “ahaṁ iti.” I am the origin (prabhavaḥ) of all, being the cause of creation through My majesty manifest as Bṛgu and others. And from Me alone proceed all things—such as intellect, knowledge, non-delusion, and so on. Thus knowing, the wise (budhāḥ), discerning ones, worship Me with minds filled with devotion.

10.shlok:
मच्चित्ता मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम्।
कथयन्तश्च मां नित्यं तुष्यन्ति च रमन्ति च।।१०.९।।
10.translit:
mat-cittā mad-gata-prāṇā bodhayantaḥ parasparam
kathayantaś ca māṁ nityaṁ tuṣyanti ca ramanti ca
10.translate: With minds fixed on Me, and lives devoted to Me, enlightening one another and always speaking of Me, they rejoice and delight.
10.sridhara: The devotion is loving devotion indeed—“mat-cittā iti.” Those whose minds are fixed on Me alone are called mat-cittāḥ. Those whose vital energies (prāṇāḥ), or senses, are dedicated to Me are mad-gata-prāṇāḥ—that is, those who have offered their lives to Me. Such wise ones (budhāḥ), enlightening one another about Me using reasoning based on scriptural proof such as the Upaniṣads, and constantly speaking of Me with intellect, rejoice (tuṣyanti) through inner satisfaction, and delight (ramanti) through bliss.

10.shlok:
तेषां सततयुक्तानां भजतां प्रीतिपूर्वकम्।
ददामि बुद्धियोगं तं येन मामुपयान्ति ते।।१०.१०।।
10.translit:
teṣāṁ satata-yuktānāṁ bhajatāṁ prīti-pūrvakam
dadāmi buddhi-yogaṁ taṁ yena mām upayānti te
10.translate: To those ever steadfast and worshipping Me with love, I give the Yoga of intelligence, by which they come to Me.
10.sridhara: To such persons, I grant true knowledge—“teṣām iti.” To those who are ever steadfast, whose minds are attached to Me, and who worship Me with love—I give that “buddhi-yoga,” the means of union, which is of the nature of discernment. “Tam” refers to that (yoga). By that means, those devotees reach Me.

10.shlok:
तेषामेवानुकम्पार्थमहमज्ञानजं तमः।
नाशयाम्यात्मभावस्थो ज्ञानदीपेन भास्वता।।१०.११।।
10.translit:
teṣām evānukampārtham aham ajñāna-jaṁ tamaḥ
nāśayāmy ātma-bhāvastho jñāna-dīpena bhāsvatā
10.translate: Out of mere compassion for them, I—dwelling in their own being—destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the radiant lamp of knowledge.
10.sridhara: Having granted the Yoga of discernment, I destroy the cycle of saṁsāra caused by ignorance, bringing it to the point of direct realization—this is stated: “teṣām iti.” Out of compassion (anukampārtham) for them, for the sake of grace alone, I destroy the darkness (tamaḥ) known as saṁsāra, which is born of ignorance. Where dwelling, and by what means do You destroy that darkness? That is answered: remaining situated in their mental function (ātma-bhāva-sthaḥ), I destroy it with the radiant (bhāsvatā), blazing lamp of knowledge characterized by illumination.

10.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
परं ब्रह्म परं धाम पवित्रं परमं भवान्।
पुरुषं शाश्वतं दिव्यमादिदेवमजं विभुम्।।१०.१२।।
10.translit:
arjuna uvāca
paraṁ brahma paraṁ dhāma pavitraṁ paramaṁ bhavān
puruṣaṁ śāśvataṁ divyam ādidevam ajaṁ vibhum
10.translate: Arjuna said: You are the Supreme Brahman, the supreme Abode, the supreme Purifier; the eternal, divine Person, the primal Deity, the unborn and all-pervading.
10.sridhara: Arjuna, desiring to know in detail the glories briefly described, praises the Lord—“paraṁ brahma iti” with seven attributes: You alone are the Supreme Brahman, and also the Supreme Abode (paraṁ dhāma), and the supreme Purifier (paramaṁ pavitram). Why is this so? Because You are the eternal (śāśvatam), the Person; also the divine (divyam), of the nature of radiance and self-luminosity; and also the Primal God (ādidevam), meaning the original among the gods. Likewise, You are the unborn (ajam), the unoriginated, and the all-pervading (vibhum). You alone are declared to be such.

10.shlok:
आहुस्त्वामृषयः सर्वे देवर्षिर्नारदस्तथा।
असितो देवलो व्यासः स्वयं चैव ब्रवीषि मे।।१०.१३।।
10.translit:
āhus tvām ṛṣayaḥ sarve devarṣir nāradas tathā
asito devalo vyāsaḥ svayaṁ caiva bravīṣi me
10.translate: All the sages have thus declared You, and so also the divine sage Nārada; likewise Asita, Devala, and Vyāsa; and now You Yourself are telling me.
10.sridhara: Who are they [that have declared this

10.shlok:
सर्वमेतदृतं मन्ये यन्मां वदसि केशव।
न हि ते भगवन् व्यक्तिं विदुर्देवा न दानवाः।।१०.१४।।
10.translit:
sarvam etad ṛtaṁ manye yan māṁ vadasi keśava
na hi te bhagavan vyaktiṁ vidur devā na dānavāḥ
10.translate: All this that You say to me, O Keśava, I believe to be true. O Lord, neither the gods nor the demons understand Your manifestation.
10.sridhara: Thus, now I no longer have any doubt regarding Your divine majesty—this is what is said: “sarvam iti.” All this—that You alone are the Supreme Brahman and so on—I consider to be true, everything You are telling me. That even the hosts of gods do not know You—this too I consider true, and so it is said: “na hi iti.” O Bhagavān, the gods do not know Your manifestation. They do not know that this manifestation is for the purpose of bestowing grace upon us. Nor do the demons know it is for the purpose of our subjugation—they certainly do not know.

10.shlok:
स्वयमेवात्मनाऽत्मानं वेत्थ त्वं पुरुषोत्तम।
भूतभावन भूतेश देवदेव जगत्पते।।१०.१५।।
10.translit:
svayam evātmanātmānaṁ vettha tvaṁ puruṣottama
bhūta-bhāvana bhūteśa deva-deva jagat-pate
10.translate: You alone know Yourself by Yourself, O Supreme Person—Creator of beings, Lord of beings, God of gods, Lord of the world.
10.sridhara: Then how is it known? “Svayam iti.” You alone know Yourself—not anyone else. And You know even by Yourself—not by any other means. Out of great reverence, Arjuna now addresses Him in many ways: O Supreme Person (puruṣottama)! These vocatives carry with them the reasons for His being Supreme: O Creator of beings (bhūta-bhāvana)! O Lord of beings (bhūteśa)! O Light of the gods (deva-deva)! O Lord of the universe (jagat-pate)!

10.shlok:
वक्तुमर्हस्यशेषेण दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः।
याभिर्विभूतिभिर्लोकानिमांस्त्वं व्याप्य तिष्ठसि।।१०.१६।।
10.translit:
vaktum arhasy aśeṣeṇa divyā hy ātma-vibhūtayaḥ
yābhir vibhūtibhir lokān imāṁs tvaṁ vyāpya tiṣṭhasi
10.translate: You alone are worthy to tell in full Your divine glories, by which, through these glories, You pervade all these worlds and remain.
10.sridhara: Since You alone know Your manifestation, not the gods and others, therefore You are alone worthy to speak of it. What kind of glories? Those that are divine (divyāḥ)—most extraordinary. You alone are qualified to tell them all in full. The phrase yābhir vibhūtibhiḥ (by which glories) is an adjective qualifying those divine manifestations—making their significance clear.

10.shlok:
कथं विद्यामहं योगिंस्त्वां सदा परिचिन्तयन्।
केषु केषु च भावेषु चिन्त्योऽसि भगवन्मया।।१०.१७।।
10.translit:
kathaṁ vidyām ahaṁ yogin tvāṁ sadā paricintayan
keṣu keṣu ca bhāveṣu cintyo ’si bhagavan mayā
10.translate: How shall I, ever meditating, know You, O Yogin? In what forms and aspects, O Blessed Lord, should I contemplate You?
10.sridhara: Showing the purpose of his request, Arjuna asks: “kathaṁ” (how), through these two verses. O Yogin! How—by what distinct manifestations—may I constantly think of You and thereby know You? Even though You are to be contemplated through various manifestations, in what particular objects should I contemplate You?

10.shlok:
विस्तरेणात्मनो योगं विभूतिं च जनार्दन।
भूयः कथय तृप्तिर्हि श्रृण्वतो नास्ति मेऽमृतम्।।१०.१८।।
10.translit:
vistareṇātmano yogaṁ vibhūtiṁ ca janārdana
bhūyaḥ kathaya tṛptir hi śṛṇvato nāsti me ’mṛtam
10.translate: Tell me again in detail, O Janārdana, of Your yoga and glories. For I am not satisfied by hearing this nectar-like speech of Yours.
10.sridhara: Thus, even if my mind is externally turned outward, let there still be contemplation on You through various kinds of manifestations—so tell it in detail, says Arjuna: “vistareṇa” (in detail). Please again speak to me of Your yoga—Your power consisting of omniscience, omnipotence, and so on—and Your glories. Why? Because, as I hear Your speech, which is like nectar, there is no satisfaction, no sense of fullness in me.

10.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
हन्त ते कथयिष्यामि दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः।
प्राधान्यतः कुरुश्रेष्ठ नास्त्यन्तो विस्तरस्य मे।।१०.१९।।
10.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
hanta te kathayiṣyāmi divyā hy ātma-vibhūtayaḥ
prādhānyataḥ kuru-śreṣṭha nāsty anto vistarasya me
10.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Very well, I shall tell you My divine glories—prominently, O best of the Kurus. There is no end to My detailed manifestations.
10.sridhara: Thus being requested, the Blessed Lord said: “Hanta te” (very well then, to you). “Hanta” is an expression of compassionate affection. Those divine glories of Mine—I shall tell them to you prominently. Why only a few? Because there is no end to the elaboration of My glories, therefore I will speak of only the principal ones.

10.shlok:
अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः।
अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च।।१०.२०।।
10.translit:
aham ātmā guḍākeśa sarva-bhūtāśaya-sthitaḥ
aham ādiś ca madhyaṁ ca bhūtānām anta eva ca
10.translate: I am the Self, O Guḍākeśa, dwelling in the hearts of all beings. I am also the beginning, the middle, and the end of all beings.
10.sridhara: Now, first, He describes a divine manifestation: “aham iti” (I am). O Guḍākeśa! I am the Supreme Self (paramātmā), dwelling within the hearts—the inner faculties—of all beings, characterized by qualities such as omniscience, and as their controller. I am the beginning—birth; the middle—existence; and the end—dissolution—of all beings. I alone am the cause of all beings, from origin to end.

10.shlok:
आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान्।
मरीचिर्मरुतामस्मि नक्षत्राणामहं शशी।।१०.२१।।
10.translit:
ādityānām ahaṁ viṣṇur jyotiṣāṁ ravir aṁśumān
marīcir marutām asmi nakṣatrāṇām ahaṁ śaśī
10.translate: Among the Ādityas I am Viṣṇu, among lights I am the radiant sun, among the Maruts I am Marīci, and among stars I am the moon.
10.sridhara: Now He begins stating His glories, from “ādityānām” to the end of the chapter. Among the twelve Ādityas, I am Viṣṇu, in the form of Vāmana. Among the luminous objects, I am the sun (Ravi), endowed with rays that pervade the universe. Among the Maruts, a group of deities, I am Marīci. Or, it may mean: among the seven groups of winds—known as Āvaha, Pravaha, Vivaha, Parāvaha, Udvaha, Saṁvaha, Parivaha—I am Marīci, the foremost. Among the stars, I am the moon. Here, in expressions such as ādityānām ahaṁ viṣṇuḥ, the genitive case (ṣaṣṭhī) mostly expresses specification or partitive relation; elsewhere, as in bhūtānām asmi cetanā, it expresses possession or association. This distinction will be clarified at the relevant places. Although Viṣṇu is also an incarnation, He is stated here as a manifestation (vibhūti) due to His extraordinary power. From this point on, although the meanings of the verses are clear, a brief explanation will be given in certain places.

10.shlok:
वेदानां सामवेदोऽस्मि देवानामस्मि वासवः।
इन्द्रियाणां मनश्चास्मि भूतानामस्मि चेतना।।१०.२२।।
10.translit:
vedānāṁ sāma-vedo ’smi devānām asmi vāsavaḥ
indriyāṇāṁ manaś cāsmi bhūtānām asmi cetanā
10.translate: Among the Vedas I am the Sāma Veda; among the gods I am Vāsava (Indra); among the senses I am the mind; among beings I am consciousness.
10.sridhara: Among the Vedas, I am the Sāma Veda. Among the gods, I am Vāsava (Indra). Among living beings, I am cetanā—the faculty of consciousness, the power of knowledge.

10.shlok:
रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम्।
वसूनां पावकश्चास्मि मेरुः शिखरिणामहम्।।१०.२३।।
10.translit:
rudrāṇāṁ śaṅkaraś cāsmi vitteśo yakṣa-rakṣasām
vasūnāṁ pāvakaś cāsmi meruḥ śikhariṇām aham
10.translate: Among the Rudras I am Śaṅkara, among Yakṣas and Rākṣasas I am the Lord of Wealth (Kubera), among the Vasus I am Pāvaka (Agni), and among lofty mountains I am Meru.
10.sridhara: Among the Rudras, I am Śaṅkara. Among the Yakṣas and Rākṣasas—who are grouped together due to similarity in cruelty—I am the Lord of Wealth, Kubera. Pāvaka is Agni, the fire. Among mountains with peaks, I am Meru.

10.shlok:
पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम्।
सेनानीनामहं स्कन्दः सरसामस्मि सागरः।।१०.२४।।
10.translit:
purodhasāṁ ca mukhyaṁ māṁ viddhi pārtha bṛhaspatim
senānīnām ahaṁ skandaḥ sarasām asmi sāgaraḥ
10.translate: Among priests, O Pārtha, know Me as the foremost—Bṛhaspati. Among generals I am Skanda; among bodies of water I am the ocean.
10.sridhara: Among the priests (purodhasaḥ), I am the foremost—Bṛhaspati—because he is the priest of the gods. Among commanders of armies, I am Skanda, the commander of the gods. Among stationary bodies of water, I am the ocean.

10.shlok:
महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम्।
यज्ञानां जपयज्ञोऽस्मि स्थावराणां हिमालयः।।१०.२५।।
10.translit:
maharṣīṇāṁ bhṛgur ahaṁ girām asmy ekam akṣaram
yajñānāṁ japa-yajño ’smi sthāvarāṇāṁ himālayaḥ
10.translate: Among great sages I am Bhṛgu; among words I am the single imperishable syllable (Om); among sacrifices I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among immovable things I am the Himālaya.
10.sridhara: Among the great sages, I am Bhṛgu. Among words—those made of parts—I am the one imperishable syllable known as “Om.” Among sacrifices, both śrauta and smārta, I am the silent sacrifice called japa.

10.shlok:
अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः।
गन्धर्वाणां चित्ररथः सिद्धानां कपिलो मुनिः।।१०.२६।।
10.translit:
aśvatthaḥ sarva-vṛkṣāṇāṁ devarṣīṇāṁ ca nāradaḥ
gandharvāṇāṁ citrarathaḥ siddhānāṁ kapilo muniḥ
10.translate: Among all trees, I am the Aśvattha (sacred fig); among divine sages, I am Nārada; among Gandharvas, I am Citraratha; among perfected beings, I am the sage Kapila.
10.sridhara: “Among all trees, I am the Aśvattha.” Among divine sages—those who, though themselves gods, have attained the status of seers by the vision of mantra—I am Nārada. Among the siddhas, who have realized the supreme truth right from their very birth, I am the sage named Kapila.

10.shlok:
उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम्।
ऐरावतं गजेन्द्राणां नराणां च नराधिपम्।।१०.२७।।
10.translit:
uccaiḥśravasam aśvānāṁ viddhi mām amṛtodbhavam
airāvataṁ gajendrāṇāṁ narāṇāṁ ca narādhipam
10.translate: Among horses, know Me as Uccaiḥśravas, born of nectar; among lordly elephants, I am Airāvata; and among men, I am the king.
10.sridhara: “Uccaiḥśravasam…” — Know that horse named Uccaiḥśravas, which arose from the churning of the ocean of milk for obtaining nectar, to be My vibhūti. The term “born of nectar” also applies to Airāvata. Among men, know Me to be the king.

10.shlok:
आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक्।
प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः।।१०.२८।।
10.translit:
āyudhānām ahaṁ vajraṁ dhenūnām asmi kāmadhuk
prajanaś cāsmi kandarpaḥ sarpāṇām asmi vāsukiḥ
10.translate: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt; among cows, I am the wish-fulfilling cow; I am Kandarpa, the cause of generation; among serpents, I am Vāsuki.
10.sridhara: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt. Kāma-dhuk means “she who yields desires”—i.e., the wish-fulfilling cow. I am Kandarpa, the deity of desire, who is the cause of procreation. But not just any desire focused on enjoyment alone is My vibhūti, because that would be unapproved by scripture. Among serpents—those with poison—I am Vāsuki, their king.

10.shlok:
अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम्।
पितृ़णामर्यमा चास्मि यमः संयमतामहम्।।१०.२९।।
10.translit:
anantaś cāsmi nāgānāṁ varuṇo yādasām aham
pitṝṇām aryamā cāsmi yamaḥ saṁyamatām aham
10.translate: Among Nāgas, I am Ananta; among beings of the waters, I am Varuṇa; among ancestors, I am Aryaman; among controllers, I am Yama.
10.sridhara: Among Nāgas, which are non-poisonous, I am Ananta, also known as Śeṣa. Among aquatic beings, I am Varuṇa, their ruler. Among Pitṛs (ancestral spirits), I am Aryaman, their king. Among those who restrain or regulate, I am Yama.

10.shlok:
प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम्।
मृगाणां च मृगेन्द्रोऽहं वैनतेयश्च पक्षिणाम्।।१०.३०।।
10.translit:
prahlādaś cāsmi daityānāṁ kālaḥ kalayatām aham
mṛgāṇāṁ ca mṛgendro ’haṁ vainateyaś ca pakṣiṇām
10.translate: Among the Daityas, I am Prahlāda; among those who measure (or control), I am Time; among beasts, I am the lion; among birds, I am the son of Vinatā (Garuḍa).
10.sridhara: Among the Daityas, I am Prahlāda. Among those who regulate or reckon, I am Time. Mṛgendraḥ means lion. Among birds, I am Garuḍa.

10.shlok:
पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम्।
झषाणां मकरश्चास्मि स्रोतसामस्मि जाह्नवी।।१०.३१।।
10.translit:
pavanaḥ pavatām asmi rāmaḥ śastra-bhṛtām aham
jhaṣāṇāṁ makaraś cāsmi srotasām asmi jāhnavī
10.translate: Among purifiers, I am the wind; among wielders of weapons, I am Rāma; among fishes, I am the makara (sea-monster); among streams, I am the Jāhnavī (Gaṅgā).
10.sridhara: “Among purifiers” (pavatām), that is, among those that purify or among swift-moving ones, I am the wind. Among wielders of weapons, I am Rāma, son of Daśaratha—or alternatively, Paraśurāma. Among fishes, I am the makara—a particular type of fish, possibly the giant whale (timingila). Among flowing waters (srotasām), I am the Bhāgīrathī (Gaṅgā).

10.shlok:
सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन।
अध्यात्मविद्या विद्यानां वादः प्रवदतामहम्।।१०.३२।।
10.translit:
sargāṇām ādir antaś ca madhyaṁ caivāham arjuna
adhyātma-vidyā vidyānāṁ vādaḥ pravadatām aham
10.translate: Of creations, O Arjuna, I am the beginning, the middle, and also the end; among all sciences, I am the knowledge of the Self; and among disputants, I am vāda (logical reasoning).
10.sridhara:
“Among creations” (sargāṇām)—those things that are created, such as ākāśa (space) and others—I am the beginning, middle, and end. In “I am the beginning and the middle” earlier (१०.२०), it was said with reference to being the Lord of creation; here, the point is that the origin, sustenance, and dissolution should be meditated upon as My vibhūti.

Among all sciences, I am adhyātma-vidyā, the knowledge of the ātman.

Among disputants (pravadatām), there are three known modes of discourse: vāda, jalpa, and vitaṇḍā. Among these, I am vāda. In jalpa, both parties put forth their position with scriptural and logical proofs and attempt to refute the other using fallacies (chala), false analogies (jāti), and the points of defeat (nigrahasthāna). In vitaṇḍā, one party simply attacks the other using these same tools without defending a position of their own. These two—jalpa and vitaṇḍā—are mere displays of argumentative ability, with the motive of victory. But vāda is undertaken by those free from desire, such as teacher and student, and is meant to determine the truth. Therefore, it is superior and said to be My vibhūti.

10.shlok:
अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च।
अहमेवाक्षयः कालो धाताऽहं विश्वतोमुखः।।१०.३३।।
10.translit:
akṣarāṇām akāro 'smi dvandvaḥ sāmāsikasya ca
ahamevākṣayaḥ kālo dhātā'haṁ viśvato-mukhaḥ
10.translate: Among letters, I am the letter 'A'; among compound words, I am the dual (Dvandva); I alone am the inexhaustible Time; I am the dispenser, facing all directions.
10.sridhara:
Among letters (akṣarāṇām), I am the letter 'A', because it is the foremost, being the basis of all speech. The Śruti says: “The letter ‘A’ is all speech; being modified with other sounds (sparśa and uṣma), it becomes manifold.”

Among compounds (samāsika), I am the Dvandva compound, like “Rāma-Kṛṣṇa,” because it gives equal prominence to both members.

I alone am Time in the inexhaustible (akṣaya) form as a continuous flow. In the earlier verse “Time among reckoners” (१०.३०), time was described in the sense of lifespan—measured in years, centuries, etc., which exhausts with the end of life. Here, it is infinite, uninterrupted time.

Among those who dispense the results of actions (karma-phala-vidhātṛṇām), I am Dhātā (the Dispenser), who faces all directions (viśvato-mukhaḥ), meaning I distribute the fruits of all actions.

10.shlok:
मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम्।
कीर्तिः श्रीर्वाक्च नारीणां स्मृतिर्मेधा धृतिः क्षमा।।१०.३४।।
10.translit:
mṛtyuḥ sarva-haraś cāham udbhavaś ca bhaviṣyatām
kīrtiḥ śrīr vāk ca nārīṇāṁ smṛtir medhā dhṛtiḥ kṣamā
10.translate: I am Death, the all-devouring; and I am the origin of future beings; among women, I am fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness, and forgiveness.
10.sridhara:
Among those who bring destruction, I am Death, the all-devouring. Among beings who are to be (bhaviṣyatām), I am their origin, meaning I am their arising or prosperity.

Among women (nāriṇām), I am the seven divine qualities—fame (kīrti), prosperity (śrī), speech (vāk), memory (smṛti), intelligence (medhā), firmness (dhṛti), and forgiveness (kṣamā). These are My vibhūtis because even a mere reflection of these qualities makes beings praiseworthy.

10.shlok:
बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम्।
मासानां मार्गशीर्षोऽहमृतूनां कुसुमाकरः।।१०.३५।।
10.translit:
bṛhat-sāma tathā sāmnāṁ gāyatrī chandasām aham
māsānāṁ mārga-śīrṣo 'ham ṛtūnāṁ kusumākaraḥ
10.translate: Among the Sāma hymns, I am the Bṛhat-Sāma; among metres, I am Gāyatrī; among months, I am Mārgaśīrṣa; among seasons, I am the flowery season (spring).
10.sridhara:
The Bṛhat-Sāma is the Sāman sung to the verse beginning tvām id dhi havāmahe; in it, Indra is praised as the Supreme Lord, and thus it is the foremost.

Among chandas (metrical hymns), I am Gāyatrī, which confers Brāhmaṇa status upon one who receives initiation and is used in the Soma-yāga. Hence, it is the highest.

Kusumākaraḥ refers to spring (vasanta).

10.shlok:
द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम्।
जयोऽस्मि व्यवसायोऽस्मि सत्त्वं सत्त्ववतामहम्।।१०.३६।।
10.translit:
dyūtaṁ chalayatām asmi tejas tejasvinām aham
jayo'smi vyavasāyo'smi sattvaṁ sattvavatām aham
10.translate: I am gambling among those who cheat; I am the brilliance of the brilliant; I am victory; I am effort; I am the strength of the strong.
10.sridhara: “I am gambling (dyūtam) among those who cheat each other”—that is, I am connected with gambling, which is practiced by those intent on mutual deception. I am the brilliance (tejas) among the brilliant ones (tejasvinaḥ). I am victory among the victorious. I am the effort (vyavasāyaḥ)—that is, the striving—among the industrious. I am the quality of sattva among those who possess sattva.

10.shlok:
वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनंजयः।
मुनीनामप्यहं व्यासः कवीनामुशना कविः।।१०.३७।।
10.translit:
vṛṣṇīnām vāsudevo'smi pāṇḍavānāṁ dhanañjayaḥ
munīnām apy ahaṁ vyāsaḥ kavīnām uśanā kaviḥ
10.translate: Among the Vṛṣṇis, I am Vāsudeva; among the Pāṇḍavas, I am Dhanañjaya (Arjuna); among sages, I am Vyāsa; among poets, I am Uśanā (Śukra).
10.sridhara: Among the Vṛṣṇis, I am Vāsudeva—namely, I, who am instructing you. Among the Pāṇḍavas, you yourself, Dhanañjaya, are My vibhūti. Among sages (munīnām), those who engage in deep reflection on the meaning of the Vedas, I am Vedavyāsa. Among poets (kavīnām)—those who are seers of poetic insight—I am Uśanā, known as Śukra.

10.shlok:
दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम्।
मौनं चैवास्मि गुह्यानां ज्ञानं ज्ञानवतामहम्।।१०.३८।।
10.translit:
daṇḍo damayatām asmi nītir asmi jigīṣatām
maunaṁ caivāsmi guhyānāṁ jñānaṁ jñānavatām aham
10.translate: Among those who discipline, I am the rod; among those who seek victory, I am policy; among secrets, I am silence; and among the wise, I am knowledge.
10.sridhara: Among those who punish (damayatām), I am the rod (daṇḍa)—that by which even the undisciplined become disciplined; that rod is My vibhūti. Among those who desire to conquer, I am policy (nītiḥ) in the form of strategies like conciliation, division, gift, and force. Among secrets (guhyānām), I am silence (maunam), that is, not speaking—for the intention of one who remains silent is unknown. Among knowers of truth (jñānavatām), I am that knowledge (jñāna).

10.shlok:
यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन।
न तदस्ति विना यत्स्यान्मया भूतं चराचरम्।।१०.३९।।
10.translit:
yac cāpi sarva-bhūtānāṁ bījaṁ tad aham arjuna
na tad asti vinā yat syān mayā bhūtaṁ carācaram
10.translate: And whatever is the seed of all beings, that, O Arjuna, I am; there is no being, moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.
10.sridhara: “And whatever is the seed (bījam) of all beings”—that is, the cause of sprouting or growth—I am that. The reason is this: there is no living being, whether moving or unmoving, that could exist apart from Me.

10.shlok:
नान्तोऽस्ति मम दिव्यानां विभूतीनां परंतप।
एष तूद्देशतः प्रोक्तो विभूतेर्विस्तरो मया।।१०.४०।।
10.translit:
nānto'sti mama divyānāṁ vibhūtīnām paraṁtapa
eṣa tūddeśataḥ prokto vibhūter vistaro mayā
10.translate: There is no end to My divine manifestations, O scorcher of foes; but this account of My vibhūtis has been stated by Me in brief.
10.sridhara: He concludes the topic: “There is no end” (nāntaḥ asti). Because My vibhūtis are infinite, they cannot be described exhaustively. This expansion (vistara) of My vibhūtis has thus been briefly mentioned (uddeśataḥ).

10.shlok:
यद्यद्विभूतिमत्सत्त्वं श्रीमदूर्जितमेव वा।
तत्तदेवावगच्छ त्वं मम तेजोंऽशसंभवम्।।१०.४१।।
10.translit:
yad yad vibhūtimat sattvaṁ śrīmad ūrjitam eva vā
tat tad evāvagaccha tvaṁ mama tejoṁśa-sambhavam
10.translate: Whatever being is possessed of glory, prosperity, or power—know that each of them is born of a portion of My splendour.
10.sridhara: Again, to the one who still desires to hear, He explains concisely and with expectation: “Whatever is endowed with vibhūti (manifest majesty), or with wealth (śrī), or is exceedingly powerful (ūrjita) by some quality such as brilliance, strength, etc.—whatever such being (sattva) exists, know that all of it is born from a portion of My splendour (tejas).”

10.shlok:
अथवा बहुनैतेन किं ज्ञातेन तवार्जुन।
विष्टभ्याहमिदं कृत्स्नमेकांशेन स्थितो जगत्।।१०.४२।।
10.translit:
athavā bahunaitena kiṁ jñātena tavārjuna
viṣṭabhyāham idaṁ kṛtsnam ekaṁśena sthito jagat
10.translate: Or, what use is there for you in knowing all this in detail, O Arjuna? I exist, pervading and sustaining this entire world with just one part of Myself.
10.sridhara: Or else, what is the use of this partial knowledge—rather, cultivate an equal vision everywhere. Thus He says: “Or (athavā), what need have you for knowing many separate details?” That which is this entire universe—I exist, pervading and upholding it with just a single portion (eka-aṁśena). There is nothing apart from Me. As the Śruti declares: “All beings are a quarter of Him.” (Ṛg Veda १०.९०.३)

11.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
मदनुग्रहाय परमं गुह्यमध्यात्मसंज्ञितम्।
यत्त्वयोक्तं वचस्तेन मोहोऽयं विगतो मम।।११.१।।
11.translit:
arjuna uvāca
madanugrahāya paramaṁ guhyam adhyātmasaṁjñitam
yat tvayoktaṁ vacas tena moho’yaṁ vigato mama
11.translate: Arjuna said: Out of compassion for me, You have spoken this supreme secret called adhyātma. By that word, this delusion of mine has been dispelled.
11.sridhara: After describing His divine glories out of supreme compassion, the Lord revealed the Universal Form to the eager Arjuna. Hence, he says: “Viṣṭabhyāham idaṁ kṛtsnam ekaṁśena sthito jagat” (१०.४२)—in this way, the form of the Supreme Lord, encompassing the entire universe, was suggested. Wishing to see that, and rejoicing in what was said earlier, Arjuna spoke this verse beginning with “madanugrahāya,” comprising four parts. “Out of compassion for me” means for the removal of my sorrow. “The supreme,” i.e., supremely rooted in the highest truth; “secret,” i.e., very hidden—even so, that which is called adhyātma, relating to discrimination between Self and not-Self, that statement which You spoke, such as: “You grieve for those who should not be grieved for…” (२.११) and the teachings extending up to the end of the sixth chapter—by that word, this delusion of mine has been destroyed. That delusion was of the form, “I am the slayer, they are slain,” etc., and it is now gone—why? Because You have declared that the Self is devoid of agency and such attributes.

11.shlok:
भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया।
त्वत्तः कमलपत्राक्ष माहात्म्यमपि चाव्ययम्।।११.२।।
11.translit:
bhavāpyayau hi bhūtānāṁ śrutau vistaraśo mayā
tvattaḥ kamalapatrākṣa māhātmyam api cāvyayam
11.translate: Indeed, the origin and dissolution of beings have been heard by me in detail from You, O lotus-eyed One, and also Your imperishable greatness.
11.sridhara: Moreover—“bhavāpyayau” means the creation and dissolution of beings. These I have heard from You alone, i.e., directly from You. I have heard in detail, again and again, in statements like “I am the source and dissolution of the entire world,” etc. O lotus-eyed One—You whose eyes are wide and clear like lotus petals—Your imperishable greatness also has been heard. Despite being the agent of the creation, dissolution, and so on of the universe, despite causing the good and evil deeds of beings, despite being the bestower of varied results such as bondage and liberation—yet You remain unaffected, impartial, unattached, and indifferent. This immeasurable greatness I have heard through verses like: “The unmanifest takes a form,” “I have pervaded this entire universe,” “Actions do not bind Me,” “I am equal in all beings,” and so on. Therefore, though the jīvas are dependent on You, still the notion that “I am the doer,” etc.,—that delusion of mine has been removed. This is the import.

11.shlok:
एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर।
द्रष्टुमिच्छामि ते रूपमैश्वरं पुरुषोत्तम।।११.३।।
11.translit:
evam etad yathāttha tvam ātmānaṁ parameśvara
draṣṭum icchāmi te rūpam aiśvaraṁ puruṣottama
11.translate: O Supreme Lord, it is even so as You have described Yourself. O Supreme Person, I desire to see Your divine form.
11.sridhara: Moreover—“evam etat”: that which I have heard such as “The origin and dissolution of beings,” and that You now describe Yourself as “I pervade this entire world” and so on—O Supreme Lord, it is indeed thus. Even here, I have no doubt. Nevertheless, O Supreme Person, I desire to see Your form that is divine—endowed with omniscience, lordliness, power, strength, heroism, and brilliance—out of curiosity.

11.shlok:
मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो।
योगेश्वर ततो मे त्वं दर्शयाऽत्मानमव्ययम्।।११.४।।
11.translit:
manyase yadi tac chakyaṁ mayā draṣṭum iti prabho
yogeśvara tato me tvaṁ darśayātmānam avyayam
11.translate: If You think that I am capable of seeing it, O Lord, then, O Master of Yoga, show me Your imperishable Self.
11.sridhara: By saying this, it is not implied, “I do not wish to see it”—thus You must reveal that form. Rather—“if You think so.” O Lord of Yogins, if You think that I, Arjuna, am capable of seeing that form, then show me Your Self possessed of that form, imperishable and eternal.

11.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
पश्य मे पार्थ रूपाणि शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः।
नानाविधानि दिव्यानि नानावर्णाकृतीनि च।।११.५।।
11.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
paśya me pārtha rūpāṇi śataśo’tha sahasraśaḥ
nānāvidhāni divyāni nānāvarṇākṛtīni ca
11.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Behold, O Pārtha, My forms by the hundreds and thousands—of various kinds, divine, and of many colors and shapes.
11.sridhara: Thus requested, intending to show that astonishing form, He draws Arjuna’s attention: “The Blessed Lord said.” With four words beginning with “paśya,” He speaks. Though the form is one, because of its manifoldness, the plural “forms” is used. Behold My forms—countless, of many kinds, divine, beyond the worldly. “Varṇāḥ” means colors such as white and black. “Ākṛtayaḥ” means the specific arrangements of limbs and features. Those forms which have many colors and shapes are called “nānāvarṇākṛtīni.”

11.shlok:
पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्विनौ मरुतस्तथा।
बहून्यदृष्टपूर्वाणि पश्याऽश्चर्याणि भारत।।११.६।।
11.translit:
paśyādityān vasūn rudrān aśvinau marutas tathā
bahūn adṛṣṭapūrvāṇi paśyāścaryāṇi bhārata
11.translate: Behold the Ādityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Aśvins, and also the Maruts. Behold many wonders never seen before, O Bhārata.
11.sridhara: He speaks of those very forms: “Behold.” See the Ādityas and others in My body. The Maruts are a particular class of forty-nine deities. “Never seen before”—forms that have not been seen earlier either by you or by others. “Wonders” means supremely marvelous forms.

11.shlok:
इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम्।
मम देहे गुडाकेश यच्चान्यद्द्रष्टुमिच्छसि।।११.७।।
11.translit:
ihaikasthaṁ jagat kṛtsnaṁ paśyādya sacarācaram
mama dehe guḍākeśa yaccānyad draṣṭum icchasi
11.translate: Behold now, in one place, the entire universe with all its moving and unmoving beings, centered in My body, O Guḍākeśa, and also whatever else you wish to see.
11.sridhara: Moreover: “Here,” in this body of Mine, the entire universe—both moving and unmoving—which cannot be seen in its entirety even after roaming for millions of years, is now situated in one place in the form of My limbs. See it now, at this very moment. And whatever else you desire to see—such as the substratum of the world, the various states of the universe, and events like victory and defeat—see all that as well.

11.shlok:
न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा।
दिव्यं ददामि ते चक्षुः पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्।।११.८।।
11.translit:
na tu māṁ śakyase draṣṭum anenaiva svacakṣuṣā
divyaṁ dadāmi te cakṣuḥ paśya me yogam aiśvaram
11.translate: But you are not able to see Me with these very eyes of yours; I grant you the divine eye. Behold My lordly Yoga.
11.sridhara: In response to Arjuna’s earlier statement, “If You think it possible for me to see,” He says: “Not with this.” With this very physical eye of yours, you are not able—nor will you be able—to see Me. Therefore, I grant you a divine eye, one that is not ordinary, but spiritual in nature. Behold My Yoga characterized by lordship—namely, My power to accomplish even the seemingly impossible.

11.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजन्महायोगेश्वरो हरिः।
दर्शयामास पार्थाय परमं रूपमैश्वरम्।।११.९।।
11.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
evam uktvā tato rājan mahāyogeśvaro hariḥ
darśayāmāsa pārthāya paramaṁ rūpam aiśvaram
11.translate: Sañjaya said: Having spoken thus, then, O King, the great Lord of Yoga, Hari, showed to Pārtha His supreme, lordly form.
11.sridhara: Having spoken in this way, the Lord revealed the form to Arjuna. Seeing that form, Arjuna offered words to Śrī Kṛṣṇa. That is the context expressed in the six verses beginning with “evam uktvā,” which Sañjaya speaks to Dhṛtarāṣṭra. “O King”—O Dhṛtarāṣṭra! Hari, who is both great and the Lord of Yoga, revealed His supreme and lordly form.

11.shlok:
अनेकवक्त्रनयनमनेकाद्भुतदर्शनम्।
अनेकदिव्याभरणं दिव्यानेकोद्यतायुधम्।।११.१०।।
11.translit:
aneka-vaktra-nayanam anekād-bhuta-darśanam
anekadivyābharaṇaṁ divyānekodyatāyudham
11.translate: With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wondrous sights, with numerous divine ornaments, and with many divine weapons held aloft.
11.sridhara: What was that form like? He says: “aneka” (many). That which possesses many mouths and eyes; that in which there are many wondrous sights; that which is adorned with many divine ornaments; that which contains many divine and raised weapons—all of that is indicated.

11.shlok:
दिव्यमाल्याम्बरधरं दिव्यगन्धानुलेपनम्।
सर्वाश्चर्यमयं देवमनन्तं विश्वतोमुखम्।।११.११।।
11.translit:
divya-mālyāmbara-dharaṁ divya-gandhānulepanam
sarvāścaryamayaṁ devam anantaṁ viśvato-mukham
11.translate: Wearing divine garlands and garments, anointed with divine fragrances, the all-wonderful, resplendent One, infinite, with faces on all sides.
11.sridhara: Moreover: “divya-mālya-ambara-dharam”—wearing divine garlands and garments. “Divya-gandha-anulepanam”—anointed with unguents of divine fragrance. “Sarvāścaryamayam”—consisting of innumerable marvels. “Devam”—resplendent in nature. “Anantam”—unbounded. “Viśvato-mukham”—one who has faces in every direction.

11.shlok:
दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता।
यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः।।११.१२।।
11.translit:
divi sūrya-sahasrasya bhaved yugapad utthitā
yadi bhāḥ sadṛśī sā syād bhāsas tasya mahātmanaḥ
11.translate: If the light of a thousand suns were to rise all at once in the sky, such would be like the radiance of that great being.
11.sridhara: The matchlessness of the brilliance of the universal form is described: “in the sky” (divi)—in the heavenly expanse—if the radiance of a thousand suns were to rise simultaneously, then that radiance might somewhat resemble the brilliance of that great Self—the Universal Form. The implication is: there is no other adequate comparison. This should be connected to the previous verse—“such a form He showed.”

11.shlok:
तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा।
अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा।।११.१३।।
11.translit:
tatraikasthaṁ jagat kṛtsnaṁ pravibhaktam anekadhā
apaśyad deva-devasya śarīre pāṇḍavas tadā
11.translate: Then, in the body of the God of gods, the Pāṇḍava saw the whole universe, divided into many forms, existing as one.
11.sridhara: What happened after that? Sanjaya says: “There” (tatra), in that place. The entire universe, divided into many kinds—existing through various distinctions—was seen by Arjuna as existing in one place in the body of the God of gods, with those parts being limbs of that body.

11.shlok:
ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जयः।
प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत।।११.१४।।
11.translit:
tataḥ sa vismayāviṣṭo hṛṣṭa-romā dhanañjayaḥ
praṇamya śirasā devaṁ kṛtāñjalir abhāṣata
11.translate: Then, filled with wonder and with hair standing on end, Dhanañjaya bowed his head to the God and spoke with joined palms.
11.sridhara: Seeing thus, what did he do? He says: “Then”—immediately after the vision—he became filled, overwhelmed with astonishment. His hair, thrilled with joy, stood on end. That Dhanañjaya bowed his head to the Lord, and with hands joined in reverence, began to speak.

11.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे
सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान्।
ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थं
ऋषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान्।।११.१५।।
11.translit:
arjuna uvāca
paśyāmi devāṁs tava deva dehe
sarvāṁs tathā bhūta-viśeṣa-saṅghān
brahmāṇam īśaṁ kamalāsana-sthaṁ
ṛṣīṁś ca sarvān uragāṁś ca divyān
11.translate: Arjuna said: I see all the gods, O Lord, in Your body, and all the various hosts of beings; Brahmā, the Lord seated on the lotus, the sages, and all the celestial serpents.
11.sridhara: Now begins Arjuna’s speech: “I see…”—with seventeen verses. “O Lord, in Your body I see all the gods, such as the Ādityas, and also all the various hosts of beings such as those born from womb, egg, etc. I see also the divine sages such as Vasiṣṭha, and celestial serpents such as Takṣaka. And also I see the lord of the gods—Brahmā. How so? Seated upon a lotus—situated on the lotus at the center of the Earth’s navel, i.e., on Mount Meru. Or, seated on the lotus sprouting from Your own navel.

11.shlok:
अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं
पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम्।
नान्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं
पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप।।११.१६।।
11.translit:
aneka-bāhūdara-vaktra-netraṁ
paśyāmi tvāṁ sarvato ’nanta-rūpam
nāntaṁ na madhyaṁ na punas tavādiṁ
paśyāmi viśveśvara viśvarūpa
11.translate: I see You with many arms, bellies, mouths, and eyes—of infinite form on every side. I do not see an end, a middle, or a beginning of Yours, O Lord of the universe, O Cosmic Form.
11.sridhara: Further: “With many…”—I see You as having many arms and other limbs. I see You as possessing infinite forms, and present on every side. Yet I do not see an end, middle, or beginning of You, because You are all-pervading.

11.shlok:
किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च
तेजोराशिं सर्वतोदीप्तिमन्तम्।
पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ताद्
दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम्।।११.१७।।
11.translit:
kirīṭinaṁ gadinaṁ cakriṇaṁ ca
tejorāśiṁ sarvato dīptimantam
paśyāmi tvāṁ durnirīkṣyaṁ samantād
dīptānalārka-dyutim aprameyam
11.translate: I see You wearing a crown, holding a mace and discus, a mass of radiance shining in all directions. You are difficult to look at from all sides, blazing like fire and the sun, and immeasurable.
