11.sridhara: Further: “Wearing a crown…”—I see You wearing a crown, bearing a mace, and holding a discus. You are a mass of radiance, shining in all directions. You are difficult to look at. The reason for that is: like the brightness of blazing fire and the sun, is Your brilliance. Therefore, You are immeasurable—of such a nature, You cannot be precisely known. I see You everywhere like this.

11.shlok:
त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं
त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्।
त्वमव्ययः शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता
सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे।।११.१८।।
11.translit:
tvam akṣaraṁ paramaṁ veditavyaṁ
tvam asya viśvasya paraṁ nidhānam
tvam avyayaḥ śāśvata-dharma-goptā
sanātanas tvaṁ puruṣo mato me
11.translate: You are the imperishable, the supreme to be known. You are the highest support of this universe. You are the unchanging protector of the eternal dharma. You are the eternal Person—I consider You thus.
11.sridhara: Because Your divine majesty is beyond reasoning, therefore: “You are the imperishable, the supreme Brahman.” How so? You are that which is to be known by those who seek liberation. You alone are the supreme support of this universe—that into which all is placed. Therefore, You are unchanging, eternal, the protector of the eternal dharma, and eternal Yourself. You are the Puruṣa—the Supreme Person—this is my conviction.

11.shlok:
अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्यं
अनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम्।
पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रं
स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम्।।११.१९।।
11.translit:
anādi-madhyāntaṁ ananta-vīryaṁ
ananta-bāhuṁ śaśi-sūrya-netram
paśyāmi tvāṁ dīpta-hutāśa-vaktraṁ
svatejasā viśvam idaṁ tapantam
11.translate: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, infinite in power, with countless arms, the moon and sun as Your eyes, with blazing fire as Your mouth, heating this whole universe with Your own radiance.
11.sridhara: Further: “Without beginning…”—without beginning, middle, or end; free from creation, sustenance, and dissolution. Of infinite power—of immeasurable energy. Of countless arms—having endless arms. The moon and sun are Your eyes—of such a nature, I see You. Likewise, blazing fire is present in Your mouths—I see You heating this whole universe with Your own radiance.

11.shlok:
द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि
व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वाः।
दृष्ट्वाऽद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं
लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन्।।११.२०।।
11.translit:
dyāvā-pṛthivyor idam antaraṁ hi
vyāptaṁ tvayāikena diśaś ca sarvāḥ
dṛṣṭvādbhutaṁ rūpam ugraṁ tavedaṁ
loka-trayaṁ pravyathitaṁ mahātman
11.translate: This space between heaven and earth, and all the directions, is indeed filled by You alone. Seeing this marvelous and terrible form of Yours, the three worlds are greatly troubled, O Great-souled One.
11.sridhara: Further: “This space…”—the space between heaven and earth, namely the sky, is pervaded by You alone. And all directions are filled (by You). Seeing this marvelous—never before seen—terrible (fearsome) form of Yours, the three worlds are agitated and extremely fearful. The sense “I see this” carries over from the previous verse.

11.shlok:
अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति
केचिद्भीताः प्राञ्जलयो गृणन्ति।
स्वस्तीत्युक्त्वा महर्षिसिद्धसङ्घाः
स्तुवन्ति त्वां स्तुतिभिः पुष्कलाभिः।।११.२१।।
11.translit:
amī hi tvāṁ surasaṅghā viśanti
kecid bhītāḥ prāñjalayo gṛṇanti
svastīty uktvā maharṣi-siddha-saṅghāḥ
stuvanti tvāṁ stutibhiḥ puṣkalābhiḥ
11.translate: Indeed, these hosts of gods are entering into You; some, afraid, with joined palms, are praising You. Saying “May it be well,” bands of great sages and perfected beings praise You with abundant hymns.
11.sridhara: Further: “Indeed, these…”—These groups of gods, being afraid, are entering into You, seeking refuge. Among them, some who are extremely frightened, standing even at a distance with hands joined in reverence, are glorifying You—entreating You with prayers such as “Victory, victory! Protect! Protect!” The rest is clear.

11.shlok:
रुद्रादित्या वसवो ये च साध्या
विश्वेऽश्विनौ मरुतश्चोष्मपाश्च।
गन्धर्वयक्षासुरसिद्धसङ्घा
वीक्षन्ते त्वां विस्मिताश्चैव सर्वे।।११.२२।।
11.translit:
rudrādityā vasavo ye ca sādhyā
viśve ’śvinau marutaś coṣmapāś ca
gandharva-yakṣāsura-siddha-saṅghā
vīkṣante tvāṁ vismitāś caiva sarve
11.translate: The Rudras, Ādityas, Vasus, Sādhyas, Viśvedevas, the two Aśvins, Maruts, and the manes, along with hosts of Gandharvas, Yakṣas, Asuras, and Siddhas—all gaze upon You, amazed.
11.sridhara: Further: “The Rudras…”—The Rudras, Ādityas, Vasus, and the gods known as Sādhyas; the Viśvedevas; the twin gods Aśvins; the Maruts, the hosts of wind-gods; the ūṣmapās—those who drink the vapor (of offerings), namely, the Pitṛs. According to the śruti: “The ūṣmabhāgas are the Pitṛs.” And the smṛti says: “As long as food remains hot, as long as it is eaten in silence, and as long as the host does not ask about the quality of the offering, the Pitṛs partake of its essence.” The Gandharvas, Yakṣas, and Asuras like Virocana, and the bands of Siddhas—all of them, being amazed, are looking upon You. This is the construction.

11.shlok:
रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं
महाबाहो बहुबाहूरुपादम्।
बहूदरं बहुदंष्ट्राकरालं
दृष्ट्वा लोकाः प्रव्यथितास्तथाऽहम्।।११.२३।।
11.translit:
rūpaṁ mahat te bahu-vaktra-netraṁ
mahā-bāho bahu-bāhūru-pādam
bahūdaraṁ bahu-daṁṣṭrā-karālaṁ
dṛṣṭvā lokāḥ pravyathitās tathāham
11.translate: Seeing Your immense form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed, with many arms, thighs, and feet, with many bellies, and terrifying with many fangs—the worlds are stricken with fear, and so am I.
11.sridhara: Further: “Your form…”—O mighty-armed! Seeing Your immense, exceedingly powerful form, all the worlds have become greatly agitated, and so too am I. What kind of form is seen? One having many mouths and eyes, many arms, thighs, and feet; many bellies; and dreadful, with many fangs—this is the meaning of “karāla” (terrifying). In other words, it is fierce.

11.shlok:
नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं
व्यात्ताननं दीप्तविशालनेत्रम्।
दृष्ट्वा हि त्वां प्रव्यथितान्तरात्मा
धृतिं न विन्दामि शमं च विष्णो।।११.२४।।
11.translit:
nabhaḥ-spṛśaṁ dīptam aneka-varṇaṁ
vyāttānanaṁ dīpta-viśāla-netram
dṛṣṭvā hi tvāṁ pravyathitāntarātmā
dhṛtiṁ na vindāmi śamaṁ ca viṣṇo
11.translate: Touching the sky, blazing, multicolored, with mouths wide open and large glowing eyes—on seeing You, my inner self is stricken with fear; I find neither steadiness nor peace, O Viṣṇu.
11.sridhara: Not only am I afraid—that alone is not all—but also: “Touching the sky…”—That which touches the sky is called nabhaḥ-spṛśam; that is, pervading the sky. Blazing—endowed with radiance. Multicolored—of many hues. Having wide-open mouths and glowing, vast eyes—seeing You thus, I, whose inner self (mind) is shaken, do not find courage nor tranquility.

11.shlok:
दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि
दृष्ट्वैव कालानलसन्निभानि।
दिशो न जाने न लभे च शर्म
प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास।।११.२५।।
11.translit:
daṁṣṭrā-karālāni ca te mukhāni
dṛṣṭvaiva kālānala-sannibhāni
diśo na jāne na labhe ca śarma
prasīda deveśa jagan-nivāsa
11.translate: Seeing Your mouths, fearful with fangs and resembling the fire of destruction, I do not know the directions, nor do I find peace. Be gracious, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe.
11.sridhara: Further: “With fangs…”—O Lord of the gods! Seeing Your mouths, terrifying with fangs and resembling the fire of destruction (kālānala), due to the flood of fear, I do not know the directions, nor do I obtain peace. O Abode of the universe, be pleased!

11.shlok:
अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राः
सर्वे सहैवावनिपालसङ्घैः।
भीष्मो द्रोणः सूतपुत्रस्तथाऽसौ
सहास्मदीयैरपि योधमुख्यैः।।११.२६।।
11.translit:
amī ca tvāṁ dhṛtarāṣṭrasya putrāḥ
sarve sahaivāvanipāla-saṅghaiḥ
bhīṣmo droṇaḥ sūta-putras tathāsau
sahāsmadīyair api yodha-mukhyaiḥ
11.translate: These sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, all of them, along with the groups of kings; Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and that son of a charioteer; together with the foremost of our warriors also—they are entering into You.
11.sridhara: What was stated earlier—"Behold in My body also whatever else you desire to see"—by this, the Lord had said to Arjuna that he should see in His form the future events of the battle such as victory and defeat. Now, seeing that, he says: “These sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra…”—The sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra like Duryodhana—all of them, along with the rulers of the earth like Jayadratha, are entering into Your mouths. This is to be connected with the next verse. Likewise, Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and that son of a charioteer, Karṇa—Not only these alone are entering, but even the foremost warriors on our side—like Śikhaṇḍin, Dhṛṣṭadyumna and others—along with them, they too are entering.

11.shlok:
वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति
दंष्ट्राकरालानि भयानकानि।
केचिद्विलग्ना दशनान्तरेषु
संदृश्यन्ते चूर्णितैरुत्तमाङ्गैः।।११.२७।।
11.translit:
vaktrāṇi te tvaramāṇā viśanti
daṁṣṭrā-karālāni bhayānakāni
kecid vilagnā daśanāntareṣu
sandṛśyante cūrṇitair uttamāṅgaiḥ
11.translate: They hurriedly enter into Your mouths, which are dreadful with terrifying fangs. Some are seen sticking between the teeth, with their heads crushed into powder.
11.sridhara: “They hurriedly…”—All these, rushing as if driven, are entering into Your mouths, which are terrifying with fangs. Among them, some are seen lodged between the gaps of the teeth, with their heads crushed and pulverized.

11.shlok:
यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः
समुद्रमेवाभिमुखा द्रवन्ति।
तथा तवामी नरलोकवीरा
विशन्ति वक्त्राण्यभिविज्वलन्ति।।११.२८।।
11.translit:
yathā nadīnāṁ bahavo ’mbu-vegāḥ
samudram evābhimukhā dravanti
tathā tavāmī nara-loka-vīrā
viśanti vaktrāṇy abhivijvalanti
11.translate: Just as the many torrents of rivers flow toward the ocean, so too these heroes among men are entering into Your flaming mouths.
11.sridhara: The act of entering is illustrated by an example: “Just as…”—Just as the currents of water, flowing from many streams of various rivers, rush toward the ocean, in the same way these heroes of the world of men enter into Your mouths, which are blazing and flaming from all sides.

11.shlok:
यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गा
विशन्ति नाशाय समृद्धवेगाः।
तथैव नाशाय विशन्ति लोका
स्तवापि वक्त्राणि समृद्धवेगाः।।११.२९।।
11.translit:
yathā pradīptaṁ jvalanaṁ pataṅgā
viśanti nāśāya samṛddha-vegāḥ
tathaiva nāśāya viśanti lokā
stavāpi vaktrāṇi samṛddha-vegāḥ
11.translate: Just as moths, with great speed, enter into a blazing fire for their destruction, so too do these beings, with great speed, enter into Your mouths for their destruction.
11.sridhara: In the previous verse, the metaphor of helpless entry like the flow of rivers was used. Now, a metaphor for deliberate entry is given: “Just as…”—Just as moths, a species of tiny winged insects, deliberately enter a blazing fire with intense speed for their own destruction, even so these beings too enter into Your mouths for destruction.

11.shlok:
लेलिह्यसे ग्रसमानः समन्ता
ल्लोकान्समग्रान्वदनैर्ज्वलद्भिः।
तेजोभिरापूर्य जगत्समग्रं
भासस्तवोग्राः प्रतपन्ति विष्णो।।११.३०।।
11.translit:
lelihyase grasamāṇaḥ samantāl
lokān samagrān vadanair jvaladbhiḥ
tejobhir āpūrya jagat samagraṁ
bhāsas tavogrāḥ pratapanti viṣṇo
11.translate: You are licking up and devouring all the worlds on every side with Your blazing mouths. Filling the entire universe with Your effulgence, Your fierce rays are scorching, O Viṣṇu.
11.sridhara: Then what follows?—“You are licking…”—While devouring, You are licking up entirely all the worlds—all these warriors—on all sides, that is, You are consuming them excessively. With what? With Your blazing mouths. Moreover, O Viṣṇu! Your lights, Your radiances, by their intense brilliance, pervade the entire universe. They are fierce and indeed scorching all.

11.shlok:
आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो
नमोऽस्तु ते देववर प्रसीद।
विज्ञातुमिच्छामि भवन्तमाद्यं
न हि प्रजानामि तव प्रवृत्तिम्।।११.३१।।
11.translit:
ākhyāhi me ko bhavān ugra-rūpo
namo ’stu te deva-vara prasīda
vijñātum icchāmi bhavantam ādyam
na hi prajānāmi tava pravṛttim
11.translate: Tell me, who are You, so fierce in form? Salutations to You, O Supreme God; be gracious. I wish to know You—the primordial Being. Indeed, I do not understand Your activity.
11.sridhara: Since this is so, therefore—“Tell me…”—Please declare who You are, fierce in form. Salutations to You! O Supreme among the gods, be gracious. I desire to know You as the primal Person in a special way. Why? Because I do not know Your activity—why You are thus engaged. Or it may mean: I do not even know any information about Your activity, O such as You are.

11.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
कालोऽस्मि लोकक्षयकृत्प्रवृद्धो
लोकान्समाहर्तुमिह प्रवृत्तः।
ऋतेऽपि त्वां न भविष्यन्ति सर्वे
येऽवस्थिताः प्रत्यनीकेषु योधाः।।११.३२।।
11.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
kālo ’smi loka-kṣaya-kṛt pravṛddho
lokān samāhartum iha pravṛttaḥ
ṛte ’pi tvāṁ na bhaviṣyanti sarve
ye ’vasthitāḥ pratyanīkeṣu yodhāḥ
11.translate: The Blessed Lord said: I am Time, the destroyer of the worlds, fully manifest. I have set forth to annihilate the worlds. Even without you, all the warriors standing in the opposing armies shall not exist.
11.sridhara: Thus being entreated, the Blessed Lord spoke—“I am Time…”—I am Time, fully expanded, the destroyer of worlds. I am now engaged in annihilating the living beings of these worlds. Therefore—“Even without you…”—Even if you do not act as their slayer, they will not survive; they will not live. Though they are not to be killed by you, even so, being devoured by Me, who am Time itself, they will certainly die. Who are they? All the warriors who are stationed in the enemy ranks—in all the armies on the side of Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and others.

11.shlok:
तस्मात्त्वमुत्तिष्ठ यशो लभस्व
जित्वा शत्रून् भुङ्क्ष्व राज्यं समृद्धम्।
मयैवैते निहताः पूर्वमेव
निमित्तमात्रं भव सव्यसाचिन्।।११.३३।।
11.translit:
tasmāt tvam uttiṣṭha yaśo labhasva
jitvā śatrūn bhuṅkṣva rājyaṁ samṛddham
mayaivaite nihatāḥ pūrvam eva
nimitta-mātraṁ bhava savyasācin
11.translate: Therefore, arise; gain glory. Conquer the enemies and enjoy a prosperous kingdom. These have already been slain by Me; be you a mere instrument, O Savyasācin.
11.sridhara: Therefore—since it is so—you rise up to fight. Let Bhīṣma, Droṇa, and others, unconquerable even by the gods, be vanquished by you, and thereby you shall obtain glory of that sort. Conquer the enemies without effort, and enjoy a prosperous kingdom. And these enemies of yours have already been slain before your battle by Me, who am Time. Even so, you be merely the instrument. O Savyasācin!—He who is capable of stringing and shooting arrows with his left hand also. By this derivation, due to his ability to shoot arrows even with his left hand, he is called Savyasācin.

11.shlok:
द्रोणं च भीष्मं च जयद्रथं च
कर्णं तथाऽन्यानपि योधवीरान्।
मया हतांस्त्वं जहि मा व्यथिष्ठा
युध्यस्व जेतासि रणे सपत्नान्।।११.३४।।
11.translit:
droṇaṁ ca bhīṣmaṁ ca jayadrathaṁ ca
karṇaṁ tathā ’nyān api yodha-vīrān
mayā hatāṁs tvaṁ jahi mā vyathiṣṭhā
yudhyasva jetāsi raṇe sapatnān
11.translate: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors—these have been slain by Me. Do you kill them; do not be distressed. Fight—you shall conquer your enemies in battle.
11.sridhara: Nor should there be any doubt such as “Which course of action is greater for us?”—as expressed in Chapter २, Verse ६ (“We do not know which is better for us…”)—that too is unnecessary. Why?—“Droṇa, Bhīṣma…”—Those whom you hesitate to fight—Droṇa and others—having already been slain by Me, do you now kill. Do not grieve—do not feel sorrow. In battle, you will certainly conquer your enemies.

11.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
एतच्छ्रुत्वा वचनं केशवस्य
कृताञ्जलिर्वेपमानः किरीटी।
नमस्कृत्वा भूय एवाह कृष्णं
सगद्गदं भीतभीतः प्रणम्य।।११.३५।।
11.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
etac chrutvā vacanaṁ keśavasya
kṛtāñjalir vepamānaḥ kirīṭī
namaskṛtvā bhūya evāha kṛṣṇaṁ
sa-gadgadaṁ bhīta-bhītaḥ praṇamya
11.translate: Sanjaya said: Having heard these words of Keśava, Arjuna, the wearer of the crown, trembling, with palms joined, prostrated himself; again bowing to Kṛṣṇa, he spoke, with a choked voice, overwhelmed with fear.
11.sridhara: Then what happened? Sanjaya spoke to Dhṛtarāṣṭra—“Having heard…”—Having heard these three preceding verses of speech from Keśava, Arjuna, trembling, with joined palms, bowed to Kṛṣṇa and again spoke. How did he speak? With a choked voice (sa-gadgada), that is, with a faltering tone caused by intense emotions of fear and wonder. Moreover, being extremely afraid—more frightened than just fearful—he bowed down (praṇamya) and, in that state, addressed Him again.

11.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
स्थाने हृषीकेश तव प्रकीर्त्या
जगत् प्रहृष्यत्यनुरज्यते च।
रक्षांसि भीतानि दिशो द्रवन्ति
सर्वे नमस्यन्ति च सिद्धसङ्घाः।।११.३६।।
11.translit:
arjuna uvāca
sthāne hṛṣīkeśa tava prakīrtyā
jagat prahṛṣyaty anurajyate ca
rakṣāṁsi bhītāni diśo dravanti
sarve namasyanti ca siddha-saṅghāḥ
11.translate: Arjuna said: Rightly, O Hṛṣīkeśa, does the world rejoice and become attached on hearing Your praise; the demons, terrified, flee in all directions, and all the hosts of the perfected beings bow to You.
11.sridhara: "Rightly"—this word (sthāne), an indeclinable, means "fittingly." O Hṛṣīkeśa, since You are of wondrous might and affectionate to devotees, therefore, at the singing of Your greatness (tava prakīrtyā, māhātmya-saṅkīrtanena), not only I alone rejoice, but the entire world (jagat sarvaṁ) rejoices—experiences great delight. This indeed is fitting—that is the meaning. Likewise, the world becomes attached—enters into love (anurajyate, anurāgaṁ ca upaiti). And that the demons, being terrified, flee in all directions (rakṣāṁsi bhītāni santi, diśaḥ prati dravanti)—that too. That all the hosts of perfected beings (siddha-saṅghāḥ) bow down (namasyanti, praṇamanti)—that also. All this too is proper, it is fitting. It is not surprising—that is the meaning.

11.shlok:
कस्माच्च ते न नमेरन्महात्मन्
गरीयसे ब्रह्मणोऽप्यादिकर्त्रे।
अनन्त देवेश जगन्निवास
त्वमक्षरं सदसत्तत्परं यत्।।११.३७।।
11.translit:
kasmāc ca te na nameran mahātman
garīyase brahmaṇo ’py ādi-kartre
ananta deveśa jagan-nivāsa
tvam akṣaraṁ sad-asat tat paraṁ yat
11.translate: And why should they not bow to You, O Great Soul—You who are greater even than Brahmā and the original creator? O Infinite One, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe, You are the imperishable, the existent and the non-existent, and that which is beyond both.
11.sridhara: There the reason is stated—“Why?” O Mahātman! O Ananta! O Lord of the gods (Deveśa)! O Abode of the universe (Jagannivāsa)! Why should they not bow to You? To whom? To You who are greater than Brahmā (Brahmaṇo'pi garīyase gurutarāya) and to the original creator (ādi-kartre), even the progenitor of Brahmā. Moreover, You are the imperishable (akṣaraṁ)—the root cause that is both the existent (sat, vyakta), and the non-existent (asat, avyaktam), and beyond both. That Brahman (yad akṣaraṁ brahma), that too is You alone. With these nine reasons, all beings bow to You. This is not surprising—that is the meaning.

11.shlok:
त्वमादिदेवः पुरुषः पुराण
स्त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्।
वेत्तासि वेद्यं च परं च धाम
त्वया ततं विश्वमनन्तरूप।।११.३८।।
11.translit:
tvam ādi-devaḥ puruṣaḥ purāṇaḥ
tvam asya viśvasya paraṁ nidhānam
vettāsi vedyaṁ ca paraṁ ca dhāma
tvayā tataṁ viśvam ananta-rūpa
11.translate: You are the primal god, the ancient person; You are the supreme refuge of this universe. You are the knower and the knowable, and the supreme abode. The universe is pervaded by You, O One of infinite forms.
11.sridhara: Furthermore—“You are…” You are the primal god (ādi-devaḥ), the first among the gods. Because You are the ancient person (purāṇaḥ puruṣaḥ)—beginningless. Therefore, You are the supreme refuge (paraṁ nidhānaṁ), the dissolution-place of this universe. Likewise, You are the knower (vettā), the one who knows the world. And You are that which is knowable (vedyaṁ vastu-jātaṁ), and also the highest abode (paraṁ dhāma), the Vaiṣṇava position (vaiṣṇavaṁ padaṁ). That too, You alone are. Therefore, O Ananta-rūpa! By You alone is this universe pervaded (tvayā eva viśvam idaṁ tataṁ vyāptam). With these seven reasons also, the implication is that You alone are worthy of worship.

11.shlok:
वायुर्यमोऽग्निर्वरुणः शशाङ्कः
प्रजापतिस्त्वं प्रपितामहश्च।
नमो नमस्तेऽस्तु सहस्रकृत्वः
पुनश्च भूयोऽपि नमो नमस्ते।।११.३९।।
11.translit:
vāyur yamo ’gnir varuṇaḥ śaśāṅkaḥ
prajāpatis tvaṁ prapitāmahaś ca
namo namas te ’stu sahasra-kṛtvaḥ
punaś ca bhūyo ’pi namo namas te
11.translate: You are Vāyu, Yama, Agni, Varuṇa, the moon, Prajāpati, and the great-grandfather (Brahmā’s ancestor). Salutations to You a thousand times; again and again, salutations to You.
11.sridhara: Further, You alone are worthy of salutation by all, because You are the embodiment of all the gods. Thus praising, he offers salutations himself—“You are Vāyu…” That You are in the form of Vāyu and others is said as indicative of Your being the essence of all gods (sarva-devatātmaka). Prajāpati is the grandsire (pitāmaha); since You are even his progenitor, You are the great-grandfather (prapitāmaha). Therefore, to You (tubhyaṁ), salutations a thousandfold (sahasra-kṛtvaḥ) and again (bhūyaḥ api), again salutations—driven by an excess of devotion and faith, not attaining satisfaction in prostration, Arjuna bows again and again.

11.shlok:
नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते
नमोऽस्तु ते सर्वत एव सर्व।
अनन्तवीर्यामितविक्रमस्त्वं
सर्वं समाप्नोषि ततोऽसि सर्वः।।११.४०।।
11.translit:
namaḥ purastād atha pṛṣṭhatas te
namo ’stu te sarvata eva sarva
ananta-vīryāmita-vikramas tvaṁ
sarvaṁ samāpnoṣi tato ’si sarvaḥ
11.translate: Salutations to You in front and behind; salutations to You from all sides, O All! Of infinite power and immeasurable might, You pervade all—therefore, You are all.
11.sridhara: Moreover—“Salutations…” O All, O Self of all (sarva-ātmān)! From every direction (sarvāsu api dikṣu), salutations to You. Then He proves Your identity with all beings (sarvātmatva): One whose might (vīryaṁ) is infinite (anantaṁ sāmarthyaṁ), and whose valor (vikramaḥ) is immeasurable (amitaḥ). Being such, You completely pervade everything (sarvam samyak antar-bahiś ca sarvātmadhā api samāpnoṣi vyāpnoṣi)—both within and without, as the inner Self of all. Just as gold pervades its own products like bracelets and earrings, so You, having pervaded, remain as their essence. Thus, You are all in every form.

11.shlok:
सखेति मत्वा प्रसभं यदुक्तं
हे कृष्ण हे यादव हे सखेति।
अजानता महिमानं तवेदं
मया प्रमादात्प्रणयेन वापि।।११.४१।।
11.translit:
sakheti matvā prasabhaṁ yad uktaṁ
he kṛṣṇa he yādava he sakheti
ajānātā mahimānaṁ tavedaṁ
mayā pramādāt praṇayena vāpi
11.translate: Thinking of You as a friend, whatever I presumptuously said—“O Krishna! O Yādava! O Friend!”—unaware of this, Your greatness, I said that out of carelessness or even affection.
11.sridhara: Now Arjuna seeks forgiveness from the Lord—“Thinking of You as ‘friend’…” The continuation is: “I beg forgiveness from You (tvām kṣāmaye).” Mistaking You to be an ordinary friend, what I said presumptuously—rudely, with disregard—that I beg pardon for. What exactly did I say? “O Kṛṣṇa! O Yādava! O Friend!”—this is to be understood. (The phrase is a poetic usage, sandhiḥ ārṣaḥ.) The reason for this rude speech? Because I, not knowing this greatness of Yours—this universal form—spoke thus either out of carelessness or even affection (sneha).

11.shlok:
यच्चावहासार्थमसत्कृतोऽसि
विहारशय्यासनभोजनेषु।
एकोऽथवाप्यच्युत तत्समक्षं
तत्क्षामये त्वामहमप्रमेयम्।।११.४२।।
11.translit:
yac cāvahāsārtham asatkṛto ’si
vihāra-śayyāsana-bhojaneṣu
eko ’thavāpy acyuta tat-samakṣaṁ
tat kṣāmaye tvām aham aprameyam
11.translate: And in whatever way You were disrespected in jest, during play, resting, sitting, or eating—whether alone or even in the presence of others—O Acyuta, O Immeasurable One, for all that I beg Your forgiveness.
11.sridhara: Furthermore—“And whatever…” O Acyuta! Whatever disrespect You received in jest (parihāsa) during play and so on (like reclining, sitting, or eating)—whether when alone (ekaḥ), meaning privately without companions, or else even in their presence (tat-samakṣam), meaning before those friends who were engaged in playful joking—that entire class of offenses, I beg You, O Immeasurable One of inconceivable majesty, to forgive (kṣāmaye).

11.shlok:
पितासि लोकस्य चराचरस्य
त्वमस्य पूज्यश्च गुरुर्गरीयान्।
न त्वत्समोऽस्त्यभ्यधिकः कुतोऽन्यो
लोकत्रयेऽप्यप्रतिमप्रभाव।।११.४३।।
11.translit:
pitāsi lokasya carācarasya
tvam asya pūjyaś ca gurur garīyān
na tvat-samo ’sty abhyadhikaḥ kuto ’nyo
loka-traye ’py apratima-prabhāva
11.translate: You are the Father of this world, of the moving and the unmoving; You are its worshipful Lord and greater than the Guru. There is none equal to You—then how could there be anyone greater—in all the three worlds, O One of incomparable power?
11.sridhara: He speaks of Your inconceivable majesty—“You are the Father…” O One of incomparable power (apratima-prabhāva), one whose power (prabhāva) has no comparison (upamā), thus incomparable! You are the Father (janaka) of this world of moving and unmoving beings. Therefore, You are the worshipful one (pūjya), and the Guru—indeed, greater than the Guru. Thus, even in the three worlds, there is none even equal to You—since there is no other Supreme Lord (parameśvara). Then how could anyone be greater than You?

11.shlok:
तस्मात्प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं
प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम्।
पितेव पुत्रस्य सखेव सख्युः
प्रियः प्रियायार्हसि देव सोढुम्।।११.४४।।
11.translit:
tasmāt praṇamya praṇidhāya kāyaṁ
prasādaye tvām aham īśam īḍyam
pitev a putrasya sakheva sakhyuḥ
priyaḥ priyāyārhasi deva soḍhum
11.translate: Therefore, bowing down, prostrating my body, I seek to appease You, O Lord, O adorable One. As a father to his son, a friend to a friend, or a beloved to the beloved—O God, You ought to bear with me.
11.sridhara: Since this is so—“Therefore…” Therefore, I seek to appease (prasādaye) You, the Lord (īśa), the adored one (īḍya), the Master of the world. How? By prostrating my body (kāyaṁ praṇidhāya), by laying it down flat like a stick (daṇḍavat nipātya), and bowing profoundly (praṇamya). Therefore, You ought to bear with my offense and forgive. Like whom? Just as a father, out of compassion, tolerates the offense of a son; just as a friend, a true friend without expectations, tolerates the fault of a friend; and just as a beloved bears the fault of the beloved for the sake of love—so too should You.

11.shlok:
अदृष्टपूर्वं हृषितोऽस्मि दृष्ट्वा
भयेन च प्रव्यथितं मनो मे।
तदेव मे दर्शय देव रूपं
प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास।।११.४५।।
11.translit:
adṛṣṭapūrvaṁ hṛṣito ’smi dṛṣṭvā
bhayena ca pravyathitaṁ mano me
tad eva me darśaya deva rūpaṁ
prasīda deveśa jagannivāsa
11.translate: Having seen what was never seen before, I am delighted; and yet my mind is also shaken with fear. Show me that (former) form alone, O Lord; be gracious, O Lord of gods, O Abode of the universe!
11.sridhara: Having thus sought forgiveness, he now makes a request—“Having seen…” O Lord! Having seen this form of Yours that was never seen before, I am delighted (hṛṣitaḥ). And yet, due to fear, my mind is also shaken (pravyathitam). Therefore, in order to relieve my agitation, show me that very form alone. O Lord of gods (deveśa), O Abode of the universe (jagannivāsa), be gracious (prasanna bhava).

11.shlok:
किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रहस्तं
इच्छामि त्वां द्रष्टुमहं तथैव।
तेनैव रूपेण चतुर्भुजेन
सहस्रबाहो भव विश्वमूर्ते।।११.४६।।
11.translit:
kirīṭinaṁ gadinaṁ cakra-hastaṁ
icchāmi tvāṁ draṣṭum ahaṁ tathaiva
tenaiva rūpeṇa catur-bhujena
sahasra-bāho bhava viśva-mūrte
11.translate: I wish to see You just as before, crowned, bearing a mace, and holding the discus. O Thousand-armed, O Universal Form, be (visible) in that very four-armed form.
11.sridhara: He now specifies that very form—“Crowned…” I wish to see You as crowned (kirīṭinam), bearing a mace (gadāvantam), and holding a discus (cakrahastam), just as I had seen You before. Therefore, O Thousand-armed One! O Universal Form! Having withdrawn this cosmic form (viśva-rūpa), become manifest in that very four-armed form (catur-bhujena rūpeṇa) adorned with crown and so on. From this, it is understood that Arjuna had formerly seen Kṛṣṇa as adorned with crown and the rest. As for what was earlier said while seeing the universal form—“I see You as crowned, mace-bearing, and with the discus”—that referred to the countless crowns and so on seen on numerous heads. Or else, for all this time, I had seen You as crowned, mace-bearing, and discus-wielding, in a calm and pleasing form—and now I see You as a mass of blazing energy, difficult to behold. Thus, the use of the plural earlier (in verse १७) was due to the multitude of forms and does not contradict the present request.

11.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
मया प्रसन्नेन तवार्जुनेदं
रूपं परं दर्शितमात्मयोगात्।
तेजोमयं विश्वमनन्तमाद्यं
यन्मे त्वदन्येन न दृष्टपूर्वम्।।११.४७।।
11.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
mayā prasannena tavārjunedaṁ
rūpaṁ paraṁ darśitam ātma-yogāt
tejo-mayaṁ viśvam anantam ādyaṁ
yan me tvad anyena na dṛṣṭa-pūrvam
11.translate: The Blessed Lord said: This supreme form has been shown to you by Me out of grace, O Arjuna, through My own Yoga-power—radiant, all-formed, infinite, and primal—this form of Mine has never before been seen by anyone other than you.
11.sridhara: Thus entreated, the Blessed Lord consoled him—“By Me…” Why are you alarmed, O Arjuna? Because this supreme form (param uttamam rūpam) has been shown to you by Me, out of grace (prasannena), through My own Yogic power (ātma-yogāt), meaning through the power of Yogamāyā. He further describes its excellence: it is full of brilliance (tejo-mayam), all-formed (viśva), infinite (ananta), and the primal (ādya) form of Mine, which was not seen before (na dṛṣṭa-pūrvam) by anyone other than you—meaning, not by anyone other than a devotee like you.

11.shlok:
न वेदयज्ञाध्ययनैर्न दानैः
न च क्रियाभिर्न तपोभिरुग्रैः।
एवंरूपः शक्य अहं नृलोके
द्रष्टुं त्वदन्येन कुरुप्रवीर।।११.४८।।
11.translit:
na veda-yajñādhyayanair na dānaiḥ
na ca kriyābhir na tapobhir ugraiḥ
evaṁ-rūpaḥ śakya ahaṁ nṛ-loke
draṣṭuṁ tvad anyena kuru-pravīra
11.translate: Not through study of the Vedas and sacrifices, nor by charity, nor by rituals, nor by severe austerities can I be seen in this form in the world of men by anyone other than you, O hero of the Kurus.
11.sridhara: He now says that this vision is extremely rare and that having obtained it, you are fulfilled—“Not through…” Because yajñādhyayana would become redundant with vedādhyayana, the phrase should be taken as veda-adhyayana-atirekeṇa yajñādhyayanasya abhāvāt—that is, study of sacrificial texts in addition to Vedic study. By the word yajña, the ritual sciences like the Kalpa-sūtras are indicated. So the meaning is: “not by study of the Vedas or the ritual sciences (yajña-vidyā), nor by charity, nor by rituals like Agnihotra, nor by severe austerities like Cāndrāyaṇa, can I be seen in this form (evaṁ-rūpaḥ) by any other person in the human world, except for you.” Rather, it is only you, through My grace, who has seen it, and thus you are fulfilled.

11.shlok:
मा ते व्यथा मा च विमूढभावो
दृष्ट्वा रूपं घोरमीदृङ्ममेदम्।
व्यपेतभीः प्रीतमनाः पुनस्त्वं
तदेव मे रूपमिदं प्रपश्य।।११.४९।।
11.translit:
mā te vyathā mā ca vimūḍha-bhāvo
dṛṣṭvā rūpaṁ ghoram īdṛṅ mamedam
vyapeta-bhīḥ prīta-manāḥ punas tvaṁ
tad eva me rūpam idaṁ prapaśya
11.translate: Let there be no fear or delusion for you on seeing this terrifying form of Mine. With fear gone and your mind gladdened, see again this very form of Mine.
11.sridhara: Even so, if by seeing this terrible form of Mine your mind is disturbed, then I shall show you that former form—so He says: “Let there be no…” On seeing this terrifying form of Mine (ī-dṛk māmakaṁ ghoraṁ rūpam), let there be no fear (vyathā) in you. Let there be no bewilderment or delusion (vimūḍha-bhāva) either. With fear gone (vyapeta-bhīḥ) and your mind gladdened (prīta-manāḥ), now again see that very form of Mine (tad eva idaṁ rūpam) clearly (prakṛṣyeṇa).

11.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
इत्यर्जुनं वासुदेवस्तथोक्त्वा
स्वकं रूपं दर्शयामास भूयः।
आश्वासयामास च भीतमेनं
भूत्वा पुनः सौम्यवपुर्महात्मा।।११.५०।।
11.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
ity arjunaṁ vāsudevas tathoktvā
svakaṁ rūpaṁ darśayām āsa bhūyaḥ
āśvāsayām āsa ca bhītam enaṁ
bhūtvā punaḥ saumya-vapur mahātmā
11.translate: Sañjaya said: Thus having spoken to Arjuna, Vāsudeva again showed His own form. The great soul, assuming a gentle form once more, consoled him who was terrified.
11.sridhara: Thus having spoken, He showed the prior form—Sañjaya said: “Thus…” Śrī Vāsudeva, having spoken thus to Arjuna, again revealed His own form (svīyaṁ rūpaṁ)—the same one as before, adorned with crown and so on, the four-armed form (catur-bhuja). He, becoming possessed of a pleasing form (prasanna-vapus), once again consoled this terrified Arjuna. The word mahātmā can mean either “He who has the universal form” or “the compassionate one.”

11.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
दृष्ट्वेदं मानुषं रूपं तव सौम्यं जनार्दन।
इदानीमस्मि संवृत्तः सचेताः प्रकृतिं गतः।।११.५१।।
11.translit:
arjuna uvāca
dṛṣṭvedaṁ mānuṣaṁ rūpaṁ tava saumyaṁ janārdana
idānīm asmi saṁvṛttaḥ sacetāḥ prakṛtiṁ gataḥ
11.translate: Arjuna said: Having seen this gentle human form of Yours, O Janārdana, I have now become composed and returned to my natural state.
11.sridhara: Then, free from fear, Arjuna said—“Having seen…” Now I have become composed (saṁvṛttaḥ), that is, with a clear and tranquil mind (prasanna-citta), I have become restored. I have attained my original condition (prakṛtiṁ gataḥ), meaning my own natural state. The rest is clear.

11.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
सुदुर्दर्शमिदं रूपं दृष्टवानसि यन्मम।
देवा अप्यस्य रूपस्य नित्यं दर्शनकाङ्क्षिणः।।११.५२।।
11.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
sudurdarśam idaṁ rūpaṁ dṛṣṭavān asi yan mama
devā apy asya rūpasya nityaṁ darśana-kāṅkṣiṇaḥ
11.translate: The Blessed Lord said: This form of Mine which you have seen is very difficult to behold. Even the gods ever long to see this form.
11.sridhara: Showing the extreme rarity of the grace He has bestowed, the Blessed Lord said—“Very hard to see…” This universal form (viśvarūpa) of Mine which you have seen is extremely difficult to behold (sudurdarśam), meaning utterly unseeable (atyantaṁ draṣṭum aśakyam). Therefore, even the gods constantly desire to see this form, but do not actually get to see it again.

11.shlok:
नाहं वेदैर्न तपसा न दानेन न चेज्यया।
शक्य एवंविधो द्रष्टुं दृष्टवानसि मां यथा।।११.५३।।
11.translit:
nāhaṁ vedair na tapasā na dānena na ca ijyayā
śakya evaṁ-vidho draṣṭuṁ dṛṣṭavān asi māṁ yathā
11.translate: Not by the Vedas, nor by austerity, nor by charity, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as you have seen Me.
11.sridhara: Here is the reason—“Not by the Vedas…” The meaning is straightforward.

11.shlok:
भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन।
ज्ञातुं दृष्टुं च तत्त्वेन प्रवेष्टुं च परंतप।।११.५४।।
11.translit:
bhaktyā tv ananyayā śakya aham evaṁ-vidho ’rjuna
jñātuṁ draṣṭuṁ ca tattvena praveṣṭuṁ ca paraṁtapa
11.translate: But by single-minded devotion, O Arjuna, can I in this form be truly known, seen, and entered into, O scorcher of foes.
11.sridhara: Then by what means can I be seen? That is said here—“But by devotion…” By ananyayā bhaktyā, devotion that is exclusive and fixed only on Me, I, in this very form (evaṁbhūtaḥ), the universal form, can truly (tattvena) be known—through scriptures—seen—directly—and entered into—by identification (tādātmya). Not by any other means.

11.shlok:
मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः।
निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव।।११.५५।।
11.translit:
mat-karma-kṛn mat-paramo mad-bhaktaḥ saṅga-varjitaḥ
nirvairaḥ sarva-bhūteṣu yaḥ sa mām eti pāṇḍava
11.translate: He who performs actions for Me, who is devoted to Me, who holds Me as supreme, who is free from attachment, and who is without hatred toward any being—such a one comes to Me, O Pāṇḍava.
11.sridhara: Therefore, hear the highest secret which is the essence of all the scriptures—“He who performs actions for Me…” One who performs action for My sake is mat-karmakṛt. One for whom I alone am the supreme goal (mat-paramaḥ). One who is devoted to Me alone (mad-bhaktaḥ), who has taken shelter in Me. Who is free of attachment to sons and so on (saṅga-varjitaḥ), and who is without enmity toward all beings (sarva-bhūteṣu nirvairaḥ)—a person of this kind alone reaches Me, not anyone else.

12.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
एवं सततयुक्ता ये भक्तास्त्वां पर्युपासते।
ये चाप्यक्षरमव्यक्तं तेषां के योगवित्तमाः।।१२.१।।
12.translit:
arjuna uvāca
evaṁ satatayuktā ye bhaktās tvāṁ paryupāsate
ye cāpy akṣaram avyaktaṁ teṣāṁ ke yoga-vittamāḥ
12.translate: Arjuna said: Of those devotees who, ever steadfast, worship You, and those who worship the imperishable and unmanifest—which of them are better versed in Yoga?
12.sridhara: This twelfth chapter begins to settle the question—between worship of the unmanifest (nirguṇa) and the manifest (saguṇa), which is superior? At the end of the previous chapter, the superiority of devotion (bhakti-niṣṭhā) was declared through statements like “mat-karma-kṛn mat-paramaḥ” (११.५५) and “kaunteya pratijānīhi” (९.३१). Similarly, the superiority of knowledge-based devotion (jñāna-niṣṭhā) was also affirmed by verses such as “teṣāṁ jñānī nitya-yukta eka-bhaktir viśiṣyate” (७.१७) and “sarvaṁ jñāna-plavenaiva vṛjinaṁ saṁtariṣyasi” (४.३६). Though both paths are praised, out of a desire to know which is greater, Arjuna now asks the Lord: “Thus, those ever steadfast, who constantly meditate on You, the all-knowing, all-powerful Lord with a cosmic form—and those who meditate on the imperishable, unmanifest, and formless Brahman—among these two, who are better versed in Yoga?” The meaning of "better" here is “superior in Yoga.”

12.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
मय्यावेश्य मनो ये मां नित्ययुक्ता उपासते।
श्रद्धया परयोपेताः ते मे युक्ततमा मताः।।१२.२।।
12.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
mayy āveśya mano ye māṁ nitya-yuktā upāsate
śraddhayā parayopetās te me yuktatamā matāḥ
12.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Those who fix their minds on Me and worship Me with constant devotion, endowed with supreme faith—they are regarded by Me as the best in Yoga.
12.sridhara: To that, the Lord replies: “Those first ones are superior.” Fixing the mind—making it one-pointed—on Me, the Supreme Lord endowed with omniscience and other attributes, remaining ever steadfast through performing actions dedicated to Me, with supreme faith, and worshipping Me—such people are considered by Me to be most accomplished in Yoga (yuktatamāḥ).

12.shlok:
ये त्वक्षरमनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं पर्युपासते।
सर्वत्रगमचिन्त्यं च कूटस्थमचलं ध्रुवम्।।१२.३।।
12.translit:
ye tv akṣaram anirdeśyam avyaktaṁ paryupāsate
sarvatra-gam acintyaṁ ca kūṭastham acalaṁ dhruvam
12.translate: But those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, the all-pervading, the inconceivable, the unchanging, the unmoving, the eternal—
12.sridhara: Then, are the others not superior? In response to this possible doubt, He speaks: “But those who…”—applying to both verses ३ and ४. Even they, who meditate on the imperishable, attain Me. The characteristics of the imperishable (akṣara) are described as follows: it is indescribable (anirdeśya)—not definable by words; unmanifest (avyakta)—devoid of form, etc.; all-pervading (sarvatra-gam); because it is unmanifest, it is also inconceivable (acintya); it is kūṭastha—standing as the substratum in the illusion called the world; unmoving (acala)—without vibration; and hence, eternal (dhruva)—unchanging, without growth or decay.

12.shlok:
संनियम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वत्र समबुद्धयः।
ते प्राप्नुवन्ति मामेव सर्वभूतहिते रताः।।१२.४।।
12.translit:
saṁniyamya indriya-grāmaṁ sarvatra sama-buddhayaḥ
te prāpnuvanti mām eva sarva-bhūta-hite ratāḥ
12.translate: Restraining all the senses, even-minded everywhere, intent on the welfare of all beings—such people also come to Me.
12.sridhara: “Restraining…”—The meaning is self-evident.

12.shlok:
क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम्।
अव्यक्ता हि गतिर्दुःखं देहवद्भिरवाप्यते।।१२.५।।
12.translit:
kleśo ’dhikataras teṣām avyaktāsakta-cetasām
avyaktā hi gatir duḥkhaṁ dehavadbhir avāpyate
12.translate: Greater is the hardship for those whose minds are attached to the unmanifest. For the path of the unmanifest is difficult to reach for those who are embodied.
12.sridhara: Now, someone might object: “But they too reach You—then how is the other path superior?” Anticipating this, the Lord speaks of the distinction in terms of hardship and ease: “Greater is the hardship…” Those whose minds are attached to the unmanifest, attributeless (nirviśeṣa) imperishable (akṣara)—their difficulty is greater. Why? Because the path directed toward the unmanifest is reached with suffering by those who identify with the body. This is because, for such embodied beings, inward turning of the mind toward the Self (pratyak-pravaṇatva) is difficult. That is the intended meaning.

12.shlok:
ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्पराः।
अनन्येनैव योगेन मां ध्यायन्त उपासते।।१२.६।।
12.translit:
ye tu sarvāṇi karmāṇi mayi saṁnyasya mat-parāḥ
ananyenaiva yogena māṁ dhyāyanta upāsate
12.translate: But those who, dedicating all actions to Me and taking Me as the supreme goal, worship Me—meditating on Me with undivided Yoga—
12.sridhara: For My devotees, perfection arises effortlessly by My grace. This is stated in the next two verses: “But those who…” Dedicating (saṁnyasya) all actions to Me, the Supreme Lord, and becoming mat-para—regarding Me as the highest aim—such people meditate upon Me, worshipping Me with a Yoga that is ananya, i.e., one in which there is no other object of devotion besides Me. In other words, they engage in exclusive devotion.

12.shlok:
तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात्।
भवामि नचिरात् पार्थ मय्यावेशितचेतसाम्।।१२.७।।
12.translit:
teṣām ahaṁ samuddhartā mṛtyu-saṁsāra-sāgarāt
bhavāmi na cirāt pārtha mayy āveśita-cetasām
12.translate: Of such persons whose minds are absorbed in Me, O Pārtha, I become, without delay, the deliverer from the ocean of death and saṁsāra.
12.sridhara: “For those”—whose minds are thus absorbed in Me—I become the complete liberator from the ocean of saṁsāra, which is bound up with death. And this I become quickly.

12.shlok:
मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय।
निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः।।१२.८।।
12.translit:
mayy eva mana ādhatsva mayi buddhiṁ niveśaya
nivasiṣyasi mayy eva ata ūrdhvaṁ na saṁśayaḥ
12.translate: Fix your mind on Me alone, place your intellect in Me; thereafter, you will dwell in Me alone—there is no doubt about this.
12.sridhara: Because this is so, therefore—“Fix your mind on Me alone…” Steady your mind (which is characterized by intention and doubt) in Me. Likewise, place your intellect—firm in resolve—entirely in Me. Doing so, and gaining knowledge through My grace, thereafter, at the time of death, you will dwell in Me alone, you will reside in Me as one whose self has become Mine—of this there is no doubt. As the śruti (Upaniṣad) also says: “At the time of death, the Lord declares the Supreme Brahman as the deliverer.”

12.shlok:
अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम्।
अभ्यासयोगेन ततो मामिच्छाप्तुं धनञ्जय।।१२.९।।
12.translit:
atha cittaṁ samādhātuṁ na śaknoṣi mayi sthiram
abhyāsa-yogena tato mām icchāptuṁ dhanañjaya
12.translate: But if you are unable to fix your mind steadily on Me, then, O Dhanañjaya, seek to reach Me through the Yoga of constant practice.
12.sridhara: Here, for the one who is incapable, He prescribes an easier method: “But if…” If you are unable to hold your mind steadily on Me, then repeatedly bring back the distracted mind, and by the Yoga of repeated practice characterized by remembrance of Me, strive to attain Me.

12.shlok:
अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव।
मदर्थमपि कर्माणि कुर्वन् सिद्धिमवाप्स्यसि।।१२.१०।।
12.translit:
abhyāse ’py asamartho ’si mat-karma-paramo bhava
mad-artham api karmāṇi kurvan siddhim avāpsyasi
12.translate: If you are even unable to do practice, then be intent on performing actions for My sake. Even by doing actions for My sake, you shall attain perfection.
12.sridhara: If not even that is possible, then He says: “If you are unable…” If you are incapable of that practice, then become one who is intent on performing acts that are for My sake—such as fasting on the eleventh day (ekādaśī), observing vows, devotional service, and congregational chanting, etc. Performing such actions for My sake, you will attain liberation.

12.shlok:
अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः।
सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं ततः कुरु यतात्मवान्।।१२.११।।
12.translit:
atha etad api aśakto ’si kartuṁ mad-yogam āśritaḥ
sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ tataḥ kuru yatātmavān
12.translate: But if you are unable to do even this, then, taking refuge in My Yoga, renounce the fruits of all actions, with self-control.
12.sridhara: Now, for one completely incapable of steadfast devotion to the Lord, an alternative is presented: “But if even this…” If you are unable to do even this, then, having taken refuge in My Yoga—that is, in exclusive surrender to Me—renounce the fruits of all actions, both seen and unseen, of all obligatory actions such as Agnihotra and the like, while being one of steady mind. The meaning is this: Actions must be performed by Me as ordained by the command of the Lord, according to one's capacity. But the results—whether visible or invisible—are dependent upon the Supreme Lord. Entrusting the outcome to Me, abandoning attachment to the fruits, you will, by My grace, become fulfilled.

12.shlok:
श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते।
ध्यानात्कर्मफलत्यागस्त्यागाच्छान्तिरनन्तरम्।।१२.१२।।
12.translit:
śreyo hi jñānam abhyāsāj jñānād dhyānaṁ viśiṣyate
dhyānāt karma-phala-tyāgas tyāgāc chāntir anantaram
12.translate: Knowledge is indeed better than practice; meditation is superior to knowledge; renunciation of the fruits of action is superior to meditation—peace follows immediately after renunciation.
12.sridhara: The Lord praises this renunciation of the fruits of action: “Better indeed…” Knowledge, preceded by proper instruction and guidance and accompanied by discriminative insight, is better than practice that lacks true understanding. Better still is meditation that arises from such knowledge. For the Śruti says, “Then he sees That, which is without parts, through meditation.” Greater even than that is the renunciation of the fruits of action characterized as previously described. Therefore, from such renunciation of the fruits of action—by cessation of attachment toward both the actions and their results—peace from saṁsāra arises immediately through My grace.

12.shlok:
अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च।
निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी।।१२.१३।।
12.translit:
adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānāṁ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca
nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣamī
12.translate: One who has no hatred toward any being, who is friendly and compassionate, free from possessiveness and ego, equal in pain and pleasure, and forgiving—
12.sridhara: The Lord now describes the qualities of such a devotee who quickly becomes a recipient of divine grace: “One who has no hatred…” Through these eight qualities. One who is without hatred toward all beings; friendly to equals; compassionate to those who are inferior—this is the meaning. One who is free from possessiveness (nirmama) and egotism (nirahaṅkāra). Because of compassion and the like, he is equal in happiness and sorrow with others. One who forgives is kṣamī.

12.shlok:
सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः।
मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः।।१२.१४।।
12.translit:
santuṣṭaḥ satataṁ yogī yatātmā dṛḍha-niścayaḥ
mayy arpita-mano-buddhir yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
12.translate: Content at all times, steadfast in Yoga, self-controlled, with firm conviction, one who has offered his mind and intellect to Me—such a devotee is dear to Me.
12.sridhara: “Content…”—such a one is always content in both gain and loss, and cheerful of mind. He is a yogī, ever watchful and attentive. One whose nature is self-restrained is yatātmā. One whose firm resolve is directed toward Me is said to have dṛḍha-niścaya. One who has offered his mind and intellect to Me—such a one, being so qualified, is My devotee and is dear to Me.

12.shlok:
यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः।
हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैर्मुक्तो यः स च मे प्रियः।।१२.१५।।
12.translit:
yasmān nodvijate loko lokān nodvijate ca yaḥ
harṣāmarṣa-bhaya-udvegair mukto yaḥ sa ca me priyaḥ
12.translate: He by whom the world is not disturbed, and who is not disturbed by the world, who is free from joy, intolerance, fear, and agitation—he too is dear to Me.
12.sridhara: Further: “He by whom…” From such a person, people feel no agitation or fear, and he himself is also unperturbed by the world. He is free from innate responses such as joy, intolerance, fear, and mental agitation. Joy is enthusiasm upon gaining what is desired for oneself; intolerance is inability to endure another’s gain; fear is dread; and agitation is mental disturbance arising from fear and the like. One who is free from these and is devoted to Me—that person is dear to Me.

12.shlok:
अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः।
सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः।।१२.१६।।
12.translit:
anapekṣaḥ śucir dakṣa udāsīno gata-vyathaḥ
sarvārambha-parityāgī yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ
12.translate: He who is free from dependence, pure, efficient, impartial, free from distress, and renounces all undertakings—such a devotee of Mine is dear to Me.
12.sridhara: Furthermore—“Free from dependence…”: One who is indifferent even to objects that appear by chance is anapekṣaḥ (independent, unattached). Śuciḥ is one who is endowed with both external and internal purity. Dakṣaḥ is one who is free from laziness. Udāsīnaḥ is one who is impartial and without bias. Gata-vyathaḥ is one who is free from afflictions such as disease. One whose nature is to renounce all undertakings or efforts—both for seen and unseen results—is called sarvārambha-parityāgī. One who is such, and is My devotee, is dear to Me.

12.shlok:
यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति।
शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्तिमान्यः स मे प्रियः।।१२.१७।।
12.translit:
yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati
śubhāśubha-parityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ
12.translate: He who neither rejoices nor hates, nor grieves nor desires, who renounces both good and evil, and is devoted to Me—he is dear to Me.
12.sridhara: Furthermore—“He who neither rejoices…”: One who does not rejoice upon obtaining what is pleasing, who does not hate upon encountering the unpleasant, who does not grieve over the loss of desirable things, and who does not long for what is yet unattained—such a one is śubhāśubha-parityāgī, whose habit is to abandon both merit and demerit. Being such, and devoted to Me, he is dear to Me.

12.shlok:
समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः।
शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः।।१२.१८।।
12.translit:
samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ
śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu samaḥ saṅga-vivarjitaḥ
12.translate: He who is the same toward enemy and friend, likewise in honor and dishonor, the same in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain, and who is free from attachment—
12.sridhara: Furthermore—“Equal to enemy and friend…”: One who is alike in both enemy and friend, and likewise equal in honor and dishonor—that is, free from elation or dejection. He who is the same in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain, and who is devoid of attachment anywhere—is saṅga-vivarjitaḥ.

12.shlok:
तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येनकेनचित्।
अनिकेतः स्थिरमतिर्भक्तिमान्मे प्रियो नरः।।१२.१९।।
12.translit:
tulya-nindā-stutir maunī santuṣṭo yena kena cit
aniketaḥ sthira-matir bhaktimān me priyo naraḥ
12.translate: He who is equal in censure and praise, silent, content with anything, without fixed residence, of steady mind—such a devotee is dear to Me.
12.sridhara: “One who is equal in censure and praise…”: Tulya-nindā-stutiḥ—one to whom blame and praise are alike. Maunī—one who speaks in a restrained and measured way. Santuṣṭaḥ yena kenacit—one who is content with whatever is obtained. Aniketaḥ—one who is without a fixed abode. Sthira-matiḥ—one whose mind is steady and settled. One who is thus, and devoted to Me, such a person is dear to Me.

12.shlok:
ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते।
श्रद्दधाना मत्परमा भक्तास्तेऽतीव मे प्रियाः।।१२.२०।।
12.translit:
ye tu dharmyāmṛtam idaṁ yathoktaṁ paryupāsate
śraddadhānā mat-paramā bhaktās te ’tīva me priyāḥ
12.translate: But those who follow this immortal dharma, as described above, with faith, and who make Me their supreme goal—those devotees are exceedingly dear to Me.
12.sridhara: The previously described class of dharmas is now concluded with their fruit: “But those who…”—The dharma described in the manner stated above is amṛta (nectar) because it leads to immortality. Some read this as dharmyāmṛtam (the righteous nectar). Those who diligently practice it with faith and take Me as the supreme goal—those devotees are exceedingly dear to Me.

13.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव क्षेत्रं क्षेत्रज्ञमेव च।
एतद्वेदितुमिच्छामि ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं च केशव।।१३.१।।
13.translit:
arjuna uvāca
prakṛtiṁ puruṣaṁ caiva kṣetraṁ kṣetrajñam eva ca
etad veditum icchāmi jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ ca keśava
13.translate: Arjuna said: I desire to understand Nature and the Person, the field and the knower of the field, knowledge and that which is to be known, O Keśava.
13.sridhara: ।।१३.१।। No commentary.

13.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते।
एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः।।१३.२।।
13.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
idaṁ śarīraṁ kaunteya kṣetram ity abhidhīyate
etad yo vetti taṁ prāhuḥ kṣetrajña iti tad-vidaḥ
13.translate: The Blessed Lord said: This body, O son of Kuntī, is called the field; one who knows it is called the knower of the field by those who understand these matters.
13.sridhara:
“I am the deliverer of devotees from saṁsāra” — the assertion made earlier (in ७.१४ and १२.७), is here supported through an exposition of tattva-jñāna (knowledge of reality). For it is not possible to lift anyone out of saṁsāra without self-knowledge. Therefore, the teaching of knowledge of tattva is commenced, through a chapter on the discrimination between prakṛti and puruṣa.

In Chapter ७, two kinds of prakṛti—aparā and parā—were described. Due to the non-discrimination between these two, the conscious portion assumes the identity of the jīva, and undergoes saṁsāra. It is through these two prakṛtis that the Lord creates the world for the enjoyment of the jīva. These very two prakṛtis are meant by the words kṣetra and kṣetrajña. The Lord now begins to define them distinctly:

“This”—meaning, this body, which is the abode of enjoyment—is called the field (kṣetra), because it serves as the fertile ground for the sprouting of saṁsāra. The one who knows it—who considers it as “I” and “mine”—is called the kṣetrajña, the knower of the field, just as a farmer is the enjoyer of the fruit of the field. This is according to those who know the distinction between the kṣetra and kṣetrajña.

13.shlok:
क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत।
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्ज्ञानं यत्तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम।।१३.३।।
13.translit:
kṣetrajñaṁ cāpi māṁ viddhi sarva-kṣetreṣu bhārata
kṣetra-kṣetrajñayor jñānaṁ yat taj-jñānaṁ mataṁ mama
13.translate: And know Me also as the knower of the field in all fields, O Bhārata. Knowledge of the field and the knower of the field—that I consider to be true knowledge.
13.sridhara:
Thus, having stated the nature of the transmigrating being, He now declares its ultimate, non-transmigrating, supreme nature: “Know the knower of the field to be Me.” That kṣetrajña, the transmigrating jīva, is in reality Myself, present in all fields through a spark of consciousness (cid-aṁśa), as indicated by the Upaniṣadic mahāvākya, “Tat tvam asi” (“You are that”).

Now, to express reverence for such knowledge, the Lord praises it: “The knowledge of the distinction between the field and the knower of the field—I consider that alone to be knowledge, since it leads to liberation. All other so-called knowledge is merely learnedness and is ultimately a cause of bondage.” Therefore, it is said: “That karma which does not lead to bondage is real karma; that knowledge which leads to liberation is real knowledge. Everything else is mere labor; other karmas are mere technical skills.”

13.shlok:
तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक् च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत्।
स च यो यत्प्रभावश्च तत्समासेन मे श्रृणु।।१३.४।।
13.translit:
tat kṣetraṁ yac ca yādṛk ca yad-vikāri yataś ca yat
sa ca yo yat-prabhāvaś ca tat samāsena me śṛṇu
13.translate: What that field is, and what it is like, what its transformations are, from what it arises, and who He is, and what His powers are—listen to that from Me in brief.
13.sridhara:
Here, although prakṛti is actually the field—distinguished by its twenty-four categories such as the mind, intellect, etc.—still, since the sense of “I” and “mine” appears distinctly only in its manifestation as the physical body, therefore the body itself is referred to as the kṣetra. In order to make this clear, the verse beginning with “idaṁ śarīraṁ kṣetram” was spoken.

Now, elaborating that, He says: “What that field is.” That field which I previously mentioned—what is it in its nature (i.e., inert and of the nature of the seen)? What is it like (i.e., possessing qualities such as desire and aversion)? What are its modifications (i.e., what transformations occur in it such as sense organs, etc.)? From what does it arise (i.e., how does it come into being from the union of prakṛti and puruṣa)? What is it (i.e., how is it diversified into moving and non-moving forms)? And who is that kṣetrajña, and what is his power (i.e., what powers does he possess due to inconceivable divine majesty)? All of this, hear from Me briefly.

13.shlok:
ऋषिभिर्बहुधा गीतं छन्दोभिर्विविधैः पृथक्।
ब्रह्मसूत्रपदैश्चैव हेतुमद्भिर्विनिश्चितैः।।१३.५।।
13.translit:
ṛṣibhir bahudhā gītaṁ chandobhir vividhaiḥ pṛthak
brahma-sūtra-padaiś caiva hetumadbhir viniścitaiḥ
13.translate: It has been sung in many ways by the sages, distinctly in various Vedic hymns, and also in the aphoristic words of the Brahma-sūtras, which are full of reasoning and certainty.
13.sridhara:
If one asks: whose detailed teachings are being briefly stated here? The answer is: “by the ṛṣis”—that is, sages like Vasiṣṭha and others, in the yoga-śāstras, where it has been described in many ways, such as the nature of meditation and concentration, or as vairāja-puruṣa.

In various Vedic hymns (chandas), which deal with nitya, naimittika, and kāmya actions and their respective deities, it has also been sung. Also by the brahma-sūtras, or aphoristic statements which indicate brahman, such as “from which all beings are born” (yato vā imāni bhūtāni jāyante), which convey indirect definitions (taṭastha-lakṣaṇa), and others like “brahman is that which is existence, knowledge, and infinity” (satyam jñānam anantaṁ brahma), which give essential definitions (svarūpa-lakṣaṇa). These also describe it extensively.

And further, by rational arguments: “In the beginning, O gentle one, there was only existence”; “How could the existent come from the non-existent?”; “Who would breathe, if bliss were not present in the space within the heart?”; “It is He who bestows bliss”—these and other statements are full of reasoning. Similarly, “Who would direct the function of apāna?”, “Who would cause the activity of prāṇa?”—these lines emphasize the necessity of an intelligent agent.

All these statements are characterized by clarity and consistency of beginning and conclusion (upakrama-upasaṁhāra), and by their unambiguous meaning. Thus, what has been elaborated in detail by them, and is difficult to grasp, I will now explain to you in brief—listen attentively.

Alternatively, the brahma-sūtras may refer to the opening aphorism: “Now, therefore, the inquiry into Brahman.” Those very statements, which help attain brahman, are the padas (words). By them, furnished with reasons—such as “from the will,” “not from mere words,” “being of the nature of bliss,” etc.—the meaning is firmly ascertained. The rest is similar.

13.shlok:
महाभूतान्यहङ्कारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च।
इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च पञ्च चेन्द्रियगोचराः।।१३.६।।
13.translit:
mahābhūtāny ahaṅkāro buddhir avyaktam eva ca
indriyāṇi daśaikaṁ ca pañca cendriya-gocarāḥ
13.translate: The great elements, ego, intellect, also the unmanifest; the ten senses and the one (mind), and the five objects of the senses.
13.sridhara:
Now the nature of the field is described: “The great elements…”—this and the next verse explain it. The mahābhūtas (great elements) are the five—earth, water, fire, air, and space. Ahaṅkāra (ego) is their immediate cause. Buddhi (intellect) is the cognitive principle known as mahat-tattva. Avyakta is the unmanifest, or mūla-prakṛti (primordial nature).

The indriyas (senses) are the ten external senses: hearing, touch, smell, sight, taste, speech, hands, reproductive organ, feet, and excretory organ. The “one” refers to the internal sense, the manas (mind). The indriya-gocarās—objects of the senses—are the five tanmātras (subtle elements), which are sound, touch, form, taste, and smell. These manifest as the specific qualities of space, air, fire, water, and earth, respectively, and are the sensory objects. Thus, the twenty-four elements have been enumerated.

13.shlok:
इच्छा द्वेषः सुखं दुःखं सङ्घातश्चेतनाधृतिः।
एतत्क्षेत्रं समासेन सविकारमुदाहृतम्।।१३.७।।
13.translit:
icchā dveṣaḥ sukhaṁ duḥkhaṁ saṅghātaś cetanā dhṛtiḥ
etat kṣetraṁ samāsena sa-vikāram udāhṛtam
13.translate: Desire, aversion, pleasure, pain, the body, intelligence, and fortitude—this field has thus been briefly described, along with its modifications.
13.sridhara:
“Desire…”—these are well-known. Saṅghātaḥ is the body. Cetanā is the consciousness-like activity of the mind, the function of cognition. Dhṛtiḥ is firmness or fortitude. These—desire, aversion, and the rest—being perceptible, are not attributes of the self, but only of the mind. Hence, they are included as part of the field.

By implication, this also includes other mental functions such as resolution, reflection, and doubt. Thus, the śruti (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad १.५.३) says: “Desire, resolve, doubt, faith, lack of faith, firmness, lack of firmness, shame, intelligence, and fear—all of this is indeed the mind.”

In this way, the qualities of the field (kṣetra)—as was promised with the word yādṛk (“of what kind”)—have been explained. “This field along with its modifications”—meaning along with its transformations such as the senses—“has been briefly stated by Me to you.” Thus, this concludes the description of the kṣetra.

13.shlok:
अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम्।
आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः।।१३.८।।
13.translit:
amānitvam adambhitvam ahiṁsā kṣāntir ārjavam
ācāryopāsanaṁ śaucaṁ sthairyam ātma-vinigrahaḥ
13.translate: Humility, absence of pride, non-violence, forbearance, straightforwardness, service to the teacher, purity, steadiness, and self-restraint.
13.sridhara:
Now, intending to describe in detail the knowable—pure kṣetrajña—which is distinct from the kṣetra just described, and the means to its realization, He begins: “Humility…”—with five terms.

Amānitvam is the absence of self-glorification.
Adambhitvam is the absence of ostentation.
Ahiṁsā is the avoidance of causing pain to others.
Kṣāntiḥ is tolerance.
Ārjavam is absence of crookedness.
Ācāryopāsanam is service to the true teacher.
Śaucam is both external and internal purity; external, through clay and water; internal, through cleansing of mental impurities like attachment. Thus the smṛti says: “Purity is declared to be twofold, external and internal. External is through earth and water; internal, through purity of intention.”
Sthairyam is firmness or single-minded devotion in the right path once undertaken.
Ātma-vinigrahaḥ is the restraint of the body.

These are said to be knowledge, as the fifth word in verse १३.१२ states: etat jñānam iti proktam—"this is said to be knowledge."

13.shlok:
इन्द्रियार्थेषु वैराग्यमनहङ्कार एव च।
जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम्।।१३.९।।
13.translit:
indriyārtheṣu vairāgyam anahaṅkāra eva ca
janma-mṛtyu-jarā-vyādhi-duḥkha-doṣānudarśanam
13.translate: Detachment from sense objects, also absence of egoism; and the perception of the faults of birth, death, old age, and disease as sources of suffering.
13.sridhara:
Further: “Detachment from sense objects…”—vairāgya means renunciation of objects of the senses.

“Perceiving the faults and sufferings in birth, death, old age, and disease” means repeatedly reflecting on the misery and defect inherent in them. Alternatively, it means recognizing the inherent defect as misery itself. The remaining meanings are straightforward.

13.shlok:
असक्ितरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु।
नित्यं च समचित्तत्वमिष्टानिष्टोपपत्तिषु।।१३.१०।।
13.translit:
asaktiḥ anabhiṣvaṅgaḥ putra-dāra-gṛhādiṣu
nityaṁ ca sama-cittatvam iṣṭāniṣṭopapattiṣu
13.translate: Non-attachment, absence of possessiveness in relation to son, wife, home, and the like; and constant even-mindedness upon the attainment of what is pleasant and unpleasant.
13.sridhara:
Further: asaktiḥ—non-attachment—is the renunciation of affection for things like sons, etc.
Anabhiṣvaṅgaḥ is the absence of intense possessiveness toward their happiness or sorrow, such as “I alone am happy” or “I alone am miserable” in relation to them.
Samacittatvam is having an even mind always, at all times, when the desirable or undesirable occurs.

13.shlok:
मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्ितरव्यभिचारिणी।
विविक्तदेशसेवित्वमरतिर्जनसंसदि।।१३.११।।
13.translit:
mayi cānanya-yogena bhaktir avyabhicāriṇī
vivikta-deśa-sevitvam aratir jana-saṁsadi
13.translate: Unwavering devotion to Me through undivided Yoga; fondness for dwelling in solitary places; and disinterest in the company of people.
13.sridhara:
Further: “Unwavering devotion to Me…”—mayi, in Me, the Supreme Lord, ananya-yogena, through undivided contemplation, avyabhicāriṇī bhaktiḥ, exclusive devotion.

Vivikta-deśa-sevitvam—the tendency or disposition to resort to solitary places, which bring about mental purity and clarity.
Aratiḥ jana-saṁsadi—lack of delight or indifference towards the assemblies of worldly people.

13.shlok:
अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम्।
एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोऽन्यथा।।१३.१२।।
13.translit:
adhyātma-jñāna-nityatvaṁ tattva-jñānārtha-darśanam
etat jñānam iti proktam ajñānaṁ yad ato ’nyathā
13.translate: Constancy in spiritual knowledge, and vision of the purpose of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge; whatever is otherwise is ignorance.
13.sridhara:
Further: adhyātma-jñāna-nityatvam—constancy in knowledge concerning the Self. This refers to steadfastness in the understanding of the meaning of “tvam” (the individual self) in “tat tvam asi”.

Tattva-jñānārtha-darśanam—seeing the purpose (artha) of the knowledge of reality (tattva-jñāna), which is liberation. That is, reflecting on the supreme excellence of liberation.

Thus, all these twenty qualities, beginning from amānitvam, have been described and are stated to be knowledge because they are the means to knowledge.

That which is contrary to this—pride, hypocrisy, etc.—is declared to be ignorance, as said by sages like Vasiṣṭha. Because it is opposed to knowledge, it must therefore be completely renounced.

13.shlok:
ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वाऽमृतमश्नुते।
अनादिमत्परं ब्रह्म न सत्तन्नासदुच्यते।।१३.१३।।
13.translit:
jñeyaṁ yat tat pravakṣyāmi yaj jñātvāmṛtam aśnute
anādimat paraṁ brahma na sat tan nāsad ucyate
13.translate: That which is to be known, I shall now declare—that, by knowing which, one attains immortality: the beginningless, supreme Brahman, which is said to be neither being nor non-being.
13.sridhara:
Now, the object to be known (jñeya), through the previously described means, is stated: “I shall declare that which is to be known.” In order to evoke eagerness in the listener, the fruit of knowledge is shown: “By knowing which, one attains amṛta,” meaning liberation. What is that?

It is anādimat—not having a beginning; that is, beginningless.
It is paraṁ brahma—the supreme Brahman, unsurpassed.
Though anādi by itself, as a bahuvrīhi compound, indicates beginninglessness, still the use of the suffix -mat is a Vedic idiom (chāndasaḥ usage). Or alternatively, anādi and matparam may be taken as two separate words—meaning “My (Viṣṇu’s) supreme, formless Brahman.”

He then says: “It is said to be neither sat (being) nor asat (non-being).”
That which is the object of affirmation (vidhi-mukha) is referred to by the word sat; and that which is the object of negation (niṣedha) is referred to by the word asat. But this [Brahman

13.shlok:
सर्वतः पाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम्।
सर्वतः श्रुतिमल्लोके सर्वमावृत्य तिष्ठति।।१३.१४।।
13.translit:
sarvataḥ pāṇi-pādaṁ tat sarvato ’kṣi-śiro-mukham
sarvataḥ śrutimalloke sarvam āvṛtya tiṣṭhati
13.translate: With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads, and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, It exists in the world pervading all things.
13.sridhara:
Now, a doubt may arise: If Brahman is beyond both being and non-being, then statements such as “All this is indeed Brahman,” “This universe is verily Brahman,” etc., from the Upaniṣads seem contradicted. To counter this, the Lord, showing that Brahman’s powers are manifold—indeed heard to be diverse such as innate knowledge, strength, and action, as confirmed by the scriptures—illustrates its all-pervading nature through inconceivable power (acintya-śakti):

“That which has hands and feet in all directions”—meaning, whose hands and feet are everywhere.
“Eyes, heads, and mouths everywhere”—meaning, whose eyes, heads, and mouths are everywhere.
“Ears in all directions”—meaning, who possesses hearing faculties in all beings.
In the world, enveloping all things, It exists.

That is, through the activities of all living beings—whose organs like hands and feet serve as limiting adjuncts—It abides as the basis of all actions.

13.shlok:
सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम्।
असक्तं सर्वभृच्चैव निर्गुणं गुणभोक्तृ च।।१३.१५।।
13.translit:
sarvendriya-guṇābhāsaṁ sarvendriya-vivarjitam
asaktaṁ sarvabhṛc caiva nirguṇaṁ guṇa-bhoktṛ ca
13.translate: It shines through the functions of all the senses, yet is itself without all senses; unattached, yet It supports all; free of qualities, yet It is the experiencer of the qualities.
13.sridhara:
Further: “It shines through the functions of all the senses”—that is, it appears through the functions such as sight, etc., of all the senses and their respective objects like form, etc., by taking on their modes. Or, it illuminates all the senses and their objects.

It is also “devoid of all senses.” Thus the scripture says: “Without hands and feet, He moves quickly; without eyes He sees; without ears He hears,” etc.

Asaktam—detached, without attachment.
Nevertheless, “It supports all”—that is, It is the sustainer of everything.
It is nirguṇam—free from the qualities such as sattva, rajas, and tamas.
Yet, It is guṇa-bhoktṛ—the experiencer or upholder of those qualities.

13.shlok:
बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च।
सूक्ष्मत्वात्तदविज्ञेयं दूरस्थं चान्तिके च तत्।।१३.१६।।
13.translit:
bahir antaś ca bhūtānām acaraṁ caram eva ca
sūkṣmatvāt tad avijñeyaṁ dūrasthaṁ cāntike ca tat
13.translate: It is both outside and inside all beings; It is unmoving and also moving. Because of Its subtlety, It is unknowable; and It is both distant and also very near.
13.sridhara: Furthermore: “It is both outside and inside all beings.” That very [Brahman

13.shlok:
अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम्।
भूतभर्तृ च तज्ज्ञेयं ग्रसिष्णु प्रभविष्णु च।।१३.१७।।
13.translit:
avibhaktaṁ ca bhūteṣu vibhaktam iva ca sthitam
bhūta-bhartṛ ca taj jñeyaṁ grasiṣṇu prabhaviṣṇu ca
13.translate: Undivided in beings, yet appearing as if divided; that is to be known as the sustainer of beings, and also as the devourer and originator.
13.sridhara:
Furthermore: “Undivided…” Among beings—those composed of the immobile and the mobile—it is undivided as the cause, being non-different. Yet, as the effect, it appears divided and distinct. Just as the foam, etc., arising from the ocean are not different from the ocean, so too is That which has been described earlier as the essential nature (svarūpa) to be known.

It is the sustainer of beings—their nourisher during the time of sustenance; during dissolution, it is grasiṣṇu—the devourer; and during creation, it is prabhaviṣṇu—the originator, taking the form of various effects.

13.shlok:
ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते।
ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानगम्यं हृदि सर्वस्य विष्ठितम्।।१३.१८।।
13.translit:
jyotiṣām api taj jyotis tamasaḥ param ucyate
jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ jñāna-gamyaṁ hṛdi sarvasya viṣṭhitam
13.translate: That, the Light of even all lights, is said to be beyond darkness. It is knowledge, the knowable, and the goal of knowledge—situated in the heart of all beings.
13.sridhara:
Furthermore: “The Light of even all lights…” It is the illuminator even of lights like the moon and sun. Hence, the śruti says: “By that (light) the sun shines, being ignited by its brilliance. There, the sun does not shine, nor the moon, nor stars, nor lightning; then what to say of this fire? All this shines after That alone; by Its light, all this is illumined.”

Thus, it is said to be beyond darkness, which is ignorance (ajñāna), and untouched by it. The śruti also says: “Of the color of the sun, beyond darkness.”

That very entity is jñānam—manifest as the functioning of the intellect (buddhi); jñeyam—the object of knowledge in the form of perceptible forms such as color; and jñāna-gamyam—that which is to be attained by knowledge, by means of the practices earlier described, characterized by humility, non-pretentiousness, etc.

The phrase jñāna-gamyaṁ further qualifies it. It is situated in the heart of every living being—viśeṣeṇa apracyuta-svarūpeṇa—with its nature never displaced, as the inner controller (niyantṛ). According to the reading adhiṣṭhitam, the meaning is: it is established as the inner foundation.

13.shlok:
इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः।
मद्भक्त एतद्विज्ञाय मद्भावायोपपद्यते।।१३.१९।।
13.translit:
iti kṣetraṁ tathā jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ coktaṁ samāsataḥ
mad-bhakta etad vijñāya mad-bhāvāya upapadyate
13.translate: Thus the field, knowledge, and the knowable have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, becomes qualified to attain My state.
13.sridhara:
He concludes what has been stated—the field, etc., along with the qualifications and the result: “Thus…”

Thus the field (kṣetra), from the great elements (mahābhūta) to firmness (dhṛti), and similarly knowledge—from humility (amānitvam) to insight into the goal of knowledge (tattva-jñānārtha-darśanam), and the knowable, which was explained beginning from “The beginningless supreme Brahman” up to “seated in the heart of all beings”—all this, which has been elaborately stated by sages like Vasiṣṭha, etc., has been stated concisely by Me.

And this, when realized by My devotee, who is of the kind described in the previous chapter, makes him qualified to attain mad-bhāva—My state, i.e., Brahmanhood.

13.shlok:
प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव विद्ध्यनादी उभावपि।
विकारांश्च गुणांश्चैव विद्धि प्रकृतिसंभवान्।।१३.२०।।
13.translit:
prakṛtiṁ puruṣaṁ caiva viddhy anādī ubhāv api
vikārāṁś ca guṇāṁś caiva viddhi prakṛti-sambhavān
13.translate: Know both Nature (prakṛti) and the Spirit (puruṣa) to be beginningless; and know that all modifications and qualities are born of Nature.
13.sridhara:
In this way, the nature of the field (kṣetra)—what it is and what it is like—has been explained. Now He elaborates what its transformations are, from where they arise, and what they are. And similarly, He explains the nature, function, and potency of the Spirit (puruṣa), as was earlier declared through the intention to speak about the cause of transmigration due to prakṛti and puruṣa—starting from: “Know prakṛti…” and over the next five verses.

There, if prakṛti and puruṣa were to have a beginning, then some other preceding prakṛti would be needed to produce them, and another before that, leading to infinite regress (anavasthā). Hence, understand both as beginningless.

Prakṛti is beginningless because of the Lord’s power; and puruṣa also, being a portion of That (the Lord), is likewise beginningless.

Moreover, the beginninglessness (anāditva) and eternality (nityatva) of the Supreme Lord and His powers has been established in extensive detail by the revered Śaṅkara Bhagavatpāda in his commentaries. Therefore, due to concern for textual length, we shall not elaborate here.

Also know the modifications—such as body and senses—and the qualities (guṇas)—such as pleasure, pain, and delusion—as arising from prakṛti.

13.shlok:
कार्यकारणकर्तृत्वे हेतुः प्रकृतिरुच्यते।
पुरुषः सुखदुःखानां भोक्तृत्वे हेतुरुच्यते।।१३.२१।।
13.translit:
kārya-kāraṇa-kartṛtve hetuḥ prakṛtir ucyate
puruṣaḥ sukha-duḥkhānāṁ bhoktṛtve hetur ucyate
13.translate: In the performance of action and the operation of cause and effect, Nature is said to be the cause; the soul is said to be the cause in the experience of pleasure and pain.
13.sridhara:
Showing that the transformations (vikāras) arise from prakṛti, He now shows the puruṣa’s involvement in transmigration: “In action and causality…”

Action (kārya) refers to the body; causes (kāraṇa) are the senses, which serve as the instruments for pleasure and pain. In the role of producing these, i.e., in their specific transformations into these forms, prakṛti is said to be the cause—this is stated by Kapila and others.

The puruṣa, the individual soul (jīva), is said to be the cause in the enjoyership (bhoktṛtva) of pleasure and pain produced by those.

The sense is this: Although prakṛti, being insentient, cannot have agency (kartṛtva) on its own, and likewise puruṣa, being changeless, cannot truly be an enjoyer (bhoktṛ), still, agency (kartṛtva) means the capacity to produce activity. And that, even in the insentient, is possible when under the influence of sentience, due to being governed by consciousness.

Just as fire burns upward, wind moves sideways, and the milk of a cow flows outward at the sight of its calf—these occur under the influence of unseen impressions (adṛṣṭa), so too is kartṛtva attributed to prakṛti due to the mere presence (sannidhāna) of the puruṣa.

Enjoyership (bhoktṛtva) is the experience of pleasure and pain. Since such experience is a function only of consciousness, it is said that puruṣa, by proximity (sannidhāna), is the enjoyer.

13.shlok:
पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान्गुणान्।
कारणं गुणसङ्गोऽस्य सदसद्योनिजन्मसु।।१३.२२।।
13.translit:
puruṣaḥ prakṛtistho hi bhuṅkte prakṛti-jān guṇān
kāraṇaṁ guṇa-saṅgo 'sya sad-asad-yoni-janmasu
13.translate: The soul, dwelling in Nature, indeed experiences the qualities born of Nature; its association with the qualities is the cause of birth in good and evil wombs.
13.sridhara:
Still, how can the changeless and birthless puruṣa be an experiencer (bhoktṛ)? This is now explained: “The puruṣa…”

Indeed, because the puruṣa abides in prakṛti, meaning it resides in the body, which is the product of prakṛti, by identification with it, therefore it experiences the pleasures and so on produced by it.

And for this puruṣa, among births that occur in noble wombs such as those of the gods, and ignoble wombs such as those of animals—what is the cause of these? Association (saṅga) with the guṇas—that is, association with the senses, which are agents of good and bad actions—is the cause. That is the meaning.

13.shlok:
उपद्रष्टाऽनुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः।
परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन्पुरुषः परः।।१३.२३।।
13.translit:
upadraṣṭānumantā ca bhartā bhoktā maheśvaraḥ
paramātmeti cāpy ukto dehe 'smin puruṣaḥ paraḥ
