13.translate: The Supreme Self in this body is also called the witness, the consenter, the sustainer, the experiencer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.
13.sridhara:
In this way, transmigration for the puruṣa arises due to non-discrimination between prakṛti and puruṣa, not due to the true nature (svarūpa) of the puruṣa. To indicate this intention, its essential nature is now described: “The puruṣa who is the witness…”

Even though existing in this body, which is a product of prakṛti, the puruṣa is paraḥ—transcendent and distinct—and is not associated with the qualities (guṇas) of the body. That is the meaning.

What are the reasons? Because He is the upadraṣṭā, the onlooker—remaining distinct, yet watching closely. Also, He is the anumantā, the consenter—He gives consent by mere presence. He is the supporter (bhartā) by His lordly nature—i.e., the sustainer. He is the bhoktā, the protector. He is also the maheśvara, the great Lord. He is the ruler of even Brahmā and others. He is called paramātmā, the inner controller (antaryāmin)—this is said in the śruti.

And thus the śruti says: “He is the Lord of beings, the Lord of the world, the protector of the world,” and so on.

13.shlok:
य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह।
सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते।।१३.२४।।
13.translit:
ya evaṁ vetti puruṣaṁ prakṛtiṁ ca guṇaiḥ saha
sarvathā vartamāno 'pi na sa bhūyo 'bhijāyate
13.translate: He who thus knows both the puruṣa and prakṛti together with the qualities—though he behaves in every way—is not born again.
13.sridhara:
He praises the one who has this discriminative knowledge between prakṛti and puruṣa: “He who in this way…”

He who knows the puruṣa in this way—as the witness and so on—and who knows prakṛti along with the guṇas, meaning along with their transformations like pleasure and pain—such a puruṣa, even if he lives in any manner, even transgressing prescribed conduct, is not born again. That is, he is truly liberated.

13.shlok:
ध्यानेनात्मनि पश्यन्ति केचिदात्मानमात्मना।
अन्ये sāṅkhyena yogena karma-yogena cāpare।।१३.२५।।
13.translit:
dhyānenātmani paśyanti kecid ātmānam ātmanā
anye sāṅkhyena yogena karma-yogena cāpare
13.translate: Some behold the Self by the Self through meditation; others by the path of knowledge (Sāṅkhya), and others again by the path of action.
13.sridhara:
The alternatives among the means for this knowledge of the distinct Self are now described: “By meditation…”—these two verses.

By meditation—i.e., by the continuous flow of the mental impression having the form of the Self—some perceive the Self within the body, by the Self, that is, by the mind.

Others perceive it through Sāṅkhya, by the contemplation of the distinction between prakṛti and puruṣa. Others through yoga, the eight-limbed system. Still others perceive it through karma-yoga—this verb “perceive” is implied in all cases.

And though there may be a sequence or combination among meditation and the other methods as appropriate, this distinction is spoken of with the intention of differentiating according to one’s own predominating path.

13.shlok:
अन्ये त्वेवमजानन्तः श्रुत्वाऽन्येभ्य उपासते।
तेऽपि चातितरन्त्येव मृत्युं श्रुतिपरायणाः।।१३.२६।।
13.translit:
anye tv evam ajānantaḥ śrutvā anyebhya upāsate
te 'pi cātitaranty eva mṛtyuṁ śruti-parāyaṇāḥ
13.translate: Others also, not knowing thus, worship after hearing from others; even they, devoted to what they have heard, certainly cross over death.
13.sridhara:
The means of liberation for those of very dull eligibility is stated: “Others…”
Others, not knowing the Self characterized in this way—such as being the witness (upadraṣṭṛ) and so on—through the path of Sāṅkhya, yoga, etc., hear about it from others, namely teachers (ācāryas), through instruction, and worship—that is, they meditate.
Even these, being devoted to the hearing of instruction, certainly cross over mṛtyu, that is, saṁsāra—gradually.

13.shlok:
यावत्सञ्जायते किञ्चित्सत्त्वं स्थावरजङ्गमम्।
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञसंयोगात्तद्विद्धि भरतर्षभ।।१३.२७।।
13.translit:
yāvat sañjāyate kiñcit sattvaṁ sthāvara-jaṅgamam
kṣetra-kṣetrajña-saṁyogāt tad viddhi bharatarṣabha
13.translate: Whatever entity is born, moving or unmoving, know that it arises from the union of the field and the knower of the field, O best of the Bharatas.
13.sridhara:
Since karma-yoga has been elaborated in chapters ३, ४, and ५, and dhyāna-yoga in chapters ६ and ८, and because meditation is also focused on the Self distinguished by Sāṅkhya, the Sāṅkhya path alone is now elaborated further beginning with “yāvat,” continuing until the chapter's end.
Whatever mere entity (vastu-mātra) is born—that is, whatever being (sattva) arises—it is all due to the contact between kṣetra and kṣetrajña, caused by ignorance, in the form of the superimposition of mutual identity. Know it to be so.

13.shlok:
समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम्।
विनश्यत्स्वविनश्यन्तं यः पश्यति स पश्यति।।१३.२८।।
13.translit:
samaṁ sarveṣu bhūteṣu tiṣṭhantaṁ parameśvaram
vinaśyatsu avinaśyantaṁ yaḥ paśyati sa paśyati
13.translate: He sees who sees the Supreme Lord standing equally in all beings, the imperishable within the perishable.
13.sridhara:
Having stated that transmigration arises from non-discrimination, now the correct vision concerning the distinct Self is described, which puts an end to that: “He who sees…”
He who sees the paramātmā, abiding equally, without distinction, in all beings—both stationary and moving—as existence itself (sat-rūpa), and therefore sees the imperishable present even in the perishable, only he truly sees—not another.

13.shlok:
समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम्।
न हिनस्त्यात्मनाऽऽत्मानं ततो याति परां गतिम्।।१३.२९।।
13.translit:
samaṁ paśyan hi sarvatra samavasthitam īśvaram
na hinasty ātmanā ātmānaṁ tato yāti parāṁ gatim
13.translate: For, seeing equally the Lord present equally everywhere, he does not harm the self by the self; therefore he reaches the supreme goal.
13.sridhara:
Why so? This is now stated: “Seeing equally…”
Because he sees the paramātmā situated everywhere, in all beings equally, unwavering from His true nature—therefore, he does not harm the Self by the self; that is, through ignorance, he does not obscure the Self, whose nature is existence-consciousness-bliss (sat-cit-ānanda), and thus does not destroy it.
And as a result, he attains the supreme goal—liberation (mokṣa).
But one who does not see in this way is a body-identifying person (dehātma-darśī), and destroys the Self along with the body.
So too the śruti says: “Those worlds are verily sunless, covered in darkness, and to them go those people who slay the Self.” (Īśopaniṣad ३)

13.shlok:
प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः।
यः पश्यति तथाऽऽत्मानमकर्तारं स पश्यति।।१३.३०।।
13.translit:
prakṛtyaiva ca karmāṇi kriyamāṇāni sarvaśaḥ
yaḥ paśyati tathā ātmānam akartāraṁ sa paśyati
13.translate: He who sees that all actions are performed entirely by Nature alone, and thus sees the Self as actionless—he truly sees.
13.sridhara:
Now, one might ask: “If differences in doing good and bad actions are seen, how can the Self be equal in all?” Anticipating this, it is said: “Actions are performed by prakṛti alone…”
All actions are performed entirely—by all means—by prakṛti alone, which has transformed into the body and senses. He who sees this, and accordingly sees the Self as non-agent—meaning, the doership of the Self exists only through identification with the body and not inherently—he alone truly sees; not anyone else.

13.shlok:
यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति।
तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा।।१३.३१।।
13.translit:
yadā bhūta-pṛthag-bhāvam ekastham anupaśyati
tata eva ca vistāraṁ brahma sampadyate tadā
13.translate: When one sees the diversity of beings as resting in the One, and their expansion as arising from That alone—then he attains Brahman.
13.sridhara:
Now, one who, seeing no difference in the Self even with the diversity caused by the different natures of beings as being only in prakṛti, attains Brahman—this is said: “When one sees…”
When one contemplates (anupaśyati) the diversity (pṛthak-bhāvam)—the distinctness—of beings, both moving and unmoving, as existing in the One—that is, in prakṛti which is of the nature of the Lord’s power (īśvara-śakti), during dissolution (i.e., as in a latent state); and from That alone—namely, from that very prakṛti—as having expanded at the time of creation; then, seeing that even the beings are non-different due to their being merely forms of prakṛti, one attains Brahman.
The meaning is: he becomes Brahman itself.

13.shlok:
अनादित्वान्निर्गुणत्वात्परमात्मायमव्ययः।
शरीरस्थोऽपि कौन्तेय न करोति न लिप्यते।।१३.३२।।
13.translit:
anāditvān nirguṇatvāt paramātmā ayam avyayaḥ
śarīrastho ’pi kaunteya na karoti na lipyate
13.translate: This Supreme Self is without beginning, without attributes, and imperishable. Though dwelling in the body, O Kaunteya, It neither acts nor is tainted.
13.sridhara:
Still, it might be said that in the state of transmigration, there is inescapable difference for the Supreme Lord due to the relation between the body and actions and their results such as pleasure and pain. How then can there be equality of vision?
To address this, it is said: “Because He is beginningless…”
Whatever has a beginning alone undergoes destruction. That which possesses guṇas perishes when the guṇas perish.
But this paramātmā is beginningless and devoid of guṇas, and therefore imperishable—that is, unchanging.
Thus, though dwelling in the body, He does nothing, nor is He tainted by the results of action.

13.shlok:
यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते।
सर्वत्रावस्थितो देहे तथाऽऽत्मा नोपलिप्यते।।१३.३३।।
13.translit:
yathā sarva-gataṁ saukṣmyād ākāśaṁ na upalipyate
sarvatra avasthito dehe tathā ātmā na upalipyate
13.translate: Just as the all-pervading space is not tainted due to its subtlety, so also the Self, though abiding in all bodies, is not tainted.
13.sridhara:
An illustration for this is now given: “Just as…”
Just as space (ākāśa), though present even in mud and the like, is not tainted by them due to its subtlety and non-attachment—
So too, the ātmā, though abiding in all bodies—whether superior, middling, or inferior—is not tainted.
That is, it is not affected by the merits or faults connected with the body.

13.shlok:
यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः।
क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत।।१३.३४।।
13.translit:
yathā prakāśayati ekaḥ kṛtsnaṁ lokam imaṁ raviḥ
kṣetraṁ kṣetrī tathā kṛtsnaṁ prakāśayati bhārata
13.translate: Just as the one sun illumines this entire world, so also the knower of the field illumines the entire field, O Bhārata.
13.sridhara:
The absence of taint due to non-attachment was explained through the illustration of space (ākāśa).
Now, to show that due to being the illuminator, it is not associated with the qualities of the illuminated, the illustration of the sun is given: “Just as…”
The meaning is clear.

13.shlok:
क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवमन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा।
भूतप्रकृतिमोक्षं च ये विदुर्यान्ति ते परम्।।१३.३५।।
13.translit:
kṣetra-kṣetrajñayoḥ evam antaraṁ jñāna-cakṣuṣā
bhūta-prakṛti-mokṣaṁ ca ye viduḥ yānti te param
13.translate: They who see—through the eye of knowledge—the distinction between the field and the knower of the field, and also the release from the nature of beings, they go to the Supreme.
13.sridhara:
The topic of the chapter is now concluded: “Between the field and the knower of the field…”
Those who, in this manner as explained, know the distinction (antara) between the kṣetra and the kṣetrajña with the eye of discrimination (viveka-jñāna-lakṣaṇa cakṣuṣ)—
And who also know the release (mokṣa) of beings from prakṛti, and the means for that release, such as meditation (dhyāna), they attain the Supreme goal (param padam).

14.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच —
परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम्।
यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः।।१४.१।।
14.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca —
paraṁ bhūyaḥ pravakṣyāmi jñānānāṁ jñānam uttamam
yaj jñātvā munayaḥ sarve parāṁ siddhim ito gatāḥ
14.translate: The Blessed Lord said: I shall again declare that supreme knowledge, the highest among all forms of knowledge, knowing which all sages have attained the highest perfection from this world.
14.sridhara:
Having refuted the independence of the spirit and matter, and describing their relationship through the influence of the guṇas, the Lord now expounds the diversity of saṁsāra in detail in this fourteenth chapter.

In the previous chapter, it was said: “Know that whatever is born, whether moving or unmoving, arises from the union of the field and the knower of the field.” (१३.२६) That union, unlike what the atheistic Sāṅkhyas propose, is not independent, but occurs only through the will of the Lord. Having declared this, the verse “guṇa-saṅgaḥ” (१३.२२) taught that association with the guṇas is the cause of birth in good and evil wombs. Now, the Lord praises the subject He is about to teach—namely, the diversity of saṁsāra caused by the guṇas.

He says: “I shall again declare to you.” Again (bhūyaḥ), I shall declare (pravakṣyāmi) to you thoroughly that knowledge (jñānam) which is supreme (param), established in the highest truth (paramārtha-niṣṭham), and which is called knowledge because it is that by which one knows. What kind of knowledge? The best among all knowledges—those concerning austerity, ritual action, etc.—because it alone leads to liberation. That very knowledge is now praised: “Knowing which, all the sages, being reflective (manana-śīlāḥ), have gone (gatāḥ) from here—that is, from the bondage of the body—to the highest perfection (parāṁ siddhim).”

14.shlok:
इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः।
सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च।।१४.२।।
14.translit:
idaṁ jñānam upāśritya mama sādharmyam āgatāḥ
sarge ’pi na upajāyante pralaye na vyathanti ca
14.translate: Resorting to this knowledge, those who have attained similarity with Me are not born at creation and are not disturbed at dissolution.
14.sridhara: Moreover—“Resorting to this”—by practicing this forthcoming knowledge as a means, those who have attained sameness (sādharmya), that is, likeness to Me, in form (mad-rūpatva), are not born even at the time of creation, when beings such as Brahmā are produced. Similarly, they do not suffer at the time of dissolution—they do not experience the sorrows of dissolution. In other words, they do not return again.

14.shlok:
मम योनिर्महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन्गर्भं दधाम्यहम्।
संभवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत।।१४.३।।
14.translit:
mama yonir mahad brahma tasmin garbhaṁ dadhāmy aham
saṁbhavaḥ sarva-bhūtānāṁ tato bhavati bhārata
14.translate: My womb is the great Brahman; into that I place the seed, and from that, O Bhārata, arises the birth of all beings.
14.sridhara:
Thus, having won over the listener with praise of the knowledge, the Lord now expresses the intended point—that the cause of the origin of all beings lies in the dependence of both prakṛti and puruṣa upon the Supreme Lord, and not in their independence.

He says: “My womb is the great Brahman (mahad brahma).” The term “mahat” implies that it is unlimited by time and space, or that it causes expansion (bṛṁhaṇa) of its effects, or that it is the cause of their growth. Brahman here means prakṛti. That great Brahman is the womb (yoni), the place of conception for Me, the Supreme Lord.

Into that I place the seed (garbhaṁ), meaning the reflection of consciousness (cid-ābhāsa), the cause of the expansion of the world. That is, at the time of creation, I unite the kṣetrajña, which had been merged in Me during dissolution but remains endowed with the residual impressions of ignorance, desire, and karma, with the field, which serves as its object of enjoyment. Therefore, from that placement of the seed arises the origin (saṁbhavaḥ) of all beings (sarva-bhūtānāṁ), from Brahmā downward.

14.shlok:
सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः।
तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता।।१४.४।।
14.translit:
sarva-yoniṣu kaunteya mūrtayaḥ sambhavanti yāḥ
tāsāṁ brahma mahad yoniḥ ahaṁ bīja-pradaḥ pitā
14.translate: Whatever forms arise, O Kaunteya, in all wombs—Brahman is their great womb, and I am the seed-giving father.
14.sridhara:
Not only at the beginning of creation does the origin of beings take place through prakṛti and puruṣa, both of which are under My control, but at all times. This is explained: “In all wombs…”

In all wombs—human and others—whatever forms (mūrtayaḥ) arise, consisting of moving and non-moving beings, for those forms, Brahman—i.e., prakṛti—is the great womb (mahad yoniḥ), the mother-like receptacle. And I am the seed-giving father (bīja-pradaḥ pitā), the one who initiates conception.

14.shlok:
सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसंभवाः।
निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम्।।१४.५।।
14.translit:
sattvaṁ rajas tama iti guṇāḥ prakṛti-sambhavāḥ
nibadhnanti mahā-bāho dehe dehinam avyayam
14.translate: Sattva, rajas, and tamas—these guṇas, born of prakṛti, bind the imperishable embodied one to the body, O mighty-armed one.
14.sridhara:
Thus, having described the origin of all beings through prakṛti and puruṣa under the Lord’s control, He now explains how the puruṣa, through contact with prakṛti, becomes bound in saṁsāra, beginning with this verse and continuing through fourteen verses.

Sattva, rajas, and tamas—these three guṇas are born of prakṛti, meaning they arise from it. The state of balance of the guṇas is prakṛti itself. These guṇas, being manifest separately from that prakṛti, are said to arise from it.

Though the embodied self (dehin), which abides in the body (prakṛti’s product), is truly immutable (avyaya) and changeless, these guṇas bind it by causing identification with the body through their respective effects—pleasure, pain, and delusion.

14.shlok:
तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्।
सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ।।१४.६।।
14.translit:
tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt prakāśakam anāmayam
sukha-saṅgena badhnāti jñāna-saṅgena ca anagha
14.translate: Among them, sattva, due to its purity, is illuminating and free from affliction; it binds by attachment to happiness and by attachment to knowledge, O sinless one.
14.sridhara:
Among them—the three guṇas—sattva is described with its characteristics and its manner of binding: “tatra” means among them. Sattva, due to its purity (nirmalatva), is transparent like crystal, and therefore illuminating (prakāśakam), and free from affliction (anāmayam), meaning peaceful. Thus, due to its peacefulness, it binds by its effect, happiness—through attachment to it. And due to its illuminating nature, it binds also by its effect, knowledge—through attachment to it.

O sinless one (anagha), the meaning is that it causes the kṣetrajña, identifying with the mental state that says “I am happy” or “I am knowledgeable,” to become associated with that.

14.shlok:
रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम्।
तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम्।।१४.७।।
14.translit:
rajo rāgātmakaṁ viddhi tṛṣṇā-saṅga-samudbhavam
tan nibadhnāti kaunteya karma-saṅgena dehinam
14.translate: Know rajas to be of the nature of passion, arising from craving and attachment; it binds the embodied one, O Kaunteya, through attachment to action.
14.sridhara: Now the characteristics and binding nature of rajas are explained: Know that the guṇa called rajas is of the nature of passion (rāgātmaka), meaning of the form of attraction or delighting. Therefore, it arises from craving and attachment (tṛṣṇā-saṅga-samudbhavam). Craving (tṛṣṇā) is the desire for that which is not yet obtained; attachment (saṅga) is the intense affection for what is already obtained. Rajas, being the source of both craving and attachment, binds the embodied one (dehinam) to actions—both seen and unseen—by attachment (karma-saṅgena), meaning by deep involvement in them. It is from craving and attachment that one becomes attached to action.

14.shlok:
तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्।
प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत।।१४.८।।
14.translit:
tamas tv ajñāna-jaṁ viddhi mohanaṁ sarva-dehinām
pramāda-ālasya-nidrābhiḥ tan nibadhnāti bhārata
14.translate: But know tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds, O Bhārata, through heedlessness, laziness, and sleep.
14.sridhara:
Now the characteristic and binding nature of tamas is explained: Tamas is born of ignorance (ajñānāt jātaṁ), meaning it arises from that aspect of prakṛti characterized by the power of concealment (āvaraṇa-śakti-pradhāna). Therefore, it is deluding (mohanam), meaning it causes confusion, for all embodied beings. Thus, it binds the embodied one through heedlessness (pramāda), laziness (ālasya), and sleep (nidrā).

Here, heedlessness (pramāda) means inattentiveness; laziness (ālasya) is lack of effort; and sleep (nidrā) is the sinking or dissolution of the mind (cittasya avasādaḥ layaḥ).

14.shlok:
सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत।
ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत।।१४.९।।
14.translit:
sattvaṁ sukhe sañjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata
jñānam āvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde sañjayaty uta
14.translate: Sattva binds one to happiness, rajas to action, O Bhārata; but tamas, covering knowledge, binds to heedlessness indeed.
14.sridhara:
The superiority of each guṇa in producing its own effect is described: Sattva binds to happiness (sukhe sañjayati), meaning it connects the embodied one to happiness. Even when there are causes for sorrow and suffering, sattva turns the embodied being toward happiness.

Similarly, though sorrow and its causes may exist, rajas binds to action alone (karmaṇi sañjayati). But tamas, even when produced in the association of great beings (mahat-saṅga), covers knowledge (jñānam āvṛtya) and binds to heedlessness (pramāde sañjayati), meaning it connects one to inattentiveness regarding truths taught by great beings.

The word uta (“indeed”) suggests that tamas also binds to laziness and the like.

14.shlok:
रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत।
रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा।।१४.१०।।
14.translit:
rajas tamaś ca abhibhūya sattvaṁ bhavati bhārata
rajaḥ sattvaṁ tamaś ca eva tamaḥ sattvaṁ rajas tathā
14.translate: Sattva arises, O Bhārata, overpowering rajas and tamas; rajas arises overpowering sattva and tamas; and tamas arises overpowering sattva and rajas.
14.sridhara:
The cause of the operation of a particular guṇa is now given: Rajas and tamas—these two guṇas—when overpowered (abhibhūya), that is, suppressed, sattva arises (bhavati), appearing due to the force of the unseen (adṛṣṭa). Then, it connects to its own effect—happiness and knowledge.

Similarly, rajas arises overpowering sattva and tamas; then, it connects to its own effects—desire and action. Likewise, tamas arises overpowering sattva and rajas; then, it connects to its own effects—heedlessness and laziness.

14.shlok:
सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते।
ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत।।१४.११।।
14.translit:
sarva-dvāreṣu dehe’smin prakāśaḥ upajāyate
jñānaṁ yadā tadā vidyāt vivṛddhaṁ sattvam iti uta
14.translate: When light arises through all the gates in this body, then it should be known that sattva has increased.
14.sridhara: Now, with three verses, the signs of the increase of sattva and the others are described. “Sarva-dvāreṣu” — in this body, which is the seat of experience for the self, when in all its gates — the senses like the ear and so on — light in the form of knowledge of sound and such arises, then, from this sign of light, it should be known that sattva has increased. By the word uta, it is also implied that one should understand this increase of sattva through the signs of happiness and the like as well.

14.shlok:
लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा।
रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ।।१४.१२।।
14.translit:
lobhaḥ pravṛttir ārambhaḥ karmaṇām aśamaḥ spṛhā
rajasya etāni jāyante vivṛddhe bharatarṣabha
14.translate: Greed, activity, initiation of actions, restlessness, and craving—these arise when rajas has increased, O best of the Bhāratas.
14.sridhara:
Furthermore: “Lobhaḥ” — greed is the ever-growing desire for wealth and such even when it is abundantly arising. Pravṛttiḥ is the constant state of being engaged in action. Ārambhaḥ karmaṇām refers to the effort to construct things like houses. Aśamaḥ is the unceasing fluctuation of thoughts like “Having done this, I will do that,” etc. Spṛhā is the intense desire for various objects seen here and there, whether exalted or base.

When rajas is predominant, these signs arise. From these signs, one should understand the increase of rajas.

14.shlok:
अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च।
तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन।।१४.१३।।
14.translit:
aprakāśaḥ apravṛttiḥ ca pramādaḥ mohaḥ eva ca
tamasya etāni jāyante vivṛddhe kuru-nandana
14.translate: Non-illumination, inactivity, heedlessness, and delusion—these arise when tamas has increased, O delight of the Kurus.
14.sridhara: Furthermore: Aprakāśaḥ — the loss of discernment; apravṛttiḥ — absence of effort; pramādaḥ — lack of mindfulness toward what ought to be done; mohaḥ — false conviction. When tamas is predominant, these signs arise. From these, one should know the increase of tamas.

14.shlok:
यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत्।
तदोत्तमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यते।।१४.१४।।
14.translit:
yadā sattve pravṛddhe tu pralayaṁ yāti deha-bhṛt
tadā uttama-vidām lokān amalān pratipadyate
14.translate: When the embodied one dies with sattva predominant, then he attains the pure worlds of the knowers of the highest.
14.sridhara: Now the specific results of sattva and the others at the time of death are stated in two verses: When sattva is predominant, if the jīva meets with death, then he attains the pure (amalaḥ), luminous realms of the knowers of the Highest—those who worship (upāsate) the excellent ones like Hiraṇyagarbha. These worlds are special places for the enjoyment of happiness.

14.shlok:
रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते।
तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते।।१४.१५।।
14.translit:
rajasi pralayaṁ gatvā karma-saṅgiṣu jāyate
tathā pralīnaḥ tamasi mūḍha-yoniṣu jāyate
14.translate: Dying when rajas is predominant, one is born among those attached to action; dying in tamas, one is born in deluded wombs.
14.sridhara: Furthermore: When rajas is predominant, and one dies, he is born among humans attached to action. Likewise, when one dies with tamas predominant, he is born in the wombs of the deluded, such as animals and the like.

14.shlok:
कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम्।
रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम्।।१४.१६।।
14.translit:
karmaṇaḥ sukṛtasyāhuḥ sāttvikaṁ nirmalaṁ phalam
rajasas tu phalaṁ duḥkham ajñānaṁ tamasaḥ phalam
14.translate: They say that the fruit of good action is sāttvika and pure; the fruit of rajas is sorrow; and the fruit of tamas is ignorance.
14.sridhara:
Now the varied results caused by sattva and the others, through their respective kinds of action, are described: “karmaṇaḥ” — of an auspicious action. Of a sāttvika action, the fruit is sāttvika — meaning predominated by sattva — pure, full of light, and happiness. This is stated by Kapila and others.

With “rajasas tu,” the meaning is “of rājasika karma.” Since the context concerns the fruits of action, its result is said to be sorrow.

With “tamasaḥ,” the meaning is “of tāmasika karma.” Its fruit is said to be ignorance — delusion.

The characteristics of sāttvika and other karmas, such as being determined and free from attachment, will be explained in Chapter १८.

14.shlok:
सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च।
प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च।।१४.१७।।
14.translit:
sattvāt sañjāyate jñānaṁ rajaso lobha eva ca
pramāda-mohau tamasaḥ bhavataḥ ajñānam eva ca
14.translate: From sattva arises knowledge; and from rajas, indeed, greed. From tamas arise heedlessness and delusion, and also ignorance.
14.sridhara:
Here, the cause for the same is given: From sattva arises knowledge. Therefore, the fruit of sāttvika karma is happiness filled with light.

From rajas arises greed. And since that is the cause of sorrow, the fruit of the karma that precedes it is sorrow.

From tamas arise heedlessness, delusion, and ignorance. Therefore, the fruit of tāmasika karma is that which leads to ignorance — and this is entirely appropriate.

14.shlok:
ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः।
जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः।।१४.१८।।
14.translit:
ūrdhvaṁ gacchanti sattva-sthā madhye tiṣṭhanti rājasāḥ
jaghanya-guṇa-vṛtti-sthā adho gacchanti tāmasāḥ
14.translate: Those abiding in sattva go upward; the rājasika dwell in the middle; and those abiding in the function of the lowest guna — tamas — go downward.
14.sridhara:
Now the difference in outcome for those engaged in sattva and the others is described: Those who are sattva-sthāḥ — those whose conduct is primarily sāttvika — ascend upward.

Due to the gradation in the excellence of sattva, they attain, with each higher stage providing a hundredfold increase in bliss, the worlds of humans, gandharvas, ancestors, gods, and so on — up to Satyaloka. That is the meaning.

The rājasika, who are agitated by thirst and so forth, remain in the middle — they take birth again in the human world.

Those who remain established in the function (vṛtti) of tamas, the lowest of the guṇas — such as heedlessness and delusion — descend downward. Due to the gradation in tamas-vṛtti, they are born in the hells like Tāmisra and so on.

14.shlok:
नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति।
गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति।।१४.१९।।
14.translit:
nānyaṁ guṇebhyaḥ kartāraṁ yadā draṣṭā anupaśyati
guṇebhyaś ca paraṁ vetti mad-bhāvaṁ saḥ adhigacchati
14.translate: When the seer perceives no agent of action other than the guṇas and knows that which is beyond the guṇas, he attains My state.
14.sridhara:
Thus having explained the cycle of saṁsāra brought about by association with the guṇas of prakṛti, now liberation attained by discriminating from that is shown: “nānyam iti.”

When the seer becomes discerning and no longer sees any doer apart from the guṇas — which are modifications in the form of intellect and the like — but sees that the guṇas themselves are the agents of action, and when he knows the Self, which is distinct and beyond the guṇas — the witness of all — then such a one attains mad-bhāva, the state of Brahman.

14.shlok:
गुणानेतानतीत्य त्रीन्देही देहसमुद्भवान्।
जन्ममृत्युजरादुःखैर्विमुक्तोऽमृतमश्नुते।।१४.२०।।
14.translit:
guṇān etān atītya trīn dehī deha-samudbhavān
janma-mṛtyu-jarā-duḥkhaiḥ vimuktaḥ amṛtam aśnute
14.translate: The embodied one, having transcended these three guṇas which give rise to the body, freed from birth, death, old age, and sorrow, attains immortality.
14.sridhara:
Then, by the removal of all afflictions caused by the guṇas, one becomes fulfilled. That is stated: “guṇān etān.”

The three guṇas — from whom the forms of body and so on arise, meaning they transform into the body — having transcended these, and being freed from birth and the rest which are caused by them, he attains amṛta, the bliss of Brahman.

14.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
कैर्लिङ्गैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतानतीतो भवति प्रभो।
किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तते।।१४.२१।।
14.translit:
arjuna uvāca
kair liṅgais trīn guṇān etān atīto bhavati prabho
kim-ācāraḥ kathaṁ ca etān trīn guṇān ativartate
14.translate: Arjuna said: O Lord, by what signs is one known who has transcended these three guṇas? What is his conduct, and how does he go beyond these three guṇas?
14.sridhara:
Hearing “he attains immortality having transcended these guṇas,” Arjuna, desiring to properly understand the characteristics, conduct, and means by which one becomes a guṇa-transcender, said:

“O Lord, by what signs — what marks that arise within the self — does the embodied one become known as transcending the guṇas?” This is the question regarding characteristics (lakṣaṇa).

“What is his conduct?” means: “What is his ācāra — how does he behave?”

And, “how does he transcend these three guṇas — by what means?” Thus, he asks for that explanation.

14.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव।
न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति।।१४.२२।।
14.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
prakāśaṁ ca pravṛttiṁ ca moham eva ca pāṇḍava
na dveṣṭi sampravṛttāni na nivṛttāni kāṅkṣati
14.translate: The Blessed Lord said: O Pāṇḍava, light (knowledge), activity, and delusion — when they arise, he does not hate them; when they subside, he does not long for them.
14.sridhara:
Though the question about the characteristics of a stable person (sthita-prajña) was already asked in Chapter २ and answered, understanding that it is now asked again with a desire for further elaboration, the Blessed Lord speaks — in six verses beginning with “prakāśaṁ ca.”

First, in this verse, He speaks of one inner characteristic:

“Prakāśa” — the light described earlier as “in this body, when the light shines through all the gates” — is the effect of sattva.
“Pravṛtti” — action — is the effect of rajas.
“Moha” — delusion — is the effect of tamas.

These three serve as indicators of sattva, rajas, and tamas respectively. When all such effects naturally arise in due course, the one who does not hate them as sorrowful, and when they recede, who does not long for them as pleasurable — such a one is said to be beyond the guṇas. This is to be connected with the next (fourth) verse.

14.shlok:
उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते।
गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येव योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गते।।१४.२३।।
14.translit:
udāsīna-vad āsīno guṇair yo na vicālyate
guṇāḥ vartanta iti eva yaḥ avatiṣṭhati na iṅgate
14.translate: He who sits like one indifferent, is not disturbed by the guṇas; who remains firm, knowing, “It is the guṇas that are acting,” and does not move.
14.sridhara:
Having now stated the self-perceived characteristic of such a person, the Lord answers the second question — “What is his conduct?” — by stating a characteristic that can be known by others, in three verses beginning with “udāsīna-vat.”

He sits like an indifferent one (udāsīna), meaning, as a witness. He who is not shaken from his nature by the guṇas, through their effects such as pleasure and pain — he is not disturbed. Rather, understanding through discriminative knowledge that “the guṇas alone act in their own ways, and I have no relation to them,” he remains silent and firm.

“Parasmai padam ārṣam” — the ending “ti” instead of “te” is a poetic license used by sages.

14.shlok:
समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः।
तुल्यप्रियाप्रियो धीरस्तुल्यनिन्दात्मसंस्तुतिः।।१४.२४।।
14.translit:
sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ svasthaḥ sama-loṣṭāśma-kāñcanaḥ
tulya-priyāpriyo dhīraḥ tulya-nindātma-saṁstutiḥ
14.translate: He who is the same in pleasure and pain, who remains in his own Self, to whom a clod, stone, and gold are alike, who is equal towards dear and undear, firm-minded, and equal in censure and praise.
14.sridhara:
Furthermore: “He who is sama — equal — in pleasure and pain,” due to being svasthaḥ — one who abides in his true Self-nature.

Therefore, for him a lump of clay, a stone, and gold are the same.

He who is equal toward what is pleasant and unpleasant — which are the causes of pleasure and pain — is called dhīraḥ (firm-minded).

He to whom censure and praise of the self are equal.

14.shlok:
मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः।
सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते।।१४.२५।।
14.translit:
mānāpamānayos tulyaḥ tulyaḥ mitrāri-pakṣayoḥ
sarva-ārambha-parityāgī guṇa-atītaḥ sa ucyate
14.translate: He who is equal in honor and dishonor, equal among friend and foe, who has abandoned all undertakings — he is said to have transcended the guṇas.
14.sridhara:
Moreover: “Equal in honor and dishonor,” — that is, he is unaffected by respect or disrespect.

Equal toward the friendly and the hostile parties.

He whose nature is to abandon all undertakings (ārambha), meaning all efforts for seen and unseen results — such a one, possessing such conduct, is called a guṇātīta — one who has transcended the guṇas.

14.shlok:
मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्ितयोगेन सेवते।
स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान् ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते।।१४.२६।।
14.translit:
māṁ ca yo ’vyabhicāreṇa bhakti-yogena sevate
sa guṇān samatītyaitān brahma-bhūyāya kalpate
14.translate: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotion through the yoga of devotion, he, having completely transcended these guṇas, becomes fit for attaining the state of Brahman.
14.sridhara:
Now, in response to the question “How does he transcend these three guṇas?” the Lord answers:

“Māṁ ca”—the word ca is used here to assert exclusivity. “He who serves Me alone, the Supreme Lord Nārāyaṇa, with avyabhicāri bhakti-yoga”—that is, with undeviating, one-pointed devotion—he alone completely transcends (samatītya) these three guṇas and becomes fit for the state of Brahman (brahma-bhūyāya), meaning liberation. He becomes eligible for mokṣa.

14.shlok:
ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाऽहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च।
शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च।।१४.२७।।
14.translit:
brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāham amṛtasya avyayasya ca
śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasya aikāntikasya ca
14.translate: For I am the foundation of Brahman—of the immortal, the immutable, of eternal dharma, and of unbroken bliss.
14.sridhara:
Here the Lord gives the reason:

“Brahmaṇaḥ hi”—because I am the pratiṣṭhā (foundation, ground) of Brahman. That is, I am the concentrated, manifest form of Brahman. Just as the solar disc is condensed light, so too I am the condensed form of Brahman—that is the meaning.

Thus, I am also the foundation of amṛta (immortality), which is mokṣa, since the liberated are eternally free; of avyaya (the imperishable); and of śāśvata-dharma, which is the eternal dharma, since it is constituted of pure sattva. Likewise, I am the foundation of aikāntika-sukha, unbroken, exclusive bliss, because I am of the nature of supreme bliss alone.

Therefore, the statement “he becomes fit for the state of Brahman” (brahma-bhūyāya kalpate) is appropriate, since those who serve Me certainly attain My state.

15.shlok:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम्।
छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित्।।१५.१।।
15.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
ūrdhva-mūlam adhaḥ-śākham aśvatthaṁ prāhur avyayam
chandāṁsi yasya parṇāni yas taṁ veda sa vedavit
15.translate: The Blessed Lord said: They speak of the imperishable aśvattha tree (worldly existence), whose roots are above and branches below. Its leaves are the Vedas. One who knows that tree is a knower of the Veda.
15.sridhara:
Without dispassion, there can be neither knowledge nor devotion—therefore, that is now clearly shown. Knowledge imbued with dispassion is instructed by the Lord in this Fifteenth Chapter.

In the final verse of the previous chapter, beginning with “he who serves Me with unwavering devotion,” it was said that Brahmanhood arises for the one who, by the grace of the Supreme Lord, has attained knowledge through exclusive devotion. But neither exclusive devotion nor knowledge arises in one who is not dispassionate. Therefore, wishing to teach knowledge preceded by dispassion, the Lord first describes the nature of worldly existence in metaphorical form—as a tree—in the first one and a half verses, beginning with “ūrdhva-mūlam,” etc.

“ūrdhva-mūlam”—the root is above, meaning that the root is the Supreme Person, who is beyond both the perishable and imperishable.
“adhaḥ-śākham”—those situated below Him, the upādhis of effect such as Hiraṇyagarbha, are the branches, i.e., the limbs spreading below.
This tree is called aśvattha—that which will not last until tomorrow—because it is perishable and unworthy of reliance, even for a day.
It is also said to be avyaya (imperishable), because of its unbroken continuity through the flow of transmigration. The Śruti also declares, “This eternal aśvattha tree, whose root is above and branches below…”

“Chandāṁsi yasya parṇāni”—its leaves are the Vedas, because, through teaching dharma and adharma, the Vedas provide shelter (like shade) by the karmic results of action. Thus, they are likened to leaves, which are essential to the vitality of a tree.

One who knows this aśvattha tree in this manner is the knower of the Veda. The root of the tree of worldly manifestation is the Lord Nārāyaṇa; Brahmā and others are His limbs, and are like branches. This tree of worldly existence is perishable, yet also eternal in the sense of its continual flow, and it is made the object of action through the karma enjoined by the Veda. This, and nothing else, is the meaning of the Veda.

Therefore, the one who knows this tree is praised as a vedavit—a knower of the Veda.

15.shlok:
अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा
गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवालाः।
अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि
कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके।।१५.२।।
15.translit:
adhaś cordhvaṁ prasṛtās tasya śākhā
guṇa-pravṛddhā viṣaya-pravālāḥ
adhaś ca mūlāny anusantatāni
karmānubandhīni manuṣya-loke
15.translate: Its branches extend both upward and downward, nourished by the guṇas; its sprouts are the sense objects. And below, in the world of men, stretch forth the roots, bound to action.
15.sridhara:
Further: “adhaś ca,” etc.
The jīvas—the embodied selves, whose bodies are the effect-based upādhis beginning from Hiraṇyagarbha—have already been said to be like branches. Among them, those who are of evil tendencies extend downward into the lower births such as animals and so on. The virtuous extend upward into higher births such as gods. These are the branches of that tree of worldly existence.

Further, being guṇa-pravṛddhā—nourished by the guṇas like sattva, etc.—they are made to grow, just as watering nourishes a tree.

“viṣaya-pravālāḥ”—the sense objects like form, etc., are like sprouts; they are likened to tender shoots because they are closely connected with the sense-based branches.

Also, “adhaś ca,” and by implication, “ūrdhvaṁ ca”—the roots spread both downward and upward. The primary root is the Lord alone. These others are secondary roots—namely, the tendencies and impressions (vāsanās) formed by various enjoyments.

Their function is now described: “karma-anubandhīni”—those (roots) to whom karma is bound as its immediate result, those are the roots extending in the world of men.

When, due to the exhaustion of karma, beings again reach the human realm, their latent impressions from previous enjoyment result in engagement in various actions suitable to those impressions.

It is only in this human world that karma can be performed, and not in other worlds. Therefore, it is said: “in the world of men.”

15.shlok:
न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते
नान्तो न चादिर्न च संप्रतिष्ठा।
अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूलं
असङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा।।१५.३।।
15.translit:
na rūpam asyeha tathopalabhyate
nānto na cādiḥ na ca sampratiṣṭhā
aśvattham enaṁ suvirūḍha-mūlaṁ
asaṅga-śastreṇa dṛḍhena chittvā
15.translate: Its form is not perceived here as it is—its end, its beginning, and its foundation are not seen. Having cut down this deep-rooted aśvattha tree with the firm axe of detachment—
15.sridhara:
Further: “na rūpam asya”, etc.
Here in this world, beings do not perceive the form of this tree of worldly existence as described above—with root above and branches below.

Its end cannot be known, due to its endlessness.
Its beginning cannot be known, due to its beginninglessness.
Its foundation—how and upon what it stands—also cannot be grasped.

Since this tree of worldly existence is thus intractable and the cause of suffering, therefore one should cut it down—so says the half-verse beginning with “aśvattham enam.”

This aśvattha, with its deeply entrenched roots, must be cut down by the firm axe of asaṅga—detachment—meaning disconnection from attachment, renunciation of “I” and “mine.” That axe is made firm by correct discernment (vicāra). Having cut it, one should then proceed.

15.shlok:
ततः पदं तत् परिमार्गितव्यं
यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः।
तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये
यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी।।१५.४।।
15.translit:
tataḥ padaṁ tat parimārgitavyaṁ
yasmin gatā na nivartanti bhūyaḥ
tam eva cādyaṁ puruṣaṁ prapadye
yataḥ pravṛttiḥ prasṛtā purāṇī
15.translate: Then that state should be sought, having gone where none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Person, from whom ancient activity has issued forth.
15.sridhara:
tataḥ—Then, that state which is its root cause—tat padaṁ, the Viṣṇu state—should be sought (parimārgitavyam), that is, it should be thoroughly investigated and pursued.

What sort of state is it? One, having gone to which, people do not return again—na nivartante means “they do not return.”

The method of investigation is described: “I seek refuge in that Primeval Person, from whom this ancient, beginningless flow of worldly existence has issued forth.”

This is to be investigated with exclusive devotion alone.

15.shlok:
निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा
अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः।
द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञैः
गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत्।।१५.५।।
15.translit:
nirmāna-mohā jita-saṅga-doṣā
adhyātma-nityā vinivṛtta-kāmāḥ
dvandvair vimuktāḥ sukha-duḥkha-saṁjñair
gacchanty amūḍhāḥ padam avyayaṁ tat
15.translate: Free from pride and delusion, having conquered the defect of attachment, established in the Self, with desires turned away, liberated from the dualities known as pleasure and pain—such undeluded ones reach that imperishable state.
15.sridhara:
Now, showing other means of attaining that state, he says: “nirmāna-mohāḥ,” etc.
Those who are free from pride and delusion—that is, from arrogance and false attachment to the body.
Those who have overcome the defect of attachment, such as affection for sons, etc.
Those who are constantly engaged in knowledge of the Self.
Those whose desires have entirely ceased.
Those who are freed from the dualities known as pleasure and pain, arising from heat and cold, etc.

Such amūḍhāḥ—undeluded ones, freed from ignorance—go to that imperishable state of Viṣṇu.

15.shlok:
न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः।
यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम।।१५.६।।
15.translit:
na tad bhāsayate sūryo na śaśāṅko na pāvakaḥ
yad gatvā na nivartante tad dhāma paramaṁ mama
15.translate: Neither the sun illumines that, nor the moon, nor fire. Having gone there, they do not return. That is My supreme abode.
15.sridhara:
He further defines that very state which is to be reached: “na tat,” etc.
That abode to which the yogins go, which neither the sun, nor others like it illumine—that is My supreme abode, My essential nature (svarūpa).

By this, because it is beyond the illumination of sun, moon, and fire, the implication is that defects such as inertness and dualities like heat and cold are excluded.

15.shlok:
ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः।
मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति।।१५.७।।
15.translit:
mamaiva āṁśo jīva-loke jīva-bhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ
manaḥ-ṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛti-sthāni karṣati
15.translate: An eternal portion of Myself, having become a living being in the world of life, draws the senses and the mind—the sixth—residing in Prakṛti.
15.sridhara:
Now, an objection may be raised: If those who attain Your abode do not return, then, according to the Śruti—“Being merged, they do not know, ‘We have merged’” and “We merge”—does it not follow that all beings attain You during deep sleep or at the time of dissolution? In that case, who would be a saṁsārin (transmigrator)? To dispel this doubt, He describes the transmigrating being in five verses, beginning here with “mama eva aṁśaḥ.”

That eternal one who, by ignorance, becomes a jīva, and who is well known as perpetually bound in saṁsāra—that one draws, again into the world of the living, those senses whose sixth is the mind, which had become latent in Prakṛti during deep sleep or dissolution.

This includes, by implication, the karma-indriyas and prāṇa.

Here is the meaning:
Certainly, even during deep sleep or dissolution, because all beings are My parts, they attain Me through merging. Still, since they are veiled by ignorance and possess latent impressions (anuśaya), their merging is into Me with Prakṛti—not into the pure (Supreme) Me.

Hence it is said in the Gītā (८.१९): “From the unmanifest, all beings come forth again.”

Therefore, the ignorant one comes forth again into saṁsāra, and draws the senses which had become latent in Prakṛti, and which are his own limiting adjuncts.

But the wise, having attained the pure essential nature, do not return.

15.shlok:
शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः।
गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात्।।१५.८।।
15.translit:
śarīraṁ yad avāpnoti yac cāpy utkramatīśvaraḥ
gṛhītvaitāni saṁyāti vāyur gandhān ivāśayāt
15.translate: When the Lord obtains a body and when He departs, He carries these [senses] and goes, just as the wind carries scents from their source.
15.sridhara:
and goes, just as the wind carries scents from their source.

Śrīdhara Svāmī’s Commentary

15.shlok:
श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च।
अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते।।१५.९।।
15.translit:
śrotraṁ cakṣuḥ sparśanaṁ ca rasanaṁ ghrāṇam eva ca
adhiṣṭhāya manaś cāyaṁ viṣayān upasevate
15.translate: Taking shelter of the ear, eye, touch, taste, and also smell, along with the mind, this being enjoys the sense objects.
15.sridhara: Now, showing what those [carried

15.shlok:
उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम्।
विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः।।१५.१०।।
15.translit:
utkrāmantaṁ sthitaṁ vāpi bhuñjānaṁ vā guṇānvitam
vimūḍhā nānupaśyanti paśyanti jñāna-cakṣuṣaḥ
15.translate: The deluded do not perceive Him who departs, remains, or enjoys—endowed with the guṇas; but those who possess the eye of knowledge perceive.
15.sridhara:
Now one might ask: “If the ātman is like this—distinct from the aggregate of body and senses—why then does everyone not perceive It?” He answers: “utkrāmantam,” etc.

Whether departing from a body, or remaining in it, or enjoying the sense objects—being endowed with the guṇas through the senses and other instruments—the deluded do not perceive this jīva.

Those whose eye is knowledge—who possess discrimination—do perceive it.

15.shlok:
यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम्।
यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः।।१५.११।।
15.translit:
yatanto yoginaś cainaṁ paśyanty ātmani avasthitam
yatanto ’py akṛtātmāno nainaṁ paśyanty acetasaḥ
15.translate: Yogins, striving through effort, see Him abiding in the self; but those of unrefined self and undeveloped understanding—even while striving—do not see Him.
15.sridhara:
He is difficult to realize, because even among the discerning, some see and others do not. This is stated: “yatantaḥ” etc.

Yogins who strive through meditation and other means—some of them see this ātman, abiding in the body, distinct [from it

15.shlok:
यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम्।
यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम्।।१५.१२।।
15.translit:
yad āditya-gataṁ tejo jagad bhāsayate ’khilam
yac candramasi yac cāgnau tat tejo viddhi māmakam
15.translate: That brilliance which, abiding in the sun, illumines the whole world; that which is in the moon and in fire—know that light to be Mine.
15.sridhara:
Thus far, beginning from “na tad bhāsayate sūryaḥ” (१५.६), the Supreme Lord’s supreme abode has been described. And the non-return of those who attain it has been stated.

Then, anticipating a doubt that there may be no saṁsārins, the nature of the saṁsārin as distinct from body etc. was explained.

Now, the very same form of the Supreme Lord is described as possessing limitless power, in four verses beginning here: “yad āditya-gataṁ tejaḥ” etc.

That light which, situated in the sun and other bodies, illumines the entire world in various ways—that light is entirely Mine alone, know this.

15.shlok:
गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा।
पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः।।१५.१३।।
15.translit:
gām āviśya ca bhūtāni dhārayāmy aham ojasā
puṣṇāmi cauṣadhīḥ sarvāḥ somo bhūtvā rasātmakaḥ
15.translate: Entering the earth, I sustain all beings with My energy. And having become the soma, full of rasa (essence), I nourish all herbs.
15.sridhara:
Furthermore: “gām āviśya” etc.

Entering the earth, abiding in it with power (vital force), I alone support all beings, moving and unmoving.

Having become the soma, full of sap (essence), I alone nourish all the herbs such as rice, etc.

15.shlok:
अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः।
प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम्।।१५.१४।।
15.translit:
ahaṁ vaiśvānaro bhūtvā prāṇināṁ deham āśritaḥ
prāṇāpāna-samāyuktaḥ pacāmy annaṁ catur-vidham
15.translate: Becoming the Vaiśvānara (digestive fire), abiding in the bodies of beings, united with prāṇa and apāna, I digest the fourfold food.
15.sridhara:
Furthermore: “ahaṁ vaiśvānaraḥ” etc.

Becoming the Vaiśvānara, the gastric fire, entering into the body of beings, associated with prāṇa and apāna—which stimulate it—I digest the four kinds of food consumed by beings.

Now, food is of four kinds:

That which is broken with the teeth (e.g., apūpa (a traditional grain cake))—this is bhakṣya (to be chewed).

That which is swallowed after being stirred only by the tongue (e.g.,  pāyāsa (rice-gruel))—this is bhojya (to be swallowed).

That which is placed on the tongue and swallowed gradually by taste (e.g., melted jaggery)—this is lehyam (to be licked).

That which is sucked, then the remnant discarded after extracting the juice (e.g., sugarcane)—this is coṣya (to be sucked). Thus, the fourfold classification.

15.shlok:
सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो
मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च।
वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो
वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम्।।१५.१५।।
15.translit:
sarvasya cāhaṁ hṛdi sanniviṣṭo
mattaḥ smṛtir jñānam apohanaṁ ca
vedaiś ca sarvair aham eva vedyo
vedānta-kṛd veda-vid eva cāham
15.translate: And I am seated in the heart of all beings. From Me arise memory, knowledge, and the loss of both. I alone am to be known by all the Vedas; I am the author of Vedānta, and I am indeed the knower of the Vedas.
15.sridhara:
Furthermore: “sarvasya cāham hṛdi sanniviṣṭaḥ”—I am well established in the heart of all living beings, in the form of the inner controller.

Therefore, from Me alone arises the memory in all beings, pertaining to previously experienced objects.

Likewise, knowledge arises—from the contact of sense and object. And the removal (forgetting) of both also arises from Me.

And by all the Vedas, I alone am to be known—as the various deities and so on are ultimately forms of Me.

I am the Vedāntakṛt—the initiator of the Vedānta tradition, the giver of knowledge, the Guru—that is the meaning.

And I alone am vedavid—the knower of the meaning of the Vedas.

15.shlok:
द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च।
क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते।।१५.१६।।
15.translit:
dvāv imau puruṣau loke kṣaraś cākṣara eva ca
kṣaraḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni kūṭastho ’kṣara ucyate
15.translate: Two Puruṣas are known in the world—the perishable and the imperishable. The perishable consists of all beings; the unchanging (kūṭastha) is called the imperishable.
15.sridhara:
Now, the previously stated phrase “That is My Supreme Abode” (१५.६) is being further elaborated by showing the Lord’s supreme excellence — through these three verses beginning with dvāv imau.

The two Puruṣas—the perishable and the imperishable—are well known in the world. These two alone exist.

Of them, the perishable Puruṣa is all beings—from Brahmā down to the immovables—which are bodies. For in the view of the undiscriminating, personhood is commonly associated with bodies alone.

Kūṭa means “a mass of stone” or “a mountain.” That which remains unchanged (nirvikāra) even when the bodies perish, like a mountain, is the kūṭastha—the conscious enjoyer (cetana bhoktā).

That, indeed, is called the imperishable Puruṣa by the discriminating.

15.shlok:
उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युदाहृतः।
यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः।।१५.१७।।
15.translit:
uttamaḥ puruṣas tv anyaḥ paramātmety udāhṛtaḥ
yo loka-trayam āviśya bibharty avyaya īśvaraḥ
15.translate: But distinct is the Supreme Puruṣa, called the Paramātman, the imperishable Lord who, entering the three worlds, sustains them.
15.sridhara:
The purpose for describing the above two (perishable and imperishable) is now stated: uttamaḥ etc.

Other than these two—the perishable and imperishable—is the Supreme Puruṣa who is distinct. That very distinction is stated: He is called Paramātman.

As the Self (ātmatva), He is distinct from the perishable (the insentient group); as the Supreme (paramatva), He is distinct even from the imperishable (the sentient enjoyer).

That Paramātman is described here: yo loka-trayam—He who, being īśvara (the Lord), possessing the nature of ruling; and avyaya (unchanging), being without transformation—enters into the three worlds completely and sustains (nourishes) them.

15.shlok:
यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः।
अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः।।१५.१८।।
15.translit:
yasmāt kṣaram atīto ’ham akṣarād api cottamaḥ
ato ’smi loke vede ca prathitaḥ puruṣottamaḥ
15.translate: Because I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, therefore I am renowned in the world and in the Veda as the Supreme Puruṣa.
15.sridhara:
This nature of being puruṣottama (the Supreme Person) is now shown through a definition: yasmāt etc.

Because I transcend the perishable group of insentient entities, being eternally free; and I am also superior to the imperishable group of sentient enjoyers, by being their controller—

Therefore, I am proclaimed (well-known) in the world and in the Veda as puruṣottama.

And thus the śruti (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad ३.७.३) states:
“sa vā ayam ātmā sarvasya vaśī, sarvasyeśānaḥ, sarvasyādhipatiḥ, sarvam idaṁ praśāsti”—
He, this very Self, is the controller of all, the lord of all, the master of all; He governs all this.

15.shlok:
यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम्।
स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत।।१५.१९।।
15.translit:
yo mām evam asammūḍho jānāti puruṣottamam
sa sarvavid bhajati māṁ sarva-bhāvena bhārata
15.translate: He who knows Me thus as the Supreme Puruṣa, without delusion, he, knowing all, worships Me with his entire being, O Bhārata.
15.sridhara:
The result of knowing the Lord to be of such a nature is now stated: yo mām etc.

He who, knowing Me as the Supreme Puruṣa in the manner described above, is free of delusion and possesses firm conviction—he worships Me alone with his entire being, in all ways.

As a result of this, he becomes sarvavit—a knower of all.

15.shlok:
इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयाऽनघ।
एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत।।१५.२०।।
15.translit:
iti guhyatamaṁ śāstram idam uktaṁ mayānagha
etad buddhvā buddhimān syāt kṛtakṛtyaś ca bhārata
15.translate: Thus this most secret teaching has been spoken by Me, O sinless one. Understanding this, a man becomes wise and accomplished in all that should be done, O Bhārata.
15.sridhara:
Now summarizing the meaning of the chapter, He says: iti guhyatamam etc.

In this way, this most secret and supremely mysterious complete teaching has been stated by Me—not merely the twenty verses of the chapter.

O sinless one (anagha)! Therefore, having understood this scripture taught by Me, one becomes buddhimān—truly wise—and kṛtakṛtya—one who has accomplished all that is to be done, whoever he may be.

O Bhārata! If that is so for anyone, what need is there to say that you, having heard it, are certainly accomplished!

16.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिः ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः।
दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम्।।१६.१।।
16.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
abhayaṁ sattva-saṁśuddhir jñāna-yoga-vyavasthitiḥ
dānaṁ damaś ca yajñaś ca svādhyāyas tapa ārjavam
16.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of mind, steadfastness in the discipline of knowledge and yoga, charity, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of the scriptures, austerity, and straightforwardness—
16.sridhara:
To determine that those who have abandoned the demoniac nature and taken refuge solely in the divine nature are liberated, this discernment is taken up in the sixteenth chapter.

At the end of the previous chapter, it was said: “Having understood this, he becomes wise and one who has done all that is to be done, O Bhārata.” In that context, with the expectation, “Who is it that understands this truth, and who does not?”, this chapter begins to distinguish between the qualified and the unqualified for knowledge of the truth. For when the goal has been established, an inquiry into eligibility arises. As stated by the Bhaṭṭas: “When a load must be carried, only after it has been weighed can it be rightly determined who is fit to bear it.”

There, describing the divine qualities that are the attributes of the qualified, the Blessed Lord speaks, beginning with abhayam:

Abhayam is the absence of fear.
Sattva-saṁśuddhiḥ is the serenity—clearness—of the mind.
Jñāna-yoga-vyavasthitiḥ is firm establishment in the discipline that is the means to Self-knowledge.
Dānam is the appropriate sharing of one’s food or wealth with others.
Damaḥ is the restraint of the external senses.
Yajñaḥ is the performance of sacrificial rites such as darśa-pūrṇamāsa, in accordance with one’s eligibility.
Svādhyāyaḥ is Vedic study, including the brahma-yajña and silent recitation (japa-yajña).
Tapaḥ is bodily and other forms of austerity, which will be stated in the following chapter.
Ārjavam is straightforwardness, absence of crookedness.

16.shlok:
अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम्।
दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम्।।१६.२।।
16.translit:
ahiṁsā satyam akrodhas tyāgaḥ śāntir apaiśunam
dayā bhūteṣv aloluptvaṁ mārdavaṁ hrīr acāpalam
16.translate: Harmlessness, truthfulness, absence of anger, renunciation, tranquillity, absence of slander, compassion for beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, and absence of restlessness—
16.sridhara:
Further:

Ahiṁsā is refraining from causing harm to others.
Satyam is speech that conforms to reality.
Akrodhaḥ is the non-arising of agitation in the mind even when struck.
Tyāgaḥ is generosity.
Śāntiḥ is tranquillity of mind.
Paiśunam is revealing the faults of others behind their back.
Its absence is apaiśunam—freedom from slander.
Dayā is compassion toward beings in distress.
Aloluptvam is absence of greed.
Avārṇalopaḥ is a Vedic expression meaning maintenance of one’s proper social and moral conduct.
Mārdavam is gentleness, non-cruelty.
Hrīḥ is social modesty—shame in engaging in wrong actions.
Acāpalam is the absence of frivolous, unrestrained activity.

16.shlok:
तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता।
भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत।।१६.३।।
16.translit:
tejaḥ kṣamā dhṛtiḥ śaucam adroho nātimānitā
bhavanti sampadaṁ daivīm abhijātasya bhārata
16.translate: Vigour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of malice, and absence of excessive pride—these belong to the divine nature of one who is born with such an endowment, O Bhārata.
16.sridhara:
Further:

Tejaḥ is boldness or assertiveness.
Kṣamā is the restraint of anger that arises in situations of insult and the like.
Dhṛtiḥ is the stabilization of the mind when it is sinking due to sorrow and similar causes.
Śaucam is external and internal cleanliness.
Adrohaḥ is the absence of harmful intent.
Nātimānitā is the absence of excessive pride—i.e., the absence of the belief in oneself as being exceedingly worthy of respect.

These qualities—starting from abhayam up to nātimānitā—numbering twenty-six, belong to one who is born with the divine nature.

That is, they exist in a person who is born oriented toward divine virtue (devayogyām sāttvikīṁ saṁpadam abhilakṣya), and therefore possessing an innate disposition for spiritual auspiciousness (bhāvikalyāṇasya pumsaḥ).

16.shlok:
दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च।
अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ सम्पदमासुरीम्।।१६.४।।
16.translit:
dambho darpo’bhimānaś ca krodhaḥ pāruṣyam eva ca
ajñānaṁ cābhijātasya pārtha sampadam āsurīm
16.translate: Hypocrisy, arrogance, self-conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance—these, O Pārtha, belong to one born of demoniac nature.
16.sridhara:
Now, describing the demoniac nature, He says: dambhaḥ, etc.

Dambhaḥ is religious hypocrisy—making a show of virtue.
Darpaḥ is arrogance—pride arising in the mind due to wealth, learning, and the like.
Abhimānaḥ has been explained earlier—it is self-conceit.
Krodhaḥ is well known—it is anger.
Pāruṣyam is harshness—cruelty of speech and behavior.
Ajñānam is ignorance—lack of discernment.
The word āsurīm implies the set. That is, these qualities such as dambhaḥ, etc., arise in one who is born oriented toward the demoniac nature—the nature of asuras and rākṣasas.

16.shlok:
दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता।
मा शुचः सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातोऽसि पाण्डव।।१६.५।।
16.translit:
daivī saṁpad vimokṣāya nibandhāyāsurī matā
mā śucas saṁpadaṁ daivīm abhijāto’si pāṇḍava
16.translate: The divine nature is regarded as conducive to liberation, while the demoniac is for bondage. Grieve not, O Pāṇḍava, for you are born with the divine nature.
16.sridhara:
Now, showing the outcome of these two types of qualities, He says: daivī saṁpad.

The divine nature, possessed by one, makes one qualified for the knowledge of truth as stated by Me.

But one possessed of demoniac nature remains perpetually bound in transmigration—this is the meaning.

Hearing this, Arjuna, with his mind agitated by doubt—"Am I qualified or not?"—is reassured by the Lord.

O Pāṇḍava! Mā śucah—do not grieve! Why? Because you are born with divine nature.

16.shlok:
द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन् दैव आसुर एव च।
दैवो विस्तरशः प्रोक्त आसुरं पार्थ मे श्रृणु।।१६.६।।
16.translit:
dvau bhūta-sargau loke’smin daiva āsura eva ca
daivo vistaraśaḥ prokta āsuraṁ pārtha me śṛṇu
16.translate: There are two types of created beings in this world—the divine and the demoniac. The divine has been described at length. Now hear from Me about the demoniac, O Pārtha.
16.sridhara:
In order to explain that the demoniac qualities must be entirely renounced, He now proceeds to elaborate on the demoniac nature:

“There are two”—i.e., two kinds of beings—“hear from Me, according to My words, the two types of beings: divine and demoniac.”

The statement “two” is made by combining the natures of the asuras and rākṣasas into one. Therefore, there is no contradiction with the threefold division of natures mentioned earlier in Chapter ९: “Those who take refuge in the deluding (moha) nature—rākṣasī and āsurī.”

The rest is self-explanatory.

16.shlok:
प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुरासुराः।
न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेषु विद्यते।।१६.७।।
16.translit:
pravṛttiṁ ca nivṛttiṁ ca janā na vidur āsurāḥ
na śaucaṁ nāpi cācāro na satyaṁ teṣu vidyate
16.translate: Demoniac people do not understand what is to be done and what is not to be done. In them, there is neither purity, nor proper conduct, nor truth.
16.sridhara:
He elaborates on the demoniac nature in detail with twelve verses, beginning here:

Pravṛtti means engagement in dharma (righteousness), and nivṛtti means abstention from adharma (unrighteousness). The people of demoniac disposition do not know these.

Therefore, śauca (purity), ācāra (proper behavior), and satya (truth) are entirely absent in them.

16.shlok:
असत्यमप्रतिष्ठं ते जगदाहुरनीश्वरम्।
अपरस्परसम्भूतं किमन्यत्कामहैतुकम्।।१६.८।।
16.translit:
asatyaṁ apratiṣṭhaṁ te jagad āhur anīśvaram
aparaspara-sambhūtaṁ kim anyat kāma-haitukam
16.translate: They say: “This world is without truth, without foundation, without a God; it is produced from the mutual union (of male and female). What else? Lust alone is its cause.”
16.sridhara:
One may ask: “How can they not know about righteous and unrighteous action as taught in the Vedas? And if they do not accept dharma and adharma, how can they explain the arrangement of pleasure and pain in the world? Why do they transgress purity, proper conduct, and so on, which are subjects of divine command?”

If one does not accept God, how can the creation of the world be accounted for?

To answer this, He says:

Asatyam—“The world is without truth,” meaning there is no authoritative evidence like the Veda and Purāṇa. That is, they do not accept the authority of the Vedas. Hence the saying: “Those who claim to be the authors of the Vedas are blasphemers, deceivers, and demons,” and so on.

Because of this, they say the world has no pratiṣṭhā—no basis in dharma and adharma. They claim the world is varied simply by nature, without any order.

Therefore, they say, anīśvaram—there is no Īśvara, no creator or governor of the world.

Then how do they say the world came into being?

They say aparaspara-sambhūtam—it was born from mutual union. That is, apara (male) and para (female), from their sexual union, the world came into being. “What else could be its cause? Nothing else. Lust alone is its cause”—thus they claim.

16.shlok:
एतां दृष्टिमवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानोऽल्पबुद्धयः।
प्रभवन्त्युग्रकर्माणः क्षयाय जगतोऽहिताः।।१६.९।।
16.translit:
etāṁ dṛṣṭim avaṣṭabhya naṣṭātmāno’lpa-buddhayaḥ
prabhavanty ugra-karmāṇaḥ kṣayāya jagato’ahitāḥ
16.translate: Clinging to this view, these ruined souls of meager intelligence, engaging in dreadful actions, arise for the destruction of the world as its enemies.
16.sridhara:
Furthermore:

Etām dṛṣṭim—This materialistic view, held by those of low intelligence—naṣṭātmānaḥ (whose minds are corrupted), alpa-buddhayaḥ (whose understanding is small), being limited to only what is visible.

Because of this, they become engaged in ugra-karmāṇaḥ—violent and cruel acts. Being ahitāḥ—the enemies of the world—they prabhavanti (arise or are born) for the kṣaya—destruction—of the world.

16.shlok:
काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः।
मोहाद्गृहीत्वासद्ग्राहान्प्रवर्तन्तेऽशुचिव्रताः।।१६.१०।।
16.translit:
kāmam āśritya duṣpūraṁ dambha-māna-madānvitāḥ
mohād gṛhītvāsad-grāhān pravartante aśuci-vratāḥ
16.translate: Resorting to insatiable desire, filled with hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, clinging to false views due to delusion, they engage in impure practices.
16.sridhara:
Furthermore:

Relying on kāmaṁ duṣpūram—desires that are impossible to satisfy—and being possessed of dambha (hypocrisy), māna (pride), and mada (arrogance), they engage in practices such as the worship of petty deities.

How?

They gṛhītvā asad-grāhān—embrace false notions, such as: “By worshiping this deity with this mantra, I will obtain immense treasure,” and so on—due only to delusion (mohāt), and they act accordingly.

Aśuci-vratāḥ—those whose vows or practices (vratāḥ) involve impure substances like wine and meat are called impure.

16.shlok:
चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः।
कामोपभोगपरमा एतावदिति निश्चिताः।।१६.११।।
16.translit:
cintām aparimeyāṁ ca pralayāntām upāśritāḥ
kāma-upabhoga-paramā etāvad iti niścitāḥ
16.translate: Taking refuge in immeasurable anxieties that end only with death, they are devoted solely to sensual enjoyment and desire, firmly convinced that this alone is the highest goal.
16.sridhara:
Furthermore: “Cintām”—they take refuge in worries. Pralaya means death; pralayāntām means: which ends only with death. Aparimeyām—worries that are immeasurable, impossible to assess.

That is, they are constantly absorbed in worry.

They are those for whom kāma-upabhoga—sensual pleasure and enjoyment—alone is supreme. They are niścitāḥ—firmly resolved, believing: “This alone is the highest puruṣārtha (goal of life); there is nothing beyond this.”

The next verse, “āśā-pāśa-śatair baddhāḥ,” connects as a continuation.

In this way, the aphorism of Bṛhaspati is aligned: “Desire alone is the puruṣārtha (human goal); and desire endowed with consciousness is the puruṣa (person).”

16.shlok:
आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः।
ईहन्ते कामभोगार्थमन्यायेनार्थसञ्चयान्।।१६.१२।।
16.translit:
āśā-pāśa-śatair baddhāḥ kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ
īhante kāma-bhogārtham anyāyena artha-saṁcayān
16.translate: Bound by hundreds of cords of hope, wholly devoted to desire and anger, they strive to accumulate wealth by unjust means, for the sake of sense enjoyment.
16.sridhara:
Therefore: āśāḥ (hopes) themselves are pāśāḥ (bonds or fetters). Śataiḥ baddhāḥ—bound by hundreds of such hopes, pulled here and there.

Those whose sole focus is kāma and krodha—desire and anger—are called kāma-krodha-parāyaṇāḥ.

For the sake of sensual enjoyment (kāma-bhoga-artham), they strive to gather (īhante) wealth (arthān)—by anyāyena, through unjust means such as theft, etc.

16.shlok:
इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम्।
इदमस्तीदमपि मे भविष्यति पुनर्धनम्।।१६.१३।।
16.translit:
idam adya mayā labdham imaṁ prāpsye manoratham
idam astīdam api me bhaviṣyati punar dhanam
16.translate: “This today has been gained by me; this desire I shall fulfill; this is mine, and this wealth also shall be mine again in future.”
16.sridhara:
Describing their deluded fantasies, He declares their future downfall:

Idam adya—“This I have obtained today.” Imaṁ manoratham prāpsye—“I shall obtain this cherished desire.”

Manoratha means “that which is dear to the mind.”

The rest is clear.

These three verses (१६.१३–१६.१५) are connected by the fourth verse which concludes: “Deluded by ignorance, they fall into hell.”

16.shlok:
असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि।
ईश्वरोऽहमहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान्सुखी।।१६.१४।।
16.translit:
asau mayā hataḥ śatrur haniṣye cāparān api
īśvaro’ham ahaṁ bhogī siddho’haṁ balavān sukhī
16.translate: “That enemy has been slain by me; and I shall slay others too. I am the lord, I am the enjoyer, I am accomplished, powerful, and happy.”
16.sridhara:
Furthermore:

Asau—“That one.” Mayā hataḥ—“has been killed by me.” Haniṣye—“I shall kill.” Aparaān api—“other enemies too.”

Siddhaḥ means “one who is fulfilled,” or considers himself to have achieved his aims.

The rest is self-explanatory.

16.shlok:
आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया।
यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्यज्ञानविमोहिताः।।१६.१५।।
16.translit:
āḍhyo’bhijanavān asmi ko’nyaḥ asti sadṛśaḥ mayā
yakṣye dāsyāmi modiṣye ity ajñāna-vimohitāḥ
16.translate: “I am wealthy and high-born. Who else is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices, I shall give in charity, I shall enjoy”—thus deluded by ignorance.
16.sridhara:
Furthermore:

Āḍhyaḥ—rich, possessed of wealth and such. Abhijanavān—of noble birth, from a high family line.

Yakṣye—“I shall perform sacrifices.” That is, through performing rituals like yajñas and so on, I shall obtain great fame, surpassing that of other initiates.

Dāsyāmi—“I shall give”—to my followers.

Modiṣye—“I shall enjoy”—I shall attain joy.

In this way, ajñāna-vimohitāḥ—deluded by ignorance—they fall into mithyā-abhiniveśa—false belief and mistaken identification.

16.shlok:
अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः।
प्रसक्ताः कामभोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ।।१६.१६।।
16.translit:
anekacitta-vibhrāntā mohajāla-samāvṛtāḥ
prasaktāḥ kāma-bhogeṣu patanti narake’śucau
16.translate: Bewildered by many thoughts, enveloped in the net of delusion, addicted to the enjoyment of desires, they fall into a foul hell.
16.sridhara:
Now hear what such persons attain:

Anekacitta—“Many thoughts,” meaning their minds are engaged in numerous fancies or desires. Thus, vibhrāntāḥ—they are distracted.

Mohajālena samāvṛtāḥ—They are covered by a net of delusion, like fish caught and controlled by a net made of string.

In this way, being attached (prasaktāḥ) and firmly clinging to sensual enjoyments (kāma-bhogeṣu), they fall (patanti) into aśucau narake—a foul, impure hell.

16.shlok:
आत्मसंभाविताः स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः।
यजन्ते नामयज्ञैस्ते दम्भेनाविधिपूर्वकम्।।१६.१७।।
16.translit:
ātma-saṁbhāvitāḥ stabdhā dhana-māna-madānvitāḥ
yajante nāma-yajñais te dambhena avidhi-pūrvakam
16.translate: Self-conceited, rigid, possessed of pride and intoxication due to wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only, out of ostentation and contrary to scriptural injunction.
16.sridhara:
The “sacrifice” (yajña) mentioned by them earlier as “I will sacrifice” is predominantly motivated by pride, arrogance, and ostentation, not by purity in the mode of sattva. Thus it is said:

Ātma-saṁbhāvitāḥ—They regard themselves as worthy of worship, not recognized as such by noble persons, but by themselves alone.

Hence, stabdhāḥ—unbending, unyielding.

They are anvitāḥ—endowed—with dhana-māna-mada, the pride and intoxication that arises from wealth.

Nāma-yajñaiḥ—Sacrifices only in name, for the sake of reputation alone, such as calling oneself “a Soma-sacrificer” merely for fame.

Such sacrifices are performed by them yajante, but dambhena—only out of show, not with true faith.

Avidhi-pūrvakam—not according to proper Vedic injunction; they conduct it however they please.

16.shlok:
अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः।
मामात्मपरदेहेषु प्रद्विषन्तोऽभ्यसूयकाः।।१६.१८।।
16.translit:
ahaṅkāraṁ balaṁ darpaṁ kāmaṁ krodhaṁ ca saṁśritāḥ
mām ātma-para-deheṣu pradviṣanto’bhyasūyakāḥ
16.translate: Taking refuge in egoism, power, arrogance, desire, and anger, these envious ones hate Me, who dwell in their own bodies and in those of others.
16.sridhara:
The very fact that they perform such acts avidhi-pūrvakam (improperly) is further elaborated:

They take shelter in ahaṅkāra (ego), bala (strength), darpa (arrogance), kāma (desire), and krodha (anger). Being so situated, they perform sacrifices.

But whom do they hate? Ātma-para-deheṣu—in their own bodies and in others’—I who abide as the conscious Self (cid-aṁśa), they pradviṣanti—despise.

Because such dambha-yajñas (ostentatious rituals) are devoid of faith (śraddhā), they merely inflict harm on themselves.

Similarly, due to improper ritual slaughter of animals and others, what remains is only an offense to the indwelling consciousness—thus it is said “they hate Me.”

Abhyasūyakāḥ—they project faults upon the virtues of those who follow the true path.

16.shlok:
तानहं द्विषतः क्रूरान्संसारेषु नराधमान्।
क्षिपाम्यजस्रमशुभानासुरीष्वेव योनिषु।।१६.१९।।
16.translit:
tān ahaṁ dviṣataḥ krūrān saṁsāreṣu narādhamān
kṣipāmy ajasram aśubhān āsurīṣv eva yoniṣu
16.translate: Those haters, cruel, and vile among men, I repeatedly hurl them into demoniacal wombs alone in the cycle of birth and death.
16.sridhara:
Now He says: They never become free from their demoniacal nature, not even accidentally:

Tān—those who hate Me, who are krūrān—cruel, and narādhamān—the lowest among men, I cast into saṁsāra—the course of repeated birth and death.

Even there, āsurīṣv eva yoniṣu—I hurl them specifically into extremely cruel wombs, such as that of tigers, etc.

Kṣipāmi ajasram—I hurl them perpetually, without end.

This means: I give such sinful ones that corresponding fruit.

16.shlok:
आसुरीं योनिमापन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि।
मामप्राप्यैव कौन्तेय ततो यान्त्यधमां गतिम्।।१६.२०।।
16.translit:
āsurīṁ yonim āpannā mūḍhā janmani janmani
mām aprāpyaiva kaunteya tato yānty adhamāṁ gatim
16.translate: Entering demoniac wombs, birth after birth, the deluded—without ever attaining Me, O Kaunteya—go to an even lower condition.
16.sridhara:
Furthermore:

Āsurīṁ yonim āpannāḥ—They take birth in demoniac wombs.

Mūḍhāḥ janmani janmani—They remain deluded, life after life.

Eva in mām aprāpyaiva emphasizes: truly, they do not attain Me. The idea of their attaining Me is thus to be rejected.

They fail to attain even the means (upāya) to reach Me, that is, the true path (sanmārga).

Tatḥaḥ—as a result—they go to adhamāṁ gatim—a state even lower than that, such as birth as worms, insects, etc.

The rest is clear.

16.shlok:
त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः।
कामः क्रोधस्तथा लोभस्तस्मादेतत्त्रयं त्यजेत्।।१६.२१।।
16.translit:
trividhaṁ narakasyedaṁ dvāraṁ nāśanam ātmanaḥ
kāmaḥ krodhas tathā lobhas tasmād etat trayaṁ tyajet
16.translate: This threefold gate of hell—destructive to the self—lust, anger, and greed: therefore, one should abandon these three.
16.sridhara:
Among the previously described demoniac faults, this triad, being the root of all faults, must absolutely be abandoned. Hence it is said:

This threefold gate (trividham)—namely, kāma (desire), krodha (anger), and lobha (greed)—is a gateway to hell (narakasya dvāram).

Therefore, it is nāśanam ātmanaḥ—destructive of the self, leading to birth in low species.

Thus, tasmāt—therefore, etat trayaṁ tyajet—one should wholly renounce this triad.

16.shlok:
