एतैर्विमुक्तः कौन्तेय तमोद्वारैस्त्रिभिर्नरः।
आचरत्यात्मनः श्रेयस्ततो याति परां गतिम्।।१६.२२।।
16.translit:
etair vimuktaḥ kaunteya tamo-dvāraiḥ tribhir naraḥ
ācaraty ātmanaḥ śreyas tato yāti parāṁ gatim
16.translate: The man who is freed from these three gates of darkness, O Kaunteya, acts for the good of the self, and then attains the supreme goal.
16.sridhara:
Now, the special fruit of such renunciation is stated:

By being vimuktaḥ—freed from these three, namely lust, anger, and greed, which are tamo-dvāraiḥ—gateways to hell, a person ācarati—engages in actions that are for ātmanaḥ śreyas—the highest good of the self, such as austerity, yoga, and other practices.

As a result, tataḥ—from that, he yāti parāṁ gatim—attains liberation (mokṣa).

16.shlok:
यः शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य वर्तते कामकारतः।
न स सिद्धिमवाप्नोति न सुखं न परां गतिम्।।१६.२३।।
16.translit:
yaḥ śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya vartate kāma-kārataḥ
na sa siddhim avāpnoti na sukhaṁ na parāṁ gatim
16.translate: He who, discarding scriptural injunctions, acts according to desire, does not attain perfection, nor happiness, nor the supreme goal.
16.sridhara:
And renunciation of desire does not occur without the performance of one's own prescribed duties. Hence it is said:

Yaḥ—he who, utsṛjya śāstra-vidhim—discards the dharma prescribed by the Vedas, vartate kāma-kārataḥ—acts according to his own desires as he pleases.

Such a person does na avāpnoti siddhim—not attain knowledge of reality (tattva-jñāna), na sukham—nor inner peace (upaśama), na parāṁ gatim—nor liberation (mokṣa).

16.shlok:
तस्माच्छास्त्रं प्रमाणं ते कार्याकार्यव्यवस्थितौ।
ज्ञात्वा शास्त्रविधानोक्तं कर्म कर्तुमिहार्हसि।।१६.२४।।
16.translit:
tasmāc chāstraṁ pramāṇaṁ te kāryākārya-vyavasthitau
jñātvā śāstra-vidhānoktaṁ karma kartum ihārhasi
16.translate: Therefore, let scripture be your authority in determining what should be done and what should not be done. Having understood what is stated in the rules of scripture, you ought to act accordingly in this world.
16.sridhara:
The conclusion is now stated:

Tasmāt—therefore, in determining idam kāryam idam akāryam—what is to be done and not to be done, te—for you, śāstram—scripture alone, such as the Śruti, Smṛti, Purāṇas and others, pramāṇam—is the authority.

Therefore, having known (jñātvā) the actions prescribed in the injunctions of scripture (śāstra-vidhāna-uktam karma), while situated here (iha) in the domain of action (karma-adhikāra), you should perform action according to your eligibility.

The meaning is: sattva-śuddhi (purity of mind), sam-yag-jñāna (true knowledge), and mukti (liberation) arise from that as their root.

17.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयाऽन्विताः।
तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः।।१७.१।।
17.translit:
arjuna uvāca
ye śāstra-vidhim utsṛjya yajante śraddhayānvitāḥ
teṣāṁ niṣṭhā tu kā kṛṣṇa sattvam āho rajas tamaḥ
17.translate: Arjuna said: Those who, abandoning the injunctions of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith—what is their position, O Krishna? Is it in sattva, rajas, or tamas?
17.sridhara:
Of the causes previously mentioned that qualify one for spiritual pursuit, faith is primary and indeed sāttvikī (aligned with sattva). Therefore, in this seventeenth chapter, the secondary (non-scriptural) types of faith are discussed as threefold.

In the final verse of the previous chapter—“He who acts according to his desires, abandoning the injunctions of scripture, does not attain perfection”—it was stated that one who follows desire by discarding scriptural ordinances is not eligible for knowledge. Now, with a desire to know whether those who, without desire but with faith, disregard the scriptures—do they have any eligibility or not?—Arjuna asks this question.

By the phrase “abandoning the injunctions of scripture and performing sacrifice,” are such persons, who know the scriptural meaning and yet transgress it, being referred to? No, because the performance of sacrifice with faith would not be consistent in that case. Faith is indeed a conviction in truth (āstikya-buddhi), and it cannot exist in those who knowingly act against scriptural knowledge.

So, who is being referred to? Only those who, without understanding the import of scripture—due to hardship, laziness, or failure to make an effort to understand—act merely on the strength of traditional customs with faith, worshipping various deities. Therefore, the meaning is this: those who, due to a mindset of difficulty or laziness, disregard the scriptural injunctions and, relying solely on the authority of custom, act with faith—what is their steadfastness (niṣṭhā)? What is their state? What is their basis?

Arjuna asks particularly: is it sattva? Or is it rajas? Or tamas? Their inclination toward deity-worship and the like—does it arise from sattva, rajas, or tamas?

Because faith is sāttvika in nature, yet the disregard of scripture due to hardship or laziness belongs to rajas or tamas, there is a threefold doubt. If they are grounded in sattva, then due to their sāttvika faith, they may still be eligible for the knowledge of the Self as described earlier. Otherwise, they are not—this is the intent behind the question.

17.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा।
सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां शृणु।।१७.२।।
17.translit:
śrī-bhagavān uvāca
trividhā bhavati śraddhā dehināṁ sā svabhāva-jā
sāttvikī rājasī caiva tāmasī ceti tāṁ śṛṇu
17.translate: The Blessed Lord said: Faith in the embodied beings is of three kinds, born of their nature—sāttvikī, rājasī, and tāmasī. Hear of that.
17.sridhara:
Here is the reply. The Blessed Lord said: “Faith is of three kinds.”

The meaning is: among those who act in accordance with the knowledge of scripture and the principles of reality, and who worship the Supreme Lord, there is only one kind of faith—sāttvikī. But among the embodied beings who act merely according to worldly customs, the faith is threefold: sāttvikī, rājasī, and tāmasī.

What is the reason for this? It is born of one's nature (svabhāva-jā), which arises from impressions (saṁskāras) of past actions—this is called “born of nature.” The nature (svabhāva) can be modified only by scriptural knowledge and the discriminative wisdom it generates. But they do not possess that.

Therefore, the faith arises solely from their nature. Thus, faith is threefold. Hear now of that threefold faith.

As was said earlier: “The resolute intellect is single-pointed, O son of Kuru” (२.४१), etc.

17.shlok:
सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत।
श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः।।१७.३।।
17.translit:
sattvānurūpā sarvasya śraddhā bhavati bhārata
śraddhāmayo ’yaṁ puruṣo yo yac-chraddhaḥ sa eva saḥ
17.translate: Faith conforms to the nature (sattva) of each individual, O Bhārata. A person is made of faith; as his faith is, so is he.
17.sridhara:
One might object: Is faith not only sāttvikī, since it is known to produce sāttvika effects? The Lord Himself instructed Uddhava: “Peace, self-restraint, forbearance, sacrifice, truthfulness, compassion, remembrance, contentment, renunciation, non-possessiveness, faith, modesty, mercy, and self-satisfaction—these are qualities of sattva.” Therefore, how can faith be said to be threefold?

It is true that faith is intrinsically sāttvika. However, when it resides in persons dominated by rajas and tamas, it becomes mixed with those guṇas. Hence, faith also appears as threefold. This is explained by the verse: “Faith conforms to one's sattva.”

That is, faith corresponds to the gradation of sattva in every person, whether discriminative or non-discriminative. Therefore, this worldly person is composed of faith (śraddhāmayaḥ)—he is a transformation of faith. He is shaped and altered by the three kinds of faith.

Thus, “as his faith is, so is he”: the one whose faith is sāttvika due to past impressions of predominating sattva, he again becomes endowed with that same sāttvika faith. Similarly, the one whose faith is rājasika or tāmasika, again becomes of that nature due to the corresponding saṁskāras.

Thus, among those who act merely according to worldly customs, faith exists as threefold: sāttvika, rājasika, and tāmasika. But for those endowed with discriminative wisdom generated by scripture, and who have conquered their nature, faith is only sāttvika. This is the contextual purport.

17.shlok:
यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान् यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः।
प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः।।१७.४।।
17.translit:
yajante sāttvikā devān yakṣa-rakṣāṁsi rājasāḥ
pretān bhūta-gaṇāṁś cānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ
17.translate: The sāttvika worship the gods; the rājasika worship yakṣas and rākṣasas; others—the tāmasika—worship ghosts and hosts of spirits.
17.sridhara:
The differentiation among sāttvika, rājasika, and tāmasika faith is now elaborated through their respective activities:

Those who are sāttvika—by nature aligned with sattva—worship the devas (gods). The rājasika worship beings of rajas-nature, such as yakṣas and rākṣasas. Others, different from these, who are tāmasika by nature, worship ghosts and groups of spirits.

From the nature of these entities (sattva, rajas, tamas), and from the inclination toward worshipping each type, the sāttvika, rājasika, and tāmasika character of the worshippers is to be inferred.

17.shlok:
अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः।
दम्भाहङ्कारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः।।१७.५।।
17.translit:
aśāstra-vihitaṁ ghoraṁ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ
dambhāhaṅkāra-saṁyuktāḥ kāma-rāga-balānvitāḥ
17.translate: Those people who practice dreadful austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, endowed with hypocrisy and pride, driven by the power of desire and attachment.
17.sridhara:
Among those of rājasa and tāmasa nature, a further distinction is stated with the two verses beginning with “aśāstra-vihitam.” Some people, though ignorant of the scriptural injunctions, become superior — that is, sāttvikas — due to impressions of past virtuous deeds. Some others are of middle nature, rājasa. The lowest are tāmasa. But those who are extremely unfortunate, being followers of others and due to association with heretical sects, emulate their conduct. Being such, they perform dreadful, fearsome austerities that are not sanctioned by the śāstra.

There, the causes are: united with hypocrisy (dambha) and pride (ahaṅkāra), and also — is “kāma” desire? Is “rāga” attachment? Is “bala” stubborn insistence or force? Being endowed with these — such persons, know them to be of demoniacal resolve — this is the connection with the next verse.

17.shlok:
कर्षयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः।
मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान्।।१७.६।।
17.translit:
karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṁ bhūta-grāmam acetasaḥ
māṁ caivāntaḥ-śarīrasthaṁ tān viddhy āsura-niścayān
17.translate: Senseless, torturing the aggregate of elements residing in the body, and also Me who dwells within the body — know them to be of demoniacal resolve.
17.sridhara:
Furthermore: “karṣayantaḥ” — torturing the collection of elements residing in the body, such as earth, etc., which dwell in the body as its constituents. They weaken it uselessly through fasting and such practices, being undiscerning (acetasaḥ). And they also torture Me, who, as the inner controller, reside within the body — that is, situated within the body, in the middle of it — by violating My command.

Thus, those who perform such austerities, know them to be of demoniacal resolve — that is, those whose determination is exceedingly cruel are to be known as demoniacal.

17.shlok:
आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः।
यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं श्रृणु।।१७.७।।
17.translit:
āhāras tv api sarvasya tri-vidho bhavati priyaḥ
yajñas tapas tathā dānaṁ teṣāṁ bhedam imaṁ śṛṇu
17.translate: Food too, which is dear to all, is threefold; so also are sacrifice, austerity, and giving. Hear this distinction among them.
17.sridhara:
In order to demonstrate the sāttvika and other distinctions through the differences in food and so on, the Lord says — beginning with “āhāras tv” and in the following thirteen verses. The food, meaning grains and so on, that is dear to all people, is, according to one’s nature, of three kinds. Likewise, sacrifices, austerities, and charities are also threefold.

Hear this distinction concerning them as it will be stated. This is being said with the intent that by renouncing food, sacrifice, etc., that are rājasa or tāmasa, and engaging in those that are sāttvika, one should endeavor to increase sattva — that is the purpose here.

17.shlok:
आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः।
रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः।।१७.८।।
17.translit:
āyuḥ-sattva-bala-ārogya-sukha-prīti-vivardhanāḥ
rasyāḥ snigdhāḥ sthirā hṛdyā āhārāḥ sāttvika-priyāḥ
17.translate: Foods which promote life, purity, strength, health, happiness, and satisfaction, which are savory, oily, firm, and pleasing — these are dear to the sāttvika.
17.sridhara:
Therein, the threefold nature of food is spoken of — in three verses beginning with “āyuḥ.” Āyuḥ means life; sattva, enthusiasm; bala, strength; ārogya, absence of disease; sukha, mental clarity or comfort; prīti, delight or appetite.

The foods that enhance these in particular — they are “rasyāḥ” (full of taste), “snigdhāḥ” (unctuous), “sthirāḥ” (firm, long-enduring in the body with essence), “hṛdyāḥ” (pleasing to the heart upon sight itself). Such foods — chewables, drinkables, etc. — are dear to the sāttvika.

17.shlok:
कट्वम्ललवणात्युष्णतीक्ष्णरूक्षविदाहिनः।
आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःखशोकामयप्रदाः।।१७.९।।
17.translit:
kaṭv-amla-lavaṇa-atyuṣṇa-tīkṣṇa-rūkṣa-vidāhinaḥ
āhārā rājasasya iṣṭā duḥkha-śoka-āmaya-pradāḥ
17.translate: Foods that are bitter, sour, salty, excessively hot, pungent, dry, and burning — these are liked by the rājasika and cause pain, grief, and disease.
17.sridhara:
Next: “kaṭv-iti” — the prefix “ati” connects to all seven qualities. “Ati-kaṭuḥ” (extremely bitter) like neem, “aty-amlaḥ” (overly sour), “ati-lavaṇaḥ” (too salty), “aty-uṣṇaś ca” (excessively hot) — these are well known. “Ati-tīkṣṇaḥ” (overly sharp) like pepper, “ati-rūkṣaḥ” (very dry) like wild millet, “ati-vidāhī” (burning) like mustard.

Such excessively bitter and other foods are dear to the rājasika. “Duḥkham” — immediate heartburn or torment; “śokaḥ” — subsequent mental dejection; “āmayaḥ” — disease. These foods give rise to such afflictions.

17.shlok:
यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत्।
उच्छिष्टमपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम्।।१७.१०।।
17.translit:
yāta-yāmaṁ gata-rasaṁ pūti paryuṣitaṁ ca yat
ucchiṣṭam api cāmedhyaṁ bhojanaṁ tāmasa-priyam
17.translate: That which is stale, tasteless, foul-smelling, decomposed, leftover, and impure — such food is dear to the tāmasika.
17.sridhara:
Then: “yāta-yāmam iti” — food that has passed a “yāma” (a quarter of a day), such as cooked rice that has become cold, is called “yāta-yāmam.” “Gata-rasam” — devoid of sap or essence, “pūti” — foul-smelling, “paryuṣitam” — cooked on a previous day, “ucchiṣṭam” — remnants of others’ meals, “amedhyam” — unfit for offering, such as stale or rotten meat.

Food of such nature — edible or consumable — is dear to the tāmasika.

17.shlok:
अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते।
यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः।।१७.११।।
17.translit:
aphalākāṅkṣibhir yajño vidhidṛṣṭo ya ijyate
yaṣṭavyam eveti manaḥ samādhāya sa sāttvikaḥ
17.translate: That sacrifice which is performed by those who are free from desire for results, in accordance with scriptural injunctions, with the thought firmly set that it is to be performed as duty alone — that is sāttvika.
17.sridhara:
Sacrifice too is threefold. Among them, the sāttvika sacrifice is described: “aphalākāṅkṣibhir” — by those who are devoid of desire for fruit; the sacrifice which is performed (ijyate) as enjoined by scriptural injunctions (vidhinā dṛṣṭaḥ) as obligatory — that is a sāttvika yajña.

How is it performed? With the mind firmly resolved that “this sacrifice is to be done alone” — that is, the performance of sacrifice is a duty, not a means to attain any separate fruit — thus focusing the mind in this manner (manas samādhāya), meaning with single-pointed attention.

17.shlok:
अभिसंधाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत्।
इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम्।।१७.१२।।
17.translit:
abhisaṁdhāya tu phalaṁ dambhārtham api caiva yat
ijyate bharata-śreṣṭha taṁ yajñaṁ viddhi rājasam
17.translate: But that sacrifice which is performed with the intent of gaining fruit, and also for show and ostentation — know that sacrifice, O best of the Bharatas, to be rājasika.
17.sridhara: Now the rājasika sacrifice is described: “abhisaṁdhāya” — with the intent of the fruit, and which is performed (ijyate), “dambhārtham” — for the purpose of proclaiming one’s own greatness — that sacrifice, know it to be rājasa.

17.shlok:
विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम्।
श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते।।१७.१३।।
17.translit:
vidhi-hīnam asṛṣṭānnaṁ mantra-hīnam adakṣiṇam
śraddhā-virahitaṁ yajñaṁ tāmasaṁ paricakṣate
17.translate: That sacrifice which is devoid of proper procedure, in which no food is offered (to Brahmins and others), without mantras, without offering of fees, and lacking in faith — is declared to be tāmasika.
17.sridhara: Now the tāmasika sacrifice is described: “vidhi-hīnam” — devoid of the scripturally enjoined procedure; “asṛṣṭānnam” — in which no food is offered or distributed to Brahmins and others; “mantra-hīnam” — devoid of proper mantras; “adakṣiṇam” — lacking the prescribed gifts; and “śraddhā-śūnyam” — devoid of faith. Such a sacrifice is declared to be tāmasika by the learned (śiṣṭāḥ).

17.shlok:
देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम्।
ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते।।१७.१४।।
17.translit:
deva-dvija-guru-prājña-pūjanaṁ śaucaṁ ārjavam
brahmacaryam ahiṁsā ca śārīraṁ tapa ucyate
17.translate: Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teacher, and the wise; purity, straightforwardness, celibacy, and non-injury — this is called austerity of the body.
17.sridhara:
To show the sāttvika and other distinctions of austerity, first the threefold division of austerity according to body, speech, and mind is described. First: bodily (śārīram) austerity is described in three verses, beginning with “deva-dvija.”

The “wise” (prājñāḥ) refers to those who are knowers of truth, distinct from one’s preceptor. Worship of gods, Brahmins, and so on, and the other practices like purity and so on, which are performed with the body — that is called bodily austerity (śārīraṁ tapaḥ).

17.shlok:
अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत्।
स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते।।१७.१५।।
17.translit:
anudvega-karaṁ vākyaṁ satyaṁ priya-hitaṁ ca yat
svādhyāyābhyasanaṁ caiva vāṅmayaṁ tapa ucyate
17.translate: Speech that does not cause agitation, that is true, pleasant, and beneficial, and the regular recitation of the Veda — this is called austerity of speech.
17.sridhara: Verbal austerity (vāṅmayaṁ tapaḥ) is described: “anudvega-karaṁ vākyaṁ” — speech that does not cause fear or agitation; “satyaṁ” — true; “priyaṁ” — agreeable to the listener; “hitaṁ” — beneficial, i.e., leading to happiness as its result. “Svādhyāyābhyasanaṁ” — the repeated recitation of the Veda — all this is austerity accomplished through speech (vāṅmayaṁ tapaḥ).

17.shlok:
मनःप्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः।
भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते।।१७.१६।।
17.translit:
manaḥ-prasādaḥ saumyatvaṁ maunam ātma-vinigrahaḥ
bhāva-saṁśuddhir ity etat tapo mānasam ucyate
17.translate: Serenity of mind, gentleness, silence, self-restraint, and purity of disposition — this is called mental austerity.
17.sridhara: Now mental austerity is described: “manaḥ-prasādaḥ” — calmness of mind; “saumyatvam” — non-cruelty or gentleness; “maunam” — the state of a muni (sage); it means inner reflection. “Ātma-vinigrahaḥ” — restraint of the mind from sense objects, i.e., withdrawal (pratyāhāra); “bhāva-saṁśuddhiḥ” — freedom from deceitfulness in conduct. All this is called mental austerity (mānasaṁ tapaḥ).

17.shlok:
श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्त्रिविधं नरैः।
अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते।।१७.१७।।
17.translit:
śraddhayā parayā taptaṁ tapas tat trividhaṁ naraiḥ
aphalākāṅkṣibhir yuktaiḥ sāttvikaṁ paricakṣate
17.translate: This threefold austerity, performed with supreme faith by steadfast men who are free from desire for fruit, is said to be sāttvika.
17.sridhara: Thus, the threefold austerity performed through body, speech, and mind has been described. Now, the threefold division — sāttvika, etc. — of that threefold austerity is given: “śraddhayā” — with supreme faith; “aphalākāṅkṣā-śūnyaiḥ” — by those devoid of desire for fruit; “yuktaiḥ” — with concentrated minds. That austerity, thus performed, is said to be sāttvika.

17.shlok:
सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत्।
क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम्।।१७.१८।।
17.translit:
satkāra-māna-pūjārthaṁ tapo dambhena caiva yat
kriyate tad iha proktaṁ rājasaṁ calam adhruvam
17.translate: That austerity which is performed for the sake of respect, honor, and worship, and with hypocrisy — that is said to be rājasika, unstable and impermanent.
17.sridhara: Now the rājasika austerity is described: “satkāraḥ” — verbal praise, such as “he is a noble ascetic” and so on; “mānaḥ” — bodily honor, such as rising, greeting, etc.; “pūjā” — material offerings, such as wealth and the like. When austerity is performed for the sake of these, and “with hypocrisy” (dambhena), then it is, consequently, “calaṁ” — inconstant, and “adhruvam” — fleeting. That austerity, being of this kind, is said to be rājasika.

17.shlok:
मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः।
परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्।।१७.१९।।
17.translit:
mūḍha-grāheṇātmano yat pīḍayā kriyate tapaḥ
parasyotsādana-arthaṁ vā tat tāmasam udāhṛtam
17.translate: That austerity which is practiced with deluded resolve, involving self-torment, or with the intention to harm others — that is declared to be tāmasika.
17.sridhara: Now tāmasika austerity is described: “mūḍha-grāheṇa” — with deluded resolve, due to lack of discrimination; “ātmanah pīḍayā” — with tormenting of the self; or “parasya utsādana-artham” — for the destruction of another, in the form of black magic (abhicāra); that austerity is said to be tāmasika.

17.shlok:
दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे।
देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम्।।१७.२०।।
17.translit:
dātavyam iti yad dānaṁ dīyate ‘nupakāriṇe
deśe kāle ca pātre ca tad dānaṁ sāttvikaṁ smṛtam
17.translate: That gift which is given with the conviction that it must be given, to one who will not return the favor, in the proper place, at the proper time, and to a worthy recipient — that is said to be sāttvika.

17.shlok:
यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः।
दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम्।।१७.२१।।
17.translit:
yat tu pratyupakārārthaṁ phalam uddiśya vā punaḥ
dīyate ca parikliṣṭaṁ tat dānaṁ rājasaṁ smṛtam
17.translate: But that gift which is given with the intention of receiving something in return, or with a view to a reward, and given with reluctance — that is considered rājasika.
17.sridhara: Now rājasika charity is stated: “yat tu” — that which; “pratyupakāraṁ kariṣyatīti” — “he will do something in return for me later” — with this thought; or “phalam vā” — with a view to a reward such as heaven; “punar dānaṁ dīyate” — when such a gift is given again; and “parikliṣṭaṁ” — accompanied by mental strain. Such a gift, being of this nature, is said to be rājasika.

17.shlok:
अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते।
असत्कृतमवज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्।।१७.२२।।
17.translit:
adeśa-kāle yad dānam apātrebhyaś ca dīyate
asatkṛtam avajñātaṁ tat tāmasam udāhṛtam
17.translate: That gift which is given at the wrong place and time, to unworthy recipients, without respect or with contempt — that is declared to be tāmasika.
17.sridhara: Now tāmasika charity is described: “adeśe” — in an impure place; “akāle” — at an impure or improper time; “apātrebhyaḥ” — to unworthy recipients such as actors, dancers, and so on — such a gift is given. Even when place, time, and recipient are appropriate, if it is “asatkṛtam” — without honor, lacking respectful acts such as washing the recipient’s feet, and “avajñātam” — accompanied by disdain or insult, then such charity is said to be tāmasika.

17.shlok:
ॐ तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः।
ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा।।१७.२३।।
17.translit:
om tat sad iti nirdeśo brahmaṇas tri-vidhaḥ smṛtaḥ
brāhmaṇās tena vedāś ca yajñāś ca vihitāḥ purā
17.translate: “Om Tat Sat” — this is declared to be the threefold designation of Brahman. By that were created long ago the Brāhmaṇas, the Vedas, and the sacrifices.
17.sridhara:
Now, upon contemplating all this, one might wonder: “Then all sacrifice, austerity, charity, etc., tend to be rājasika or tāmasika — what is the use of such efforts?” In response to this doubt, the means of transforming even such actions into sāttvika is shown: “Om iti” — the threefold designation “Om Tat Sat” is said to be the name, the indication (vyapadeśa), of Brahman, the Supreme Self, according to the wise.

Now, “Om” is known from śruti such as “Om iti trivṛd brahma,” etc., and is a name of Brahman — being the cause of the universe and extremely well-known. For those who are not learned, it remains indirect (parokṣa). “Tat” is also a name of Brahman. “Sat,” due to the associations of ultimate reality, goodness, and excellence, is likewise a name of Brahman — as found in the śruti: “sad eva somya idam agra āsīt” (“Only Sat existed in the beginning, O gentle one”).

This threefold designation, though nirguṇa (attributeless), has the power to bestow guṇas (qualities) — hence it is praised. By this threefold designation of Brahman were the Brāhmaṇas, the Vedas, and the sacrifices appointed or brought into being in the beginning by the Creator (vidhātṛ). Or alternatively, the Brāhmaṇas, etc., who are the purest beings, were created by that Supreme Self who possesses this threefold designation. Therefore, this triple designation is supremely praiseworthy.

17.shlok:
तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः।
प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम्।।१७.२४।।
17.translit:
tasmād om ity udāhṛtya yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ
pravartante vidhānoktāḥ satataṁ brahma-vādinām
17.translate: Therefore, uttering “Om,” the acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity as enjoined in the scriptures are always undertaken by those who study and speak of Brahman.
17.sridhara:
Now the particular greatness of each — Om, Tat, and Sat — is explained. First, that of Om: “tasmāt” — since the designation of Brahman is so praiseworthy, therefore, with the utterance of “Om,” the scripturally enjoined acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity of the followers of the Vedas are always performed.

Even when there is some deficiency in the limbs (of the ritual), they still proceed effectively. The meaning is: they acquire the sāguṇa (qualified, auspicious) character.

17.shlok:
तदित्यनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः।
दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभिः।।१७.२५।।
17.translit:
tad ity anabhisandhāya phalaṁ yajña-tapaḥ-kriyāḥ
dāna-kriyāś ca vividhāḥ kriyante mokṣa-kāṅkṣibhiḥ
17.translate: Uttering “Tat,” and without seeking reward, acts of sacrifice, austerity, and various kinds of charity are performed by those desiring liberation.
17.sridhara: Now the second name is praised: “Tat iti” — the phrase “with the utterance of Tat” is implied by continuity from the previous verse. “With the utterance of Tat,” the various acts of sacrifice, etc., are performed by those with pure minds who desire liberation, without any thought of reward. Thus, because it leads to purification of the mind and abandonment of desire for results, and thereby brings about the qualification for liberation, the designation “Tat” is praiseworthy — this is the meaning.

17.shlok:
सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते।
प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते।।१७.२६।।
17.translit:
sadbhāve sādhu-bhāve ca sad ity etat prayujyate
praśaste karmaṇi tathā sac-chabdaḥ pārtha yujyate
17.translate: The word “Sat” is used in the sense of existence and in the sense of virtue; and, O Pārtha, it is also used in reference to auspicious action.
17.sridhara:
The praiseworthiness of the word sat is now stated by the two terms: “sadbhāva” and “sādhubhāva.” In the sense of sadbhāva — existence — as in the expression, “Devadatta’s son exists”; and in the sense of sādhubhāva — virtue — as in “Devadatta’s son is noble,” in both these senses, the word sat is employed.

Also, in regard to praśasta karmaṇi — auspicious, meritorious actions such as marriage rituals and the like — the expression “this is a sat-karma” is used. In such a context, the word sat is applied — it is either used (prayujyate) or fits (yujyate).

17.shlok:
यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते।
कर्म चैव तदर्थीयं सदित्येवाभिधीयते।।१७.२७।।
17.translit:
yajñe tapasi dāne ca sthitiḥ sad iti cocyate
karma caiva tad-arthīyaṁ sad ity evābhidhīyate
17.translate: Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity, and gift is also called Sat; and any action performed for that purpose is also spoken of as Sat.
17.sridhara:
Furthermore: “yajñe,” etc. — the steady engagement (sthitiḥ) in sacrifice and the rest — with committed intent — is also called sat. And that action which is tad-artham — done for the sake of Him who possesses this threefold name (Om Tat Sat) and who is the Supreme Self — such as acts of worship, offering, cleaning the home or temple, decoration, or auspicious rituals, all performed with the intention of attaining Him — these are referred to as sat.

Even actions that are indirectly related, such as tending a garden, cultivating a rice field, or earning money — if done for that end — are also called sat, even if distantly connected.

Because this threefold designation is extremely praiseworthy, the implied purport (tātparya) is that it should be uttered for the sanctification of all such actions.

And here, due to the impracticality of taking this as mere praise (arthavāda), a prescription (vidhi) is implied — following the principle that “the object is being praised because it is enjoined.”

Some, however, say that the verbs in the earlier verses — pravartante (they commence), kriyante (they are performed), uchyate (it is said) — though present in form, are intended in a prescriptive sense, just like in examples such as “he offers the firewood” (samidho yajati), where it implies obligation.

But since in the usages such as “sadbhāve, sādhubhāve,” etc., the meaning is already self-evident, the assumption of a new prescription does not naturally follow.

Thus, as per the prior sequence, treating this as an implied prescription (vidhi-kalpanā) is superior.

17.shlok:
अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत्।
असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह।।१७.२८।।
17.translit:
aśraddhayā hutaṁ dattaṁ tapas taptaṁ kṛtaṁ ca yat
asad ity ucyate pārtha na ca tat pretya no iha
17.translate: Whatever is offered, given, or performed, and whatever austerity is practiced without faith — it is called Asat, O Pārtha; it yields nothing, either after death or here.
17.sridhara:
Now, in order to emphasize that all actions must be undertaken only with faith, everything done without faith is condemned: “aśraddhayā” — performed without faith — “hutaṁ” — offering into fire; “dattaṁ” — charity; “taptaṁ” — practiced austerity; and “yat kṛtaṁ” — any other act whatsoever, all of it is said to be asat.

Because of its lack of efficacy (viguṇatvāt), it bears no fruit after death (pretya), i.e., in the next world. Nor does it bear fruit here (iha), in this world — because it brings disrepute (ayaśaskaratvāt).

18.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
संन्यासस्य महाबाहो तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम्।
त्यागस्य च हृषीकेश पृथक्केशिनिषूदन।।१८.१।।
18.translit:
arjuna uvāca
saṁnyāsasya mahā-bāho tattvam icchāmi veditum
tyāgasya ca hṛṣīkeśa pṛthak keśiniṣūdana
18.translate: Arjuna said: O mighty-armed one, I wish to understand the true nature of saṁnyāsa (renunciation), O Hṛṣīkeśa, and also of tyāga (abandonment), O slayer of Keśi, as distinct from each other.
18.sridhara:
By distinguishing saṁnyāsa and tyāga, the entire meaning of the Gītā is summarized here — clearly and definitively — in this eighteenth chapter, which concludes with the final determination of the supreme truth.

Now, in previous verses such as “Having mentally renounced all actions, he dwells happily, the self-controlled one, united with the yoga of renunciation,” and so on (e.g., ५.१३), renunciation of action (karma-saṁnyāsa) has been taught. Likewise, in verses like “Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of action, being ever content and independent,” and “Therefore, perform action, abandoning the fruit, being self-controlled,” etc., the performance of action accompanied only by the abandonment of its fruits has been taught.

And the omniscient and supremely compassionate Lord would not teach mutually contradictory doctrines. Therefore, Arjuna, desiring to understand the method by which karma-saṁnyāsa and the performance of action with phala-tyāga (abandonment of fruits) can be reconciled and are non-contradictory, said: “saṁnyāsasya iti” — O Hṛṣīkeśa (controller of all senses)! O Keśi-niṣūdana (slayer of Keśi)! Keśi was a mighty horse-formed demon who rushed to devour You with his gaping mouth in battle — but You inserted Your left arm into that wide-open mouth, and in that very moment, with that same arm made massive, You tore him asunder like a wood-apple and destroyed him. Therefore, “O mighty-armed one!” is also a fitting address.

I wish to know the tattva — the essential reality — of saṁnyāsa and tyāga, considered distinctly from one another.

18.shlok:
श्री भगवानुवाच
काम्यानां कर्मणां न्यासं संन्यासं कवयो विदुः।
सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं प्राहुस्त्यागं विचक्षणाः।।१८.२।।
18.translit:
śrī bhagavān uvāca
kāmyānāṁ karmaṇāṁ nyāsaṁ saṁnyāsaṁ kavayo viduḥ
sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṁ prāhus tyāgaṁ vicakṣaṇāḥ
18.translate: The Blessed Lord said: The renunciation of actions performed with desire is understood by the wise as saṁnyāsa; the abandonment of the fruits of all actions is declared by the discerning to be tyāga.
18.sridhara:
Now, in response, the Blessed Lord said — “kāmyānām iti”: the renunciation (nyāsa) or abandonment of actions that are enjoined with a desire-motive — such as "He who desires a son should perform this sacrifice," "He who desires heaven should perform that sacrifice," and so on — is known as saṁnyāsa by the sages (kavayaḥ), i.e., the learned knowers. The implication is that even all actions in general (sarva-karmaṇām), when renounced along with their fruits, are regarded by the learned as saṁnyāsa.

But the abandonment of only the fruits of all actions — including both desire-based (kāmya) and obligatory (nitya-naimittika) duties — is declared to be tyāga by the discerning (vicakṣaṇāḥ), those who are skilled in discrimination, and not the renunciation of the actions themselves in their essential nature.

Now, an objection is raised: for obligatory actions like nitya and naimittika, no fruits are prescribed in the scriptures. So how can one speak of giving up fruits that do not exist? Just as a barren woman cannot give up her child, how can there be fruit-abandonment where there is no fruit?

This is answered: although specific fruits are not explicitly mentioned in injunctions like “Let one perform the Sandhyā (twilight worship) daily,” or “Let one offer Agnihotra until the end of life,” which are seen to be daily duties, still, in order to engage a rational person toward some goal, the Vedic injunction implicitly implies a general result, as in “One should perform the Viśvajit sacrifice,” etc. Therefore, the Veda implicitly points toward a fruit even if not explicitly stated. Do not suppose that the purpose of such injunctions is solely fulfilled by the act itself, due to intense faith, as some claim — because the person would then have no motivation to act. Since it is impossible to engage someone in purposeful action without some result being in view, the fruit is understood to be implied.

Moreover, even in relation to obligatory duties (nitya-karma), we do hear of results in the scriptures, such as: “All these attain the worlds of merit,” “By karma, one reaches the world of ancestors,” and “By dharma, sin is dispelled.” Therefore, it is appropriate to say, “The abandonment of the fruits of all actions is called tyāga by the wise.”

Now another objection may arise: “But by merely abandoning fruits, one would still be engaged in action, even in fruitless action.” That is not a defect, because all actions, when performed for the sake of vividhiṣā — the desire to know the Self — with a clear sense of distinction between means and ends, have a legitimate application. As the Śruti says: “Desiring to know that very Self, the Brāhmaṇas perform sacrifices, give charity, practice austerity, and undertake vows.”

Thus, renouncing all fruits of action — which are considered binding — while performing actions with the aim of Self-knowledge (vividhiṣā), is indeed fitting.

Now, vividhiṣā is the inward turning of the intellect (buddhi) caused by dispassion, born of discrimination between the permanent and the impermanent, and by renouncing identification with the body. Until such Self-realization arises, one must continue performing necessary actions that are not opposed to knowledge, for the sake of purification of the mind (sattva-śuddhi). And renunciation of the fruits alone in this way is what is known as tyāga — not the renunciation of action in its essence.

Accordingly, the Śruti also says: “By performing actions here, one should desire to live a hundred years” (Īśopaniṣad २). Beyond that, all actions automatically cease of their own accord. This is stated in the text Naiṣkarmya-siddhi: “The intellect that has turned inward produces action for the sake of purification; once its purpose is fulfilled, they cease like rain-clouds in autumn.”

Likewise, it is said in the Gītā itself: “The man who delights in the Self, who is satisfied in the Self, and who is content in the Self — for him there is nothing to do.”

Also, the sage Vasiṣṭha has said: “The yogī does not abandon actions; rather, he is abandoned by them — due to the destruction of their root, which is mental volition (saṅkalpa).”

Therefore, only when action becomes an obstacle to steadfastness in knowledge should it be renounced. Thus, in the Bhāgavata, the Lord has said: “Let one continue performing actions until one becomes disenchanted; or, until faith in hearing My glories arises.”

Also: “Whether one is steadfast in knowledge, or dispassionate, or devoted to Me, one may abandon external marks of āśrama and wander unrestricted.”

Let us not indulge in excessive elaboration — we shall proceed with the main topic.

18.shlok:
त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः।
यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यमिति चापरे।।१८.३।।
18.translit:
tyājyaṁ doṣavad ity eke karma prāhur manīṣiṇaḥ
yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyam iti cāpare
18.translate: Some wise ones say that action should be abandoned as having fault, like an evil; others declare that acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should not be abandoned.
18.sridhara:
It is to establish firmly that the meaning of the word “tyāga” (abandonment) refers only to the renunciation of fruit and not to the abandonment of action — this is done by showing the difference of opinion: “tyājyaṁ doṣavat” — some say that all action is to be abandoned as possessing fault, like violence and so on, and therefore being a cause of bondage. This is the view of certain Sāṅkhyas, referred to by the word “manīṣiṇaḥ” (the discerning).

To elaborate: “One should not injure any being” — such prohibitions imply that injury is harmful to a person. However, scriptural injunctions such as “one should offer the animal in the Agniṣomīya sacrifice” indicate that injury is supportive of the ritual. Since these refer to different topics, being governed by the rule of general versus specific (sāmānya-viśeṣa-nyāya), there is no conflict of annulment between them. And because injury and the like can occur in all actions that are dependent on material substances, they conclude that all action is to be abandoned. As it is said: “Because it is associated with impurity, decline, and excess — both seen and heard of.”

Its meaning is this: the method called Jyotiṣṭoma and others is also considered a known method because it is heard from a teacher, and the śruti (Veda) reveals it. In that, the impurity is violence, and through that, there is decline or destruction. There is also gradation among the results of acts like Agnihotra and Jyotiṣṭoma, such as attainment of heaven. But superiority over others results in making all others miserable.

Others, however — namely the Mīmāṁsakas — say that sacrifice and so on should not be abandoned. The meaning is this: the injury involved in a ritual act like a sacrifice, though arising from a person, must still be performed. And even if done for another purpose, it leads to sin for that person alone. Why? Because a Vedic injunction mandates that an act must be performed for a specific purpose, and that purpose gives it the nature of being subordinate to the main aim. But a prohibition does not depend on a purpose — it only requires that the action not occur at all. Otherwise, if one commits a prohibited act due to ignorance or negligence, one would be guiltless — which is unreasonable.

Thus, because the two (injunction and prohibition) concern the same topic, and because a general rule is overridden by a specific one, it is concluded that the act is not faulty. Therefore, sacrifice and so on should not be abandoned, as they are obligatory.

In this way, the view that both injunction and prohibition are equally authoritative is refuted. The rule regarding general and specific texts is established to show this.

18.shlok:
निश्चयं श्रृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम।
त्यागो हि पुरुषव्याघ्र त्रिविधः संप्रकीर्तितः।।१८.४।।
18.translit:
niścayaṁ śṛṇu me tatra tyāge bharata-sattama
tyāgo hi puruṣa-vyāghra trividhāḥ saṁprakīrtitaḥ
18.translate: Hear from Me the conclusion about this renunciation, O best of the Bharatas. For renunciation, O tiger among men, has indeed been declared to be of three kinds.
18.sridhara:
Thus, after presenting the divergence of views, the Lord now states His own position: “niścayam iti” — Hear My definitive conclusion regarding renunciation (tyāga), wherein there is such divergence of opinion. One might ask, “Renunciation is well known in the world — what is there to be heard?” To counter this disregard, He says, “O tiger among men (puruṣavyāghra),” meaning “O best among men.” This renunciation is not easy to grasp.

Why? Because this renunciation of action has been clearly taught by those who know reality (tattvavids) to be of three kinds — classified as tāmasa, rājasika, and sāttvika. The division into three — renunciation in the mode of tamas, rajas, and sattva — will be elaborated starting from the verse “niyataṁ saṅgam tyaktvā” (१८.७).

18.shlok:
यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत्।
यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम्।।१८.५।।
18.translit:
yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma na tyājyaṁ kāryam eva tat
yajño dānaṁ tapaś caiva pāvanāni manīṣiṇām
18.translate: Acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should not be renounced; they must indeed be performed. For sacrifice, charity, and also austerity are purifiers of the wise.
18.sridhara: Now, firstly, the conclusion is stated through these two half-verses: “yajña-dāna-tapaḥ-karma…” — acts of sacrifice, charity, and austerity should not be abandoned. Why? Because they are purifiers (pāvanāni), i.e., they produce purity of mind (citta-śuddhi), for the wise (manīṣiṇām), that is, for the discriminating.

18.shlok:
एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च।
कर्तव्यानीति मे पार्थ निश्चितं मतमुत्तमम्।।१८.६।।
18.translit:
etāny api tu karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalāni ca
kartavyānīti me pārtha niścitaṁ matam uttamam
18.translate: Even these actions should be performed, giving up attachment and also the fruits, O Pārtha. This is My firm and best conclusion.
18.sridhara: Now, showing the manner in which these actions become purifying, He says: “etāni iti” — These very actions, yajña (sacrifice), etc., which I have said are purifying, must indeed be performed. How? Having given up attachment (saṅga), which means the egoistic identification as the doer (kartṛtva-abhimāna), they are to be done solely as worship of the Lord. And having given up desire for their fruits as well, they are to be performed. This is My firm (niścitaṁ) opinion (matam), and therefore it is the best (uttamam).

18.shlok:
नियतस्य तु संन्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते।
मोहात्तस्य परित्यागस्तामसः परिकीर्तितः।।१८.७।।
18.translit:
niyatasya tu saṁnyāsaḥ karmaṇo nopapadyate
mohāt tasya parityāgas tāmasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ
18.translate: But the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper. Abandonment of it due to delusion is declared to be Tāmasic.
18.sridhara: Now, having made the assertion, the threefold nature of renunciation is presented: “niyatasya iti” — with these three verses. Renunciation (saṁnyāsa) of desire-motivated action is appropriate because such actions cause bondage. But renunciation (tyāga) of niyata-karma — that is, daily obligatory duties — is not appropriate, because it leads to liberation through purification of the mind (sattva-śuddhi). Therefore, its abandonment can only arise from delusion, based on the reasoning that “even what is to be accepted must be abandoned.” Such abandonment, being rooted in ignorance, is declared to be tāmasic.

18.shlok:
दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत्।
स कृत्वा राजसं त्यागं नैव त्यागफलं लभेत्।।१८.८।।
18.translit:
duḥkham ity eva yat karma kāya-kleśa-bhayāt tyajet
sa kṛtvā rājasaṁ tyāgaṁ naiva tyāga-phalaṁ labhet
18.translate: That action which one abandons merely thinking “it is painful,” out of fear of bodily suffering — such renunciation, performed in the mode of passion, does not yield the fruit of renunciation.
18.sridhara: Now, the renunciation that is rājasika is described: “duḥkham iti” — Without realization of the non-doership of the Self, if one merely thinks, “This is painful,” and abandons obligatory action out of fear of bodily effort, such renunciation is rājasika, because pain (duḥkha) belongs to rajas. Therefore, having performed such rājasika renunciation, the person of rājasic disposition does not attain the fruit of renunciation — which is established in knowledge — that is the meaning.

18.shlok:
कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन।
सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः।।१८.९।।
18.translit:
kāryam ity eva yat karma niyataṁ kriyate ’rjuna
saṅgaṁ tyaktvā phalaṁ caiva sa tyāgaḥ sāttviko mataḥ
18.translate: Whatever obligatory action is performed with the understanding, “this ought to be done,” giving up attachment and also the fruit — that renunciation is regarded as Sāttvika, O Arjuna.
18.sridhara: Now, the sāttvika renunciation is described: “kāryam iti” — Thinking “this must be done,” that action which is prescribed and known to be obligatory (niyata), and which is performed having given up attachment and desire for fruit — such renunciation is known to be sāttvika.

18.shlok:
न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते।
त्यागी सत्त्वसमाविष्टो मेधावी छिन्नसंशयः।।१८.१०।।
18.translit:
na dveṣṭy akuśalaṁ karma kuśale nānuṣajjate
tyāgī sattva-samāviṣṭo medhāvī chinna-saṁśayaḥ
18.translate: The renouncer who is imbued with goodness, intelligent, and free from doubt — he neither hates disagreeable action, nor is attached to agreeable one.
18.sridhara: Now, the characteristic of one established in such sāttvika renunciation is described: “na dveṣṭi iti” — The renouncer, who is pervaded by sattva (sattva-samāviṣṭaḥ), does not hate actions that are disagreeable, that is, that bring pain — such as bathing early in the cold season; nor does he become attached to agreeable actions — such as bathing in midday during summer. Why? Because he is intelligent (medhāvī), possessing a steady understanding. That is, even in situations where there is great suffering due to criticism or insult, he endures it; and he renounces even heavenly pleasures. So what then of mere transient pleasure and pain? This is his reflection. Therefore, he is one whose doubts have been cut — that is, whose false knowledge, marked by desires for pleasure and aversion to pain relating to the body, has been destroyed.

18.shlok:
न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः।
यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते।।१८.११।।
18.translit:
na hi deha-bhṛtā śakyaṁ tyaktuṁ karmāṇy aśeṣataḥ
yas tu karma-phala-tyāgī sa tyāgīty abhidhīyate
18.translate: Indeed, it is not possible for one who possesses a body to entirely renounce actions. But one who gives up the fruits of action is truly called a renouncer.
18.sridhara: Now, one may object: “Would not total renunciation of all actions be better than merely giving up the fruits of actions? That way, with no disturbance from activities, one could more easily attain the joy of absorption in knowledge.” To address this, the Lord says: “na iti” — It is not so. For one who bears a body, i.e., one who identifies with the body (dehātmābhimānavān), it is not possible to renounce all actions completely. As has been said earlier: “Na hi kaścit kṣaṇam api jātu tiṣṭhaty akarma-kṛt” — “No one ever remains even for a moment without performing action.” Therefore, one who performs actions but gives up the fruits — he alone is called the true renouncer in the primary sense.

18.shlok:
अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम्।
भवत्यत्यागिनां प्रेत्य न तु संन्यासिनां क्वचित्।।१८.१२।।
18.translit:
aniṣṭam iṣṭaṁ miśraṁ ca trividhaṁ karmaṇaḥ phalam
bhavaty atyāgināṁ pretya na tu saṁnyāsināṁ kvacit
18.translate: Undesirable, desirable, and mixed — this threefold fruit of action accrues after death to those who do not renounce; but never to renouncers.
18.sridhara: Now the result of this kind of renunciation of fruit is stated: “aniṣṭam iti” — Undesirable means hellish birth; desirable means divine birth; and mixed means human birth. In this way, the threefold result of actions — arising from sinful, meritorious, and mixed actions — is well-known. All this occurs after death (pretya) to those who do not renounce (atyāginām), i.e., those who act with desire. Since they perform all three types of actions, they receive the respective results. But never do such results accrue to sannyāsins — here, the term sannyāsī includes the fruit-renouncers spoken of earlier, due to their similarity. As stated at the beginning: “Anāśritaḥ karma-phalaṁ kāryaṁ karma karoti yaḥ, sa sannyāsī ca yogī ca” — “He who performs action without depending on its fruit — he is a sannyāsī and a yogī.” Therefore, since the sāttvika renouncer is free from sinful actions and has renounced the fruits of meritorious actions through offering them to the Lord, the threefold fruit of action does not accrue to them — that is the meaning.

18.shlok:
पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे।
सांख्ये कृतान्ते प्रोक्तानि सिद्धये सर्वकर्मणाम्।।१८.१३।।
18.translit:
paṅcaitāni mahā-bāho kāraṇāni nibodha me
sāṅkhye kṛtānte proktāni siddhaye sarva-karmaṇām
18.translate: O mighty-armed, understand from Me these five causes declared in the Sāṅkhya system for the accomplishment of all actions.
18.sridhara: Now, one might doubt: “How can one who performs actions avoid the result of those actions?” In anticipation of this, the Lord seeks to demonstrate that one who has renounced attachment and ego is not bound by the fruit of actions: “pañcaitāni” — these five causes will be mentioned. For the accomplishment (siddhaye) or completion of all actions, these five causes must be understood, as taught by Me. In order to give up the egoistic notion of authorship, these must certainly be known. To glorify them, He says “sāṅkhye” — that which reveals (khyāyate) the Supreme Self in entirety is called Sāṅkhya, i.e., knowledge of the truth. “Kṛtānta” means the final conclusion — that which puts an end to action, or Vedānta. Or, Sāṅkhya refers to the enumeration of principles (tattvas), and Kṛtānta refers to the final decision. In that system — i.e., Sāṅkhya — these causes are stated; therefore, understand them thoroughly.

18.shlok:
अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम्।
विविधाश्च पृथक्चेष्टा दैवं चैवात्र पञ्चमम्।।१८.१४।।
18.translit:
adhiṣṭhānaṁ tathā kartā karaṇaṁ ca pṛthag-vidham
vividhāś ca pṛthak ceṣṭā daivaṁ caivātra pañcamam
18.translate: The body (as the seat), the agent, the various instruments, the manifold activities, and the divine (factor) as the fifth — these are the five causes here.
18.sridhara: These very five are now stated: “adhiṣṭhānam iti” — The body is the adhiṣṭhāna (seat or basis); the agent (kartā) is the ego — the conjunction of consciousness and matter (cit-jaḍa-granthi); the karaṇam or instruments are of various kinds — the senses such as eye, ear, etc.; ceṣṭāḥ are the vital activities (prāṇa, apāna, etc.), differing according to function and form. Among these, the fifth is daivam — the divine factor, which is the cause of action through the presiding deities such as the sun for vision, and ultimately, the internal regulator (antaryāmin).

18.shlok:
शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः।
न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः।।१८.१५।।
18.translit:
śarīra-vāṅ-manobhir yat karma prārabhate naraḥ
nyāyyaṁ vā viparītaṁ vā pañcaite tasya hetavaḥ
18.translate: Whatever action a person undertakes with body, speech, and mind — whether right or wrong — these five are its causes.
18.sridhara: Now, it is stated that these are indeed the causes of all actions: “śarīra iti” — Whatever action is undertaken with body, speech, or mind, is said to be physical, verbal, or mental action, respectively. These threefold actions are widely known. So whatever action a person performs — whether righteous (nyāyya) or unrighteous (viparīta) — its causes are these five.

18.shlok:
तत्रैवं सति कर्तारमात्मानं केवलं तु यः।
पश्यत्यकृतबुद्धित्वान्न स पश्यति दुर्मतिः।।१८.१६।।
18.translit:
tatraivaṁ sati kartāram ātmānaṁ kevalaṁ tu yaḥ
paśyaty akṛta-buddhitvān na sa paśyati durmatiḥ
18.translate: Thus being the case, one who sees the Self — which is pure — as the agent, due to untrained understanding, does not truly see; he is of distorted intellect.
18.sridhara: So then what? He answers: “tatra” — in the case of all actions, these five are the causes — thus being so, “kevalam” — the pure, unconditioned, unattached Self — he who sees that Self as the agent, due to unrefined understanding (from abandonment of scriptural study and preceptor’s guidance), is of perverted understanding and does not truly see.

18.shlok:
यस्य नाहंकृतो भावो बुद्धिर्यस्य न लिप्यते।
हत्वापि स इमाँल्लोकान्न हन्ति न निबध्यते।।१८.१७।।
18.translit:
yasya nāhaṅkṛto bhāvo buddhir yasya na lipyate
hatvāpi sa imāṁl lokān na hanti na nibadhyate
18.translate: He who has no sense of egoism, whose intellect is untainted — even if he slays all these people, he neither slays nor is bound.
18.sridhara: Who then is the rightly-minded person who is not tainted by action? Anticipating this, he says: “yasya” — one who does not have the notion “I am the doer,” i.e., he for whom the idea “I am the agent” is absent. Or, “ahaṅkṛtaḥ” means the conviction of doership that belongs to ego — one in whom that is absent. That is, one who sees that the body and so on alone are the doers of action. Therefore, “yasya buddhir na lipyate” — his intellect is not tainted; he does not become attached to action with the judgment of desirability or undesirability. Such a person, one who sees the Self as distinct from the body, “hatvā api imān lokān” — even having slain all these beings from the worldly point of view, “na hanti” — does not slay from his own perspective. Nor is he bound by their results — he does not incur bondage. Why? Would even actions which give rise to indirect knowledge through purification of the heart bind him? No — that is the meaning. As it was earlier stated: “Brahmaṇy ādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ, lipyate na sa pāpena” — “He who performs action dedicating it to Brahman, abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin.”

18.shlok:
ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं परिज्ञाता त्रिविधा कर्मचोदना।
करणं कर्म कर्तेति त्रिविधः कर्मसंग्रहः।।१८.१८।।
18.translit:
jñānaṁ jñeyaṁ parijñātā trividhā karma-codanā
karaṇaṁ karma karteti trividhaḥ karma-saṅgrahaḥ
18.translate: Knowledge, the knowable, and the knower — this triad constitutes the impulse to action. The instrument, the action, and the agent — this triad constitutes the foundation of action.
18.sridhara: To justify the statement “even when killing, he neither kills nor is bound,” it is now shown that, since the Self is beyond the three guṇas, it has no connection with the incitement to action, the basis of action, or the fruit of action, all of which are guṇa-based. So He says: “jñānam iti” — Knowledge is the cognition that something is a means to a desired result. The object to be known is the action itself, as a means to a desired result. The knower is the one who possesses such knowledge. This triad — knowledge, the known, and the knower — is the “karma-codanā” — the impulse that incites action (codanā: that by which one is impelled). Or, codanā may mean “injunction,” as stated by the Bhaṭṭas: “codanā copadeśaś ca vidhiś caikārthavācinaḥ” — “codanā, instruction, and injunction are synonymous.” Thus, the idea is: the injunction to action operates based on this triad of knowledge, etc., which are all threefold and composed of the guṇas. As was stated: “traiguṇya-viṣayā vedāḥ” — “The Vedas deal with the three guṇas.” Now, “karaṇam” — the instrument is that which accomplishes the act (e.g., the senses); “karma” is that which is desired most by the agent (e.g., the outcome); “kartā” is the one who performs the act. The term “karma-saṅgrahaḥ” means “that in which action is comprehended.” Thus, the triad — instrument, act, and agent — is called the support or foundation of action. The other case elements (like recipient, etc.) are only indirectly involved and not directly the basis of action. Therefore, only this triad is called the support of action.

18.shlok:
ज्ञानं कर्म च कर्ता च त्रिधैव गुणभेदतः।
प्रोच्यते गुणसंख्याने यथावच्छृणु तान्यपि।।१८.१९।।
18.translit:
jñānaṁ karma ca kartā ca tridhāiva guṇa-bhedataḥ
procyate guṇa-saṅkhyāne yathāvac chṛṇu tāny api
18.translate: Knowledge, action, and the agent are said — in the doctrine of the guṇas — to be threefold, according to the distinction of guṇas. Hear them duly.
18.sridhara: So what follows from that? He says: “jñānam iti.” The sāṅkhya-śāstra is called the guṇa-saṅkhyāna — the enumeration of guṇas — because the guṇas are thoroughly distinguished and analyzed in it. In that system, knowledge, action, and agent are each said to be threefold according to the distinctions of sattva, rajas, and tamas. These — knowledge and so on — will now be described; listen to them properly. The emphasis of the word “only” (eva) in “tridhā eva” is to exclude the Self’s inherent doership etc., apart from the upādhis (limiting adjuncts) of the three guṇas. In the १४th chapter, it was stated: “tatra sattvaṁ nirmalatvāt” and so on, describing how the guṇas bind. In the १७th chapter, the nature of the guṇas was shown by indicating that those in sattva worship gods, etc., and by teaching that through sattvic food and the like, one should develop sattvic nature while rejecting rajas and tamas. But here, the point is to demonstrate that action, its factors, and its results have no connection with the Self, since all of these are made of the guṇas — this is the special purpose to be understood.

18.shlok:
सर्वभूतेषु येनैकं भावमव्ययमीक्षते।
अविभक्तं विभक्तेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि सात्त्विकम्।।१८.२०।।
18.translit:
sarva-bhūteṣu yenaikaṁ bhāvam avyayam īkṣate
avibhaktaṁ vibhakteṣu taj jñānaṁ viddhi sāttvikam
18.translate: That by which one sees the one imperishable reality in all beings, undivided in the divided — know that knowledge to be sāttvika.
18.sridhara: Here, the threefold nature of knowledge — sāttvika, etc. — is explained in the next three verses, starting with “sarva-bhūteṣu.” In all beings — from Brahmā down to immovable life forms — which appear distinct and mutually differentiated, the one undivided (avibhakta), all-pervading, immutable (avyaya), non-transforming reality — the supreme Self — that which sees or discerns that, such knowledge is to be known as sāttvika.

18.shlok:
पृथक्त्वेन तु यज्ज्ञानं नानाभावान्पृथग्विधान्।
वेत्ति सर्वेषु भूतेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि राजसम्।।१८.२१।।
18.translit:
pṛthaktvena tu yaj jñānaṁ nānā-bhāvān pṛthag-vidhān
vetti sarveṣu bhūteṣu taj jñānaṁ viddhi rājasam
18.translate: But that knowledge which sees in all beings various distinct entities, each of separate kinds — know that knowledge to be rājasika.
18.sridhara: Now the rājasika knowledge is explained: “pṛthaktvena iti.” The phrase “pṛthaktvena tu yaj jñānam” is elaborated as follows — in all beings (sarveṣu bhūteṣu), in all bodies, one who perceives many distinct entities (nānā-bhāvān), who are truly many (vastuta eva anekān), many individual knowers of the field (kṣetrajñān), of diverse forms such as happy, unhappy, etc., by means of knowledge which so understands — know that knowledge to be rājasika.

18.shlok:
यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहैतुकम्।
अतत्त्वार्थवदल्पं च तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्।।१८.२२।।
18.translit:
yat tu kṛtsnavad ekasmin kārye saktam ahaitukam
atattvārtha-vad alpam ca tat tāmasam udāhṛtam
18.translate: But that which clings to one single thing as if it were the whole, irrational, lacking in truth, and trivial — that is declared to be tāmasika.
18.sridhara: Now the tāmasika knowledge is explained: “yat tu iti.” That which is attached to one single effect — a body, or a deity form like an idol — as if it were the whole (kṛtsnavat), with the conviction that “this alone is the Self or the Lord,” full of such mistaken belief; which is irrational (ahaitukam), without any logical basis; which is contrary to the real meaning (atattvārthavat), lacking in foundation upon the highest truth — and therefore is meagre (alpam), insignificant, due to its narrow scope and limited fruit — such knowledge is said to be tāmasika.

18.shlok:
नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम्।
अफलप्रेप्सुना कर्म यत्तत्सात्त्विकमुच्यते।।१८.२३।।
18.translit:
niyataṁ saṅga-rahitam arāga-dveṣataḥ kṛtam
aphala-prepsunā karma yat tat sāttvikam ucyate
18.translate: Action that is enjoined, done without attachment, without desire or aversion, by one not seeking results — that is said to be sāttvika.
18.sridhara: Now the threefold nature of action is described: “niyatam” — that which is regularly enjoined, i.e., prescribed as nitya (daily or obligatory); “saṅga-rahitam” — free from attachment or obsession; “arāga-dveṣataḥ” — that which is not done out of affection, like love for one’s son, or out of hatred, like enmity toward an opponent. The action that is thus performed by one who is free from desire (niṣkāma), who does not seek fruit (aphala-prepsunā), such action is declared to be sāttvika.

18.shlok:
यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहङ्कारेण वा पुनः।
क्रियते बहुलायासं तद्राजसमुदाहृतम्।।१८.२४।।
18.translit:
yat tu kāmepsunā karma sāhaṅkāreṇa vā punaḥ
kriyate bahulāyāsaṁ tad rājasam udāhṛtam
18.translate: But that action which is done by one desiring to fulfill desires, or with egoism, and with excessive effort — that is said to be rājasika.
18.sridhara: Now rājasika action is described: “yat tu karma kāmepsunā” — that action which is performed by one desiring its fruit; “sāhaṅkāreṇa vā” — or by one who is possessed of firmly rooted egoism, thinking “Who is equal to me? Who else is such a learned one?”; and “kriyate bahulāyāsam” — that which is executed with excessive exertion and much affliction — such action is said to be rājasika.

18.shlok:
अनुबन्धं क्षयं हिंसामनपेक्ष्य च पौरुषम्।
मोहादारभ्यते कर्म यत्तत्तामसमुच्यते।।१८.२५।।
18.translit:
anubandhaṁ kṣayaṁ hiṁsām anapekṣya ca pauruṣam
mohād ārabhyate karma yat tat tāmasam ucyate
18.translate: That action which is begun out of delusion, without regard for consequences, loss, injury, or one’s own ability — that is said to be tāmasika.
18.sridhara: Now tāmasika action is described: “anubandham” — the future outcome, good or bad, that will follow; “kṣayam” — the expenditure of wealth; “hiṁsām” — harm to others; “pauruṣam” — one’s own ability. Without consideration of all this (anapekṣya), without reflection — that action which is undertaken solely out of delusion (mohāt eva) is said to be tāmasika.

18.shlok:
मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः।
सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योर्निर्विकारः कर्ता सात्त्विक उच्यते।।१८.२६।।
18.translit:
mukta-saṅgo ’nahaṁvādī dhṛtyutsāha-samanvitaḥ
siddhy-asiddhyor nirvikāraḥ kartā sāttvika ucyate
18.translate: One who is free from attachment, not self-conceited, endowed with steadiness and enthusiasm, and unchanged in success or failure—that agent is called sāttvika.
18.sridhara: Now the threefold agent is explained: “mukta-saṅgaḥ” — one who has abandoned attachment; “anahaṁvādī” — free from egoistic assertion; “dhṛtiḥ” — firmness; “utsāhaḥ” — effort or enterprise; “samanvitaḥ” — endowed with both these; “siddhi-asiddhyoḥ” — in success and failure of the action begun; “nirvikāraḥ” — one who remains unaffected, free from elation or dejection — the agent who is such is called sāttvika.

18.shlok:
रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः।
हर्षशोकान्वितः कर्ता राजसः परिकीर्तितः।।१८.२७।।
18.translit:
rāgī karma-phala-prepsur lubdho hiṁsātmako ’śuciḥ
harṣa-śokānvitaḥ kartā rājasaḥ parikīrtitaḥ
18.translate: One who is attached, desirous of the fruit of action, greedy, of harmful nature, impure, and affected by joy and sorrow—such an agent is said to be rājasika.
18.sridhara: Now the rājasika agent is explained: “rāgī” — one who has affection, for example toward a son, etc.; “karma-phala-prepsuḥ” — one who desires the fruit of actions; “lubdhaḥ” — one who covets the possessions of others; “hiṁsātmakaḥ” — of violent nature; “aśuciḥ” — lacking in prescribed purity; “harṣa-śokānvitaḥ” — affected by joy and sorrow in gain and loss—such an agent is said to be rājasika.

18.shlok:
अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकोऽलसः।
विषादी दीर्घसूत्री च कर्ता तामस उच्यते।।१८.२८।।
18.translit:
ayuktaḥ prākṛtaḥ stabdhaḥ śaṭho naiṣkṛtiko ’lasaḥ
viṣādī dīrgha-sūtrī ca kartā tāmasa ucyate
18.translate: The agent who is unsteady, unrefined, arrogant, deceitful, insulting, lazy, gloomy, and procrastinating is called tāmasika.
18.sridhara: Now the tāmasika agent is explained: “ayuktaḥ” — inattentive; “prākṛtaḥ” — devoid of discernment; “stabdhaḥ” — not humble; “śaṭhaḥ” — one who hides his abilities; “naiṣkṛtikaḥ” — one who insults others; “alasaḥ” — lacking in effort; “viṣādī” — sorrowful; “dīrgha-sūtrī” — one who, even though something is to be done today or tomorrow, does not complete it even in a month—an agent who is such is said to be tāmasika. By this threefold classification of the agent, the threefold division of the knower (jñātṛ) is also established. Likewise, from the threefold classification of action, the threefold classification of the knowable (jñeya) should be understood. From the threefold classification of intellect (buddhi), the threefold classification of the instrument (karaṇa) will also be stated.

18.shlok:
बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं श्रृणु।
प्रोच्यमानमशेषेण पृथक्त्वेन धनञ्जय।।१८.२९।।
18.translit:
buddher bhedaṁ dhṛteś caiva guṇatas trividhaṁ śṛṇu
procyamānam aśeṣeṇa pṛthaktvena dhanañjaya
18.translate: Hear from Me the threefold distinction of intellect and fortitude, according to the guṇas, fully and separately, O Dhanañjaya.
18.sridhara: Now the threefold nature of intellect and fortitude is declared: “buddhiḥ iti.” The meaning is self-evident.

18.shlok:
प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये।
बन्धं मोक्षं च या वेत्ति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी।।१८.३०।।
18.translit:
pravṛttiṁ ca nivṛttiṁ ca kāryākārye bhayābhaye
bandhaṁ mokṣaṁ ca yā vetti buddhiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī
18.translate: That intellect which knows engagement and withdrawal, what ought to be done and what ought not, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation—that intellect, O Pārtha, is sāttvika.
18.sridhara: Now the sāttvika intellect is explained: “pravṛttiṁ ca nivṛttiṁ ca”—engagement in dharma, and withdrawal from adharma; what should be done and not done in a particular place and time; “bhaya-abhaye”—the beneficial and the harmful, as causes of action and non-action; “bandham mokṣam ca”—how bondage occurs, and how liberation occurs—“yā buddhir antaḥkaraṇam vetti,” that intellect which knows all these, is sāttvika. Though it should be said, “yaya pumān vetti” (by which a person knows), the instrument is referred to as the agent, just as in the example “the sticks cook” (kaṣṭhāni pacanti), i.e., the sticks are said to cook even though the fire does.

18.shlok:
यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च।
अयथावत्प्रजानाति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ राजसी।।१८.३१।।
18.translit:
yayā dharmam adharmaṁ ca kāryaṁ cākāryam eva ca
ayathāvat prajānāti buddhiḥ sā pārtha rājasī
18.translate: That intellect which understands dharma and adharma, as well as what is to be done and what is not to be done, incorrectly—that intellect, O Pārtha, is rājasika.
18.sridhara: Now the rājasika intellect is described: “yayā iti” — the one by which dharma and adharma, and what is to be done and what is not, are known incorrectly. “Ayathāvat” means in a manner that is doubtful or uncertain. The rest is clear.

18.shlok:
अधर्मं धर्ममिति या मन्यते तमसाऽऽवृता।
सर्वार्थान्विपरीतांश्च बुद्धिः सा पार्थ तामसी।।१८.३२।।
18.translit:
adharmaṁ dharmam iti yā manyate tamasā ’vr̥tā
sarvārthān viparītāṁś ca buddhiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī
18.translate: That intellect, O Pārtha, which, covered by darkness, considers adharma to be dharma and perceives all things in a perverted way—that intellect is tāmasika.
18.sridhara: Now the tāmasika intellect is described: “adharmaṁ iti” — that intellect which grasps the opposite of the truth, is tāmasika. “Buddhiḥ” means the inner organ (antaḥkaraṇa), as was stated earlier. “Jñāna” is a modification (vṛtti) of that. “Dhṛtiḥ” is also a modification of it. Or, since intellect is the dharmī (substrate) of the antaḥkaraṇa, it is said to be a modification because it is characterized by decisive cognition (adhyavasāya). Even though the modifications like desire and aversion are many, this threefold division is made because they are principal as they are the means of dharma, adharma, fear, and fearlessness. And this serves as a representative classification for others.

18.shlok:
धृत्या यया धारयते मनःप्राणेन्द्रियक्रियाः।
योगेनाव्यभिचारिण्या धृतिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी।।१८.३३।।
18.translit:
dhṛtyā yayā dhārayate manaḥ-prāṇendriya-kriyāḥ
yogenāvyabhicāriṇyā dhṛtiḥ sā pārtha sāttvikī
18.translate: The firmness by which the functions of the mind, life-force, and senses are held with unwavering discipline through yoga—that firmness, O Pārtha, is sāttvika.
18.sridhara: Now the threefold nature of firmness (dhṛti) is described: “dhṛtyā iti” — by the firmness which, through yoga, meaning through the cause of mental concentration (citta-ekāgrya), unwavering and not deviating toward other objects, one restrains the functions of the mind, life-force (prāṇa), and senses — that firmness is sāttvika.

18.shlok:
यया तु धर्मकामार्थान् धृत्या धारयतेऽर्जुन।
प्रसङ्गेन फलाकाङ्क्षी धृतिः सा पार्थ राजसी।।१८.३४।।
18.translit:
yayā tu dharma-kāmārthān dhṛtyā dhārayate ’rjuna
prasaṅgena phalākāṅkṣī dhṛtiḥ sā pārtha rājasī
18.translate: But the firmness by which, O Arjuna, one holds to dharma, kāma, and artha out of attachment and with desire for fruit—that firmness, O Pārtha, is rājasika.
18.sridhara: Now the rājasika firmness is described: “yayā tu dhṛtyā” — by that firmness one holds to dharma, artha, and kāma, predominantly and does not abandon them; and, due to attachment to them, becomes desirous of the result — that firmness is rājasika.

18.shlok:
यया स्वप्नं भयं शोकं विषादं मदमेव च।
न विमुञ्चति दुर्मेधा धृतिः सा पार्थ तामसी।।१८.३५।।
18.translit:
yayā svapnaṁ bhayaṁ śokaṁ viṣādaṁ madam eva ca
na vimuñcati durmedhā dhṛtiḥ sā pārtha tāmasī
18.translate: That firmness by which a person of corrupted intellect does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, depression, and pride—that firmness, O Pārtha, is tāmasika.
18.sridhara: Now the tāmasika firmness is described: “yayā iti” — the person whose intellect (medhā) is corrupted and full of non-discrimination (duṣṭā aviveka-bahulā), and who, by that firmness, does not give up sleep and so on, but repeats them again and again — “svapna” here means sleep — that firmness is tāmasika.

18.shlok:
सुखं त्विदानीं त्रिविधं श्रृणु मे भरतर्षभ।
अभ्यासाद्रमते यत्र दुःखान्तं च निगच्छति।।१८.३६।।
18.translit:
sukhaṁ tv idānīṁ trividhaṁ śṛṇu me bharatarṣabha
abhyāsād ramate yatra duḥkhāntaṁ ca nigacchati
18.translate: Now hear from Me, O best of the Bhāratas, the threefold happiness, in which one delights through practice and which leads to the end of sorrow.
18.sridhara: Now He introduces the threefold division of happiness: “sukham iti.” The meaning is clear. Among these, He now describes sāttvika happiness: “abhyāsād iti sārdhena.” That happiness in which one delights through constant practice—not like sense pleasure, which brings delight immediately—, and by delighting in which one thoroughly attains the end (cessation) of sorrow—that is what is described.

18.shlok:
यत्तदग्रे विषमिव परिणामेऽमृतोपमम्।
तत्सुखं सात्त्विकं प्रोक्तमात्मबुद्धिप्रसादजम्।।१८.३७।।
18.translit:
yat tad agre viṣam iva pariṇāme ’mṛtopamam
tat sukhaṁ sāttvikaṁ proktam ātma-buddhi-prasādajam
18.translate: That which is like poison at first, but like nectar in the end—that happiness is said to be sāttvika, born of the clarity of the intellect directed toward the Self.
18.sridhara: What kind of happiness is that? “Yat tad iti”—that which, at first (agre), due to being dependent on mental discipline, appears painful like poison. But in the end, it becomes like nectar. It is born of the clarity (prasāda) of the intellect (buddhi) directed toward the Self (ātma-buddhi), meaning, it arises from the purification that results from the elimination of the impurities of rajas and tamas, and from the state of inner clarity. That happiness is declared to be sāttvika by the yogis.

18.shlok:
विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगाद्यत्तदग्रेऽमृतोपमम्।
परिणामे विषमिव तत्सुखं राजसं स्मृतम्।।१८.३८।।
18.translit:
viṣayendriya-saṁyogād yat tad agre ’mṛtopamam
pariṇāme viṣam iva tat sukhaṁ rājasaṁ smṛtam
18.translate: That happiness which arises from contact between the senses and sense-objects, which is like nectar at first, but like poison in the end—that is remembered as rājasika happiness.
18.sridhara: Now the rājasika happiness is described: “viṣayendriyeti”—that happiness arising from the contact of the senses and their objects, such as enjoyment of women and so on, which is popularly regarded as happiness. That happiness, which at first (agre) appears like nectar, but in the end (pariṇāme) becomes like poison due to being a cause of sorrow in this world and the next—that happiness is remembered as rājasika.

18.shlok:
यदग्रे चानुबन्धे च सुखं मोहनमात्मनः।
निद्रालस्यप्रमादोत्थं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम्।।१८.३९।।
18.translit:
yad agre cānubandhe ca sukhaṁ mohanam ātmanaḥ
nidrālasya-pramādotthaṁ tat tāmasaṁ udāhṛtam
18.translate: That happiness which both at the beginning and in consequence deludes the self, arising from sleep, laziness, and negligence—that is said to be tāmasika.
18.sridhara: Now tāmasika happiness is described: “yad iti”—that happiness which deludes the self both at the beginning (agre) and in the end (anubandhe). That is explained further: arising from sleep, laziness, and negligence. “Nidrā” is sleep; “ālasyam” is inertia; “pramāda” is mental heedlessness due to lack of attentiveness to what ought to be done, and indulgence in fanciful thinking. The happiness arising from these—that is said to be tāmasika.

18.shlok:
न तदस्ति पृथिव्यां वा दिवि देवेषु वा पुनः।
सत्त्वं प्रकृतिजैर्मुक्तं यदेभिः स्यात्त्रिभिर्गुणैः।।१८.४०।।
18.translit:
na tad asti pṛthivyāṁ vā divi deveṣu vā punaḥ
sattvaṁ prakṛti-jair muktaṁ yad ebhiḥ syāt tribhir guṇaiḥ
18.translate: There is no entity on earth, or again among the gods in heaven, that is free from the three guṇas born of prakṛti.
18.sridhara: Although not stated before, the subject is now summarized to serve the context of the discussion: “na tad asti iti”—there is no being, whether on earth among humans, or in heaven among the gods, which exists free from (muktaṁ), that is, devoid of the three guṇas—sattva, rajas, and tamas—which arise from prakṛti, the primordial nature.

18.shlok:
ब्राह्मणक्षत्रियविशां शूद्राणां च परंतप।
कर्माणि प्रविभक्तानि स्वभावप्रभवैर्गुणैः।।१८.४१।।
18.translit:
brāhmaṇa-kṣatriya-viśāṁ śūdrāṇāṁ ca paraṁtapa
karmāṇi pravibhaktāni svabhāva-prabhavair guṇaiḥ
18.translate: The duties of Brāhmaṇas, Kṣatriyas, Vaiśyas, and Śūdras, O scorcher of foes, are divided according to the guṇas born of their respective natures.
18.sridhara:
Now, one might ask: “If all action, agents, instruments, results, and even all beings are constituted of the three guṇas, then how can there be mokṣa?” To answer this, and to briefly indicate the essence of the entire Gītā—namely, that mokṣa is attained through knowledge gained by the grace of the Supreme Lord, which arises from worshipping Him through one's prescribed duties in accordance with one's qualification—a new section is commenced from this verse until the end of the chapter: “brāhmaṇa–” and so on.

O scorcher of foes! The duties of Brāhmaṇas, Kṣatriyas, Vaiśyas, and Śūdras are pravibhaktāni—clearly divided and prescribed according to their own nature. The duties of Śūdras are mentioned separately due to their distinct nature from the twice-born, by absence of Brāhminhood, etc. The basis of these divisions is now mentioned—svabhāvaḥ, which means the predominance of sattva, etc., arises (prabhavati) from these guṇas. Alternatively, svabhāva refers to the impressions from past births (pūrvajanma-saṁskāra), and the guṇas are those which arise from that.

Among them, those with predominance of sattva are Brāhmaṇas; those with predominance of rajas with sattva subordinate are Kṣatriyas; those with predominance of rajas with tamas subordinate are Vaiśyas; and those with predominance of tamas with rajas subordinate are Śūdras.

18.shlok:
शमो दमस्तपः शौचं क्षान्तिरार्जवमेव च।
ज्ञानं विज्ञानमास्तिक्यं ब्रह्मकर्म स्वभावजम्।।१८.४२।।
18.translit:
śamo damaḥ tapaḥ śaucaṁ kṣāntir ārjavam eva ca
jñānaṁ vijñānam āstikyaṁ brahma-karma svabhāva-jam
18.translate: Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, straightforwardness, knowledge, realization, and faith—these are the duties of a Brāhmaṇa, born of their nature.
18.sridhara:
Now, the natural duties (svābhāvikāni karmāṇi) of the Brāhmaṇa are described: “śamaḥ” and so on.

Śama is the quietude of the mind.
Dama is the restraint of the external senses.
Tapaḥ is the previously mentioned austerity of the body, speech, and mind.
Śauca is both external and internal purity.
Kṣāntiḥ is forgiveness.
Ārjavam is straightforwardness or absence of crookedness.
Jñānam is scriptural knowledge.
Vijñānam is direct realization.
Āstikyam is the firm conviction in the existence of the other world (i.e., faith in dharma, mokṣa, and God).

These qualities such as śama, etc., constitute the natural duty of a Brāhmaṇa, arising from their nature.

18.shlok:
शौर्यं तेजो धृतिर्दाक्ष्यं युद्धे चाप्यपलायनम्।
दानमीश्वरभावश्च क्षात्रं कर्म स्वभावजम्।।१८.४३।।
18.translit:
śauryaṁ tejo dhṛtir dākṣyaṁ yuddhe cāpy apalāyanam
dānam īśvara-bhāvaś ca kṣātraṁ karma svabhāva-jam
18.translate: Heroism, boldness, fortitude, skill, and also not fleeing in battle, generosity, and lordliness—these are the duties of a Kṣatriya, born of their nature.
18.sridhara:
