Now, the natural duties of a Kṣatriya are described: “śauryam” and so on.

Śaurya is bravery or prowess.
Tejas is spiritedness or boldness.
Dhṛti is steadfastness or fortitude.
Dākṣyam is skill.
Apalāyanaṁ is not turning away from battle.
Dānam is generosity.
Īśvara-bhāvaḥ is the power or capacity to govern.

These are the natural duties of a Kṣatriya, born of his nature.

18.shlok:
कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यं वैश्यकर्म स्वभावजम्।
परिचर्यात्मकं कर्म शूद्रस्यापि स्वभावजम्।।१८.४४।।
18.translit:
kṛṣi-gau-rakṣya-vāṇijyaṁ vaiśya-karma svabhāva-jam
paricaryātmakaṁ karma śūdrasyāpi svabhāva-jam
18.translate: Agriculture, cow protection, and trade are the duties of a Vaiśya, born of his nature; and service-oriented action is the duty of a Śūdra, also born of his nature.
18.sridhara:
Now the duties of Vaiśyas and Śūdras are described: “kṛṣir” and so on.

Kṛṣi is ploughing or cultivation.
Gaurakṣyam is protection of cows—i.e., cattle-rearing.
Vāṇijyam is buying and selling, etc.—i.e., commerce.

These are the natural duties of a Vaiśya.

The Śūdra's natural duty consists in service to the three higher castes.

18.shlok:
स्वे स्वे कर्मण्यभिरतः संसिद्धिं लभते नरः।
स्वकर्मनिरतः सिद्धिं यथा विन्दति तच्छृणु।।१८.४५।।
18.translit:
sve sve karmaṇy abhirataḥ saṁsiddhiṁ labhate naraḥ
sva-karma-nirataḥ siddhiṁ yathā vindati tac chṛṇu
18.translate: A person devoted to his own duty attains perfection. Hear now how, being engaged in his own duty, he attains success.
18.sridhara:
Now it is stated how the Brāhmaṇa's and others’ respective actions become causes of knowledge: “sve sve iti”—a person who is fully devoted (abhirataḥ) to his own prescribed duties, which are enjoined according to one’s eligibility (svādhi-kāra), attains saṁsiddhi, that is, fitness for knowledge.

Then, beginning with “svakarma–” He explains the way (prakāra) by which such a person, firmly engaged in his own duties, obtains knowledge of the Reality (tattva-jñāna): “Hear that method.”

18.shlok:
यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम्।
स्वकर्मणा तमभ्यर्च्य सिद्धिं विन्दति मानवः।।१८.४६।।
18.translit:
yataḥ pravṛttir bhūtānāṁ yena sarvam idaṁ tatam
svakarmaṇā tam abhyarcya siddhiṁ vindati mānavaḥ
18.translate: From whom arises the activity of all beings, and by whom all this is pervaded—by worshipping Him through one’s own duty, a human attains perfection.
18.sridhara: He (the person) worships that very Lord—“yataḥ,” from whom, as the inner controller, all activities of beings arise, and “yena,” by whom, in the causal form, this entire universe is pervaded and permeated. By worshipping that Lord through one’s own prescribed duty (svakarmaṇā), a human being attains perfection (siddhi).

18.shlok:
श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्।
स्वभावनियतं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम्।।१८.४७।।
18.translit:
śreyān svadharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt sv-anuṣṭhitāt
svabhāva-niyataṁ karma kurvan nāpnoti kilbiṣam
18.translate: Better is one’s own duty, though devoid of qualities, than another’s duty well performed. By doing the duty prescribed by one’s nature, one does not incur sin.
18.sridhara:
Now the fruit of the special qualifier “by one’s own duty” (svakarmaṇā) is stated: śreyān iti—one’s own dharma, though deficient in qualities (viguṇaḥ), is better than another’s duty well performed (samyak-anuṣṭhitāt).
And one should not think that the path of begging (as a renunciate), which involves non-violence, is better than one’s own dharma of fighting, which involves killing of relatives and others.
Why? Because performing the action determined by one’s nature (svabhāva-niyataṁ karma), as described earlier, one does not incur sin (kilbiṣam).

18.shlok:
सहजं कर्म कौन्तेय सदोषमपि न त्यजेत्।
सर्वारम्भा हि दोषेण धूमेनाग्निरिवावृताः।।१८.४८।।
18.translit:
sahajaṁ karma kaunteya sadoṣam api na tyajet
sarvārambhā hi doṣeṇa dhūmenāgnir ivāvṛtāḥ
18.translate: One should not abandon one’s natural duty, O Kaunteya, even though it may be faulty; for all undertakings are enveloped by fault, just as fire is covered by smoke.
18.sridhara:
If, from the perspective of the sāṅkhya philosophy (which emphasizes renunciation), you consider your own duty, which involves violence, to be faulty, and thus regard the duty of another as superior, then, with the intent of showing that fault is equally present in other duties as well, it is said: sahajam iti.

One should not abandon one’s natural, inherent duty (sahajaṁ karma), even though it may be faulty. Why? Because all undertakings, whether yielding visible or invisible results, are indeed covered by some fault. Just as fire is naturally enveloped by smoke, so too is action covered by some defect.
Hence, just as one accepts fire despite the smoke for removing darkness, cold, etc., similarly, one should accept the good parts of action, discarding its faults, for the sake of purification of the mind (sattva-śuddhi).

18.shlok:
असक्तबुद्धिः सर्वत्र जितात्मा विगतस्पृहः।
नैष्कर्म्यसिद्धिं परमां संन्यासेनाधिगच्छति।।१८.४९।।
18.translit:
asakta-buddhiḥ sarvatra jitātmā vigata-spṛhaḥ
naiṣkarmya-siddhiṁ paramāṁ saṁnyāsenādhigacchati
18.translate: He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has mastered himself, and is free from desire—through renunciation he attains the supreme perfection of freedom from action.
18.sridhara:
Now, in anticipation of the question: “How can one attain only the good aspects of karma by abandoning its faults?”—this is addressed by asakta iti.
He whose intellect is unattached (asaktā, devoid of attachment), whose self is mastered (jitātmā, free from ego), and who is free from desire for the fruits of action (vigata-spṛhaḥ), such a person—by renunciation (saṁnyāsa) marked by giving up attachment and the desire for fruits of action, which was already described as sattvic renunciation—attains naiṣkarmya-siddhi, the perfection of non-action, characterized by complete cessation of all karma and purification of the mind (sattva-śuddhi).

Although action done without attachment and desire for fruit is itself non-action, due to absence of the doer’s ego (kartṛtvābhimāna), as already stated earlier (e.g., “naiva kiñcit karomīti…” in verse ५.८ and the four verses following it), still, by renunciation in this manner, one attains the supreme perfection of non-action (paramāṁ naiṣkarmya-siddhim)—that which is described as: “Having renounced all actions in the mind, the self-controlled one rests happily” (५.१३), which is synonymous with the highest state of the Paramahaṁsa.

18.shlok:
सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे।
समासेनैव कौन्तेय निष्ठा ज्ञानस्य या परा।।१८.५०।।
18.translit:
siddhiṁ prāpto yathā brahma tathāpnoti nibodha me
samāsenaiva kaunteya niṣṭhā jñānasya yā parā
18.translate: How one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman—learn that from Me briefly, O Kaunteya, that supreme consummation of knowledge.
18.sridhara:
Now the process by which the paramahaṁsa—one who has attained naiṣkarmya-siddhi—reaches Brahman through steadfastness in knowledge (jñāna-niṣṭhā) is taught in the next six verses, beginning here.

Having attained naiṣkarmya-siddhi, the way in which one reaches Brahman—learn that way from Me briefly.

18.shlok:
बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्याऽऽत्मानं नियम्य च।
शब्दादीन् विषयांस्त्यक्त्वा रागद्वेषौ व्युदस्य च।।१८.५१।।
18.translit:
buddhyā viśuddhayā yukto dhṛtyā''tmānaṁ niyamya ca
śabdādīn viṣayāṁs tyaktvā rāgadveṣau vyudasya ca
18.translate: Endowed with purified intellect, controlling the self with firmness, having abandoned the sense-objects beginning with sound, and having cast off attraction and aversion—
18.sridhara: This is further explained — “buddhyā” etc. Endowed with purified intellect — that sāttvika intellect described earlier. Controlling the self — that very intellect — by sāttvika firmness, making it steady; abandoning the sense-objects beginning with sound, and casting off the attachment and aversion toward them. The phrase “endowed with purified intellect…” is to be connected with “becomes fit for Brahmanhood” (brahmabhūyāya kalpate) in verse १८.५३ through the third verse’s construction.

18.shlok:
विविक्तसेवी लघ्वाशी यतवाक्कायमानसः।
ध्यानयोगपरो नित्यं वैराग्यं समुपाश्रितः।।१८.५२।।
18.translit:
viviktasevī laghvāśī yatavākkāyamānasaḥ
dhyānayogaparo nityaṁ vairāgyaṁ samupāśritaḥ
18.translate: Dwelling in solitude, eating little, with speech, body, and mind restrained; always intent upon the yoga of meditation, having fully resorted to dispassion—
18.sridhara: Furthermore — “viviktasevī” etc. Residing in pure places (viviktasevī), eating little (laghvāśī), by these means becoming one whose speech, body, and mind are restrained (yatavākkāyamānasaḥ). Always — at all times — intent upon that yoga which is contact with Brahman through meditation; having well and firmly resorted again and again to dispassion in order to avoid interruption of meditation.

18.shlok:
अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं परिग्रहम्।
विमुच्य निर्ममः शान्तो ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते।।१८.५३।।
18.translit:
ahaṅkāraṁ balaṁ darpaṁ kāmaṁ krodhaṁ parigraham
vimucya nirmamaḥ śānto brahmabhūyāya kalpate
18.translate: Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger, and possessiveness, becoming free from the notion of ‘mine’ and peaceful—he becomes fit for Brahmanhood.
18.sridhara: Furthermore — “ahaṅkāram” etc. Being thus dispassionate, he abandons egoism beginning with the idea “I am such and such,” stubbornness (bala), and arrogance — the tendency to deviate from the right path due to the strength of yoga. Even in the case of objects that come due to destiny (prārabdha), he gives up desire (kāma), anger (krodha), and possessiveness (parigraha) — having thoroughly renounced them. Even when forcibly obtained, becoming free from the sense of “mine” (nirmamaḥ), peaceful (śāntaḥ), having attained supreme calm, he becomes fit for the unshakable state of “I am Brahman” — i.e., for firm abidance in Brahman.

18.shlok:
ब्रह्मभूतः प्रसन्नात्मा न शोचति न काङ्क्षति।
समः सर्वेषु भूतेषु मद्भक्तिं लभते पराम्।।१८.५४।।
18.translit:
brahmabhūtaḥ prasannātmā na śocati na kāṅkṣati
samaḥ sarveṣu bhūteṣu madbhaktiṁ labhate parām
18.translate: Becoming Brahman, serene in the self, he neither grieves nor desires; being equal to all beings, he attains supreme devotion to Me.
18.sridhara: The result of unwavering abidance in the state “I am Brahman” is now stated — “brahmabhūtaḥ” etc. Becoming Brahman — abiding in Brahman — and serene in mind, he does not grieve over what is lost. Nor does he desire what is not obtained, due to the absence of identification with the body and so on. Thus, being equal toward all beings — due to the absence of disturbance caused by attachment and aversion — he attains supreme devotion to Me, marked by constant contemplation of Me in all beings.

18.shlok:
भक्त्या मामभिजानाति यावान्यश्चास्मि तत्त्वतः।
ततो मां तत्त्वतो ज्ञात्वा विशते तदनन्तरम्।।१८.५५।।
18.translit:
bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaś cāsmi tattvataḥ
tato māṁ tattvato jñātvā viśate tad-anantaram
18.translate: By devotion, he knows Me—how great I am and who I am—in truth. Then, having known Me truly, he enters into Me thereafter.
18.sridhara: Then — “bhaktyā mām” etc. By that supreme devotion, he knows Me in truth. How so? He knows Me as I truly am—how great I am, and what I am: of the nature of existence, consciousness, and bliss (sat-cit-ānanda), and all-pervading. And having thus known Me in truth, then, upon the cessation even of that knowledge, he enters into Me—he becomes of the nature of supreme bliss.

18.shlok:
सर्वकर्माण्यपि सदा कुर्वाणो मद्व्यपाश्रयः।
मत्प्रसादादवाप्नोति शाश्वतं पदमव्ययम्।।१८.५६।।
18.translit:
sarvakarmāṇy api sadā kurvāṇo madvyapāśrayaḥ
matprasādād avāpnoti śāśvataṁ padam avyayam
18.translate: Even while always performing all actions, one who has taken refuge in Me attains, by My grace, the eternal and imperishable state.
18.sridhara: The method of liberation through worship of the Supreme Lord by one’s own duties is now concluded — “sarvakarmāṇi” etc. Performing all actions—nitya (daily), naimittika (occasional), and kāmya (desire-motivated)—in the previously described manner, taking refuge in Me, that is, regarding Me alone as the one to be resorted to, not seeking fruits like heaven, such a person attains, by My grace, the eternal (without beginning), imperishable, supremely excellent Vaiṣṇava state.

18.shlok:
चेतसा सर्वकर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्परः।
बुद्धियोगमुपाश्रित्य मच्चित्तः सततं भव।।१८.५७।।
18.translit:
cetasā sarvakarmāṇi mayi saṁnyasya matparaḥ
buddhiyogam upāśritya maccittaḥ satataṁ bhava
18.translate: Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, considering Me as the Supreme, resorting to the yoga of understanding, become one whose mind is always fixed on Me.
18.sridhara: Since this is so, therefore — “cetasā” etc. Mentally renouncing all actions into Me—offering them to Me—being mat-paraḥ, one for whom I alone am the Supreme, the ultimate goal and the puruṣārtha (human aim), resorting to the yoga of firm intellect (vyavasāyātmikā buddhi), during the time of performing actions as well, become one whose mind is always fixed on Me, following the logic: “the oblation is Brahman, the offering is Brahman,” etc.

18.shlok:
मच्चित्तः सर्वदुर्गाणि मत्प्रसादात्तरिष्यसि।
अथ चेत्त्वमहङ्कारान्न श्रोष्यसि विनङ्क्ष्यसि।।१८.५८।।
18.translit:
maccittaḥ sarvadurgāṇi matprasādāt tariṣyasi
atha ced tvam ahaṅkārān na śroṣyasi vinaṅkṣyasi
18.translate: Fixing your mind on Me, you will cross over all obstacles by My grace. But if, out of egoism, you do not listen, you will perish.
18.sridhara: Now hear what will happen as a result — “maccittaḥ” etc. Fixing your mind on Me, you will cross over all difficult worldly miseries by My grace. As the opposite case, the defect is stated: “But if again, due to egoism”—from the delusion of being the knower—“you do not listen to this instruction of Mine, then you will perish,” that is, you will fall away from the puruṣārtha (supreme goal).

18.shlok:
यदहङ्कारमाश्रित्य न योत्स्य इति मन्यसे।
मिथ्यैष व्यवसायस्ते प्रकृतिस्त्वां नियोक्ष्यति।।१८.५९।।
18.translit:
yad ahaṅkāram āśritya na yotsya iti manyase
mithyaiṣa vyavasāyas te prakṛtis tvāṁ niyokṣyati
18.translate: If, resorting to egoism, you think “I will not fight,” this resolve of yours is in vain; your nature will compel you.
18.sridhara: If you say, “Let me perish, but I will not fight against my relatives,” to that he says — “yad ahaṅkāram āśritya” etc. Disregarding My instruction and resorting only to egoism, if you think “I will not fight,” this resolve of yours is indeed false, because you are not independent. Therefore, it is said: your nature (prakṛti), having matured in the form of rajo-guṇa, will impel you to action—it will surely make you act in battle.

18.shlok:
स्वभावजेन कौन्तेय निबद्धः स्वेन कर्मणा।
कर्तुं नेच्छसि यन्मोहात्करिष्यस्यवशोऽपि तत्।।१८.६०।।
18.translit:
svabhāvajena kaunteya nibaddhaḥ svena karmaṇā
kartuṁ necchasi yan mohāt kariṣyasy avaśo’pi tat
18.translate: O Kaunteya, bound by your own action born of your nature, that which, out of delusion, you do not wish to do—you shall do that even against your will.
18.sridhara: Furthermore — “svabhāvajena” etc. Your svabhāva, which is the cause of your being a kṣatriya, is the impression from previous karma. Bound by that very karma born of it—by qualities like valor described earlier—you are not independent. What you do not wish to do due to delusion—that action, which is of the nature of battle—you will perform even unwillingly.

18.shlok:
ईश्वरः सर्वभूतानां हृद्देशेऽर्जुन तिष्ठति।
भ्रामयन्सर्वभूतानि यन्त्रारूढानि मायया।।१८.६१।।
18.translit:
īśvaraḥ sarvabhūtānāṁ hṛddeśe’rjuna tiṣṭhati
bhrāmayan sarvabhūtāni yantrārūḍhāni māyayā
18.translate: The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, causing all beings to revolve by His māyā, as if mounted on a machine.
18.sridhara: Thus, in the previous two verses, dependence on prakṛti according to the sāṅkhya view was explained—subservience to one's nature (svabhāva) and action (karma). Now His own view is stated in two verses, beginning with “īśvaraḥ”. The Lord, as the indwelling controller (antaryāmin), abides in the heart of all beings. What does He do? Causing all beings to revolve through māyā—His own power—He engages them in their respective actions. Just as in the world, a puppeteer causes wooden dolls mounted on a machine to move, so too here. Or else, “machines” means bodies, and beings mounted on them—those jīvas who identify with the body—He causes to revolve. Thus the Śvetāśvatara Mantra says: “The One Lord, hidden in all beings, all-pervading, the inner Self of all beings… the overseer of karma, the indweller of all beings, the witness, the knower, the one alone, devoid of guṇas.” And the Antaryāmin Brāhmaṇa declares: “He who, dwelling in the self, controls the self from within… this is the immortal inner controller.”

18.shlok:
तमेव शरणं गच्छ सर्वभावेन भारत।
तत्प्रसादात्परां शान्तिं स्थानं प्राप्स्यसि शाश्वतम्।।१८.६२।।
18.translit:
tam eva śaraṇaṁ gaccha sarvabhāvena bhārata
tatprasādāt parāṁ śāntiṁ sthānaṁ prāpsyasi śāśvatam
18.translate: Go to Him alone for refuge with your whole being, O Bhārata. By His grace, you will attain supreme peace and the eternal abode.
18.sridhara: Since all beings are dependent on the Supreme Lord, therefore, abandoning ego, take refuge in that very Lord with your whole being—with all your self. Then, by His grace, you shall attain the highest tranquility (supreme peace) and the eternal abode which belongs to the Supreme Lord.

18.shlok:
इति ते ज्ञानमाख्यातं गुह्याद्गुह्यतरं मया।
विमृश्यैतदशेषेण यथेच्छसि तथा कुरु।।१८.६३।।
18.translit:
iti te jñānam ākhyātaṁ guhyād guhyataraṁ mayā
vimṛśyaitad aśeṣeṇa yathecchasi tathā kuru
18.translate: Thus, to you has knowledge—more secret than even the secret—been declared by Me. Reflect fully upon it, and then do as you wish.
18.sridhara: Bringing together the meaning of the entire Gītā, He says — “iti” etc. In this manner, this knowledge has been taught to you by Me, the omniscient and supremely compassionate one. How is it? More secret than all other secret knowledge like mantras, meditation, yoga, etc.—this Gītā-śāstra has been taught by Me. Reflect fully upon it, and afterward act as you wish. The sense is that once this is thoroughly contemplated, your delusion will be dispelled.

18.shlok:
सर्वगुह्यतमं भूयः श्रृणु मे परमं वचः।
इष्टोऽसि मे दृढमिति ततो वक्ष्यामि ते हितम्।।१८.६४।।
18.translit:
sarvaguhyatamaṁ bhūyaḥ śṛṇu me paramaṁ vacaḥ
iṣṭo’si me dṛḍham iti tato vakṣyāmi te hitam
18.translate: Hear again My supreme word, the most secret of all. Because you are very dear to Me, I will speak what is beneficial to you.
18.sridhara: For one who is unable to deeply reflect upon the exceedingly profound Gītā-śāstra in its entirety, out of compassion, He now summarizes its essence—“sarvaguhyatamam” etc. My teaching, more secret than all secrets, though already taught here and there, is now again to be heard, repeated again and again. The reason for this repetition is stated: Because you are exceedingly dear to Me, therefore I shall speak what is beneficial to you. Alternatively, since you are dear to Me, and what I speak is certain and fully supported by all means of knowledge, therefore I shall declare it to you. (Some read “dṛḍhamatir” instead of “dṛḍham iti”.)

18.shlok:
मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु।
मामेवैष्यसि सत्यं ते प्रतिजाने प्रियोऽसि मे।।१८.६५।।
18.translit:
manmanā bhava madbhakto madyājī māṁ namaskuru
mām evaiṣyasi satyaṁ te pratijāne priyo’si me
18.translate: Fix your mind on Me, be devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow to Me. You shall come to Me alone—this is truth—I promise you, for you are dear to Me.
18.sridhara: He states it again — “manmanā” etc. Be one whose mind is fixed on Me—have your thought on Me. Be My devotee—be devoted to Me alone. Be My worshipper—one who sacrifices to Me. Bow down to Me. Being thus, by My grace and with the knowledge attained, you will come to Me alone—you shall attain Me. Do not entertain any doubt in this. For you are dear to Me; therefore, this is the truth—I make a promise to you.

18.shlok:
सर्वधर्मान्परित्यज्य मामेकं शरणं व्रज।
अहं त्वा सर्वपापेभ्यो मोक्षयिष्यामि मा शुचः।।१८.६६।।
18.translit:
sarvadharmān parityajya māmekam śaraṇaṁ vraja
ahaṁ tvā sarvapāpebhyo mokṣayiṣyāmi mā śucah
18.translate: Abandoning all dharmas, take refuge in Me alone; I shall liberate you from all sins—do not grieve.
18.sridhara: Now, that which is even more secret than all that has been said is stated—“sarvadharmān parityajya”. With firm conviction that everything will be accomplished by devotion to Me alone, give up the multiplicity of ritualistic obligations and become one who takes refuge in Me alone. Being thus situated, if some sin were to arise due to renouncing actions, do not grieve—do not fall into sorrow. For I shall liberate you, who have taken exclusive refuge in Me, from all sins.

18.shlok:
इदं ते नातपस्काय नाभक्ताय कदाचन।
न चाशुश्रूषवे वाच्यं न च मां योऽभ्यसूयति।।१८.६७।।
18.translit:
idaṁ te nātapaskāya nābhaktāya kadācana
na cāśuśrūṣave vācyaṁ na ca māṁ yo’bhyasūyati
18.translate: This is never to be spoken by you to one who is without austerity, nor to one who lacks devotion, nor to one who is not willing to listen, nor to one who finds fault with Me.
18.sridhara: Having taught the truth of the meaning of the Gītā, a rule is given regarding its transmission — “idaṁ te”. This truth of the Gītā’s meaning should not be spoken by you to one who lacks austerity—that is, one devoid of commitment to their own dharma. Nor should it ever be spoken to one who is devoid of devotion to the Guru and the Lord. Nor to one unwilling to listen, who does not serve or attend. Nor to one who finds fault with Me, the Supreme Lord—who reviles Me by projecting human faults.

18.shlok:
य इमं परमं गुह्यं मद्भक्तेष्वभिधास्यति।
भक्ितं मयि परां कृत्वा मामेवैष्यत्यसंशयः।।१८.६८।।
18.translit:
ya imaṁ paramaṁ guhyaṁ madbhakteṣv abhidhāsyati
bhaktiṁ mayi parāṁ kṛtvā mām evaiṣyaty asaṁśayaḥ
18.translate: Whoever teaches this supreme secret to My devotees, showing supreme devotion to Me, shall come to Me without doubt.
18.sridhara: The fruit of teaching the Gītā-śāstra to devotees, free from the previously mentioned faults, is stated — “ya imaṁ”. One who speaks this to My devotees—such a person performs supreme devotion to Me. Therefore, without doubt, he attains Me.

18.shlok:
न च तस्मान्मनुष्येषु कश्िचन्मे प्रियकृत्तमः।
भविता न च मे तस्मादन्यः प्रियतरो भुवि।।१८.६९।।
18.translit:
na ca tasmān manuṣyeṣu kaścin me priyakṛttamaḥ
bhavitā na ca me tasmād anyaḥ priyataro bhuvi
18.translate: Nor is there anyone among humans who does dearer service to Me; nor shall there be any other on earth more dear to Me than he.
18.sridhara: Moreover — “na ca tasmāt”. Among men, there is no one who renders greater service to Me than he who teaches the Gītā-śāstra to My devotees. Nor will there be anyone in the future more dear to Me than he. And even now, there is no one on earth dearer to Me than he.

18.shlok:
अध्येष्यते च य इमं धर्म्यं संवादमावयोः।
ज्ञानयज्ञेन तेनाहमिष्टः स्यामिति मे मतिः।।१८.७०।।
18.translit:
adhyeṣyate ca ya imaṁ dharmyaṁ saṁvādam āvayoḥ
jñānayajñena tenāham iṣṭaḥ syām iti me matiḥ
18.translate: And he who studies this righteous dialogue between us—by that knowledge-sacrifice, I am worshipped by him—such is My conviction.
18.sridhara: The fruit of studying is stated — “adhyeṣyate”. One who studies this righteous dialogue between us—Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna—this discourse which is not opposed to dharma, who recites it like a japa—by such a person I am worshipped through the jñāna-yajña, the highest of all sacrifices. Even if he does not understand the meaning of the Gītā and simply recites it, My conviction is that by hearing it, he reveals Me. Just as in the world, someone randomly calls out another’s name and that person responds, thinking, “He is calling Me”, I too become present to that person. That is why I was pleased even with Ajamila and others like him, such as the kṣatriya-bandhu, who merely uttered My name. Likewise, I become pleased with this one too.

18.shlok:
श्रद्धावाननसूयश्च श्रृणुयादपि यो नरः।
सोऽपि मुक्तः शुभाँल्लोकान्प्राप्नुयात्पुण्यकर्मणाम्।।१८.७१।।
18.translit:
śraddhāvān anasūyaś ca śṛṇuyād api yo naraḥ
so’pi muktaḥ śubhāñl lokān prāpnuyāt puṇyakarmaṇām
18.translate: Even the man who listens with faith and without envy—he too, being liberated, attains the auspicious worlds of the righteous.
18.sridhara: The fruit for one who listens while another recites is stated—“śraddhāvān iti”. The man who, endowed with faith, simply listens—just this much is praised. To preclude the objection, “Why is he chanting improperly, without order?” or “He recites it incorrectly,” the next word is given: “anasūyaś ca”—free from fault-finding. One who listens in this way, being freed from all sins, attains the auspicious worlds attained by performers of great meritorious acts such as the Aśvamedha sacrifice.

18.shlok:
कच्चिदेतच्छ्रुतं पार्थ त्वयैकाग्रेण चेतसा।
कच्चिदज्ञानसंमोहः प्रनष्टस्ते धनञ्जय।।१८.७२।।
18.translit:
kaccid etac chrutaṁ pārtha tvayaikāgreṇa cetasā
kaccid ajñānasammohaḥ pranaṣṭas te dhanañjaya
18.translate: O Pārtha, has this been heard by you with focused mind? O Dhanañjaya, has the delusion born of ignorance been destroyed?
18.sridhara: With the intent that, if clear understanding has not arisen, He will again teach, He asks—“kaccid iti”. “Kaccid” is interrogative. “Ajñāna-sammohaḥ” means delusion born of ignorance which causes misapprehension. The rest is clear.

18.shlok:
अर्जुन उवाच
नष्टो मोहः स्मृतिर्लब्धा त्वत्प्रसादान्मयाच्युत।
स्थितोऽस्मि गतसन्देहः करिष्ये वचनं तव।।१८.७३।।
18.translit:
arjuna uvāca
naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtir labdhā tvatprasādān mayācyuta
sthito’smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṁ tava
18.translate: Arjuna said: My delusion is destroyed, and I have regained memory through Your grace, O Acyuta. I am firm, free from doubt—I will act according to Your word.
18.sridhara: Arjuna, having attained fulfillment, said—“naṣṭa iti”. My delusion concerning the Self is destroyed. Therefore, the memory that “this I am”—in the form of Self-reflection—has been regained by me through Your grace. Hence, I stand firm—I am ready for battle. I, who am free from doubt about what is dharma, will do Your bidding.

18.shlok:
सञ्जय उवाच
इत्यहं वासुदेवस्य पार्थस्य च महात्मनः।
संवादमिममश्रौषमद्भुतं रोमहर्षणम्।।१८.७४।।
18.translit:
sañjaya uvāca
ity ahaṁ vāsudevasya pārthasya ca mahātmanaḥ
saṁvādam imam aśrauṣam adbhutaṁ romaharṣaṇam
18.translate: Sañjaya said: Thus I heard this wondrous, hair-raising dialogue between Vāsudeva and the high-souled Pārtha.
18.sridhara: Having thus narrated the dialogue between Śrī Kṛṣṇa and Arjuna to Dhṛtarāṣṭra, and reflecting again on the present topic, Sañjaya said—“iti iti”. I heard this dialogue that causes hair to stand on end. The rest is clear.

18.shlok:
व्यासप्रसादाच्छ्रुतवानेतद्गुह्यमहं परम्।
योगं योगेश्वरात्कृष्णात्साक्षात्कथयतः स्वयम्।।१८.७५।।
18.translit:
vyāsaprasādāc chrutavān etad guhyam ahaṁ param
yogaṁ yogeśvarāt kṛṣṇāt sākṣāt kathayataḥ svayam
18.translate: Through Vyāsa’s grace I have heard this supreme and secret yoga directly from Kṛṣṇa, the Lord of Yoga, Himself speaking it.
18.sridhara: He expresses how he came to hear it—“vyāsaprasādāt”. The divine eye and ear were granted to me by the blessed Vyāsa. Thus, by Vyāsa’s grace I heard this. What is that?—the supreme yoga. Its supremacy is now stated: I heard it directly from Kṛṣṇa, the Lord of Yoga, as He Himself spoke it.

18.shlok:
राजन्संस्मृत्य संस्मृत्य संवादमिममद्भुतम्।
केशवार्जुनयोः पुण्यं हृष्यामि च मुहुर्मुहुः।।१८.७६।।
18.translit:
rājan saṁsmṛtya saṁsmṛtya saṁvādam imam adbhutam
keśavārjunayoḥ puṇyaṁ hṛṣyāmi ca muhur muhuḥ
18.translate: O King, remembering again and again this wondrous and holy dialogue between Keśava and Arjuna, I rejoice again and again.
18.sridhara: Furthermore—“rājan iti”. “Hṛṣyāmi” means “I become thrilled” or “I experience delight.” The rest is clear.

18.shlok:
तच्च संस्मृत्य संस्मृत्य रूपमत्यद्भुतं हरेः।
विस्मयो मे महान् राजन् हृष्यामि च पुनः पुनः।।१८.७७।।
18.translit:
tac ca saṁsmṛtya saṁsmṛtya rūpam atyadbhutaṁ hareḥ
vismayo me mahān rājan hṛṣyāmi ca punaḥ punaḥ
18.translate: And remembering again and again that most wondrous form of Hari, great is my astonishment, O King; I rejoice again and again.
18.sridhara: Furthermore—“tac ca iti”. “Tat” refers to the Viśvarūpa (Universal Form). The rest is clear.

18.shlok:
यत्र योगेश्वरः कृष्णो यत्र पार्थो धनुर्धरः।
तत्र श्रीर्विजयो भूतिर्ध्रुवा नीतिर्मतिर्मम।।१८.७८।।
18.translit:
yatra yogeśvaraḥ kṛṣṇo yatra pārtho dhanur dharaḥ
tatra śrīr vijayo bhūtir dhruvā nītir matir mama
18.translate: Wherever there is Kṛṣṇa, the Lord of Yoga, and wherever there is Pārtha, the wielder of the bow—there are fortune, victory, prosperity, and firm righteousness—such is my conviction.
18.sridhara:
Therefore, with the intent “You should abandon your fear concerning your sons’ kingdom, etc.,” he says—“yatra iti”:
Wherever, on the side of the Pāṇḍavas, the Lord of Yoga, Śrī Kṛṣṇa, is present, and wherever the wielder of the Gāṇḍīva bow, Pārtha, is—there alone is śrī (royal prosperity); there alone is vijaya (victory); there alone is bhūti (ever-increasing prosperity); there alone is nīti (sound policy), which is firm. All four—śrī, vijaya, bhūti, and nīti—are connected to “tatra” (there). “Iti matiḥ mama”—this is my firm conviction.

Thus ends the commentary on the Bhagavad Gītā.

Summary of the Gītā’s Meaning (Gītārtha-Saṅgrahaḥ)
“By the grace of the Lord, one endowed with devotion to Him attains realization of the Self, and from that Self-realization comes liberation from bondage—this is the summary of the Gītā’s meaning.” ||१||

Indeed, the Supreme Person, O Pārtha, is attained only by exclusive devotion:
“Bhaktyā tv ananyayā śakya aham evaṁ-vidho ’rjuna” (१८.५५) — From such verses, it is clearly understood that single-pointed devotion to the Lord alone, accompanied by only subsidiary activity such as knowledge arising from His grace, is the true cause of liberation. That knowledge functions merely as a support to devotion.

“Teṣāṁ satata-yuktānāṁ bhajatāṁ prīti-pūrvakam, dadāmi buddhi-yogaṁ taṁ yena mām upayānti te” (१०.१०),
“Mad-bhakta etad vijñāya mad-bhāvāyopapadyate” (१३.१९), and other such statements reveal that it is only through devotion that the Lord is to be truly known.

“Samaḥ sarveṣu bhūteṣu mad-bhaktiṁ labhate parām” (१८.५४),
“Bhaktyā mām abhijānāti yāvān yaś cāsmi tattvataḥ” (१८.५५), etc., show the Lord is known through devotion by stating the distinction between the devotee and the Lord.

Otherwise, if knowledge alone were sufficient, it would contradict the Śruti statement:
“Evam etad vijānīyāt ātmānam eva atimṛtyum eti nānyaḥ panthā vidyate ’yanāya” — “Knowing thus, one transcends death—there is no other path to liberation.”

But since knowledge is only a subsidiary support to bhakti, there is no contradiction.

Just as when one says, “The wood cooks,” it is not that the flames are not the instrument—rather, the flame is assumed.

Moreover, as stated:
“Yasya deve parā bhaktir yathā deve tathā gurau
tasyai te kathitā hy arthāḥ prakāśante mahātmanaḥ**”
— “Only to one who has supreme devotion to the Lord and equally to the guru do the truths of the scriptures become revealed.”

And also:
“At the moment of death, the Lord, who is the Supreme Brahman, reveals Himself; He is attained by that person. Therefore, He is attained.”

Such statements from the Śruti, Smṛti, and Purāṇas all remain harmonious only when bhakti is accepted as the cause of liberation.
Thus, it is proven: Bhakti alone is the cause of liberation.

Therefore, by that very understanding given by Him, this commentary on the Gītā has been composed.
May that Mādhava, the Supreme Bliss, be pleased by it. ||१||

This Subodhinī commentary has now been made by Śrīdhara Svāmī, the ascetic who bears the dust of the lotus feet of the Lord of Supreme Bliss. ||२||

Even if one repeatedly churns the Bhagavad Gītā using the force of their own cleverness to understand its essential meaning,
how will one attain the nectar of truth without the grace-filled glance of the guru?

Just as a person cannot reach the jewels lying at the bottom of the ocean by scooping out the water with cupped hands—
does anyone dive into the ocean without a proper boat and expert captain?

Likewise, to know the ultimate truths of the Bhagavad Gītā, one must approach a true guru with surrender and humility, and only then will those truths be revealed.
